DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush to Address Nation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will address the nation at 9 a.m. EDT Wednesday concerning the Persian Gulf crisis. The White House announced Bush's speech late Tuesday night. Television networks are expected to carry the president's speech.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Put 28 Americans on Buses with Unknown Destination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 8 grafs new or rewritten, some Americans apparently located in Baghdad; picks up 5th graf pvs: ``We hold,''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops rounded up 28 Americans in Kuwait on Monday and some of them later were reported in Baghdad, the State Department said Monday night. The Americans were among more than 300 British citizens and other foreigners picked up by the Iraqis at three hotels in Kuwait. ``We have reports that a dozen or so (Americans) have arrived in Baghdad,'' said a State Department official who spoke on condition that his name not be used. ``The embassy is taking steps to verify these reports and get in contact with them.'' The official said he had no immediate word on the citizens of other countries picked up in Kuwaiti hotels or on the rest of the Americans, but ``this does not mean anything is wrong'' in view of the time needed to locate and identify people in the Iraqi capital. It appeared that the new arrivals were being housed in the same hotel where 11 American oilfield workers picked up by invading Iraqi troops were taken, this official said. In London, a British spokesman said that government believed 366 people had been assembled, mostly passengers from a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait since the invasion by Iraqi troops began Thursday. Before reports of the location of the U.S. citizens in Baghdad were received in Washington, U.S. officials said they did not rule out that the foreigners would show up in Baghdad unharmed. Nonetheless, they issued a warning. ``We hold Iraq responsible for their safety,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``It's premature to call them hostages,'' she said. ``We don't know their destination.'' Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat to the State Department to demand information about the whereabouts of the 28. The meeting with Kelly lasted less than 15 minutes, after which the Iraqi ambassador tried to evade reporters by leaving through a side entrance. When reporters caught up with him, he said, ``I have no statement to make.'' The safety of Americans was also brought up at a meeting in Baghdad earlier in the day when President Saddam Hussein summoned the senior U.S. diplomat there, Joseph Wilson. During the two-hour meeting, Wilson demanded that Iraq respect a commitment given last week to protect Americans, said Tutwiler. The meeting apparently occurred before U.S. officials learned of the 28 missing Americans. Tutwiler described the meeting as ``serious'' but declined to divulge details. Another official said the session was ``not terribly pleasant.'' Secretary of State James Baker discussed the safety of U.S. citizens in Kuwait and Iraq with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in a 30-minute telephone conversation Monday. Shevardnadze, whose government has announced an arms boycott of Iraq, said he was worried about Soviet citizens in Kuwait and Iraq, said another official. It was the second time since the invasion that the State Department has raised an alarm about missing Americans, reflecting the vulnerability of the estimated 3,000 U.S. citizens in Kuwait and 500 others in Iraq. On Thursday, 11 American oil workers were picked up by Iraqi troops at three oilfields in Kuwait. They turned up in Baghdad on Saturday and were free to leave the country once the airport reopens. Airports and ports in Kuwait and Baghdad remained closed Monday, but some Americans managed to leave Kuwait, said Tutwiler. Another State Department official said the number of those who managed to get out was small, but he declined to say how they left. Several Americans managed to drive to Saudi Arabia late last week. U.S. consular officials were standing by on the Saudi side of the border to assist anyone who comes out. The U.S. embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait have been in touch with most of the Americans in those countries, said Tutwiler. The State Department is also in touch with the families of Americans in the United States through a special hotline.

DOC.HEAD: White House Discussing Military Action With Iraq's Neighbors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, bgng: There was xxx to UPDATE with State Department saying it has reports of a dozen Americans in Baghdad.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday ``the world is united'' to stop Iraq's aggression, while Pentagon sources said U.S. warships had moved close enough to launch air strikes throughout the Persian Gulf or even against Iraqi targets. A possible blockade against Iraq was mentioned by both British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney after they met separately with Bush. In a victory for Bush, the U.N. Security Council voted 13-0 for sweeping trade and military sanctions, including a ban on oil purchases, as punishment for Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``These sanctions will be enforced _ whatever it takes,'' Bush vowed. Mrs. Thatcher said the West would have to consider a naval blockade of the Persian Gulf if United Nations sanctions against Iraq proved ineffective. Mulroney agreed that a blockade might be necessary to make the sanctions stick. ``If you look at the geography, it certainly wouldn't hurt at all,'' he said. The White House said it was discussing ``military possibilities'' with Persian Gulf states to prevent Iraq's Saddam Hussein from taking his conquering army into oil-rich Saudi Arabia. Mrs. Thatcher said Britain had ordered two additional frigates to join its single warship in the gulf, making Britain the second NATO ally to send extra forces. France earlier dispatched a frigate to join two French warships. The United States also pressed a campaign to choke off Iraq's oil exports by closing pipelines in Turkey and Saudi Arabia. Bush refused to say what Turkey and Saudi Arabia would do but said, ``I think you'll see a lot of countries now coming together to deny this man (Saddam) any market at all.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney went to the Saudi city of Jiddah to discuss security arrangements and Secretary of State James A. Baker III was ordered to go to Turkey at midweek. There was rising concern for the safety of Americans. Twenty-eight U.S. citizens were among foreigners rounded up by Iraqi troops from three hotels in Kuwait and taken away by bus, the State Department said. About a dozen were reported to be in Baghdad, the department said. ``We hold Iraq responsible for their safety,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. With anger growing about gasoline price increases at home, members of Congress set hearings for Tuesday on possible price-gouging in reaction to the Mideast situation. The Justice Department said it would be looking for anti-trust violations and would vigorously prosecute any it found. The administration was heartened by the U.N. vote. ``The world is united against the kind of aggression that we've witnessed,'' the president said. He said the U.N. measure ``gives an awful lot of muscle to countries and we want to see them use it'' against Iraq. He noted that oil is a commodity that could be cut off under the U.N. measure. Mrs. Thatcher, standing alongside Bush, said, ``I cannot remember a time when we had the world so strongly together against an action as now.'' NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner, also at the White House, said, ``This is the moment for the West to show cohesion, determination, to make it clear what cannot be accepted in this world and to safeguard its own security interests.'' Warning of dire consequences to America's economy from curtailed oil supplies, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said it was ``clearly in the national interest to stop Saddam Hussein.'' With Saddam's troops massed on the border of Saudi Arabia, Fitzwater said, ``The defense of Saudi Arabia is paramount.'' Bush, asked if Saddam had pledged not to invade Saudi Arabia, said, ``I have had no such assurances directly to me.'' Iraqi officials have said they will not invade Saudi Arabia. Bush consulted over lunch with House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. He also conferred with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney over dinner. Posing for pictures with Mulroney, Bush said, ``We have a lot to consult about, given the naked aggression of Iraq.'' Afterward, Mulroney told reporters, ``If those pipelines were shut down and if there was a degree of appropriate interdiction, they would have a great deal of difficulty in selling their product.'' ``And if the resolution of the United Nations Security Council bit the way it must bite, then they're going to have a great deal of difficulty in buying products that they need for their citizenry.'' He said Turkey deserved NATO protection if necessary if it cut Iraq's pipeline. The NATO treaty requires members to treat an attack against one as an attack against all, and Turkey is a member of NATO. Defense Secretary Cheney, after an overnight flight, arrived in the Saudi city of Jidda for talks on security arrangements. ``We have discussed military possibilities and our abilities with all the countries in the gulf,'' Fitzwater said. ``From the moment the first Iraqi soldier entered Kuwait, it has been clearly in the national interest to stop Saddam Hussein,'' he said. ``This is an overt situation. His tanks are real and moving. Our response is real and moving on all the fronts: diplomatic, economic, political and military.'' Bush also ordered Baker to Turkey, which controls a vital pipeline for Iraq's oil. Another pipeline for Iraqi oil crosses Saudi Arabia. In a display of superpower cooperation, Baker talked by telephone for 30 minutes with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze about moving quickly at the United Nations for sanctions against Iraq, Tutwiler said. The State Department urged all Americans in Kuwait and Iraq to leave as soon as possible and said it was withdrawing all non-essential embassy personnel and their families from those countrie. Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat to demand information about the whereabouts of the missing 28 Americans. ``It's premature to call them hostages,'' Tutwiler said. ``We don't know their destination.'' Meanwhile, Iraq's Saddam summoned the senior U.S. diplomat in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, for a meeting that lasted several hours, Tutwiler said. She said Wilson raised the question of safety of the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and the 500 in Iraq. The administration said there was no sign that Iraqi military units were pulling out of Kuwait. ``To the contrary, the Iraqi military presence throughout Kuwait, including along the Saudi border, remains extremely large and threatening,'' Fitzwater said. Pentagon sources said two U.S. aircraft carriers, the USS Independence near the Persian Gulf and the USS Eisenhower in the Mediterranean Sea, had moved within range to launch warplanes down the Persian Gulf and as far as Iraqi targets. Jawboning suppliers, Fitzwater said, ``It is not clear that all of the increases that have been reported at the consumer level are necessary.'' Nevertheless, Fitzwater said, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ``threatens regional and world stability, threatens OPEC and could force severe economic consequences in the United States. Bush talked by telephone Sunday night with Jordan's King Hussein, who has stood out in defending Saddam against world condemnation.

DOC.HEAD: Miss America Pageant Negotiating to Bring Back Bert Parks
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: The Miss America Pageant is negotiating to bring back for this year's show Bert Parks, who serenaded newly crowned beauty queens with ``There She Is'' for 25 years before being dumped as emcee in 1980. ``I can confirm we are talking to people on behalf of Mr. Parks'' and to Parks himself, pageant director Leonard Horn said Monday. ``Nothing has been finalized.'' Gary Collins and Phyllis George would still be co-hosts of the show, but Parks would sing ``There She Is'' during the winner's traditional walk down the runway, said a source on the pageant board of directors. Calls to Parks, 75, at his Greenwich, Conn., home were not immediately returned. His firing a decade ago in favor of Ron Ely, who played ``Tarzan'' on television, stirred a public outcry. Johnny Carson led a letter-writing campaign in support of Parks, and 20,000 people took part. Parks went on to play host at other pageants, some serious, others silly. Former pageant director Albert Marks Jr., who died last year, said in 1980 that he fired Parks because he wanted to appeal to a younger generation unfamiliar with Parks or little enamored of his rendition of the theme song. Parks has said the firing was the best thing to happen to his career. He has since been host of the Mrs. America Pageant, the U.S. Man of the Year, a small-dog contest and a prettiest tugboat contest. In the new Marlon Brando movie ``The Freshman,'' he serenades a Komodo dragon, a 6-foot lizard. This year's pageant is scheduled for Sept. 4-8 and will be shown on NBC. State pageant directors applauded the effort to bring back Parks. ``I like Bert. I thought he did a great job,'' said Charlie Welsh, director of the Miss Oklahoma Pageant. ``I'm sure he is capable of doing a great job.'' ``He and the Miss America Pageant were kind of synonymous,'' said Nate Zauber, director of the Miss New Jersey Pageant. ``This would be the return of a legend. It would be a return to tradition and very welcome.'' The source on the Miss America board said the pageant would be redressing a wrong. ``A lot of people were very unhappy the way he was fired,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said Parks learned of his firing from the news media. Horn said Parks' possible return is part of an effort to do something special for the pageant's 70th anniversary, for which at least 26 former Miss Americas are returning. ``He was a major contributor to the popularity of the program,'' Horn said.

DOC.HEAD: Vote, Vote, Who Gets the Vote?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Yvette Hernandez never votes _ not for mayor of New York, not for Congress, not even for president. But if Puerto Rico's future comes to a vote, she's ready to head for the nearest polling place. ``Why shouldn't I vote? I'm Puerto Rican,'' she declares. That this furniture saleswoman has lived in New York for 17 years matters little. She was born in Puerto Rico, and if the island is to decide its future _ independence, statehood, or no change _ she wants a say. She is not alone. Even as Congress debates when and if to hold a plebiscite, a parallel debate is going on in and out of the mainland Puerto Rican community: Should Puerto Ricans who left the island _ and even the descendants of those emigrants _ have a vote in its destiny? ``We think of ourselves as one nation and Puerto Rico is never out of mind for us. And that's a fact,'' explains U.S. Rep. Jose Serrano, D-Bronx. Serrano, himself Puerto Rican born, has proposed an amendment to the plebiscite legislation that would extend the vote to anyone born in Puerto Rico or with at least one parent born on the island. The proposal is unprecedented, according to Columbia University law professor Henry P. Monaghan. ``There is no case in which there have been people who are not living in a territory who are enfranchised,'' he said. The idea of 2.5 million people on the mainland taking part in the plebiscite doesn't sit well with everyone, especially Sergio Pena Clos, a member of the island's Senate. ``They've left the island. They've abandoned the island and now they want to vote?'' said Pena Clos. ``They'll be affecting my destiny, the island's destiny and the destiny of my descendants.'' Serrano's reply: ``This is not an election for public office. This is an election on status _ political status _ and that decision belongs to all the Puerto Rican people.'' Serrano's words echo on the streets of East Harlem, home to many of New York's 1 million Puerto Ricans. ``This is something that is a big decision. This is not like an election that takes place every four years,'' said Carlos de Jesus, the New York-born son of a woman from Puerto Rico. ``Because, depending on the outcome of that vote, many people here might just want to go back to Puerto Rico.'' His wife, Carmen, also born in New York, wants to vote. ``No matter where in the world they are now, they should be allowed to vote. It's our right and no one has the right to take that away,'' she said. Puerto Rico, in fact, has not been independent since it was conquered by Ponce de Leon for Spain in 1509. The island remained a Spanish colony until the Spanish-American War of 1898, when became a U.S. territory. Puerto Rico became a U.S. commonwealth in 1952, exposing its people to a dizzying array of contradictory rights and proscriptions. Puerto Ricans are U.S. citizens and are eligible for military service, but cannot vote for president. They elect their own governor and Legislature, but their representative to Congress has no vote there. Federal law applies to the island, but Puerto Ricans pay no federal taxes. In a 1967 non-binding referendum, 60 percent of Puerto Ricans said they wanted to retain commonwealth status while 39 percent wanted statehood. But recent polls indicate that a slim majority favors statehood. It is not clear that they will have an opportunity to vote in the near future. President Bush, who strongly backs statehood for Puerto Rico, has urged Congress to pass plebiscite legislation mandating that whatever is decided by the voters be implemented by 1993. In a letter to the House subcommittee considering the bill, Bush wrote: ``How can we applaud the exciting and momentous movements toward freedom in Eastern Europe, Latin America and elsewhere while refusing to grant to our own citizens the right to self-determination?'' But the chances of passing such a bill in 1990 appear slim. Action on the House version has been delayed by the illness of Del. Ron de Lugo, D-V.I., chairman of the Interior subcommittee on insular and international affairs. The bill's Senate counterpart, which has been approved by the Energy and Commerce Committee, still must be considered by the Finance, Agriculture and Judiciary committees before it can go to the full body. And, because it's an election year, Congress is hoping to adjourn earlier than usual. Still, the debate about who would vote continues, off the island and on. Rafael Hernandez Colon, Puerto Rico's governor and leader of the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party, has said he favors allowing first-generation Puerto Ricans living in the United States to vote in the plebiscite but believes most island residents oppose the idea. And former Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo, of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party, said any effort to determine who would be eligible to vote would be a ``logistical nightmare.'' Pena Clos noted that Puerto Rico has about 3.5 million people, about 2.1 million of whom eligible to vote. ``How can 2.5 million people living in the United States be allowed to affect the future of those on the island?'' he asked. Miguel Colom, who moved to New York 12 years ago, agrees that he and others living here have no business voting on the island's future. ``I'm an American. That's it,'' he said. ``Why should they vote if they live here? They're not affected by what happens there. I know a lot of people who say, `I'm Puerto Rican,' but if they sit down and think about it, they'll realize they were born here, live here and work here. Why should they vote there?'' Gilberto Seda was born in New York. ``It's not that I don't care about Puerto Rico; I do,'' he said. ``And it's not that I deny I'm Puerto Rican. But my homeland is New York.'' But Serrano said such thinking is too narrow. ``If this were the United Nations, this would be easy to understand _ that there is a nation of Puerto Ricans just as there is a nation of Jews around the world and a nation of Palestinians,'' he insisted. Which is the same reasoning that Puerto-Rican born Yvette Hernandez _ the non-voter _ uses in asserting her right to vote in a plebiscite. ``I live here, but I'm Puerto Rican. So I should vote,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bar Association Narrowly OKs Neutrality on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The American Bar Association is demonstrating how deeply divided it is over taking a public stand on abortion, and the future of its pro-choice policy remains in doubt. By a vote of 885-836 Monday, members at the ABA's Assembly meeting adopted a resolution that supporters say is designed to restore the nation's largest lawyers' group to a position of neutrality on abortion. ``Questions presented by a decision to terminate pregnancy are extremely divisive,'' the resolution said. ``The ABA for the good of the association will not adopt a policy supportive of a particular viewpoint.'' The resolution urged repeal of a pro-abortion-rights stand adopted by the ABA's policymaking body, its House of Delegates. That body will meet Wednesday to decide whether it should adopt the recommendation and rescind its pro-choice stand approved in February by a margin of better than 2-1. ABA Secretary-elect Anthony Palermo of Rochester, N.Y., sponsor of the repeal resolution, said the narrow victory Monday is a good sign that the ABA may be ready to abandon its position. ``This vote demonstrates how divisive this issue is. But it's not over yet,'' he said. Palermo denied that rescinding the pro-choice position would be ``a slap in the face'' to women in the organization. Sally Determan of Washington D.C., a leader of the drive to retain the policy favoring abortion rights, said she is not disheartened by Monday's developments. ``I'm pleased the vote was this close,'' she said. If the House of Delegates reaffirms its previous policy, the Assembly could reconvene and by a two-thirds vote force a referendum by the ABA's 360,000 members. Monday's vote was preceded by nearly two hours of debate. Those urging repeal of the pro-choice stand said adoption of the resolution would not be interpreted as a vote against privacy rights for women. But opponents of the resolution said backing away now from support of abortion rights would damage the group's credibility. ``ABA members want the right to decide and speak for themselves individually on abortion matters and they do not want the ABA to adopt a policy of organization abortion advocacy,'' Palermo said. But Ms. Determan said, ``A great organization should never recede from principle because of threats of resignations and financial pressure.'' She said the organization has a duty to speak out on the leading issues of the day, no matter how controversial. The ABA's darkest hour was in the 1950s when it remained silent over civil rights and discrimination, she said. The abortion controversy has cost the ABA 1,500 members and $300,000 in annual fees. The Assembly vote was open to any of the 12,000 association members attending this week's annual convention who paid a $250 registration fee. The resolution adopted by the House of Delegates in February said government should not interfere ``with the confidential relationship between a pregnant woman and her physician'' in deciding on abortions. ABA members noted that being on record on the abortion issue put the organization in position to express itself formally when state legislatures and courts consider abortion laws. The repeal fight took on new significance with President Bush's nomination of David H. Souter to the Supreme Court. The ABA plays a key role in evaluating the qualifications of high court nominees, and some opponents of the ABA's stand have said the organization's role in judicial selection is now suspect. They say the ABA could appear to be biased against a nominee who opposes abortion. Souter's views on abortion are largely unknown. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who addressed the ABA on Monday, told a news conference the organization would be wise to restore its neutrality on abortion. ``Its credibility will suffer if the ABA takes a position on every hot button issue of the day,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Psychologist Skinner Recalls Life and Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: B.F. Skinner, the psychologist who popularized behavior modification, is facing his approaching death by leukemia with no regrets, a fitting end to a life he claimed was governed by rational rules. Skinner, 86, is preparing what may be his final work, a defense of controversial research that explored the uses of positive and negative reinforcement to improve human behavior. ``I will be dead in a few months,'' Skinner said with a laugh. ``But it hasn't given me the slightest anxiety or worry or anything; I always knew I was going to die.'' For years, Skinner has endured a battering by many American psychologists who scorned his belief that behavior could be engineered to make society better. Not everyone will accept his final work, he said in a recent interview. ``I'm writing a paper which is my summing up of what psychology is all about and attacking cognitive psychologists,'' Skinner said. ``The cognitive psychologists won't like it, but that doesn't bother me at all.'' Cognitive psychology emphasizes the unconscious structures of the human mind, rules for the brain's operation that can't be explained by conditioning. Skinner's principle of ``operant behavior'' holds that even seemingly spontaneous action is a response to rewards and punishment. People don't shape the world, he has said. The world shapes them. On Friday, Skinner is to be honored by the American Psychological Association in Boston. The appearance will be tricky. The cancer has decimated Skinner's immune system, and visitors to his Cambridge home must wash their hands before meeting him. ``They're going to smuggle me up on the stage and then take me right back out,'' Skinner said. ``I won't go to a reception and shake anyone's hands. ``I suppose,'' he added with a chuckle, ``I could show up with rubber gloves on.'' Burrhus Frederic Skinner (B.F. to the world, Fred to his friends) grew up in Susquehanna, Pa., and spent most of his career at Harvard University, where he applied his observations of animals to the motives and manipulation of human conduct. He retired from the faculty in 1974. Skinner argued that ``behavioral technology'' could be put to work to create a world free of overpopulation, war and pollution. In ``Walden Two,'' published in 1948, he described a tightly controlled Utopia in which people are motivated by positive and negative reinforcements. The novel was required reading for many college students in the 1960s and 1970s. In Walden Two, everyone is happy. People don't know the meaning of envy and jealousy. Buildings are communally owned, and everyone helps out with chores. Many psychologists found Skinner's Walden to be a tyrannical place _ others said it was bland. But his application of the ideas of the Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov have left an indelible stamp on American society. ``We now know that many principles govern human behavior, not just `operant behavior,' but that doesn't diminish his importance,'' said Jerome Kagan, chairman of the Harvard psychology department. Operant conditioning is used every day by parents, Kagan said, ``every time they praise a behavior they want and punish one they don't want.'' To his regret, Skinner may be best remembered for teaching pigeons to play pingpong, using the Skinner Box. The pigeons pressed buttons or levers to receive food in return for doing what the experimenter wanted them to do. A Life magazine photograph of the pigeons hangs in Skinner's wood-paneled study in his home. Nearby is a signed portrait of Pavlov, whose experiment showed dogs could be conditioned to salivate at the ring of a bell. Skinner's frame is lean but otherwise he shows little sign of illness. His snow-white hair is combed back from an expansive forehead and his blue-gray eyes sparkle when he discusses his work. He laments the search among cognitive psychologists for an ``inner creator'' responsible for human behavior, likening them to creationists who scorn Darwin's theory of evolution. Skinner compares the search for an inner self to the search for God. Skinner doesn't believe in God, either. And how does Skinner want to be remembered? ``Somebody asked my daughter recently what she remembered most about me,'' he says. ``It was very strange. She said I used to come and put her to bed and talk with her, and I'd take her hand and there'd be tears in my eyes.'' ``I'd hate to have people say he's the man who taught pigeons to play pingpong.''

DOC.HEAD: Visitors Find Americans Friendly, Cities Busy, Softball Boring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The electrical worker from Czechoslovakia says he must have met a hundred Americans in his 2{ months in America _ but everyone was too busy to become real friends. Whenever he talked to the owner of the Virginia publishing company where he interned, ``I was seeing that the time was running in his head.'' The young lawyer from Poland bemoaned Americans' lack of knowledge about Europe _ or even about America. In an after-hours competition with his fellow summer clerks at a prestigious Washington law firm, he was able to name 45 states of the union. The best any of his new Harvard-educated friends could do was 36 or 37. These young East Europeans _ a translator, a civil engineer, a law professor, a legal advisor to the Hungarian parliament, a Polish radio and television worker and others, many of them with a history of dissidence _ had been in America since mid-May, learning the ropes of capitalism and democracy. They worked in banks, in bookstores, in congressional offices and state government, chiefly in Washington and North Carolina, side-by-side with American counterparts in a program run by the non-profit National Forum Foundation. Recently, they spent the morning discussing what they liked, what they disliked and what surprised them. Piotr Kochanski, 28, a lawyer, was the Pole who outshined the other summer clerks at Hogan & Hartson by listing 45 states ``and all the presidents of the U.S. in the 20th Century.'' He played softball with the firm's young lawyers, but found it ``a boring game.'' What dismayed him was how little Americans in turn knew about Europe. ``They know nothing about our country, our history, our culture,'' he said. ``I was asked very funny questions many times,'' agreed Mirek Kleber, a novice Polish businessman who speaks Russian, French and German and interned with a bank in Lumberton, N.C. ``Do we have television in Poland? Do we have cars?'' On the other hand, Kochanski marveled, ``Americans can organize something in an hour. Everybody has confidence in the others. Everybody can trust one another. I love it _ this ability for working together.'' And he was struck by how Americans can tear down a perfectly fine building ``and in two months a new beautiful building can go up.'' ``We have all this history in Poland,'' he said. ``I love this history _ but I think we can learn from your creativity, your pragmatism, this modern mentality.'' ``I am from a city one thousand years old,'' said Beata Kalczynska-Gasic, a civil engineer from Krakow. In Raleigh, N.C., where she worked with the state Department of Transportation, she was shown a picture of the city. What struck her was that no building was more than 40 years old. ``Americans seem to be running toward the future and don't look back,'' she said. But, she asked, ``Where is the soul in your cities?'' Kalliope Bakirdzi, 31, press secretary for a new political party in Hungary, the Alliance of Free Democrats, worked in the office of the lieutenant governor of North Carolina and observed the Democratic Senate primary campaign. She liked the civility of American politics, the acceptance of compromise. ``Whatever you are _ Republican or Democrat _ you know there will always be Republicans and Democrats and you have to get along with the other side,'' she said. In Hungary, she said, ``We hate each other much more than is needed for normal political life.'' She was impressed, too, that American politicians can spend 80 percent of their time talking to, meeting, dealing with the voters. ``Our politicians never cared about the people,'' she said. But she was puzzled by the fuss over flag-burning in this country. Recalling a television news report, she said, she was ``a little shocked how they allowed the Ku Klux Klan to march but they try to ban burning the flag. If you burn a flag, you don't hurt anybody, but the Ku Klux Klan can hurt people.'' Daria Golebiowska, 22, advertising director for a Warsaw fashion house, interned at Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper. She liked the way people assumed responsibility without direction. ``Everybody's working away,'' she said, describing a newsroom's chaos. ``Everything seems to be so loose. People are coming in and out and talking on the telephone. And suddenly a newspaper comes out! ``This responsibility for their own work gives people a feeling they are really important.'' Jan Lamper, 35, a Czechoslovak worker at an electrical plant, translator and former dissident, said he thinks Americans work too hard, much harder than he expected. His friendships didn't have time to develop. ``People are too busy to get involved deeper,'' he said. ``They're working all the time.'' Andrzej Slaski, 35, a sanitary engineer from Poland, was struck by the friendliness of the people of Raleigh. ``A lot of people in the street say, `hello,' `good morning,' `hi,''' he said. In Poland, he said, that would happen only in a village. And he couldn't get over of the purity of the water that emerged from the modern North Carolina sewerage treatment plant he had visited _ 99.8 percent pure, cleaner than river water. He kept saying, ``99.8 percent clean!'' Gabor Nagy, 29, legal adviser to Hungary's Alliance of Young Democrats and teacher of sociology, worked in a congressman's office and told of seeing how easily someone was fired for incompetence. He wasn't dismayed. ``That's good!'' he exclaimed. ``This is a competitive society. Our society was too egalitarian, socialist.'' Nagy marvelled at the separation of powers, the disdain of the legislative branch toward the executive branch of government. ``People's attitude toward power is not to obey,'' he said. ``It is almost a kind of distrust of power. Lawmaking is always a compromise, negotiations between different factions, finding a common answer. This is very inspiring.''

DOC.HEAD: Australians Becoming Less Receptive to Immigrants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: This land of immigrants opened its doors wide after World War II, but now the ``Welcome'' on the mat has begun to fade. Most Australians seem to feel they should continue showing compassion for refugees, but resentment is increasing, particularly toward Asians. Demonstrators protest large Japanese purchases of prime real estate. Arriving boatloads of Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees raise fears of an uncontrollable flood from Southeast Asia. Several white-supremacist groups have sprung up. Six members of the Australian Nationalists Movement are to face trial this year for allegedly trying to drive Asians out with a terror campaign. Advocates of immigration say it generally has been positive for Australia. They say most immigrants are young, with needed skills and initiative, and provide new perspectives. Critics contend immigrants exacerbate pollution, unemployment, housing and other problems. They also claim there is a trend away from assimilation. Some city neighborhoods like Cabramatta, a Vietnamese district of Sydney, have become virtual ethnic enclaves. A government decision allowing Chinese students, afraid to go home after the pro-democracy movement was crushed, to stay in Australia at least four years added to the immigration debate. No one was happy. The students wanted permanent-resident status and other ethnic groups complained about an accompanying reduction in their quotas. The Australian, a national daily newspaper, said the decision demonstrated the lack of a coherent immigration policy and described the government rules as ``a camel of a policy, a camel being a horse designed by committee.'' Australia's combination of large size and relatively small population makes it appear ideal for growth. The land area of 3,073,000 square miles is roughly equal to the contiguous United States, but Australia has only 17 million people, about one-fifteenth the U.S. total. Environmentalists say that, unless the desert can be made to bloom, it is more appropriate to compare Australia to Canada, with its vast areas of nearly unusable tundra. Much of Australia's population is in the coastal cities, and immigrants tend to settle there. Nearly half the people live in the Sydney and Melbourne areas, and projections indicate rapid growth will continue. Sydney's state, New South Wales, received 65,000 immigrants last year, nearly triple the number in 1984. Nearly 40 percent of the immigrants live in Sydney, at least initially. That has led to housing shortages and suburban expansion that puts a greater burden on public transportation. Supporters of high immigration levels say foreigners are being used as scapegoats by politicians unwilling to to make unpopular, expensive decisions about housing and public services. Australians have been spoiled by a relative abundance of raw materials, they say, and now are starting to pay the price. Since the end of World War II, the population has increased by 150 percent as part of a growth policy designed, in part, to make Australia less susceptible to attack. About 500,000 of the new residents were refugees and Australia gained a reputation as a haven for the homeless. It still takes more refugees per capita than any other main resettlement country, but the strains have begun to show. ``We are the last country ... to regard ourselves as the first asylum country for refugees, and it's about time we changed our view of ourselves,'' Luke Hardy, executive director of the Refugee Council of Australia, said recently. ``Australia has tried to bathe in the luxury of going abroad to select refugees from camps and then bringing them here under fixed quotas every year,'' Hardy said. ``We can't just pretend we can go and find our own refugees. We have to deal maturely and compassionately and methodically with refugees claiming asylum on our shores and in our cities.'' The refugee issue has led to friction with neighboring countries, particularly Indonesia. Many boat people stop there en route to Australia, often because their boats are unsafe, and end up in refugee camps. Nearly 15,000 Vietnamese are housed in one camp on Galang, an Indonesian island south of Singapore, and the number of Cambodian refugees also is increasing.

DOC.HEAD: Embarrassed but Undaunted, Mubarak Continues Mediation Effort
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: As a peace broker who had put his country's weight and his personal standing on the line, President Hosni Mubarak was deeply embarrassed by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. After Iraqi President Saddam Hussein aired his grievances against Kuwait last month, Mubarak traveled to the capitals of Iraq, Kuwait, and Saudi Arabia on a single day in peacemaking efforts. He returned home apparently heartened by what he called Iraqi assurances of peaceful intentions. He proudly told reporters July 25 that Iraq and Kuwait would stop their war of words and hold direct talks to settle their differences over oil and land. The talks collapsed after the first round of talks in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, on Aug. 1. The Iraqis invaded Kuwait the next day. The invasion undoubtedly was a let-down for Mubarak, who said he had personal assurances from Saddam that he would not resort to arms. Diplomats in Cairo said they had no doubt Mubarak was telling the truth and that Saddam lied. Ibrahim Nafei, editor of the leading newspaper Al-Ahram and known to be close to Mubarak, wrote: ``With the first shot fired at Kuwait, Mubarak could have come out and laid bare before the Arab people many shameful positions (by Iraq), but he preferred caution and wanted the fire put out before it got out of hand.'' He described Mubarak's feeling upon hearing of the invasion as ``very painful grief.'' Mubarak himself, a courteous man who shuns scathing words, rejected a reporter's suggestion Saturday that the invasion was a stab in the back to him. He indicated he may have been deceived by Iraqi leaders. But with his military background, he said he understood why Iraqi leaders hid their invasion plans. ``Really I was very upset,'' Mubarak said. `` But I can't say it is a stab in the back. If anybody is planning to make an invasion, he will never say (so) exactly, otherwise he is going to spoil everything.'' But he was adamant on three things: Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait, the Kuwaiti ruler Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah must be reinstated, and the two countries must agree on ways to settle the conflict peacefully. He spoke the day after his Foreign Ministry issued a statement censuring the invasion and making the same demands. The statement came 24 hours after the invasion, and the interim silence from Cairo caused surprise. Mubarak rejected a reporter's suggestion this was because Egypt was afraid of Saddam's wrath. ``We could easily have given a very nervous statement right away after the invasion, but we had to understand all the reasons and make some effort,'' he said. ``Still the efforts are going on.'' Underlying Cairo's caution was a sense of being torn between two close friends. Egypt's predicament was summed up by columnist Anis Mansour in the newspaper Al-Ahram. ``President Saddam took an entire nation hostage,'' he wrote. ``The Arab countries stood confused and at a loss, torn between the murderer brother (Iraq) and the murdered brother (Kuwait). What is our right hand going to do with our left hand, which has slapped us on both cheeks and on the back of the neck, too?'' The invasion has not deflected Mubarak from pursuing his drive to settle the Iraq-Kuwait conflict peacefully. He wants this done strictly within the Arab family. ``Arab leaders are capable of finding a solution to this problem without any foreign intervention at all,'' he told reporters on Saturday. ``We are doing our maximum ... and Arab efforts must succeed.''

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Terrorizing Train Station Battle Police
DOC.TEXT: A gang of thieves preying on foreign tourists at the Central Train Station engaged police in a running battle and succeeded in freeing a colleague already under arrest, a newspaper reported. The same gang is suspected of beating and slashing the husband of an American Peace Corps worker July 30 as his family looked on. The incidents reflect the skyrocketing crime rate in Poland in the year since the Communists lost power, partly because of the hard economic times connected with the new Solidarity-led government's economic reform program. The police force is being restructured, and crime-fighting units in general are understaffed, underfunded and demoralized. Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's largest daily, reported Monday that thieves rescued their handcuffed compatriot at about 6 a.m. Sunday as he was being led away by two police officers. Later that morning, about 50 officers were confronted on an empty platform by 20 gang members who challenged them to fight. They charged the police and escaped. The day's final confrontation took place in the afternoon in a nearby underground passage, Gazeta Wyborcza said. Fifteen officers closed in on the thieves, who responded by shooting tear gas pistols, throwing stones, and swinging boards broken off from benches. Only one of the suspected gang members was apprehended, police Maj. Wojciech Kinowski told The Associated Press on Monday. Police were armed with guns, clubs and spray cans of a Mace-like irritant, but could not fire their pistols in the crowded station, he said. On July 30, John Zukowski-Faust was attacked at the station before boarding a train with his wife, Jean Zukowska-Faust, associate director for education of the U.S. Peace Corps in Poland, and their two teen-age children. Zukowski-Faust was sprayed with tear gas, cut in the face with a knife and had his leg broken in two places. He is hospitalized in London, said Peace Corps spokeswoman Hanna Grzedzicka on Monday. The gang working the train station watches for foreign tourists and either assaults and robs them or uses other ruses, such as creating a distraction while a colleague picks their pockets. Kinowski said police were not giving up, but ``will strengthen our efforts'' to catch the gang.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Launches Contest for Best Federation Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Boris Yeltsin, the president of the Soviet Union's largest republic, is trying an unorthodox, somewhat capitalist ploy to get a blueprint for its future relations with the Kremlin. Yeltsin announced Monday via the Tass news agency that he's holding a contest for the best draft plan for a federal treaty for the Russian republic. The treaty will govern Russia's relations with the central government and the 14 other Soviet republics. Tass said the first prize winner will get 5,000 rubles ($8,400). Entries must be received by Oct. 15.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Concerned about Safety of Foreigners Kidnapped in Liberia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are concerned about the safety of 14 to 15 foreigners, including one American, who were kidnapped from a Monrovia hotel by Liberian rebel troops and taken to an insurgent headquarters. The action appeared to be part of a campaign by Prince Johnson, the leader of one Liberian rebel faction, to provoke international intervention in Liberia's civil war by seizing foreigners. He believes that such intervention will help topple the 10-year rule of President Samuel K. Doe. The kidnapping occurred at the Hotel Africa on Monday, two days after Johnson issued his warning. The captives were taken to Johnson's headquarters in the town of Caldwell. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the U.S. Embassy reported to the State Department late Monday, Liberia time, that Johnson's forces ``have seized hostages.'' She said there was no indication that any of the captives had been harmed. No information on the identity of the American was available except that he was in Monrovia as a private citizen. Despite Johnson's appeals for foreign intervention, the Bush administration has adopted a hands-off policy and has called repeatedly for a diplomatic solution. The insurgency against Doe is now in its eighth month and has left the capital without public water, electricity or telephone service. Food shortages have intensified. U.S. officials said they were worried that Johnson may resort to even more extreme measures if the kidnappings do not provoke foreign intervention. One concern is that his forces may launch attacks on foreign embassies. The administration has been increasingly troubled by events in Liberia since last week when government forces murdered hundreds of civilians who had sought sanctuary at a Monrovia church. After Johnson issued his warning about kidnapping foreigners, President Bush ordered the partial evacuation of foreigners. Among the first group to be evacuated were 62 Americans and 12 other foreigners. U.S. Marines operating from a flotilla of vessels offshore evacuated an additional 20 people from Liberia on Monday, including six Americans and 14 other foreigners, Ms. Tutwiler said. The maneuver, code-named ``Sharp Edge,'' was launched from four warships stationed in international waters off Liberia since early June. The United States has made a standing offer to help Doe leave the country, but he has shown no interest in accepting it. U.S. officials said they also understood that Nigeria and perhaps other countries in West Africa were planning to evacuate citizens stranded in Liberia. They said between 1,200 and 1,600 Nigerians have been camped out at the Nigerian embassy compound and some are in ``dire circumstances.'' There also have been reports that Nigeria may attempt to send troops to Liberia in an effort to stop the fighting and set up an interim government. Nigeria has been working closely on the Liberian issue with other countries from the Economic Community of West African States. Community members include Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone, Togo and Liberia.

DOC.HEAD: Last US Naval Blockade Was Against Cuba; Allied Help Needed for Success
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A naval blockade of Iraq would succeed in choking off most of Saddam Hussein's oil exports and food imports, experts say, but it carries the danger of drawing hostile fire from the trapped Iraqis. A blockade is on the Bush administration's list of options to punish Iraq for its invasion last week of neighboring Kuwait. To be fully successful, the allies would need help from Turkey and possibly Jordan to close off all trade to Iraq. But a naval blockade _ a tactic last used by the United States during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis _ would not be without risk of bloodshed. Iraq has French-made Exocet missiles, which proved deadly in Iraq's attack against the USS Stark in 1987 and when used by Argentina against British ships in the Falklands War. Any lengthy blockade likely would have the undesired effect of driving up world oil prices, hurting the United States and other Western economies. That could give Saddam a small victory even if he was ultimate missiles instead of one. ``They would have a significant aerial capability to counter the blockade, but their successes would be limited if we have three carriers in the vicinity,'' Blackwell said. ``We'll dominate the air over the seas and limit what the Iraqis could do.'' But Blackwell and others, including a State Department analyst who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said a successful economic blockade would hinge on preventing Iraq from exporting oil through land-based pipelines and from importing food through its neighbors. Iraq pipes oil across Turkey, and Turkish President Turgut Ozal promised Monday to go along with a United Nations trade embargo against Iraq. According to CIA data, Iraq imports about $13 billion in goods a year, with Turkey its No. 1 trading partner. Other Iraqi trading partners include the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Japan, the Soviet Union and Italy. It was a four-day blockade of Cuba in October 1962 that brought the missile crisis to an end. President Kennedy warned the Soviet Union that its ships would be boarded and inspected, and none carrying weapons tried to cross through the U.S. ships. Moscow ultimately agreed to withdraw its missiles from Cuba in exchange for a U.S. promise not to invade. The U.S. Navy has not attempted a blockade since then, although such actions were considered against North Vietnam, against Cuba again during President Reagan's first term because of arms shipments in Central America, and as recently as last January to block cocaine shipments from Colombia. Six British ships were lost and 10 others damaged during the blockade of the Falklands in 1982. But the blockade prevented food, fuel and other supplies from reaching Argentine troops.

DOC.HEAD: Two Saxes Blow in from Chicago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs
DOC.TEXT: The concert was called ``Blowin' in from Chicago'' and it starred two tenor saxophonists born in the Windy City, Johnny Griffin, 62, and Von Freeman, 67. Monday evening's ``Classical Jazz at Lincoln Center'' concert was rooted in bebop, once considered too intellectual for mass listeners, now become mainstream jazz. It proved that tunes composed by Griffin and Freeman, not often heard, are as enjoyable as standards _ more enjoyable than some overtired standards _ when played as well as their quartets played them. Both men spoke entertainingly, while staying relaxed. Both sets had variety of mood, including excitement, never pushed to hysteria. Alice Tully Hall held strong fans of the two musicians, who aren't often heard here. Freeman and his pianist John Young usually play in Chicago. On Monday, Ron Carter played bass and Billy Higgins played drums with them. Griffin's tight quartet included Michael Weiss, piano, Dennis Irwin, bass, and Kenny Washington, drums. Griffin, who lives in Europe, played first. He began with Thelonious Monk's ``Evidence,'' played his own ``Chicago Calling,'' which swings lightly. He told a tale of a woman leaving him and taking all his money, making it funny, said he ``heard three sad notes in my mind's ear'' and wrote ``Woe Is Me.'' The tune was a sweet, remote memory of melancholy rather than anger or pain. The quartet cooked on ``Hot Sake'' and did an encore which Griffin called ``a cross between honky tonk and blues with strange changes.'' Freeman's rhythm section played with inventive interaction. They played ``After Dark,'' he said, although ``We about wore that one out,'' for his son, tenor saxophonist Chico Freeman, whom he later introduced. Then, saying, ``I usually heat things up before I get into this but I feel like playing it,'' the quartet played the melodic ``Lost in the Fog.'' Griffin joined them for the final two numbers, in which the two saxophonists played in unison and traded solos, building and driving but staying loose. They also traded compliments. And the audience gave them a standing ovation.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Announces Plan to Enlarge Police Force
DOC.TEXT: Spurred by a series of violent crimes, Mayor David Dinkins announced plans to ``take back our streets'' by hiring 1,058 more police officers, most of them to walk the beat. Dinkins on Monday said he ``scraped, scratched and squeezed'' $24 million out of the city's $27.8 billion budget to pay for the additions to the 26,000-member force. The mayor said he wants to change the ``image people have that they are not safe in our town.'' Among recent events that have put Dinkins under pressure have been the slayings of four children by stray bullets and the killings of an advertising executive making a call from a pay phone and a 14-year-old shot over a moped. In addition, 19 cab drivers have been killed this year. On Monday, a sleeping baby was wounded by a bullet that went through the wall of his apartment. The bullet cracked his skull but didn't penetrate his brain, said Judy Murphy, spokeswoman for St. Luke's Hospital. Police had no suspects. ``We will take back our streets by night as well as by day because a safe New York, at peace and free of fear, is the legacy we intend to leave our children,'' Dinkins said. The mayor's proposal will be presented to the City Council on Wednesday for approval. ``We think that this is not only the right direction to go, but what the people of the city expect,'' said City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone. Most of the new officers would walk beats, Dinkins said. The police force now includes 10 community patrol officers in each of the 75 precincts. Last month, more than 1,100 officers were shifted from specialized units into seven high-crime precincts. An additional 200 senior officers were assigned to overtime duty in Operation Take-Back in those areas.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Armed Action Had Little Effect on South African Government
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress' 29-year guerrilla campaign intended to force the white minority government to negotiate with the black majority and end apartheid. It was never designed to topple the vast power of the white state. And it never came close. The ANC military wing never engaged in a battle with the South African army and seldom attacked any fortified or military installation. The ANC camps in neighboring countries could not fight off South African Defense Force raids, which were mounted with helicopters and bombers. But hundreds of civilians, policemen, guerrillas and soldiers were killed and injured in bombings, grenade attacks, police raids and in township shootouts. During an ANC urban bombing campaign from 1984 to 1989, 37 people were killed and 680 injured. Early today, ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela announced the cessation of all armed action by the guerrilla organization he helped found in 1961. During his 1964 trial on charges of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government, Mandela said that ANC's armed wing, Spear of the Nation, ``was to perform sabotage; and strict instructions were given to its members right from the start, that on no account were they to injure or kill people.'' When he was released from prison in February, and asked about the civilian casualties from the urban bombs, Mandela replied that the country was at war, and civilians sometimes were killed in the crossfire. Mandela's changed attitude reflected the different goals the military wing commanders had been given by the ANC leadership during Mandela's 27 years in prison. The first fatal bombing for which the ANC claimed responsibility occurred a few months after Mandela was sentenced to life in prison. Mandela had said in 1964 that ``planned destruction of power plants, and interference with rail and telephone communications'' would scare away foreign capital and ``make it more difficult for goods from the industrial areas to reach the seaports on schedule.'' Mandela and the other early guerrilla commanders hoped economic disruption would cause whites to reconsider their support of apartheid. In 1988, after a series of bombs in shopping malls and restaurants, ANC commander Chris Hani explained the new Spear of the Nation reasoning: ``We want to make apartheid costly, and very painful and bitter for whites.'' ANC leaders suggested that frightened whites would turn against their leaders and force them to negotiate with the ANC. But even such as Helen Suzman, a member of Parliament for the anti-apartheid Progressive Federal Party, noted ``no sign of any fear or trepidation as a result.'' She said the ANC had underestimated the determination of the white minority to stay in power and the ``ferocity'' of the reprisals the government would take. Security police bragged that they had informers at the highest levels of the ANC, and the government arrested scores of guerrillas, many of whom were hanged. There were several cases of guerrillas blowing themselves up. Many also died in police custody. Each new bomb brought a vow from former President P.W. Botha that he would never negotiate with ``terrorists.'' The last major bombing attributable to the ANC occurred in August 1989 after President F. W. de Klerk had come to power. He reversed Botha's policy by legalizing the ANC and freeing Mandela before they met the long-standing government demand to renounce violence. ANC leaders other than Spear of the Nation commanders were often ambivalent about their support of, and reasons for, bombings and grenade attacks. The exiled leadership in Lusaka, Zambia, rarely acknowledged that any bombing had been committed by Umkhonto we Sizwe. They often said the guerrillas were operating across the border and underground, and couldn't be kept track of. They said some bombs, such as one that exploded in a bar frequented only by blacks, may have been left by untrained activists. They also said the police caused some explosions.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Food Prices Seen Rising Faster Than Anticipated
DOC.TEXT: Rising consumer food prices are set to make news again, with or without the Mideast war jitters and threats of inflation, Agriculture Department analysts say. The freezing weather that ripped into Texas and Florida last Christmas boosted fruit and vegetable prices more than anyone in USDA had anticipated, says Denis Dunham of the department's Economic Research Service. By itself, the freeze damage was enough to drive up overall food prices sharply in the first three months of 1990. Vegetable prices came down later as more production came into line, but fruit prices are still high and will continue that way until the new crop is ready. Last fall, USDA forecast 1990 food prices, on the average, would rise 3 percent to 5 percent during the year. But that was before the December freeze. Further, Dunham said Monday in a telephone interview, livestock and dairy prices are up, particularly hogs and milk. That has put more upward pressure on retail prices this year. ``We started off thinking commodity prices would be pretty flat (this year),'' Dunham said. ``But hogs and milk are higher than we thought, and cattle gained a bit more, too.'' Retail food prices gained 5.8 percent in 1989, on the average, the most since 1981. This year's increase is expected to be even sharper, although USDA won't announce the new forecast until Aug. 17. Some analysts have said, however, that a revised forecast of 6 percent to 8 percent is in the works, while other have speculated that an increase of 8 percent to 10 percent may be more like it. While Dunham and other agency economists attribute the sharper increase on higher prices at the farm gate, they also concede quickly that the farm price of most raw commodities is a fraction of what consumers pay at retail. ``Farm prices are very volatile'' and can swing widely in a short time, Dunham said. But the ``marketing spread'' of prices between farmers and consumers creeps higher each year. The spread includes the costs of transportation, processing, packaging and merchandising food after it leaves the farm. ``While the farm price is going up and down, that spread is just persistently going up _ and contributing all the time to that increase in retail prices,'' Dunham said. Farmers and their advocates frequently quote USDA ``market basket'' figures showing how little producers realize from consumer food dollars. In 1989, Dunham said, the farm value of a marketbasket of foods sold at grocery stores represented 30 cents of each $1 spent by consumers for food, unchanged from 1987 and 1988. The 30-cent farm share of the food dollar also was the lowest since 1950, according to USDA, and Dunham said it probably will be about the same in 1990.

Prospects of large soybean crops in Brazil and other Southern Hemisphere countries probably made U.S. farmers leery about expanding bean acreages this year, says a Agriculture Department report. In March, a planting survey showed farmers would cut the U.S. soybean acreage by 2 percent from last year, the department's Economic Research Service said in the August issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. But the most recent estimate puts the 1990 acreage down 4 percent. The weather also was a big factor, the report said. Over the entire United States, May was the sixth wettest since 1895. Rainfall was especially heavy during the second quarter in Arkansas, Idaho, Iowa, Massachusetts, Missouri and Oklahoma. ``In sharp contrast, some durum wheat growers and North Dakota and Montana are experiencing their third consecutive year of abnormally dry weather,'' the report said. Many thought the heavy rainfall would cause farmers to switch from corn to sorghum or soybeans, which are less vulnerable to midsummer heat. Also, soybeans mature faster than corn. ``But the weather improved in the first two weeks of June, and many farmers got their corn into the ground quickly,'' the report said. ``Farmers' decisions to proceed with late corn were apparently based on expectations of strengthening corn prices and weakening soybean prices relative to benefits from the corn program.'' Ironically, the report added, decisions to hold back on soybean plantings ``have now pushed up soybean futures prices.''

Agriculture Department scientists say low-fat hamburgers can be made tender and juicy by adding potato starch. Potato starch gel is now used as a thickener in salad dressings. When mixed with the meat, the gel helps bind the water to the meat. ``Burgers containing the additive actually cook faster than pure beef,'' said the department's Agricultural Research Service. ``The faster cooking and increased moisture retention created cooked patties with 4.5 percent less fat than cooked all-beef burgers.'' The starch-gel has been approved for use in food by the Food and Drug Administration but would have to be approved for its specific use in meat by FDA and the USDA before it can be sold for public consumption.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last item to RESTORE first reference to spokeswoman.
DOC.TEXT: Singer Janet Jackson postponed two concerts this week in Detroit after passing out backstage in the middle of a St. Louis show. Jackson, 24, collapsed Sunday after singing three songs. She was taken to a hospital, treated for an acute viral infection and released, Kathleen Heinz, a spokeswoman for the St. Louis Arena, said Monday. A doctor recommended Jackson not perform for at least four or five days, Heinz said. Jackson, the sister of Michael Jackson, has suffered from exhaustion during her tour and had come down with a fever and an ear infection that caused dizziness the day before she passed out, Heinz said. The Detroit concerts had been scheduled for today and Wednesday but were moved to Aug. 22 and 23.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 9 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Sales of Existing Homes Down 0.5 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes slipped 0.5 percent in the second quarter from a year ago as psychological paralysis gripped homebuyers, a real estate trade group reported today. The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes, town houses, apartment condominiums and cooperatives totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.68 million, compared with 3.70 million units during the same period in 1989. ``The second-quarter resale statistics reflect a slightly stalled housing market, caused in small part by regional economic downturns and in large part by a psychological paralysis that has gripped consumers,'' said Realtors President Norman D. Flynn. ``The credit crunch, which primarily has affected builders, has stirred fear on the part of homebuyers,'' he added. ``Also, there has been a perception this year, which is totally unfounded, that we are on the brink of a national housing recession.'' But Flynn said when mortgage interest rates began falling in May, buyers resumed house hunting, particularly in areas with relatively affordable prices. ``People have started jumping in where the water's not too deep,'' he said. According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., the average cost of a fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage was 10.67 percent during the first week in May and dropped to 10.15 percent by the end of June. The Realtors' survey also found the median price of an existing home ranging from $345,000 in Honolulu to $45,100 in Youngstown, Ohio. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half less. California's high-cost markets remained among the most expensive, however. San Francisco with a $263,600 price; Anaheim-Santa Ana, $248,900, and Los Angeles, $216,900, ranked second, third and fourth, respectively. But overall, prices in the West declined 0.8 percent to $138,300, while they rose 5.8 percent in the Midwest to $75,000. The median price rose 1.5 percent to $86,200 in the South but fell 1.6 percent to $143,500 in the Northeast. The U.S. median price was $96,200, a 3.4 percent increase. By region, sales fell by 14.5 percent to 650,000 units at an annual rate in the Northeast and 3.1 percent to 620,000 units in the West. Sales gained 4.4 percent to 1.41 million units in the South and 4.2 percent to 990,000 units in the Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Military Challenge to Saddam Could Provoke Use of Chemical Arms
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's vow to defeat any challenge of his stranglehold on Kuwait carries an implied threat to use chemical weapons, American experts say. After all, he's used them before _ even on his own countrymen. The experts interviewed Monday said they saw little reason for the Iraqi president to resort to using mustard gas and other elements of his chemical arsenal. But they said President Bush, in contemplating military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait, would have to consider the possibility of a chemical response. ``The Iraqis have used chemical weapons before and have threatened to use them again; therefore it would be perilous in any military plan not to consider the possibility again,'' said Brian Jenkins, a terrorism expert at Kroll Associates, a consulting firm in Los Angeles. Elisa Harris, a chemical weapons specialist at the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based think tank, said there are no reliable estimates of the size of Iraq's chemical arsenal. But there's no doubt that it is substantial, she said. ``Iraq is probably the most powerful chemical country in the region,'' she said. Frank Gaffney, a former Pentagon official and now director of the Center for Security Policy, a private research firm, said he believed it likely that Saddam would use chemical weapons if he attacked Saudi Arabia and met stiff resistance. ``They have about as good an understanding'' of the military use of chemicals as anyone in the world, Gaffney said. Israeli media reported Sunday that the Israeli army was stepping up its distribution of gas masks to civilians in response to the invasion of Kuwait. Israel is not directly involved in the conflict, but last spring Saddam threatened to ``scorch half of Israel with poison gas'' if Israel attacked Iraq with nuclear arms. The use of chemical weapons is outlawed by the 1925 Geneva Protocol, but Iraq repeatedly demonstrated during its eight-year war against Iran that it is willing to use its arsenal, which is believed to include mustard gas and other nerve agents. In March 1988 the Iraqi military used poison gas in attacking Halabja, an Iraqi village in the Kurdish section of the country, after the town was captured by Iranian forces. Doctors who treated survivors said mustard gas, cyanide gas and other nerve agents were used, causing burns to skin, eyes and lungs. In response to a worldwide condemnation of its invasion, Iraq warned other countries not to come to Kuwait's aid. Baghdad Radio said Iraqi armed forces would make Kuwait ``a graveyard for those who launch any aggression.'' On Saturday in Washington, the Iraqi ambassador, Mohamed Sadiq Mashat, said without mentioning the United States by name that any attempt by outside nations to try to restore the Kuwaiti royal family to power ``will be thoroughly dealt with.'' Bush has not ruled out using military force against Iraq. The president has all but committed himself to deploying U.S. troops to the Arabian Peninsula in the event of an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia, the most important American ally in the region and supplier of 15 percent of U.S. oil imports. Bush said at a joint press conference with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher last Thursday that he agreed with Mrs. Thatcher's statement that Iraq's chemical capability does not limit Western military options against Iraq. ``You cannot have a situation where one country marches in and takes over another country which is a member of the United Nations,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``I don't think the particular weapons they have affects that fundamental position.''

DOC.HEAD: Metzenbaum Says Basis Established to Overturn Bailout
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, says he thinks a subcommittee he chairs has established the legal basis to overturn a 1988 savings and loan bailout he describes as ``very sweet.'' Arizona insurance executive James M. Fail acknowledged on Monday there were inaccuracies and omissions in disclosure statements he signed before acquiring 15 failed thrifts, now operating under the name Bluebonnet Savings Bank, Dallas. One of the penalties for improper disclosure is removal as S&L owner. ``I believe there is enough to reopen and renegotiate the contract. The real issue is can we save the taxpayers millions and possibly billions of dollars. I believe the answer is yes,'' Metzenbaum told reporters after an all-day session of his Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust. Fail acknowledged omissions in documents filed initially with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board concerning fraud allegations leveled against him in 1976 in Alabama. However, he said that before the bailout deal was signed on Dec. 22, 1988, he fully disclosed the relevant details. Former senior regulators who testified to the subcommittee previously said they did not know all of the details of the fraud allegations and that if they had, Fail would have been disqualified. Metzenbaum said the Bluebonnet deal and other bailouts completed in a headlong rush at the end of 1988 were ``very sweet,'' virtually assuring S&L acquirers a profit from generous government subsidies. ``The regulators couldn't possibly have known what they were doing in the hustle and bustle,'' he said. In the Bluebonnet transaction, Metzenbaum is scrutinizing the role of GOP lobbyist Robert Thompson, who represented Fail in negotiations with regulators. Thompson was an aide to President Bush when he served as vice president. Thompson, who had been fighting the panel's subpoena, appeared briefly at the hearing, delivered documents and read a prepared statement. He is scheduled to be questioned by the panel Sept. 11. The lobbyist continues to dispute the subcommittee's jurisdiction, but said, ``I do not want to give any one any excuse to say that my absence from these proceedings indicates I have something to hide.'' Thompson said his representation of Fail ``followed all rules of propriety'' and ``not one word has been uttered, not one fact has been disclosed, that suggests I did anything improper.'' He said he was promised 2 percent of Fail's profits in the deal but has received nothing because Bluebonnet has yet to pay a stock dividend. Fail disputes him, saying he knew that would be an improper arrangement under federal regulations. In the Alabama case, Fail was indicted on fraud charges, which were subsequently dismissed, and a company he controlled, United Security Holding Co., pleaded guilty to fraud and paid a $5,000 fine. As part of the settlement, Fail agreed not to conduct insurance business in Alabama. Fail said he reported the details in a Dec. 18 letter to Thomas Lykos, then in charge of the bank board's bailout program in the Southwest. Fail said that on Dec. 19 he sent an attorney to New York to further discuss the case with regulators. ``We went out of our way to see that it was disclosed,'' he said, adding that hiding the incident ``would be like trying to slip an elephant into a girls' dormitory.'' However, Sens. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, complained that the disclosures were confusing, made at the last minute and buried in fine print. ``You didn't put in the part that made you look bad,'' Specter added. Fail acknowledged that he had signed the original incomplete disclosure documents but said they had been prepared by his staff and he did not read them closely. He also admitted he did not disclose civil suits that were connected to the Alabama criminal indictment. ``I had a very bad habit in the past, which I can assure you I will not have in the future, of signing a great many things which are placed before me,'' Fail said. Monday's session was the third held by the Metzenbaum panel. Just before Fail took his place at the witness table, Thomas K. Pennington, former president of an insurance company controlled by Fail, said Fail and a top aide, Harry Carneal, believed they couldn't lose in the Bluebonnet bailout. ``They felt it was a no-brainer _ that they'd have to be awful stupid not to make money,'' Pennington said.

DOC.HEAD: Invasion of Kuwait Cuts Off Iraq's Image-Polishing in U.S.
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat said recently his priority was ``reversing a tide of unflattering press reports'' about his country. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is definitely setting things back. ``Everything has to be suspended, put on hold until the place settles down,'' said Ron Cathell, executive director of the National Council on U.S.-Arab Relations. His group sponsors frequents visits to Iraq for educators, members of Congress and other policymakers. Such efforts at U.S.-Iraq business, government and cultural ties were cut off by Iraq President Saddam Hussein's overthrow of Kuwait, and a spokesman for one U.S.-Iraq group says the small Iraqi community in the United States is on the defensive. Iraq had tried to polish its image in this country since diplomatic ties resumed five years ago. But even before the invasion, the State Department had been weighing whether to place Iraq on the list of countries that support terrorism. Despite al-Mashat's earlier comments to Dossier magazine about building better Iraq-U.S. ties, he has declined repeated requests for interviews since last Thursday's invasion. He invited reporters to the Iraq Embassy twice since Thursday but has declined to answer extensive questions. On Monday, he tried to evade reporters at the State Department after Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned him to ask about the fate of Americans in Kuwait. Faisal Arabo, head of the Iraqi-American Foundation _ a Detroit-based group that tries to promote understanding and good will between Americans and Iraqis _ conceded, ``We're doing a lousy job.'' Arabo, who produces a television program titled ``Arab Voice,'' said there are about 200,000 Iraqi-Americans in the United States, including about 70,000 in the Detroit area. Many of them are upset by world developments, he said. ``The Iraqis are somehow starting to think they can't speak their mind,'' he said. ``We hate to see this relationship with strife.'' Personal relations between Iraqis and Americans generally have been friendly and cordial despite the diplomatic strains, he said. Iraqis have never harbored strong anti-American sentiments of the kind that developed among Shiite Moslem religious fanatics in neighboring Iran. Arabo estimated there are several hundred Iraqi students studying in the United States. Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said the agency was working to develop an official head count, although no official action has been taken against the students. More serious, to some, was President Bush's cutoff of commercial relations between the two countries following the invasion. ``The executive order has stopped all business,'' said Marshall Wiley, head of the U.S.-Iraq Business Forum, a group that represents American companies seeking to do business in the oil-rich country. Wiley said the forum, supported by about 70 dues-paying American companies, is trying to help them avoid serious financial losses as a result of the order. For instance, the forum wants to find out what happens to Iraqi oil that has been purchased by Americans, but remains on the high seas in tankers. Wiley said he can't predict whether his group will disband after some of those problems are resolved. The Commerce Department estimated that in 1989, Iraq bought goods worth $1.1 billion from the United States, mostly food. By comparison, the United States purchased about $2.4 billion from Iraq, mostly oil. Few Iraqi businessmen are based in the United States because most trade is through Iraq's government, he said.
