Wiley said his biggest concern was that the Bush administration's steps to punish Saddam might backfire, making him a hero in the eyes of other Arab states and spawning deep-seated bad feelings towards the United States. If that is the case, American businesses could find themselves shut out of expanding opportunities in Iraq and other Arab countries, he said. In addition, Wiley said he doubted that a broad sanctions program orchestrated by the United States would work. ``Other countries will start cheating, but we won't,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Rose And Fell With Army's Blessings
DOC.TEXT: Benazir Bhutto rose to power with the blessings of Pakistan's powerful army generals. Some say she fell that way too. After 20 months in office, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan abruptly dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government on Monday, citing corruption and failure to control ethnic violence in the prime minister's home province of Sindh. Although 11 years of military rule ended on Aug. 17, 1988, the army still casts a long shadow on Pakistan's infant democracy. And most politicians, diplomats and political analysts say Ishaq Khan would not have dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government without the military's consent. Most who attended the swearing-in ceremony of Mustafa Jatoi as head of the caretaker government were Pakistan's most powerful military men _ the army chief of staff, the joint chief of staff, the air force and naval chiefs of staff and the corps commanders. Immediately after the president's announcement, soldiers were deployed throughout the federal capital and took control of the state television network and the telephone and telex exchanges, cutting off foreign circuits. The army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, insisted the military was only trying to maintain peace, not take power. ``We are not involved in politics. We have never been involved in politics. We are not going to get involved in politics,'' Beg said before the swearing-in ceremony. The relationship between Ms. Bhutto and the army _ which has ruled Pakistan for 25 of its 43-year history _ has never been smooth. But it went into a nosedive in late May. From prison and then from exile in England, Ms. Bhutto spent a decade fighting Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who overthrew her father in a 1977 coup and ordered him hanged two years later. But she was forced to call out the army when ethnic violence flared anew in Sindh and claimed more than 400 lives. The army blamed members of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party for the violence and demanded sweeping powers to maintain order and to arrest, try and convict troublemakers. Ms. Bhutto refused, setting an army that never became accustomed to being out of power on an apparent collision course with a government that never seemed to get used to having it. The 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto, educated at Harvard and Oxford, was one of the best political stories of the 1980s. When Zia died in a mysterious plane crash on Aug. 17, 1988, clearing the way for the first democratic elections in a decade, Ms. Bhutto led her party to victory. She became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. But in order to gain the job she wanted, Ms. Bhutto had to make certain concessions to the military, including hands-off on foreign policy, particularly in Afghanistan, and defense spending. She agreed. ``Benazir Bhutto was created from the rib of Aslam Beg and she fell from the rib of Aslam Beg,'' one diplomat said on condition of anonymity. Senior Cabinet members had repeatedly accused the army of trying to destablize her democratically elected government. Army officers, on the other hand, did not hide their contempt for Ms. Bhutto's party, accusing members of blatant corruption and involvement in criminal activity. A meeting last month between Ms. Bhutto and Beg failed to resolve their differences. Against Beg's advice, Ms. Bhutto extended the tenure of a lieutenant general. The military high command saw it as a blatant attempt to divide the army and win the political support of some officers by patronizing them. Ms. Bhutto suffered a serious setback when Beg forced the officer to retire. Although Ms. Bhutto's government was caught off guard on Monday, political opponents had said privately for weeks that Ishaq Khan planned to dissolve the National Assembly and call new elections, possibly as early as October. Ishaq Khan set an election for Oct. 24 and declared a state of emergency for up to four months that allows the president and the caretaker government to make laws and to suspend individual rights and civilian courts. Ms. Bhutto got few favorable marks from Pakistanis. Her government passed no legislation except for a federal budget and spent most of its energy fending off a hostile opposition and corruption charges. Her popular support, rated at 54 percent when she took office, had steadily been eroded by the mounting accusations of corruption, which were never proved. But a poll released last month showed her popularity had tumbled to 34 percent. Late Monday, Ms. Bhutto told a news conference she didn't blame the president for bringing down her government, saying there were ``other elements who wanted me out.'' She urged party members to accept the decision and refrain from doing anything that would prompt another phase of martial law.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto-At-A-Glance
With PM-Pakistan-Bhutto, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the career of Benazir Bhutto from her return to Pakistan four years ago to her removal as prime minister on Monday: April 10, 1986 _ Benazir Bhutto returns to Pakistan after several years in exile to resurrect the Pakistan People's Party founded by her father, who was executed by the military government. Aug. 17, 1988 _ Gen. Mohammad Zia-ul Haq, Pakistan's military ruler and an opponent of Ms. Bhutto's left-of-center party, dies in a mysterious plane crash. Zia's death clears the way for democratic elections. Nov. 16, 1988 _ Ms. Bhutto's party emerges as country's largest in the nation's first free elections after more than a decade of military rule. She begins talks with smaller parties and independents on forming a governing coalition. Dec. 2, 1988 _ Ms. Bhutto takes the oath of office as prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. Dec. 12, 1988 _ Ms. Bhutto wins first vote of confidence in Parliament. Dec. 31, 1988 _ Ms. Bhutto scores a foreign policy triumph by meeting Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the first time an Indian leader has traveled to Pakistan to meet his counterpart since 1960. Feb. 12, 1989 _ Five people die as Islamic fundamentalists stage demonstrations against Indian-born British writer Salman Rushdie, author of ``The Satanic Verses,'' while Ms. Bhutto is visiting China. March 10, 1989 _ Islamic clergy organize day of protest against what they say are Ms. Bhutto's secular policies. May 5, 1989 _ Political honeymoon ends for the prime minister as squabbling in all four of Pakistan's provinces interferes with implementation of Ms. Bhutto's multimillion-dollar ``people's program'' to improve health, education and public works. Nov. 2, 1989 _ Ms. Bhutto narrowly survives a parliamentary no-confidence vote that is called after an ethnic party that helped her gain power withdraws its support. Dec. 2, 1989 _ A year after Ms. Bhutto takes office, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan tells Parliament that ``expectations have sunk into despair.'' Corruption charges start to be leveled regularly against Cabinet ministers and Bhutto family members, including her husband, businessman Asif Ali Zardari. Jan. 25, 1990 _ Ms. Bhutto gives birth to a baby girl. May 29, 1990 _ Ethnic violence in Pakistan's southern Sindh Province prompts military control in the cities of Karachi and Hyderabad. May 1990 _ Relations between Pakistan and India plummet in a dispute sparked by violent clashes between Indian security forces and Moslem separatists in India's Jammu-Kashmir state. Fears arise that another war between the two neighbors might erupt. Aug. 5, 1990 _ The president dissolves Pakistan's National Assembly and removes Ms. Bhutto as prime minister, accusing her administration of corruption, nepotism and political ineptitude.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Lives Of Thousands Of Infants Could Be Saved
DOC.TEXT: Existing medical skills could save the lives of 10,000 babies each year and protect an additional 100,000 from disabilities if the United States can find way to assure proper care is delivered, according to an administration report. The draft report's conclusions are similar to those reached over the past few years by other groups, including a congressionally chartered commission headed by former Democratic Sen. Lawton Chiles of Florida, and by the Institute of Medicine. It found that some pregnant women don't get needed medical care for themselves and their unborn children because they can't afford it and that, for a variety of reasons, others do not obtain the care for which their eligible. ``For some women who need assistance and qualify for it, the complexity of the Medicaid qualifying process itself ... constitutes a barrier to care,'' the report says. ``Applications can be lengthy (they average 14 pages) and require more verification that a tax return.'' Copies of the draft report by the White House Task on Infant Mortality have been leaked by those who complain that the Bush administration has shelved the study. The New York Times carried an account in its Monday editions. Another copy was obtained Monday by The Associated Press. ``We are anxious to see a final report out of the president, followed by leadership,'' Chiles, chairman of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, said Tuesday in a statement. Chiles said an additional annual expenditure of $500 million, or ``only one-tenth of 1 percent of the total spending annually on personal health care in the U.S.,'' could put recommendations of the report into effect. Sixty percent of the babies who die before their first birthdays weighed less than 5.5 pounds at birth, the report said. Another common characteristic is they come from poor families. Other contributing reasons include maternal alcohol and drug abuse, poor diet, and smoking. ``By applying the knowledge it already has this country can prevent an additional 10,000 infant deaths and an estimated 100,000 disabling conditions in the newborn,'' the report said. Some 40,000 infants die each year in the United States before reaching the first birthday and an additional 400,000 are handicapped by mental retardation or physical problems, the report said. Slightly fewer than 4 million babies are born in the United States every year. In 1987 the U.S. infant mortality rate was 10.1 deaths per 1,000 live births, a rate bettered by 21 other industrial countries and twice the rate in Japan and Scandinavia. For blacks the rate was 17.9 deaths and for whites it was 8.6 deaths. Those rates have been declining, but the report noted that the rate of decline for blacks has slowed. And the fetal death rate for blacks went up 2.7 percent in 1987, the first increase since the 1960s. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said the study began in July 1989 and there is no due date for its completion.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Psychologist's Tapes Can Be Used in Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: Carving out an exception to the therapist-client privilege, a judge ruled conversations between a psychologist and two brothers charged with murdering their parents can be used at trial. The ruling Monday covers tapes of psychotherapy sessions held between Erik and Lyle Menendez and their psychologist, L. Jerome Oziel, after the slayings. The sessions ``concern the brothers' emotional and psychological state after the murder of their parents,'' Superior Court Judge James Albracht said. Albracht said Oziel had believed the brothers made threats during the sessions and it was necessary to disclose the conversations to prevent danger. The judge said that such a threat constitutes an exception to the psychologist-patient privilege. The ruling provoked a gasp in the courtroom from the Menendez family. The defense said it would appeal to the California Supreme Court if necessary to prevent the tapes from being used in the brothers' prosecution. Normally, conversations between a patient and therapist or between a priest and penitent are not admissible. ``If the judge's ruling is upheld it brings a virtual end to the psychotherapist-patient privilege,'' said defense attorney Leslie Abramson. Deputy District Attorney Elliott Alhadeff expressed confidence the ruling would be upheld. He added, however, ``We consider it to be very important evidence, but it is not crucial to the case.'' Erik Menendez, 19, and Lyle Menendez, 22, are charged with the shotgun slayings of their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, at the family's Beverly Hills mansion last August in a scheme to collect the couple's $14 million fortune. Jose Menendez was president of a video production company. The brothers remain in jail without bail. They could face the death penalty if convicted. Ms. Abramson said Albracht based his ruling on a recent court decision that held that if a psychotherapist discusses a patient's statements with someone else, the privilege disappears.

DOC.HEAD: In Iran, Saddam is Generalissimo, Foster Child and Frankenstein
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt ^By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
DOC.TEXT: Iranian editorial writers are rejoicing now that the world is waking up to one of their most hated bogeymen: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. A Monday headline: ``We warned you Frankenstein would torment his own creators.'' Saddam attacked Iran in September 1980 after a series of border skirmishes, spawning a war that dragged until an August 1988 cease-fire. The conflict has still not formally ended. Iran's late fundamentalist patriarch, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, vowed for years to unseat Saddam. Never at a loss for a vivid phrase, he compared accepting the cease-fire with Saddam to drinking poison. The status of Great Satan was reserved for the United States, the all-encompassing public enemy No. 1 for the Islamic Republic. Iran frequently accuses both the U.S. and Saddam of trying to undermine the Islamic revolution. Saddam conveniently boasts of having alone staunched the tide of radical Islam. In fact one of his reasons for invading Kuwait on Thursday, the Iraqi press noted, was its gall in demanding back tens of billions of dollars loaned to Iraq during the war Saddam says he fought for all Arabs. Over the past six months, successful U.N.-sponsored efforts toward face-to-face negotiations between Iraq and Iran robbed Iranian newspapers and television commentators of a favorite target. Saddam's overthrow of the emir of Kuwait changed all that. Old scores came brimming to the surface. Kuwait, after all, reflagged tankers in the United States during the Iran-Iraq war, ushering in the reason for the arrival of the U.S. Navy in the Persian Gulf in force. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency printed excerpts Mondya of an editorial from the Ettela'at newspaper that was headlined: ``Foster child turns rapaciously on nourisher Kuwait.'' It noted that Kuwait had blindly supported Iraq, ``little knowing that it was feeding a wild beast in her own neighborhood.'' Saddam has also been called generalissimo and The Invader. Under the Frankenstein headline, IRNA said in its own commentary: ``For the time being, tiny Kuwait ... breathes no more. With its sheikh a stateless person, and its powerful dinar which bankrolled the Iraqi military mere garbage, Kuwait is a nonentity, swallowed up by the dangerous pet it reared.'' Despite all the attention to the dangerous pet, the Great Satan has not been forgotton. According to Iran's pundits, the Great Satan planned it all. It wanted to get the Navy back in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Bodyguard Convicted in Slaying of Tourists
DOC.TEXT: A bodyguard has been convicted in the slayings of two American tourists he mistook for U.S. agents after they wandered into a restaurant celebration by Mexican drug traffickers. Monday's verdict against Javier Vasquez Velasco was the last in the latest trial over the slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. The case has strained U.S. relations with Mexico and entangled more than 40 people in the two countries. Vasquez, 38, portrayed by federal prosecutors as a drug lord's bodyguard, was convicted of two counts of violent crimes in aid of racketeering in the 1985 slayings of John Walker and Alberto Radelat in a Guadalajara restaurant. Prosecutors said Walker and Radelat were mistaken for drug agents after they wandered into a party for drug kingpins. Vasquez was not charged in the Camarena case but was tried with three other men who were. Those three were convicted earlier. ``We can take no pleasure in the final outcome of this trial, due to the grisly events outlined by the evidence presented,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. ``However, there is justice in the fact that many of those responsible for the brutal kidnapping, torture and murder of DEA Special Agent Enrique `Kiki' Camarena have now been held accountable for their dreadful acts.'' Vasquez could get life in prison at sentencing Oct. 29. His lawyer fought to have his trial separated from that of the other defendants. But U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ruled the two cases were sufficiently related to try them together. Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were abducted, tortured and killed in 1985 at a ranch outside Guadalajara. Prosecutors said the slayings were revenge for Drug Enforcement Administration raids on marijuana and cocaine operations that cost the drug barons $5 billion in profits. Earlier in the trial, Ruben Zuno Arce, brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria, was found guilty of racketeering, kidnapping and conspiracy in Camarena's death. He was not charged with the actual murder. Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican policeman, was found guilty of kidnapping but innocent of murder. Drug baron Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros was convicted of kidnapping, but the jury also refused to convict him of murder. In the first U.S. trial stemming from the Camarena slaying, two defendants were convicted in 1988 of murder, and a third was found guilty of aiding the escape of a Mexican drug lord after the slayings. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country. More than 20 have been imprisoned in Mexico. Fourteen others are at large in Mexico, including the former head of Mexico's Interpol. Still pending is the case of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, who was spirited out of Mexico at the behest of the DEA and brought to Los Angeles to face charges in the Camarena case.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 27,653.07, down 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Video Retailers Look to Boost Lagging Growth With Catchy Perks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lenard in last graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: After 10 years of fast-forward growth, video retailers facing industrywide slo-mo are adding pizzazz, and in at least one case pizzas, to get movie rentals back on track. Film-savvy clerks, easier-to-find titles, candy counters, video reference databases and free telephones for renters who need to consult with those at home regarding second choices are among the perks being offered to keep the customer satisfied, participants at an industry convention say. ``Going to the video store is no longer fun,'' said Robert Klingensmith, president of Paramount Picture's video division. In a glum keynote address at the ninth annual Video Software Dealers Association convention, Klingensmith told retailers what they already knew _ that sales growth has leveled off after a boom decade. ``We have new customers who are hard to reach and old customers whose interests may be waning or need to be reinforced,'' he said. To counter the trend, renting videos must become less of an ordeal, Klingensmith said. That's the goal at the Video Station in Alameda, Calif., where video shoppers can take home fresh, ready-to-bake pizzas. Customers unable to decide on a second choice after failing to find what they're after at New Hampshire's Empire Video can call home for free. Simple improvements like better shelf organization can help, said Mitch Lowe, chairman of the convention. ``The thing that I hate the most is where films are just thrown anywhere,'' Lowe said. ``You can't just expect people to find the title they want by putting it on the wall.'' Other simple measures are hiring more knowledgeable clerks, stocking a wider variety of candy and installing after-hours drop slots and rental machines. About 15,000 delegates are attending the convention, in its third day today. Ken Dorrance, who owns Video Station with his wife, said his pizzas are part of a larger plan to give consumers the attention video chains often cannot. He lets patrons reserve movies by phone, sells movie-related toys and hires clerks with some movie knowledge. ``What else can you excel at besides customer service? Everybody else has the same titles,'' Dorrance said. Lowe said it may cost $2 more per hour to employ clerks who know ``Steel Magnolias'' isn't a how-to tape on gardening. ``But if you pay someone $2 more per hour, they can tell people about films and rent two or three more movies an hour,'' he said. According to the trade publication Video Flash, 4.1 billion tapes were rented last year and 196 million were sold. Although up from the previous year, the growth does not parallel the rise in the number of U.S. households with video cassette recorders, now an estimated 70 percent. Many customers complain they cannot always find what they are looking for. More than 75 percent of all renters did not find what they wanted on at least one occasion, and 6 percent left the store with no tape at all, Video Flash said. Video Munch, a supplier of snacks for video stores, is showing off a new Ninja Turtle gummy candy at its convention booth to complement a gourmet line that includes spice drops, jelly rings and natural pistachios. ``What we want to do is get a mini candy store in every outlet,'' said Lenard LaPan, a company sales representative.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Marshall Released from Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall has been released from a hospital, five days after he suffered a fall in the lobby of his Chicago hotel. In announcing his release Monday, court spokeswoman Kathy Arberg said Marshall, 82, underwent testing and observation after being admitted to National Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md. She said she had no other details. Marshall fell as he was preparing to address the annual convention of the American Bar Association in Chicago.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Postpones South American Trip
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is postponing a South American trip in September, but still plans to spend five days stumping for Republican candidates around the country. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Monday that Bush put off a scheduled Sept. 16-22 trip to Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Venezuela. Bush postponed the trip because of ``the need to be personally involved in the budget negotiations in September and the prospect of preparing for a sequestration on Sept. 30,'' he said. Fitzwater said Bush plans to travel to Kennebunkport, Maine, on Friday for a 24-day summer vacation. Here is the president's full travel schedule: Aug. 10: Departs White House for summer home in Kennebunkport. Aug. 20: Travels to Baltimore to address Veterans of Foreign War convention, returns to Maine. Sept. 3: Returns to White House from Maine. Sept. 6: Travels to Topeka, Kan., for fund-raiser for Gov. Mike Hayden and to Tallahassee, Fla., for Rep. Bill Grant, R-Fla., and the Florida GOP. Sept. 9: Attends dedication of the restored Ellis Island in New York harbor. Sept. 11-12: Flies to Denver for fund-raiser for Rep. Hank Brown, a Senate candidate, and the Colorado GOP. Proceeds to Los Angeles for a fund-raiser for Sen. Pete Wilson, running for governor, and spends night in Los Angeles. Flies to San Francisco Sept. 12 for another Wilson fund-raiser. Sept. 26-27: Flies to Akron, Ohio, for fund-raiser for former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich, now running for governor, then to Chicago for a fund-raiser for Rep. Lynn Martin, a Senate candidate. Spends the night in Minneapolis. He attends a fund-raiser on Sept. 27 in Minneapolis for the GOP gubernatorial candidate, flies to Cleveland for another fund-raiser for Voinovich and then Detroit for a fund-raiser for Senate candidates. Sept. 30: Travels to New York City to attend the U.N. Conference on Children, remains overnight. Oct. 1: Addresses U.N. General Assembly.
DOC.HEAD: American Returning Home From Captivity in Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: An American tourist who spent four days in a military jail in his native Yugoslavia is headed home after paying a $4,500 fine for deserting the Yugoslav army 30 years ago. Zjelko Skalicki, a Cleveland industrialist and naturalized U.S. citizen, also was given a suspended four-month prison sentence by a Yugoslav military tribunal, said Pero Novak of Cleveland, who lobbied Congress for Skalicki's release. Skalicki, 53, was making his first visit to his homeland with his wife and three children when he was arrested last week in a hotel in Porta Rose, Slovenia. Skalicki, who became a U.S. citizen 22 years ago, was a young man nearing the end of a mandatory two-year tour of duty in the Yugoslav military when he fled the country. Novak said he did not know whether the Yugoslav military returned the $7,000 bond that Skalicki posted for his release from jail on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Market Narrows Losses, Dollar Stable
DOC.TEXT: The key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange made up huge morning losses Tuesday afternoon, while the dollar remained stable against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, which lost 1,327 points at the end of morning trading, narrowed its losses to 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent, ending the day at 27,653.07. The index has lost 3,184.92 points since Thursday, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The dollar closed at 150.60 yen. It had opened 1.25 yen from Monday's close of 149.50 yen. The currency moved between 150.48 yen and 151.10 yen during the afternoon session. Traders said the Nikkei recovered late afternoon as investors finally started picking up underpriced issues that have declined in the last few days. Until mid-morning, almost half of the 225 issues on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange were left without prices because no one was interested in buying them, traders said. They said the index could fall further in the afternoon when participants gradually filed sell orders. ``Investors are panicking because their fears are growing as they now realize how serious the situation could be,'' said a trader with Nomura Securities Co. who spoke on condition of anonymity. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average had lost 1,327 points, or 4.64 percent, to end the morning session at 27,271.86. The index lost 729.42 points on Friday, and 916.23 points on Monday. The Nomura trader said soaring oil prices had fueled investors' fears of inflation and accelerated panic-selling. In New York, the oil price surpassed $28 per barrel on Monday. Oil prices continued to rise in early Asian trading, as October Brent sold at $27.05 per barrel Tuesday morning. ``There were almost no buyers for 40,000 issues offered for sale in initial trading,'' said Yoshihide Koyama, an analyst with Nikko Securities. Koyama said buyers were staying out of the market because of uncertainty over the Middle East, rising oil prices and Monday's 93.31-point drop in the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. In currency markets, dealers said the yen was recovering its stability following dollar sales as investors took profits despite the dollar's strong overnight increase in New York. ``Uncertainty about the Middle East is a factor that encourages dollar-buying, but on the other hand, pessimistic prospects over the U.S. economy, which is a dollar-selling factor, is equally strong,'' said Takashi Fujii, a trader with the Bank of Tokyo. ``Right now, investors are watching both factors _ the Middle East situation and the U.S. economy, and the currency could move in either direction, '' he said. As part of an international effort to isolate Iraq, Japan is freezing both Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in Japan and suspending credit in cooperation with international sanctions voted by the U.N. Security Council, said Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. Hashimoto said the yen will strengthen in aftermath of Iran-Kuwait crisis. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds soared to 8.135 percent from Monday's close of 7.935 percent. Their price slipped to 82.85 points from 83.71.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Attacks Kuwait Royal Family
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD more details on royal family, INSERT 4 grafs after 11th period, `Kuwait's per ... a year.' Picks up 12th pvs, `There have ...' ^By NICK LUDINGTON
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi media attacks on the ousted royal family of Kuwait indicate concern in Baghdad that the family is still recognized at home and abroad as tahe legitimate rulers of Kuwait. ``The corrupt al-Sabah family are not Arabs,'' Iraq's ruling Baath Party newspaper Al-Thawra declared on Monday. Another Iraqi newspaper said the Kuwaiti royal family was descended from Christian crusaders who were defeated by Arabs in the 11th century. After their defeat, ``they wandered in the desert where they practiced primitive medicine among the Arab tribes,'' Al-Qadissiya newspaper said. Iraq's state-controlled newspapers said the al-Sabah family had been removed from Kuwait forever. After its invasion of Kuwait on Thursday, Iraq replaced the royal family with the ``provisional government of free Kuwait,'' a leadership of nine previously unknown officers. However, Arab nations and the rest of the world still recognize Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, in exile in Saudi Arabia, as Kuwait's legitimate ruler. The al-Sabah family began its rule in 1756 after arriving in the Persian Gulf region from central Arabia. The family's rule had been uninterrupted until Iraq's invasion, although Kuwait was a British protectorate from 1899 to 1961. After its attack, Iraq was unable to find any prominent Kuwaiti to serve in the revolutionary government it installed. Most experts believe the family is admired for its shrewd investment of Kuwait's huge oil income. Investment funds set up to provide income for the state after the country's oil runs out are estimated at more than $100 billion. Last year, the funds earned Kuwait more income than it received from oil exports. Kuwait's per capita income is $20,000 a year. The number of al-Sabah princes has grown to more than 1,000. But the rulership is given to members of two branches descended from the Emir Mubarak the Great who ruled at the turn of the century. Princes serve as head of state, prime minister, fill key ministries and other critical jobs such as head of Kuwait's office in London which oversees the massive foeign investments. Power of attorney over Kuwait's public wealth is held by the ruler, making the emirate virtually a family business like Saudi Arabia. But the Kuwaiti princes have generally led more austere lives than their Saudi counterparts. ``They take a share but they don't rub it in,'' said a Kuwaiti newspaper editor before the invasion. There have been pressures for more democracy in the emirate, with calls for a Western-style Parliament. Kuwait experimented with a Parliament twice in the 1970s and 1980s with a fully-elected, 50-seat body. Both times the Parliament was closed by the emir after members engaged in harsh criticism of government ministers' performance. Elections were held in June for a third try at a Parliament, with one-third of the members appointed by the ruler. Only male Kuwaiti citizens over 21 were eligible to vote. Turnout was 63 percent and most government-sponsored candidates won handily. A group of 30 former liberal parliamentarians organized a boycott of the elections, saying the parliament should be fully elected. With the exception of a handful of radicals, however, most opposition members were thought to favor more power-sharing by the al-Sabah family but not its overthrow. Some in the Arab world welcomed the Iraqi invasion. Some Palestinians, for example, believed Kuwait had not done enough to support their cause against Israel. In Jordan, where more than 50 percent of the population is of Palestinian origin, the media said the Iraqi invasion was justified. A Jordanian journalist said resentment was based on three factors: Kuwait's failure to give enough support to Jordan as a front-line state facing Israel; not investing in Jordan to boost its economy; and treatment of the large Palestinian minority in Kuwait as second-class citizens. More than 300,000 Palestinians are among the 1.2 million expatriates in Kuwait. There are only 600,000 Kuwaiti citizens. Few expatriates had dared speak out against the Kuwaiti monarchy for fear of deportation. They faced losing much higher income and better living conditions in Kuwait than they would find at home in India, Pakistan, Iran or Egypt. The Al Ahrar newspaper of Cairo, expressing the opinion of poorer Arabs, referred to the invasion as a ``problem of rich and poor. While some countries like Somalia and Sudan starve, other have billions.'' The Palestine Liberation Organization was among seven members of the Arab League that refused to condemn Iraq for the invasion. PLO leader Yasser Arafat was believed unwilling to offend Iraq, a more likely hero for the Palestinians in their battle to gain a homeland from Israel.

DOC.HEAD: `Ghost' Reappears in First Place
DOC.TEXT: ``Ghost,'' the Patrick Swayze thriller, has proved a strong presence at the box office, landing in first place for the third time. Not even ``Dick Tracy'' or ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder'' has been No. 1 for more than two weeks during a summer that has failed to produce a blockbuster. ``No one would have picked `Ghost' as a top summer picture,'' said John Krier of Exhibitor Relations Co. ``But there it is.'' ``Ghost,'' about the return of a murdered man's spirit to protect his lover and solve his own slaying, also stars Demi Moore and Whoopi Goldberg. It took in $10.2 million at the box office last weekend. ``Presumed Innocent,'' the Harrison Ford courtroom drama about a prosecutor charged with murdering a former lover, earned $10.1 million and traded places with ``Ghost'' after bumping it from first place the week before. In third with $8 million was the debut of ``Young Guns II,'' a sequel starring Lou Diamond Phillips, Emilio Estevez, Kiefer Sutherland and Christian Slater. It is a retelling of the fight between Billy the Kid and lawman Pat Garrett. ``Problem Child,'' despite universally bad reviews, remained in the top five for its second week, delivering $6.8 million in ticket sales. In fifth place was creepy-crawly ``Arachnophobia,'' capturing $5.9 million. ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder'' sixth with $4.8 million. Director Spike Lee's ``Mo' Better Blues'' opened in limited release and sold $4.3 million in tickets for seventh place. The movie stars Denzel Washington as a jazz trumpeter playing notes when not pursuing two women. Gone from the top 10 were two of the most touted movies of the summer, ``Days of Thunder'' and ``Dick Tracy,'' which earned slightly over $1 million, enough to put it in the six-digit category with $101 million in earnings over eight weeks. ``Days'' earned $2.6 million, and with a total of $73.7 million, seems hard-pressed to pass the $100 million mark. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $10.7 million, 1,766 screens, $6,115 per screen, $69.1 million, four weeks. 2. ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. $10.1 million, 1,380 screens, $7,374 per screen, $28.3 million, two weeks. 3. ``Young Guns II,'' 20th Century Fox, $8 million, 1,770 screens, $4,530 per screen, $11.8 million, one week 4. ``Problem Child,'' Universal, $6.8 million, 1,768 screens, $3,870 per screen, $22.1 million, two weeks. 5. ``Arachnophobia,'' Disney, $5.9 million, 2,005 screens, $2,975 per screen, $34.1 million, three weeks. 6. ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder,'' 20th Century Fox, $4.8 million, 1,946 screens, $2,475 per screen, $95.6 million, five weeks. 7. ``Mo' Better Blues,'' Universal, $4.3 million, 544 screens, $8,065 per screen, $4.3 million, one week. 8. ``Ducktales,'' Disney, $3.8 million, 1,549 screens, $2,499 per screen, $3.8 million, one week. 9. ``The Freshman,'' Tri-Star, $3.4 million, 1,044 screens, $3,295 per screen, $10.1 million, three weeks. 10. ``The Jungle Book,'' Disney, $2.7 million, 1,478 screens, $1,868 per screen, $31.7 million, four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: China to Double Number of Panda Reserves
DOC.TEXT: China plans to open up 14 panda reserves, more than doubling the number of protected zones for the endangered animal and forcing some people to relocate, an official newspaper said today. Foreigners who have visited some of the 13 existing panda reserves in China have found the areas heavily inhabited by people, pushing the pandas to small mountaintop areas and preventing them from mingling during mating season. More than 4,000 peasants live in China's showcase panda research and breeding center in Wolong, in southwest China's Sichuan province. The China Daily report today said residents now living in the proposed conservation areas would be persuaded to move and extensive publicity and education would be used to ``arouse the public's consciousness on protection of pandas.'' The World Wildlife Fund, which uses the panda on its logo, is to provide money, equipment and facilities, the paper said, without providing a figure. The organization will send experts to train Chinese staff and carry out laboratory work, the report said. In Britain last week, senior World Wildlife Fund officials said pandas do not have much chance of survival if the Chinese government does not provide funds for the ``panda management plan'' the organization helped the Chinese formulate. The China Daily report did not say whether the new reserves were part of the plan. It did say that the World Wildlife Fund participated in studies on the proposed reserves, and that final approval was needed from both the wildlife fund and the State Council, China's Cabinet. Western experts estimate that China has 1,100-1,500 pandas living in the wild. Poaching is the main cause of China's dwindling panda population, though the government has instituted harsh penalties for panda killing including the death penalty. Panda skins can fetch tens of thousands of dollars. The paper said the Chinese government each year allocates $850,000 to rescue and protect the species. Today's report said the new reserves would be set up in the provinces of Sichuan, Gansu and Shaanxi, in southwest and central China, and would take 10 years to establish. The report did not say how much area the reserves would cover or how many pandas are in the areas to be protected.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Differ On Possible Oil Shortages
DOC.TEXT: As nations look to Saudi Arabia and elsewhere to make up loss of oil from Kuwait and Iraq, predictions from experts on world supplies range from no immediate danger of shortages to severe restrictions soon. Uncertainty has sent prices surging. In New York, West Texas intermediate crude was $28.05 a barrel at Monday's close, a five-year high and $3.65 up on Friday's close. In Tokyo today, North Sea Brent Blend was trading at $27.75, up $1.40 from its close Monday. The United Nations Security Council voted 13-0 on Monday to impose broad sanctions against Iraq, punishment for its invasion of Kuwait. The penalties include a ban on imports and exports aimed at blocking Baghdad's oil trade. ``There will be a potential restriction of oil supply in the near future that could range in intensity from significant to highly severe,'' the Middle East Economic Survey, a weekly newsletter published in Cyprus, said Monday. But in London, experts said disruption of oil supplies from Iraq and Kuwait posed no immediate danger of shortages. They said, however, that extra world capacity could be called upon quickly, pushing prices higher. Iraq produced 3.1 million barrels of oil daily in July and Kuwait 1.6 million. Together, that accounted for 9 percent of world output, the International Energy Agency reported. Excluding Iraq and Kuwait, the Persian Gulf has unused capacity of 3.2 million barrels a day, the agency said. The extra capability is concentrated in Saudi Arabia, but analysts say there are doubts the Saudis would be willing to antagonize Iraq by stepping up output. ``The key obviously lies with Saudi Arabia; and there must be considerable doubt as to how far the Kingdom would be prepared to go in antagonizing Iraq,'' the newsletter said. But Lucy Mullins, an oil analyst at the London investment company Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd., said: ``In the short term, I don't think people are panicking too much. The world could last six months or so almost quite happily.'' She said Norway, which doesn't belong to OPEC, might be able to kick in an extra 200,000 barrels a day. Britain's North Sea supplies, amounting to 3.6 million barrels a day in July, have been constrained by summer maintenance and industrial action by workers. And oil producer Venezuela said Monday it would not immediately increase its oil prices or production. The reaction in Mexico, the world's fifth-biggest exporter of crude oil, was the same: ``We're watching prices very closely, but we have not changed our policy,'' said a source at the state petroleum monopoly Pemex. Mexico has been exporting an average of 1.2 million barrels of oil a day and experts said the oil wells are pumping at full capacity. Worldwide, the oil market has had an excess of supply and oil importers' stocks are high, experts say. The oil shocks of the 1970s also have made industrial nations accomplished in cutting demand. Before the U.N. vote, the United States, the 12-nation European Economic Community, Japan and other countries had announced plans to impose an embargo on Iraqi oil purchases. Iraq, which pipes most of its oil through Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea and Turkey to the Mediterranean, on Monday cut back the oil flow through its Turkish pipeline following reports the United States had asked Turkey to block the lines. President Turgut Ozal of Turkey said before the U.N. Security Council imposed its embargo that he would abide by it. Kuwaiti production was halted after Iraq's invasion. The Dutch government said Monday it was stopping Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil shipments to Rotterdam, one of the world's largest oil harbors. France said Monday ships carrying Iraqi oil or under Iraqi control would be refused permission to dock at French ports. And Australia, Brazil and Switzerland on Monday all announced embargoes on Iraqi oil imports. Brazil buys about 30 percent _ 160,000 barrels a day _ of its oil from Iraq. ``We are in a comfortable position because we produce over half the oil we use and already have 70 days worth of stocks,'' said Lanning Elwis, a spokesman for Brazil's state oil monopoly Petrobras.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senator Denies Influencing Bank Regulators in CenTrust Seizure
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Bob Graham says he never tried to delay the government seizure of CenTrust Bank, whose failure led to a record $1.7 billion bailout. NBC reported Monday that Graham special counsel Steve Josias arranged a 1987 meeting between banking regulators and CenTrust lawyers and used his position at the senator's office to bring pressure on regulators looking into the thrift. Graham, a Democrat and member of the Senate's powerful Banking Committee, said he first learned in March about the meeting. The senator said it was ``bad judgment'' for his aide _ who had done legal work for the thrift _ to attend. But he said, ``I would say categorically (my office) did not have any effect on any action by federal regulators that would have affected their decisions.'' Josias, who served as special counsel to Graham for six months and whose law firm had handled some real estate matters for CenTrust, called the NBC allegations ``ludicrous.'' He said he merely convened the meeting with regulators from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board at the request of CenTrust officials who felt government officials were failing to respond to questions on regulatory procedures. But Josias admitted he should have told all concerned about his firm's work for CenTrust. When regulators seized CenTrust in February, they blamed its failure on speculative investing, including the purchase of more than $1 billion in junk bonds. They also cited the lavish spending of the institution's chairman, David L. Paul, who allegedly spent millions of thrift dollars on a museum-quality art collection for his home, a company yacht, limousines and a corporate jet. Paul has declined comment about CenTrust and its seizure, which has led to the biggest bailout to date of the savings and loan crisis. Investigators are examining the legality of $328,000 in political contributions by Paul. Graham said he never received money from Paul or any CenTrust political action committees. Previously, five other senators have come under scrutiny by the Senate Ethics Committee for meeting with regulators about Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., after accepting a combined $1.3 million in political contributions from the failed thrift's owner, Charles Keating Jr. The senators are Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz., and Donald Riegle, D-Mich.

DOC.HEAD: `National Night Out' Anti-Crime Effort Goes International
DOC.TEXT: Block parties, a candlelight march and a U.S.-Canadian motorcade top the plans for tonight's seventh annual National Night Out, in which citizens step outside to reclaim the streets from criminals. Organizers are hoping that millions of ordinary people across the country will turn on porch lights and emerge from behind locked doors to meet local police and let street predators know they're watching. The neighborhood activism began in 1984 with an idea advanced by Matt Peskin and the National Association of Town Watch. ``It's a July 4 atmosphere, but there's seriousness,'' Peskin said. ``We call it a party with a purpose.'' This year it's going international, with a noontime ``hands across the border'' ceremony scheduled at Mather Arch in Fort Erie, Ontario. Slated to take part were 300 members of police agencies and neighborhood groups from western New York and southern Ontario. The ceremonies in Canada were to be followed by a motorcade across the Peace Bridge to the New York State Armory in Buffalo, led by Canadian Pipes and Drums and Royal Mounted Police. ``This will demonstrate that crime doesn't stop at the international boundary and policing is a universal job,'' said Peskin. Cities around the country are sponsoring block parties. Milwaukee planned 1,000 parties and demonstrations to show people how to illuminate their homes. Police in Plainsboro, N.J., will give away two cases of floodlights. Syracuse, N.Y., planned a city-county candlelight march. In Louisville, Ky., sirens and church bells will sound at 8 p.m., a signal for people to turn on their outside lights and check the batteries in their home smoke detectors. ``It's a rare chance, especially for the kids. The event seems to draw out neighborhoods that have usually been tough to involve in anything,'' Peskin said. ``Generally, most people are law-abiding and they want to be neighborly. But nowadays, if you try to be neighborly, many people are likely to be suspicious.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``They did not expect the international community _ the Russians, Japanese, Europe, at our instance, the Americans _ to come together so clearly and so soon against this act of aggression.'' _ British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, on the worldwide condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

``We think what has happened today forms an important turning point.'' _ President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa, after the African National Congress announced it was suspending all armed actions against the white minority government.

``He and the Miss America Pageant were kind of synonymous. This would be the return of a legend. It would be a return to tradition and very welcome.'' _ Nate Zauber, director of the Miss New Jersey Pageant, on the possibility of emcee Bert Parks returning to the Miss America Pagaent.

DOC.HEAD: Impeached Federal Judge Jailed for Toting Gun
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr., impeached by Congress for a perjury conviction, is back behind bars on charges he carried a gun during an illegal turkey shoot, a violation of his parole. Nixon, 61, was arrested Monday at his Ocean Springs home after the U.S. Justice Department learned of his state conviction on misdemeanor hunting offenses. Nixon was convicted July 6 of hunting over a field illegally spread with corn to lure wild turkeys. He was fined $100. Testimony revealed he carried two guns in cases. Felons on parole are barred from carrying firearms. The U.S. Parole Commission could order Nixon to serve the three years of prison time remaining from his perjury conviction, or he could receive as little as a reprimand. He was being held at the Copiah County Jail. Al Binder, Nixon's attorney, said the former judge ``is very concerned and I'm sure he's upset.'' ``I'm hopeful when they hear the whole story that they'll give him some consideration and not revoke his parole,'' Binder said. Nixon was convicted in 1986 of perjury for lying to federal grand jury about discussions he had with a prosecutor about a drug case. The Senate stripped Nixon of his judgeship and $89,500 annual salary last November. He was paroled the same month after serving two years of a five-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge Again, Dollar Strengthens
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply today to its lowest level in nearly 22 months as uncertainties over the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait grew. The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 150.60 yen, up 1.10 yen from Monday's 149.50 finish. The currency opened at 150.75 yen and ranged between 150.48 and 151.10. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent, ending the day at 27,653.07, the lowest level since Oct. 26, 1988, when the index fell to 27,620.60. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday, the index has lost 3,184.92 points, or 11.5 percent. First section volume today was thin, estimated at 500 million shares, up from Monday's 330 million. On an active day, more than 1 billion shares are traded. The index ended the morning session with a 1,327-point decline before bargain-hunting helped regain some of the loss in the afternoon, according to traders who spoke on condition of anonymity. They said the Nikkei's decline was caused by growing fears among investors of Middle East developments, surging oil prices, plunging government bond prices and the weakening yen. Oil prices continued moving up in Asia, with October Brent valued at $27.80 to $28.00 a barrel at around 3 p.m. It sold at $27.05 at the beginning of the day. Meanwhile, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 82.98 points, down from Monday's 83.71-point finish. The yield finished at 8.105 percent, up from 7.935 percent. ``Market players were increasingly getting pessimistic, and they were almost panicking,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. There were plenty of sellers today but buyers stayed out of the market, analysts said. ``Unless they figure out the extent of its effect, investors are inclined to stay away from the stock market,'' Nomura said. The Japanese government has imposed a set of sanctions against Iraq for invading Kuwait, including a ban on oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait and on all Japanese exports to the two nations. Japan relies on imports for 99 percent of its oil needs and has never previously banned the import of petroleum. While top officials acknowledge the sanctions will affect daily life, they point out that the nation's petroleum reserves, which are estimated to last for 142 days, should cushion the impact. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will ask other oil-producing Arab countries later this month to expand their crude oil production if the embargo is prolonged. In currency dealings, soaring oil prices and further declines in stock and bond markets added to the currency market's bearish sentiment toward the yen, although there was a slight recovery of stability, dealers said. They said some market players sold the U.S. currency to take profits from its strong overnight increase in New York. ``Uncertainty about the Middle East is a factor that encourages dollar buying, but on the other hand, pessimistic prospects over the U.S. economy, which is a dollar-selling factor, is equally strong,'' said Takashi Fujii, a trader with the Bank of Tokyo. ``Right now, investors are watching both factors _ the Middle East situation and the U.S. economy _ and the currency could move in either direction, '' he said. Finance Minister Hashimoto said earlier today that the yen will strengthen in the aftermath of the Middle East crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Postponed by Supermarket Workers
DOC.TEXT: A strike threatened by 80,000 California supermarket workers was put on hold early today so contract talks could continue. Negotiators for the Food and Commercial Workers Union, representing meat cutters and clerks, and the Food Employers Council, representing six grocery chains, talked through the night, past a strike deadline of 12:01 a.m. ``I would not characterize this as major progress, but it is substantive,'' union spokesman Bob Bleiweiss said. Monday was the fourth day of talks. The union represents 73,000 clerks and 7,000 meat cutters at 800 supermarkets in central and southern California. The council represents the grocery chains Vons, Ralphs, Alpha Beta, Lucky, Albertsons and Stater Bros.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Express Solidarity On Eve of Presidential Inauguration
DOC.TEXT: World leaders in Colombia for today's inauguration of president-elect Cesar Gaviria have pledged to aid the violence-weary country in its fight against drug trafficking and terrorism. Security in the capital was heavy, with some 5,000 soldiers and policemen guarding against possible attacks by drug-bankrolled terrorists. Army officials declared a maximum security alert in the hours leading up to the inauguration. Military helicopters circled Bogota, and the army set up 40mm anti-aircraft guns on a hill half a mile from the presidential palace, where Gaviria was to take the oath of office for a four-year term. Roadblocks and army checkpoints lined major roads and highways. Gaviria, 43, has promised to hold to the current tough line against cocaine barons, who have waged a nearly year-old war against the government in an attempt to force and end to the extradition of drug traffickers. About 500 people have died in a wave of bombings and assassinations. On Monday, the presidents of Venezuela, Argentina, Ecuador and Haiti, along with high-level delegations from scores of other countries, arrived in Bogota for the inaugural ceremonies. Vice President Dan Quayle was expected today. ``Drug trafficking is a blow to the international community, and it must be fought through international cooperation,'' said Ecuador's President Rodrigo Borja. Giovanni Spadolini, president of Italy's senate, echoed Borja's sentiments: ``We are particularly sensitive to this fight against the drug scourge, and we offer our solidarity.'' But in his inaugural speech, Gaviria was expected to ask foreign nations to provide economic aid and special trade status rather than military assistance, said the RCN radio network. Colombian drug cartels supply about 80 percent of cocaine purchased in the United States. Cocaine is a multibillion dollar business in Colombia and the revenues and jobs it provides have helped prop up the economy. A year ago, the United States sent Colombia $65 million in military aid including helicopters and bullet-proof vests. But the economic aid Colombia had hoped for, such as preferential treatment for its exports, never materialized. RCN said Gaviria would also ask industrialized countries to control money laundering by drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Women Killed In Apparent Revenge For Slayings of Jews
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian woman was shot to death as she drove past a Jewish West Bank settlement early today, and officials suspected she was killed by settlers in revenge for the slayings of two Israeli teen-agers. In Jerusalem, police poured hundreds of additional forces into the city following mass anti-Arab riots that were sparked by the discovery of the youths' bodies on Monday. Thousands took to the streets in at least seven neighborhoods and officials said the extent of the rioting was unprecedented in this mixed Jewish-Arab city. The violence persisted this morning as Arabs heading to work in Jerusalem came under attack on the highway linking the city to the occupied West Bank town of Bethlehem. An angry Israeli mob forced a Palestinian-owned car to stop on that road and then smashed its windshield with iron bars, injuring seven passengers, Arab reports said. Soldiers at nearby roadblocks later urged Palestinians not to enter Jerusalem, warning they could get stoned and most returned home. Thousands of Israelis were expected to attend the funeral of the two youths later today _ and police feared trouble. The slain Palestinian woman was identified by Arab reports as Aziza Salem Jaber, 27, from the West Bank town of Hebron. Mrs. Jaber was shot twice in the head as the station wagon she rode past the Jewish settlement of Kiryat Arba at about 2 a.m., police officials said, refusing to elaborate. An official source confirmed police suspected the shooting was by a settler in revenge for the brutal slayings of the two Jewish teen-agers, 18-year-old Ronen Karamani and 17-year-old Lior Tubul. Arab witnesses said a group of settlers were standing near the Kiryat Arba entrance when the shots were fired. The reports said Mrs. Jaber's cousin, Najeh, was wounded in the shoulder. Mrs. Jaber and other relatives were reportedly accompanying a pregnant cousin to a hospital at the time of the shooting. Her death would bring to 726 the number of Palestinians slain by Israelis since the December 1987 start of the Palestinian uprising. Another 245 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. The slayings of Tubul and Karamni brought the Israeli death toll in the uprising to 47. Teen-age volunteers found their bodies Monday with multiple stab wounds in a dry river bed near the Jewish neighborhood of Ramot in Arab east Jerusalem, just inside the city limits. The army swiftly clamped a curfew on a nearby village and conducted wide searches but no arrests were made. News of the slayings sparked the worst anti-Arab riots in Jerusalem. ``The scope was unprecedented,'' Amir Heshin, advisor to Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek on Arab Affairs, said on army radio. Several thousand angry Israelis blocked main highways throughout the city, showering Arab-owned cars with rocks and cinderblocks. Some 20 to 30 Arabs were injured by police estimate. The depth of anti-Arab feelings stirred by the stabbings was also reflected in Israel's mass-circulation news dailies Tuesday. The three most widely read newspapers splashed across their front pages a picture of Karamani's corpse. The photo showed the youth lying face down in a rocky field, a towel tied around his mouth and his blue T-shirt ripped by stab wounds. The Yediot Ahronot daily linked the slayings to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``The war of Arabs against Arabs, just like the war of Arabs against us are a different face to a process of reducing the limits of human morality,'' Yediot editorialized. The conservative Maariv daily called on security officials to restrict the free movement of Palestinians in Israeli-controlled territories. ``Perhaps it would harm our liberalism to a certain extent, but the harm done by the murderers is much more serious and in order to thwart them it is permissible to compromise on the open gates policy,'' Maariv wrote.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Drug for Lung Disease of Premature Infants
DOC.TEXT: Doctors have a new drug effective against a lung disease that kills about 3,000 premature infants a year. The Food and Drug Administration said Monday it approved Exosurf, which cuts the death rate in half in premature infants suffering from respiratory distress syndrome, the most common cause of death in babies under 30 days old. The drug is a mixture of synthetic chemicals that mimics the action of lung surfactant, a liquid in the lungs that helps keep them inflated. Premature infants cannot make surfactant, and their lungs can collapse if not treated. The drug was invented by Dr. John Clements of the University of California at San Francisco and is made by Burroughs Wellcome Co. of Research Triangle Park, N.C. Approval of the drug ``is a very important development,'' said Dr. Mary Ellen Avery, professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School in Boston. ``There has been a significant reduction in deaths among those who were treated.'' Respiratory distress syndrome afflicts 50,000 infants each year and kills about 3,000 of them, the American Lung Association said. Exosurf and another experimental surfactant made from cows' lungs, Survanta, have been available since last year, when the FDA allowed distribution under a policy to make life-saving drugs available before approval. Survanta, is made by Abbott Laboratories in Abbott Park, Ill.An Abbott spokesman said approval of Survanta was expected soon. Both drugs have been widely used, and although they have not been directly compared, ``both work pretty well,'' Avery said. Dr. Anthony Corbet, a neonatologist at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston who has participated in studies of Exosurf, said the drug could significantly lower the U.S. infant mortality rate. The U.S. rate is 10 deaths per 1,000 live births, and about three infant deaths per 1,000 are due to respiratory distress syndrome, he said. In studies with 1,600 infants with respiratory distress syndrome, Exosurf cut the death rate 66 percent, the company said. When given to 1,800 infants who were at risk of developing the disease but had not yet contracted it, the drug reduced the death rate 50 percent, company officials said. The company said side effects include a slight increase in bleeding in the lungs and apnea, a treatable disorder in which infants intermittently stop breathing. Dr. Richard Kent of Burroughs Wellcome explained that without surfactant, the little air sacs in the lung called alveoli collapse like balloons if air pressure is not maintained. When surfactant is added, the alveoli become more like bubble-gum bubbles and maintain their shape when air pressure falls, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Married at Fair Sideshow
DOC.TEXT: Julie Gilmore's wedding march was a success. She didn't trip over the guillotine. Ms. Gilmore wed Joseph Berlyak on Monday on the Palace of Illusions stage at the Ohio State Fair, where they met last year when Berlyak coaxed her into volunteering for the guillotine act. When Ms. Gilmore, 38, emerged intact, the couple ``fell head over heels'' for each other, said show manager Maureen Reno. The two lovers from Akron had dinner after their intial meeting under a guillotine blade. Berlyak, 42, emcee of last year's magic show, said he was careful not to flub his lines during the wedding ceremony amid other gruesome props such as a bed of nails and an electric chair. ``If I stutter and don't say yes, she's going to sit me in the electric chair and threaten to turn it on,'' he said. The bride wore a white dress and the groom a pinstripe suit, rather than traditional carnival garb. ``We didn't want to turn it into a circus,'' Berlyak said.

DOC.HEAD: No Bone to Pick About This Sort of Postal Service
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service extended bare bones service to Kerrie Shannon, delivering a wrapper-less fossilized leg bone mailed to her by a sister in New Mexico. The foot-long artifact took about a week to arrive, with Ms. Shannon's home address neatly printed on the bone with a marking pen and a $2.40 postage meter stamp affixed. ``We only have a mail slot, so when my father came home, he found it sticking halfway out,'' Ms. Shannon said. ``Greetings from New Mexico,'' read the message from Colleen Shannon, a park employee at Bandelier National Monument in New Mexico. Two weeks earlier, Kerrie Shannon had complained her sister hadn't answered any of her six letters. ``I told her to send me something, and she did,'' she said. Joe Sniadecki, a South Bend postal superintendent, said he's heard of coconuts mailed from Hawaii, but never bones from New Mexico. ``It doesn't happen every day, but there's nothing wrong with it as far as regulations,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Newspapers Pull Doonesbury Strips
DOC.TEXT: A set of ``Doonesbury'' comics containing suggestive language and showing a woman wearing nothing but rope and a bucket is in poor taste, say two newspaper editors who pulled the strips. ``If we had been running it on the op-ed page, we probably would have thought differently about it,'' said Phil Record, associate executive editor of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram. ``But we just did not think this was suitable on a page we try to draw kids to.'' The newspaper said Monday it will not publish this week's strips but has notified readers they can pick up copies at newspaper offices. The Republic in Columbus, Ind., also decided to drop the strips. The newspaper will run old ``Doonesbury'' comics instead, editor John Harmon said. ``It just didn't meet our guidelines for taste,'' he said. ``If our photographers came back with something like that, we wouldn't run it.'' The Baton Rouge (La.) State-Times and Morning Advocate decided to run the strip opposite the editorial page rather than on the comics page. ``It contains language and art that I would be very reluctant to invite children to look at,'' said Jim Hughes, executive editor. ``And children read the comics page.'' The strip by Garry Trudeau apparently refers to controversy over National Endowment of the Arts funding. Some politicians have tried to block government money going to art they consider obscene, and some artists have lost grants. In Monday's strip, the character J.J. tells her husband she has a new concept for performance art so innovative that the NEA will have to reconsider her grant application. She is covered only by a strategically placed rope and her hand, and she has a bucket over her head. In strips for later in the week, J.J. utters words such as ``ooze,'' ``lubricate'' and ``hot juices,'' although she makes no direct reference to sex acts. Lee Salem, editorial director at the strip's distributor, Universal Press Syndicate, said only about eight to 10 newspapers called with concerns. The Kansas City company distributes the strip to about 1,000 newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Continues in East Today
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the East early today. Skies were mostly clear over the rest of the nation except for a thunderstorm in San Diego. Spectacular thunderstorms lit up Southern California late Monday, knocking out power, bringing hard rain and sparking fires in the drought-stricken area. Sunshine and scorching heat were forecast for the region today. Temperatures were expected to climb into the 110s around the southern tip of California and southwest Arizona. Rain was forecast in the Northeast. A band of showers was also expected from the Deep South to the Virginias. Sunny skies were forecast for the Midwest and much of the West, with showers possible in New Mexico and Arizona. Temperatures were expected to reach the 80s in the East and Midwest, and the 90s in the South and the north central region. Lower temperatures were forecast for the Northwest, with highs only in the 70s. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 122 degrees at Death Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard: Spill Cleanup Procedures Ignored Over Last Decade
DOC.TEXT: The system for cleaning up oil spills has deteriorated over the last decade, a Coast Guard panel said in winding up an investigation of 12 spills in the New York area this year. The nine-member board led by Rear Adm. William G. Henn said Monday the system worsened as public and government concern waned until recently. ``We would not have been talking about this 10 years ago and we had pretty much the same number of spills,'' Henn said. ``What we thought was good in 1980 is not good enough today.'' There were 12 oil spills in the area around the Port of New York and New Jersey during the first seven months of 1990, including a 570,000-gallon spill from an Exxon refinery in Linden, N.J., into the Arthur Kill on Jan. 2. The Coast Guard panel recommended a 10 percent increase in the number of inspectors in the area. About 75 inspectors monitor ship and shore facilities. The report also recommended a system of radar screens for monitoring ships in the harbor. Such a tracking system was shut down in 1988 because of budget constraints. It would cost about $10 million to get it fully operational again.

DOC.HEAD: Phantom Gardener Beautifies New Hampshire Neighborhood
DOC.TEXT: Dorothy Silber knew the phantom had struck when she discovered a row of marigolds underneath a window at her office. The next day there were more, and soon after that, there were geraniums. Her phantom gardener even watered them. ``It's everybody's dream come true to have a garden and not have to plant it,'' said Silber, who said the phantom enriched her property with more than 400 plants. The mystery was solved when she caught the generous green-thumb at work early one morning. He told her he lives in the neighborhood and grows all his plants from seed. All he wants is to see them flourish in attractive settings. Tracked down by the The Telegraph of Nashua, the phantom said he just plants ``what I want, where I want to do it.'' He spoke freely about his work in this city about 30 miles north of Boston, but worried any publicity might make him too busy. ``I don't want my name in the paper,'' he said. ``Everybody will be calling me.''

DOC.HEAD: Western Europe Acts In Unison, But France Faulted For Arms Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with sanctions imposed by Switzerland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark; Picks up 9th pvs, `In Britain...'
DOC.TEXT: Western Europe has acted almost in unison in opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, to the extent that even neutral Switzerland announced today it will join in imposing sanctions. However, the French government is encountering harsh criticism at home from some political figures who say it bears partial responsibility for the attack by encouraging massive arms sales to Iraq over the past decade. A former national intelligence director, Pierre Marion, said in an interview published Monday that France provided Iraq with one-fourth of its military arsenal while pursuing a ``shortsighted, incoherent'' Middle East policy. The sales earned an estimated $5 billion for France, which trailed only the Soviet Union as Iraq's biggest arms supplier. France's neighbors haven't echoed such criticisms, and the French delegation played a leading role at the weekend meeting in Rome of the European Community, which voted for an embargo on imports of Iraqi oil. The community's 12 member countries also voted to freeze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets. Switzerland, not a member of the European Community, NATO or any other political alliance, demonstrated the broad consensus on the Iraq-Kuwait conflict today, announcing it would break from its traditional policy of not taking part in international embargoes. Switzerland said it would follow the lead of the U.N. Security Council and ban all trade with Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. It also prohibited all payments and other financial transfers to Iraq and Kuwait. Switzerland had refused to join the U.N.-endorsed sanctions campaigns against Rhodesia and South Africa. Sweden, Norway and Denmark also announced today they were imposing a complete trade embargo against Iraq and Kuwait. In Britain, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Monday the crisis in the Persian Gulf had produced a rare degree of unity, transcending customary alliances. In contrast to some recent foreign policy issues, his government has not found itself at odds with any major allies. The Iraqis ``have got themselves into a corner,'' Hurd told BBC-TV. ``They did not expect the international community _ the Russians, Japanese, Europe, at our instance, the Americans _ to come together so clearly and so soon against this act of aggression.'' Britain's relations with Iraq had been strained severely since the March 15 execution by that country of Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian journalist with the British newspaper, The Observer. On March 28, British authorities announced the seizure of parts that could be used in nuclear bomb triggers just before they were put aboard an Iraq-bound airliner. In April, large pipes were seized that Britain alleged were parts for an Iraqi ``super gun'' project. In France, the government responded quickly to the Iraqi invasion by announcing a halt to all arms sales to Baghdad and an end to training of Iraqi fighter pilots. Officials said arms sales in fact had stopped in May because of problems arising from Iraq's debt to France of more than $4 billion. But the actions failed to ward off criticism. On Sunday, the head of France's Greens party, Antoine Waechter, said the government practiced ``blind diplomacy'' during the years of arms sales to Iraq. ``France is partly responsible for what is happening today,,'' Waechter said. ``France sold arms even when it was obvious that Iraq had this type of dominating, expansionist behavior.'' Marion, who in 1981-82 headed France's external intelligence agency, told the Paris newspaper Le Figaro that France had sold Iraq 210 Mirage warplanes and state-of-the art missiles. Sales continued even after the Iran-Iraq war ended in 1988, he said. Since early this year, Marion said, the French military contractor Thomson CSF has sold $160 million worth of electronics equipment to Iraq that could be used to develop sophisticated military radar systems. Four French companies have sold equipment that could be used to increase the range and accuracy of Soviet-made Scud missiles possessed by Iraq, Marion was quoted as saying. ``Because of the complaisant attitude which it had in the past toward Saddam Hussein... France today must have a bad conscience and some regrets,'' said an editorial Monday in the Courrier de l'Ouest, a newspaper in Angers. In West Germany, there also has been extensive media criticism of allegedly illegal shipments by West German companies to Iraq over the past several years. The news magazine Der Spiegel reported Saturday that German companies have played central roles in helping Iraq with its military buildup.

DOC.HEAD: Aspiring Entrepreneur Builds Gazebo in Tree Tops
DOC.TEXT: Look up when you pass the Davenports' place and you just might see Ed and Sandie up a tree, sipping soda pop in their gazebo tree house. Davenport, a 46-year-old farmer, hopes combining his childhood longing for a hideaway in the tree tops with an adult penchant for the peace and quiet of a gazebo will lead to some off-season work. It's free advertisement atop a giant cottonwood, 18 feet in circumference, that's middle limbs were torn off in a wind storm. ``I couldn't have found a more perfect tree because it is big enough and it did look strange without those middle limbs,'' Davenport said recently. ``Of course, some people think it looks strange now.'' Davenport started his project about a month ago with a stairway more than 20 feet into the tree. Two weeks after he hammered in the first nail, Davenport completed the yellow, white and gray latticework structure, which reaches 30 feet high and seats eight people. Davenport hopes the project will attract people interested in contracting with him to build gazebos in the winter when work on the farm is slow. He says he expects most people would want ground-level structures, but if any of them want to go out on a limb, he's willing.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Steady In Thin, Uncertain Trading, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was steady in thin, uncertain trading in Europe late this morning. Gold prices were up, but off their early highs as an Asian rally turned to profit-taking, dealers said. Traders said they expected the dollar to recover slightly after having hit bottom on Monday. Dealers said, however, that market conditions remained nervous because of the tense situation in the Middle East. ``It's fairly quiet this morning, but quite tense,'' said one trader at Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank in Frankfurt. ``If Saudi Arabia cuts off Iraq's oil pipeline and Iraq then invades Saudi Arabia, then I could imagine people would turn to the dollar as a safe haven.'' Some traders said they were optimistic about the Middle East dispute being settled by diplomatic means. But Iraq's blunt warning to the United States to stay out of the Persian Gulf crisis on Monday and other signs of heightened tension are prompting traders to try to find safe middle ground, the Frankfurt trader said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.10 yen to a closing 150.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 149.73 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.5766 West German marks, up from 1.5762 _1.3266 Swiss francs, down from 1.3315 _5.2875 French francs, up from 5.2863 _1.7783 Dutch guilders, up from 1.77660 _1,152.50 Italian lire, down from 1,154.00 _1.1488 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1490 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.8803, compared with $1.8725 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $386.20 a troy ounce, up from $382.50 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $383.95. In Zurich, the bid price was $383.90, up from $382.00 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $4.94 to close at a bid $383.52. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.93 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.91.

DOC.HEAD: Salmonella Outbreak May Be Linked to Raw Tomatoes
DOC.TEXT: Raw tomatoes may be the common link in a salmonella outbreak that has sickened more than 100 people in four Midwest states since July, health officials say. In Illinois, 51 salmonella cases have been reported since July 1, mostly in the Chicago area, said Dr. Bernard Turnock, the state's public health director.
