Minnesota has reported 38 cases, Michigan 10 and Wisconsin three. Minnesota officials said Monday the outbreak of salmonella javiana was definitely linked to tomatoes. Turnock said test results from Illinois cases ``show an association with tomatoes as the common source.'' Investigators believe tomatoes from a single farm or distributor may have been contaminated with manure used as fertilizer, but the source hasn't been pinpointed, said Tom Schafer, a spokesman for the Illinois Department of Public Health. Fecal matter is a common source of salmonella bacteria. Tomatoes associated with the outbreak came from grocery stores and were eaten at restaurants. ``Most likely in the fields these tomatoes were fertilized with manure that got on the tomatoes, plants and such,'' Schafer said. ``If not properly washed, they could carry salmonella.'' Consumers and food-service workers should wash tomatoes thoroughly and remove the area where the stem is attached, as well as any bruised or damaged areas. Sliced or cut tomatoes should be refrigerated until serving. Cooked tomatoes and tomato products aren't considered a potential problem because cooking destroys the salmonella bacteria, Turnock said. Salmonella symptoms include vomiting, diarrhea and stomach cramps. In 1985, Illinois was the center of a massive Midwest salmonella outbreak in which more than 16,000 cases were confirmed. The disease was traced to contaminated low-fat milk processed by a Chicago-area dairy. Schafer said the reported cases in the current outbreak may represent only a fraction of people stricken. Typically in salmonella outbreaks, only a relatively small portion of those afflicted are treated and diagnosed by a physician. ``A lot of people could have it and think it was stomach cramps,'' Schafer said.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Marine General Dead of Bone Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Retired Marine Corps Gen. Lemuel Cornick Shepherd Jr., who led the 6th Marine Division to victory at Okinawa in World War II and also served as Corps commandant, has died of bone cancer. He was 94. Shepherd died Monday at his home in this San Diego suburb. He received more than 60 decorations during his 42-year military career and twice was awarded the Legion of Merit while on active duty. Shepherd was appointed commandant of the Marine Corps in 1952 by President Truman. He served in that position until 1955. He was the first Marine commandant to serve as a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He was born in Norfolk, Va., and attended the Virginia Military Institute. He graduated a year early, in 1917, so he could volunteer for the Marines after the United States entered World War I. Less than a month after reporting for duty, Shepherd sailed for France. He was wounded twice in fighting at Belleau Wood in 1918. He also saw action in the Meuse Argonne offensive and was wounded a third time. Shepherd received the Navy Cross, the Army Distinguished Service Cross and the French Croix de Guerre for gallantry at Belleau Wood. After the war, he worked as a junior aide to President Harding, and served in Haiti until the Marines withdrew from the Caribbean island in 1934. Shepherd took command of the 9th Marine Regiment as a colonel in March 1942, a few months after the United States entered World War II. He was promoted to brigadier general before commanding the 1st Marine Brigade in the attack on Guam. In 82 days of combat at Okinawa, his 6th Marine Division _ known as the ``Striking 6th'' _ captured Naha, the largest city occupied by Marines during World War II. Shepherd also received the surrender of the Japanese forces in Tsingtao, China, on Oct. 25, 1945. When the Korean War broke out, Shepherd was a lieutenant general in command of all Marines in the Pacific. Shepherd retired in January 1956, but two months later was recalled to active duty. He retired again three years later and lived in Warrenton, Va., until he moved to La Jolla in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Cease-Fire Clears Way For Talks On Ending White Minority Rule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th pvs, `The way...' with 15 people killed in fighting between black factions. Pickup 5th pvs, `President F.W. ...'
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress announced today that it is ending its 29-year guerrilla campaign and suspending all military action, clearing the way for full-scale talks on ending white minority rule. ANC leader Nelson Mandela said his organization was making every effort to notify supporters to immediately end all armed action against the government. The two sides pledged after 16 hours of talks to work together to counter growing political violence that has claimed hundreds of lives in recent months. ``The way is now open to proceed towards negotiations on a new constitution,'' a joint statement by the two sides declared. Police said today at least 15 blacks had been killed in scattered faction fights around the country since Sunday. The dead included 11 killed in Kagiso outside Johannesburg in a power struggle between ANC supporters and Inkatha, the conservative Zulu political movement, police said. The independent South African Press Association said Kagiso was tense but quiet today, with police patrols deployed in force in the area. President F.W. de Klerk, who announced the cease-fire with Mandela after the talks, hailed the breakthrough, saying, ``We think what has happened today forms an important turning point.'' The two leaders looked tired but pleased as they announced the agreement in the early morning hours. ``In the interest of moving as speedily as possible towards a negotiated peaceful political settlement, and in the context of the agreement reached, the ANC announced it was now suspending all armed actions with immediate effect,'' said a joint statement released by the ANC and the government. Mandela said the ANC would halt the infiltration of guerrillas and arms from neighboring countries. ``We hope that we will be able to communicate with our people and inform them of what we have decided,'' he said. Mandela and the ANC now face a major test of their leadership to see if blacks, especially militant youths in black townships, observe the call for a cease-fire. Some critics fear the ANC has little actual control at the grass roots level and violence will continue since many young blacks oppose a peaceful settlement. Immediate reaction to the ANC announcement was glowing. Anglican Archbiship Desmond Tutu, a leading anti-apartheid activist, said, ``It's tremendous news ... we want to commend the ANC very warmly for its actions.'' But Tutu echoed warnings from ANC leaders that the government must act to curb the police and ensure the law was administered fairly. ANC leaders contend the police oppose reform and continue to persecute opposition groups. Tutu said, ``We must warn the South African government very sharply that if it does not act very firmly indeed to bring the police under control, then it will wreck the prospects of a negotiated settlement.'' Mandela said the decision to end the ANC's guerrilla campaign was made even before his five-man delegation arrived for the talks with de Klerk and Cabinet members. The two sides have been trying since May to remove obstacles to full-scale talks on ending white rule. Although the ANC's guerrilla wing, Spear of the Nation, has made no major attacks in the past year, ANC officials have acknowledged that guerrillas continued to infiltrate the country, stockpile weapons and plan attacks. Mandela had resisted declaring a cease-fire, saying the government had to make concessions. The ANC demanded the government release hundreds of political prisoners, grant amnesty to about 20,000 exiles, remove laws restricting political activity and end the state of emergency in Natal province. Today's statement indicated the government has gone some distance toward meeting ANC demands though stopping short of outright acceptance. Further discussion of the issues will now take place. The joint statement said the government would consider repealing some security laws and lifting the state of emergency in Natal. The emergency gives police wide powers to detain people and restrict political activity. Both sides also agreed to draw up plans for the release of ANC-connected prisoners and for granting amnesty to many of the exiles who want to return home. Asked what the government had conceded, de Klerk said his administration would try to ensure that the police deal with all problems in what he called ``an even-handed manner.'' In a bit of friction at the news conference, Mandela interjected that the government had so far failed to bring the police under control. ``It's a totally unsatisfactory situation, and until the government tames the police, we will be dissatisfied,'' Mandela said. The joint statement also said the government would continue to review security legislation under which scores of ANC activists, including a member of the National Executive Committee, have been detained by police during the past few weeks. De Klerk had been under pressure to secure major concessions from the ANC after he legalized black opposition groups and, in February, freed Mandela after 27 years in jail. White critics of de Klerk charged the government failed to gain anything by its concessions. The United States and other Western nations had been urging the ANC to renounce its armed struggle and seek a peaceful settlement. During Mandela's last years in prison, the ANC guerrilla wing waged an urban bombing campaign. From July 1986 through August 1989, the campaign killed 37 people and injured 680.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Accused of Killing 12 Civilians
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary police broke into houses in a Srinagar suburb and opened fire on sleeping residents, killing at least 12 people and injuring 15, witnesses said today. Authorities said several civilians were killed in the city on Monday night but said they had no details of the events. The authorities also reported that troops of the Border Security Force raided a house outside Srinigar on Monday and captured two top Moslem militants and their nine comrades. The capture of Yasin Malik, the commander of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, and his deputy, Abdul Hamid Sheikh, was the government's biggest victory since it began a crackdown on the militants in January. Witnesses said policemen Monday broke into homes in the Hawal locality searching for Moslem separatists who had earlier attacked a patrol party with grenades and machine-gun fire. ``The policemen broke down locked doors and opened blind fire,'' said Bashir Ahmed, a resident. He said three houses were then set ablaze. Other witnesses said the victims included an 8-year-old girl and a 75-year-old man. J.N. Saxena, the top police official in Jammu-Kashmir state, said he had ordered an inquiry into the incident. He said the paramilitary policemen would be tried for murder if charges of unprovoked firing were found to be true. Srinagar, a city of 1 million people, is at the center of the Moslem movement for secession of the Kashmir valley. At least 935 people have been killed in the valley since the Indian government cracked down on the insurrection on Jan. 20. The state of Jammu-Kashmir, which includes the valley and the Jammu plains to the south, is the only one of India's 25 provinces with a Moslem majority. At least 65 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Meeting With Latin Leaders on Drug War
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops grafs 1-2 to update with departure; picks up pvs graf 3: David Beckwith
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle left today for Bogota for the inauguration of Colombian President Cesar Gaviria, the first stop on a followup to President Bush's drug summit with the leaders of cocaine-producing nations. On his seventh vice presidential trip to Latin America, Quayle was to confer with the new presidents of Colombia and Peru, and with President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia. David Beckwith, Quayle's spokesman, said the three-day mission demonstrates the administration's commitment to cooperation in the drug war. The Feb. 15 Cartagena drug summit was held behind a tight military shield at a heavily guarded Colombian naval base. Even so, there was controversy about Bush's visit to a nation plagued by drug violence and assassinations. Quayle was to attend an outdoor inauguration ceremony in a Bogota government plaza, so security clearly was a concern. ``We're satisfied the vice president will be secure,'' Beckwith said. Bush had no major new aid or support measures to offer the three South American leaders, although he was renewing U.S. offers of military equipment and training to combat the cocaine cartel. Colombia's Gaviria has pledged to continue the drug war launched by outgoing President Virgilio Barco. He ran for the office after drug terrorists assassinated a top candidate to succeed Barco a year ago. In Lima, Peru, tonight and Wednesday, Quayle was to meet with recently inaugurated President Alberto Fujimori, who faces an economic crisis that prompted him to say he had ``inherited a disaster.'' Fujimori took office as president of Peru on July 28, succeeding Alan Garcia. The United States has offered Peru $36 million in military equipment and training aid for use in combating drugs, but Garcia never signed off on it. Fujimori has said he probably will, but he also said it won't solve the cocaine problem. He wants support for economic development to give cocaine growers another way to make a living. But Quayle is expected to tell him that without firm Peruvian measures against the drug trade, economic aid will face trouble in Congress. The vice president travels to La Paz, Bolivia, on Wednesday, where he is expected to call for ratification of an extradition agreement under which drug-trafficking suspects could face U.S. trials. Extraditions played a major role in Barco's Colombian drug war. Paz Zamora met with President Bush in Washington on May 8. They signed a new trade and investment agreement and a $60 million, three-year food aid program. Gaviria saw Bush on July 13, repeating a point all the Andean leaders stress: cutting the cocaine traffic is going to require cutting consumption of illegal narcotics in the United States. They also want trade and assistance for their troubled economies. At the drug summit in Cartagena, Bush and the three South American leaders agreed that substituting legal crops for coca would have ``significant, immediate and long-term economic costs'' for the nations involved. Bush since has proposed measures he said would begin creating a Western Hemisphere common market, with free trade in North and South America. He called for a new inter-American investment fund and steps to ease the Latin debt burden in exchange for economic, investment and environmental reforms. But the United States also has spurned a Colombian request for preferential treatment under an existing trade agreement. Colombia is irked at the U.S. tariff on cut flowers, boosted in May, and at its losses since the collapse of a world coffee pricing agreement after the United States withdrew from the pact last summer. Bush had planned to visit five Latin American nations Sept. 16 to 22, but has put that off indefinitely because of budget negotiations and other problems at home. Quayle is to return to Washington late Thursday after a stop in Haiti, where he'll meet with military and civilian leaders of an interim government to urge support for elections scheduled on Nov. 4.

DOC.HEAD: Caretaker Government Backed By Military Takes Power
With PM-Pakistan-Bhutto, Bjt
LaserPhotos ISL1
DOC.TEXT: An army-backed caretaker government with sweeping emergency powers consolidated control today after Benezir Bhutto's administration was dismissed in what one diplomat called ``a constitutional coup.'' Exercising his constitutional power, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan abruptly dismissed Prime Minister Bhutto's government Monday and dissolved the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament. ``Corruption and nepotism in the federal government has reached such proportions'' that the people have lost faith in the government, the president said in a statement. Ishaq Khan set new elections for Oct. 24 and declared a state of emergency, saying national security was ``threatened by external aggression and by internal disturbances.'' The president did not elaborate, but his statement likely referred to border tensions with neighboring India and ethnic violence in Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sindh that has left hundreds dead. Opposition leader Mustafa Jatoi was sworn in as acting prime minister Monday. Most of those attending the ceremony were members of the military high command. Sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Pakistani army strongly supported Ishaq Khan's move. They said the army has become increasingly impatient with Ms. Bhutto's unwillingness to find a political solution to the ethnic violence and her perceived meddling in military affairs. Army Chief of Staff Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, said the military, which has ruled the country for 25 years of its 43-year history, had no intention of seizing power. ``We are not going to get involved in politics,'' Beg said. Ms. Bhutto, 37, said in a statement before leaving for her home in the southern port city of Karachi that the president's action was ``arbitrary, illegal and unconstitional.'' But she said she did not believe the president had betrayed her. ``Other forces wanted me out,'' a subdued Ms. Bhutto told a news conference. The president's decision caught members of Ms. Bhutto's government by surprise, but opponents said the president starting drafting the order two months ago. ``She has nobody to blamed but herself. She had plenty of warnings,'' said Abida Hussein, a former lawmaker and one of Ms. Bhutto's most outspoken critics. ``This was a kind of constitutional coup staged while world attention was focused on the events of Kuwait and Iraq,'' said one diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But something had to be done. If things had continued, the only ultimate solution would have been martial law.'' Shortly after Ishaq Khan dissolved the government, the army took control of the state-run television network and the telephone and telegraph exchange. Soldiers were deployed throughout the capital. Emergency rule, valid for up to four months, allows the president and the caretaker government to suspend individual rights and civilian courts and to make laws. Educated at Harvard and Oxford Ms. Bhutto inherited the political mantle of her father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. He was ousted by Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in a 1977 coup and hanged two years later. Zia himself was killed, in a mysterious plane crash on Aug. 17, 1988. His death led to the first democratic elections after more than a decade of military rule. When Ms. Bhutto, who led her party to victory, took office in December 1988, she pledged to restore democracy and her family name. But many diplomats and political analysts say Ms. Bhutto never made the transition from a fighter of political oppression to prime minister. Her popular support, rated at 54 percent when she took office, was steadily eroded by mounting accusations of corruption against senior Cabinet ministers and members of her family, including her husband, Asif Zardari. None of the allegations was proved, but a poll released last month showed Ms. Bhutto's popularity had tumbled to 34 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Continues as Crews Prepare Barge for Cutting
DOC.TEXT: Cleanup crews hoped to scrape up the last pockets of oil today along a seven-mile stretch of shoreline stained by a massive spill in Galveston Bay. About 700,000 gallons of oil spilled into the busy bay July 28 after a tanker collided with two barges in the Houston Ship Channel. One barge remained crippled in the channel today, blocking traffic. Crews were scouring its emptied tanks so the vessel could be cut up and moved out of the way. ``We don't want to cut it open and have a mini-oil spill added to what we've already got,'' said Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt. Also, a cutting torch could ignite a fire if the tanks are oily, he said. A few heavy patches of oil remained along the shoreline today and a light sheen floated about two miles into the bay. ``They're going to try and get the very last of it,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Scott Campbell. ``They've already released some cleanup crews. They're just isn't that much to do.'' Campbell said cleanup crews might be finished by the end of the day. However, other officials said it probably would take the rest of the week to finish the cleanup, estimated to cost $5 million. The channel was open Monday to two-way barge traffic, but deep-draft ships were allowed only one way at a time because their wakes could disrupt the salvage operations. The heavy, black oil stained several beaches, seeped into some marshes and collected around several residential docks. However, officials said it spared other marshes that are breeding grounds for much marine life. Crews used vacuum trucks again Monday to clean up oil on shore. More than 300,000 gallons of an oil-and-water mixture has been picked up so far, said Meidt. Crews also sprayed oil-gobbling microbes on a marsh south of Cedar Bayou, said Campbell. The microbes were sprayed on another marsh Sunday and a beach last week. The microbes, used in a process call bioremediation, reduce the oil to a fatty emulsion that is eaten by marine animals. Coast Guard officials said they received no reports of injured birds or wildlife. However, Larry McKinney, director of the resource protection division of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, said his crews found some dead crabs, mussels, small fish and other small marine animals along the shores around Houston Point.

DOC.HEAD: Man Claims His Father Helped Assassinate JFK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to add comment from Ricky White's mother, clarify not all investigations concluded that Oswald acted alone, correct 2nd graf pvs that Roscoe White allegedly a police department employee in 1963 but not yet a sworn officer. Picks up 10th graf `However, Gary...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: The CIA and FBI dismissed as ``ludicrous'' and ``not credible'' renewed claims that the CIA had a hand in the assassination of President Kennedy and allegations one gunman is living in secrecy in Texas. Ricky Don White, an unemployed oilfield worker, claimed on Monday that his father, a Dallas police department employee acting on orders from the CIA, fired the shots that killed Kennedy. White's father, Roscoe White, died in 1971. The CIA broke a longstanding policy against commenting on alleged covert operations to deny the story. ``These allegations _ that this was done on CIA orders, that this guy worked for us and that CIA had any role in the assassination of President Kennedy _ are ludicrous,'' CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield said in Washington. The FBI said in a statement that it had received the same information in 1988 but ``determined that this information is not credible.'' The story adds another conspiracy theory to the bulging file on the assassination, even though the Warren Commission concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald, acting alone, shot the president from the sixth floor of the Texas School Book Depository. In 1978, a divided House committee concluded that Oswald shot the president but that a second gunman also fired a shot that day that missed. Theories have circulated for years that the CIA had a part in the assassination. White gave his account at a news conference Monday, although he had been shopping his story to reporters for some time. His claim was backed by his mother, Geneva White Galle, who told The Odessa American ``there is no doubt in my mind that my husband did shoot Kennedy.'' She was married to Roscoe White for 15 years, and remarried after White died. Mrs. Galle, who has terminal cancer, said she wished the information had been revealed sooner and added, ``I lost my health because of it.'' In his news conference, Ricky White did not repeat an earlier contention that one of the three purported co-conspirators lives a reclusive, fearful existence near Dallas. However, Gary Shaw, who helped organize Monday's event, said the co-conspirator was not mentioned ``because we want to approach this in a way not to make them run.'' At the news conference, White said he hoped his story would result in a book and movie contract. White said much of his theory is based on information he said was in a diary kept by his father, who served in the Marines with Oswald. White said the diary _ which he showed to no one _ is missing, and suggested it was taken by the FBI. White, who lives in Midland, said his father joined the Police Department three months before the assassination in 1963 to carry out the plot. White claimed the diary shows his father was on a grassy knoll in front of the presidential motorcade and fired two shots that struck Kennedy. Oswald was part of the conspiracy but fired no shots, White said. White said his father also killed police Officer J.D. Tippit about an hour after the assassination. Tippit's slaying has been blamed on Oswald. White died at age 35 in what his son called a suspicious fire and explosion at an equipment company in suburban Garland, where he was shop foreman. White said he believes a CIA ``witness elimination'' squad killed his father. Ricky White made his claims at the JFK Assassination Information Center, a private group that researches assassination theories.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney For Woman Cited In Archbishop's Resignation Says She Was Manipulated
DOC.TEXT: The woman whose relationships with Archbishop Eugene Marino and a priest led to their resignations was seduced by the bishop but never had sex with the priest, her attorney said. The woman, Vicki R. Long, 27, of Riverdale, has accused a third priest of fathering her child. Louisiana attorney Anthony Fontana said Monday that some people might consider Ms. Long a seductress, but ``once the facts come out, the public will know ... grown women can suffer sexual abuse even in a relationship not termed to be perverse. One person can make demands and manipulate the other to satisfy those demands.'' Fontana, known for arguing sexual abuse cases against the Roman Catholic Church, said Marino manipulated his client into a sexual relationship to which she did not consent. ``She went to see Archbishop Marino for counseling and pastoral help'' in dealing with sexual abuse, Fontana said. ``He took advantage of that situation, manipulating that situation.'' Archdiocese spokesman Peter Dora said he does not believe Marino would ``take advantage of anyone,'' but declined to comment further. Fontana said Ms. Long ``categorically denies'' she had a sexual relationship with the Rev. Michael Woods, a Sandy Springs priest who resigned Saturday after admitting he had an ``intimate'' relationship with her. Woods, who said he was the godfather of Ms. Long's 4-year-old daughter, previously was Ms. Long's pastor at a Hapeville church. ``She doesn't deny (the relationship) was intimate but she categorically denies it was sexual,'' said Fontana. Ms. Long may file a lawsuit against the church, he said. Archdiocese officials confirmed last week that Marino, 56, formerly the nation's highest-ranking black Catholic, resigned earlier this year because of an ``intimate relationship'' with Ms. Long that involved paying her $1,500 a month. The archdiocese said it would investigate whether church funds were paid improperly to Ms. Long. Fontana said Monday that his client was certain church funds were used. Marino has not commented publicly on his relationship with Ms. Long. Ms. Long also has refused to comment. Several years ago, she filed a paternity suit claiming that another priest, Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus, Ga., fathered her daughter. He denied paternity, and blood tests supported him, but the archdiocese is paying her child support. Church officials decline to explain why. In December 1987, Fontana represented an altar boy who sued the church claiming the Rev. Gilbert Gauthe of Lafayette, La., molested him. A jury awarded the boy $1.55 million and his parents $250,000. Gauthe is serving a 20-year sentence on the molestation charges.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Appears Ready to Cut Iraqi Pipeline as Pressure Increases on Saddam
LaserPhotos NY13,8
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Cheney in Egypt, latest oil prices, CORRECTS attribution from Turkish government on pipeline. No pickup. ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: The economic pressure increased on an increasingly isolated Saddam Hussein today as Turkey agreed to comply with U.N. sanctions against Iraq, which likely would involve closing a pipeline carrying Iraqi oil through its territory. A worldwide trade embargo already forced Iraq to stop the flow through one of its two Turkish pipelines and sharply reduce it in the other. Oil executives said today Iraq's use of a Saudi Arabian pipeline also had been drastically cut, because there was no one to buy the oil once it reached the other end. If successful, the U.N.-ordered embargo could cripple Iraq's oil-dependent economy. In other developments today: _Jordan appeared ready to provide an overland escape route for foreigners caught in Kuwait, which Iraqi troops have occupied since Thursday. _Travelers said Saudi Arabia deployed missiles along its border with Kuwait facing the Iraqi military buildup. _Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived in Egypt for talks with President Hosni Mubarak on the crisis. Mubarak has been trying to mediate the dispute. _The Tokyo Stock Exchange followed its New York counterpart today, plunging 3.32 percent on fears of economic fallout from the Persian Gulf crisis. Oil prices rose, with Brent North Sea crude oil trading at $27.75 per barrel, up $1.40 from its close Monday in New York. The Turkish government announced today it would comply with a U.N. Security Council vote Monday ordering broad economic sanctions against Iraq to pressure it to withdraw from Kuwait. When asked if Turkey would close a pipeline pumping hundreds of thousands of barrels of Iraqi crude oil through his country, State Minister Mehmet Yazar said: ``These details of implementing the U.N. decision are being worked out.'' But a senior official speaking on condition of anonymity said Turkey intended to shut down the pipeline, which carries Iraqi oil to a terminal on the Mediterranean for export. On Monday, Turkish officials said Iraq informed them it had slashed the pipeline's capacity to 70 percent and closed its second Turkish pipeline because of the reduced market for Iraqi oil. Oil executives in Saudi Arabia said today Iraq also significantly reduced the flow of petroleum through a pipeline across Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea. One executive, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the flow through the Saudi pipeline, which had been about 800,000 barrels a day, was down to 200,000 barrels. Others said they thought the flow was somewhat higher. The Saudi and Turkish pipelines carry more than two-thirds of Iraq's daily oil output of about 3 million barrels. Iraq also pumps oil through the Persian Gulf. The Washington Post reported today that Saddam summoned U.S. charge d'affaires Joseph Wilson in Baghdad on Monday and threatened to attack Saudi Arabia if Iraqi pipelines through that country were closed. Oil is at the root of the crisis. Iraq invaded Kuwait after accusing it of cheating on OPEC production quotas and driving down the price of oil. It also alleged that Kuwait stole $2.4 billion worth of oil from a field that includes land both sides claim. Kuwait and Iraqi officials met Aug. 1 in an attempt to resolve their differences, but the talks broke down. Iraq invaded Kuwait the next day, drove out the ruling family, and installed a government. The Iraqi forces also moved within a few miles of the Saudi border, raising fears they would try to occupy the kingdom, which is the world's No. 1 oil producer. Travelers in the region said today Saudi Arabia had deployed missiles along the Kuwaiti border. The civilian travelers said they saw large numbers of what they described as Saudi ``guided missiles.'' On the other side of the border, they reported a large number of Iraqi tanks. The publisher of a Lebanese newspaper, Talal Salman of the leftist As-Safir in Beirut, said in a front-page article today that the Iraqis ``have installed missiles to strike at Saudi Arabia's oil wells'' in the event of an attack from Saudi Arabia. In Jordan, Iraqi, U.S. and Jordanian officials said Iraq was considering allowing foreigners, including U.S. Embassy staff and dependents, to leave Iraq and Kuwait by land through Jordan. A senior Jordanian official said: ``Any foreigner who wishes to depart Iraq or Kuwait through Jordan is more than welcomed.'' A Kuwaiti businessman who escaped the occupied sheikdom said conditions were getting worse there and that people were fleeing across the desert to Saudi Arabia at a rate of about 1,000 a day. ``Some Iraqi troops are looting private houses and shops. They particularly seem to want gold and jewelry,'' said the man, who arrived in London toay. He refused to give his name for fear of reprisals to his family. When he left Monday, the businessman said, the Iraqis were building up heavy armaments about three miles from the Saudi border and seemed to show no signs of withdrawing. Pressure grew worldwide for a naval blockade of Iraq if the U.N. sanctions did not prove effective. The Washington Post said the Pentagon proposed an international blockade of the Persian Gulf that would include forces from the Soviet Union. The French naval destroyer Dupleix sailed into the Suez Canal early today on its way to the Persian Gulf to join two other warships. The Dupleix is capable of carrying helicopters and missiles, including the sophisticated Exocet missile. The U.S. already has two aircraft carriers, the Independence and the Eisenhower, at the mouth of the Persian Gulf and dispatched two more from the eastern United States. They would bolster the U.S. presence in the gulf itself, which amounts to eight warships. In Ankara, a U.S. Embassy official said 14 F-111 bombers from a U.S. base in England have been flown to Incirlik, Turkey, 425 miles from the Iraqi border in what he called a routine regularly scheduled transfer. Saudi military aircraft were sighted landing and taking off at airfields on the fringes of Riyadh, the Saudi capital, said local residents reached by telephone. Journalists in helicopters reported sighting a Soviet destroyer nearing the Straits of Hormuz, the entrance to the gulf from the Arabian Sea. Shipping sources, who declined identification, said no Soviet warship had been in the Persian Gulf for two months. The Iraqi-installed provisional government of Kuwait announced that it had decided to consider its currency, the dinar, the equivalent of the Iraqi dinar. The action has no practical impact because the Kuwait dinar is frozen on currency exchanges. Also today, the Beirut bureau of the Kuwait News Agency reported the ``Kuwaiti Resistance'' released a communique announcing three attacks against the Iraqi invasion army, killing or wounding 11 Iraqis. The report did not disclose the times of the attacks. It could not be independently confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli-Allied Militia Kills Two Palestinian Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-affiliated militiamen killed two Palestinian guerrillas in an ambush on the northern edge of an Israeli-controlled zone in south Lebanon, police said today. A police spokesman said two guerrillas of the Libyan-backed Palestine Popular Struggle Front were killed Monday while trying to cross into Israel's self-proclaimed security zone. The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia spotted the guerrillas as they were trying to infiltrate into the security zone east of Sidon, the southern provincial capital. The police spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the guerrillas were killed in a brief firefight with the militia. Later Monday, guerrillas fired seven surface-to-surface Katyusha rockets into Marjayoun, a town in the security zone where the militia is headquartered. The militia-run Voice of the South radio said the rockets exploded in empty fields near the town, causing no casualties. Israel established the 440-square-mile security zone when it withdrew the bulk of its army from southern Lebanon in 1985, ending a three-year occupation of Lebanon. The zone serves as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla infiltration into northern Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Threatens to Attack U.S. Marines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 12th graf, ``West African...' to show that 400,000 refugees fled Liberia. SUBS 3 grafs bgng with 16th graf, ``Taylor is...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Taylor considering accepting foreign intervention. Pickup pvs 19th graf, `Refugees behind...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, among them Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Rebel leader Prince Johnson, who holds several foreign hostages, says he will attack American Marines at the U.S. Embassy if the U.S. or other foreign troops do not intervene to end Liberia's civil war. Some of the 235 Marines airlifted into Monrovia to evacuate Americans and other foreign nationals on Monday took up defensive positions within the walled U.S. Embassy compound. Johnson presented eight foreign hostages to reporters and said he would not free them until a peacekeeping force comes to this West African nation torn by a 7-month-old tribal conflict in which 5,000 people have died. Johnson, who killed a relief worker Friday who he said was selling rice to Monrovia's starving citizens, said he had killed one Liberian congressman for spying and would kill another. The hostages, kidnapped Monday night from Hotel Africa, on the northwestern outskirts of Monrovia, include an American, an Argentine, three Britons, two West Germans and a Dutchman. The U.S. State Department said Johnson was holding 14 or 15 hostages. The British Foreign Office said there were 16, including four Britons. There was no explanation for the discrepancy in the number of people kidnapped. On Saturday, Johnson warned that his fighters, who hold most of Monrovia, would start detaining foreigners to provoke international intervention in Liberia. ``What this country really needs is the peaceful intervention of the United States or'' the Economic Community of West African States, Johnson told rebel fighters outside his headquarters on Monrovia's Bushrod Island. ``If they don't intervene I will attack the American Marines.'' Washington has said the Marines' only role in the conflict is to evacuate endangered nationals, and protect U.S. installations and a skeletal staff remaining at the U.S. Embassy. The U.S. mission in Liberia included staff and families numbering more than 500 before rebels invaded Dec. 24 from Liberia's northeastern border with Ivory Coast and advanced to the Atlantic Ocean capital. West African leaders decided Monday to send troops into Liberia, saying the war is affecting the entire region, which is supporting nearly 400,000 refugees from the nation of 2.3 million people. Sources at the summit said a naval task force to include ships from Nigeria, Ghana, Sierra Leone and Guinea will go to Monrovia and troops will be sent across Liberia's land borders with Sierra Leone and Guinea. Not represented at the conference was Liberia's third neighbor, Ivory Coast, which has supported rebel leader Charles Taylor. Johnson, a former captain in President Samuel Doe's army, was one of Taylor's chief commanders before he set up a splinter rebel faction in February. Taylor has said he opposed any foreign intervention and has said he will attack any foreign peace enforcers. But today, Taylor's National Patriotic Front said it might accept such a force. The Front's Defense Minister Tom Woewiyu flew to Bangul, Gambia, to meet with representatives of the West African nations that are considering sending in troops. Woewiyu appeared to indicate that as long as the force remained neutral it would be welcome. Refugees behind Taylor's rebel lines at the U.S. Omega ship-tracking station near Paynesville gave a letter to The Associated Press appealing to the United States or any other government to help end the war. ``We are beseeching you to make the international world come to our aid. We are being slaughtered like pigs by our government, the freedom fighters and anyone who feels we should not live,'' the letter said. Johnson said his men executed Liberian Sen. Fred J. Blay on Sunday night. The rebel leader claimed Blay, a former minister for youth and sports, had been sent by Doe to spy on his headquarters. He said Blay was shot dead by a firing squad. Then he presented to journalists Congressman William Jabrah and said he, too, would be executed for spying. The legislator was led away with his hands bound. The foreign hostages presented at the news conference identified themselves as: Terry Good, 67, a British mining engineer from Essex; Seymour Grann, 32, a British businessman; Paul Temple, 36, a British timber merchant; Dieter Riech, 53, a West German; Klaus Moffer, 58, West German managing director of a soap factory; Chris Mendes, 27, an American mining contractor from Sacramento, Calif.; Abraham Lokker, 57, a Dutch mining engineer; Enrique Mansilla, 32, an Argentine mining engineer.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages Poland's Holiest Catholic Shrine
DOC.TEXT: A fire burned through the night at Poland's holiest shrine, the Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa, and two monks were injured while saving centuries-old volumes from the library. The jewel-robed Black Madonna, the burnished icon to which millions of pilgrims pay homage each Aug. 15, was not damaged, said Sister Daria at the Roman Catholic curia in Czestochowa. The monks suffered smoke inhalation while rushing through the burning building to save books, including some illuminated manuscripts dating to the 15th century, from the library built in 1739. Polish radio said they were in stable condition. The fire started at 10:35 p.m. Monday and was extinguished at 8:30 this morning, said Father Simon Stefanowicz at the monastery. Radio said it appeared to have been caused by a short circuit. Stefanowicz said there was no significant damage to the many historical objects housed at Jasna Gora, which was founded in 1382 by the hermetic Paulite order from Hungary. However, firefighters had to break through the copper roof of the building where the fire broke out. In addition to the library and the archives, the building houses a small hotel for visiting priests and the editorial offices of a monthly monastery bulletin. The damaged building is adjacent to the chapel in which the icon is housed. More than 15,000 pilgrims left Warsaw on Monday to begin the nine-day walk to Czestochowa for Assumption Day on Aug. 15, a tradition that has been maintained every year since 1711. En route to the monastery, 175 miles southeast of Warsaw, the pilgrims will be joined by faithful from parishes nationwide, camping in fields and churches. Up to 170,000 pilgrims make the trip on foot, many covering the final miles on their knees. In all, a half-million worshippers are expected to fill the field at the monastery. Jasna Gora, or Bright Mountain, rests on a brick fortification and houses an extensive collection of Polish historical objects, from the weapons of kings to tear-gas grenades lobbed at Solidarity protesters. It provided sanctuary for the Solidarity movement through its decade-long fight against Poland's Communist government. The Black Madonna was brought to the monastery in 1384 by Duke Ladislaus of Opole, adviser to Louis of Anjou, King of Poland and Hungary. Many miracles have been attributed to the doleful painting, including a 1655 siege in which 70 monks and 180 supporters held off nearly 4,000 soldiers from the Protestant Swedish army and inspired the country to rise up and throw out the invaders.

DOC.HEAD: Former De Gaulle Minister Jacques Soustelle Dies at 78
DOC.TEXT: Jacques Soustelle, a former Cabinet minister who clashed with Gen. Charles de Gaulle over the Algerian conflict, died today in the suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine, the Academie Francaise announced. He was 78. A distinguished anthropologist noted for his study of pre-Colombian culture, Soustelle was named to the prestigious Academie in 1983. The organization's terse statement announcing his death did not give a cause of death or list survivors. Born in Montpellier, Soustelle studied letters at the Ecole Normale Superieure and married Georgette Fagot in 1931. They made several scientific missions to Central America during the 1930s. Strongly opposed to fascism, Soustelle was among the first to rally to de Gaulle's appeal on June 18, 1940 from London to fight the Vichy government that collaborated with Nazi Germany. After the liberation of France in 1944, Soustelle worked as minister of information and later minister of colonies. He served as governor of Algeria in 1955-56 during the outbreak of the war for independence. De Gaulle returned to power in 1958 as the Algerian war threatened to tear France apart. Soustelle again became minister of information and later a deputy foreign minister. The two men had a falling out when de Gaulle made clear his intention to grant independence to the North African country. Soustelle resigned, saying he could not ``make a deal with cutthroats.'' Soustelle left France in 1961 and was charged Sept. 22, 1962 with ``attempts against the state.'' The same year, renegade army officers tried to assassinate de Gaulle for giving Algeria independence. Soustelle lived in exile until 1968, when he returned to France under a general amnesty and resumed his academic and political career. The Academie made him a member June 2, 1983 for his studies of ancient American culture, outlined in such books as ``Life of the Aztecs'' and ``The Maya Civilization.'' Funeral arrangements were not announced.

DOC.HEAD: 20,000 Briefly Arrested Protesting Price Rises
DOC.TEXT: More than 20,000 demonstrators protesting rises in food prices were briefly detained today after they scuffled with police outside Parliament, police said. The marchers were organized by the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Police said they had orders to stop the asssmbly of more than five people around the red sandstone parliament building. ``We have strict orders not to allow any demonstration to reach the Parliament,'' said a police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We had to stop the Congressmen.'' He was referring to the members of the Congress Party. Policemen and commandos armed with machine pistols and automatic rifles guarded the parliament complex as members inside began a debate on inflation. But outside the Gandhi supporters shouted slogans calling for the resignation of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. A senior police officer then took a microphone and announced that the 20,000 demonstrators were under arrest. Some of the protesters then scuffled with policemen. The 20,000 demonstrators were briefly detained and released. Since Singh came to power last November prices of vegetables doubled and gasoline rose 25 percent. Overall inflation is about 10 percent. Singh's National Front coalition came to power last year after the Congress Party failed to win enough seats in the November 1989 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Former Atlanta Mayor, Lieutenant Governor Face Off in Runoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with early turnout in Georgia called low, move up percentages received in first vote. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `We've been...'. SUBS 11th graf, `Miller received...', to delete now-redundant material.
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young took his underdog bid to become Georgia's first black governor to the voters today in a runoff for the Democratic nomination against Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. Kansas and Michigan also were holding primaries for governor. Max Cleland, Georgia's secretary of state, predicted just 38 percent of the state's 2.7 million registered voters would cast ballots, and early turnout was slow in some areas. ``We had a flowing river three weeks ago and today we had a trickle,'' said Liz Thompson, poll manager at the Jewish Community Center in Atlanta. Forty-four percent of eligible voters turned out for the July 17 primary, in which Miller got 41 percent of the vote and Young received 29 percent. Young, a former Atlanta mayor and ambassador to the United Nations, and Miller spent Monday traveling around the state and thanking black supporters on the 25th anniversary of President Lyndon B. Johnson's signing of the Voting Rights Act. ``We've been tracking Zell Miller all day like a hound dog after a scared rabbit and we're going to catch him,'' Young said after arriving in Augusta and Savannah as Miller left. Young trailed by about 20 points in two polls last week. Miller said he was optimistic. Repeating a favorite campaign phrase, he quoted an inscription on a mountain tombstone: ``I done my durndest.'' Race had rarely been mentioned during their three-week campaign after the two survived a five-man contest in the primary. Georgia requires a runoff if no candidate receives more than half the vote, but the requirement was under challenge as discriminatory against blacks, who make up about 28 percent of Georgia's voters. On Monday, Young referred to his days in the civil rights movement and spoke of his accomplishments on behalf of blacks. He took a jab at Miller's pet issue, establishment of a state lottery. ``I don't believe anybody marched, I don't believe anybody went to jail _ or died, for certain _ for a lottery,'' Young said. Miller appeared before about 50 members of the Political Advisory Council of Chatham County, a black group that endorsed him over Young. Miller said the group helped him when he won his first race for lieutenant governor. ``Now, 16 years later, when it's so difficult to do what you're doing, you're reaching out to me again,'' Miller said. The winner of the primary will meet Republican state Rep. Johnny Isakson in the November election. Two-term Gov. Joe Frank Harris, a Democrat, is not eligible to seek re-election. In Kansas, Republican Gov. Mike Hayden braced in his bid for a second, four-year term for a strong primary challenge from real estate agent Nestor Weigand of Wichita. Democratic former Gov. John Carlin was favored to win the Democratic nod to seek his old job. In Michigan, state Senate Majority Leader John Engler was expected to win easily over General Motors Corp. engineer John Lauve in the GOP primary for governor. Engler has focused on Democratic Gov. James Blanchard and his own 20 years' experience in the Legislature. Blanchard, seeking a third, four-year term, has no primary opponent. In Missouri, U.S. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt was expected to win easily the Democratic primary for re-election in his St. Louis district. His challenger is Nicholas F. Clement, a supporter of right-wing extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Three Republicans were up for their party's nomination in the district.

DOC.HEAD: Rockets Kill 14, Injure 10
DOC.TEXT: More than a dozen rockets slammed into Afghanistan's capital of Kabul today, killing 14 people and injuring 10, Afghan state radio reported. No one immediately claimed repsonsibility for the attack. But the Radio Kabul broadcast, monitored in Islamabad, blamed ``extremists,'' presumably referring to U.S.-backed guerrillas headquartered in Pakistan. Moslem insurgents have been fighting for more than a decade to topple Afghanistan's Communist-style government. In the past year, hundreds of people have died and thousands more injured in rocket assaults on the Afghan capital.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Declares Wisconsin's School Choice Program Constitutional
DOC.TEXT: A program that would let poor Milwaukee children attend private schools at state expense has been declared constitutional by a state judge, apparently clearing the way for it to begin this fall. Dane County Circuit Court Judge Susan Steingass ruled Monday that the state's school choice program was legal because it served to improve education quality and thus met the ``public purpose'' requirement of the Wisconsin Constitution. ``I conclude that education is a public purpose and that the program is the Legislature's reasonable assessment of how to improve the quality of education to the benefit of the entire state,'' Ms. Steingass wrote. In addition, the judge ruled that State School Superintendent Herbert Grover, who must administer the program but has publicly opposed it, exceeded his authority in demanding certain requirements of participating private schools, including complex forms that are difficult to fill out. She ordered Grover to redraft his the forms or face further court action. Grover did not immediately return a telephone message left at his home Monday night seeking comment on the decision. The school choice program, approved by the Legislature and signed by Gov. Tommy Thompson last spring, provides up to $2,500 in state funds per pupil to let poor, inner-city Milwaukee schoolchildren attend private schools. The state budget includes $2.5 million for the program this year, meaning that the program could accommodate 1,000 students. It is believed to be the first of its kind in the country and has drawn praise from the Bush administration. ``Judge Susan Steingass made the right decision _ one in favor of our children,'' Thompson said Monday. Critics of the program, including Grover and two teachers' unions, claim the plan undermines public education and places pupils in private schools that are not fully accountable to the state. Supporters of the program said it provides poor parents with another choice to improve their children's education and does not force participation. Clint Bolick, an attorney for the Washington-based Landmark Legal Center Foundation for Civil Rights, said the judge's decision ``was a slam-dunk for parental choice in education.'' ``It will stand up very well under any appeal,'' Bolick said, adding that he doubted whether opponents would have enough time to attempt to legally block the program before it begins in the next few weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Called Chaotic, Unemployment Jumps
With Germany-Unification
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment in East Germany almost doubled between June and July, official figures released today said. The West German official overseeing East Germany's businesses said the economy is in chaos. Reiner Gohlke's remarks, published today in an East German newspaper, are some of the most ominous to date concerning the country's rapidly deteriorating economic situation. They coincided with the release of the latest official unemployment figures showing the number of East German jobless jumped to 272,017 last month, up from 142,096 in June. More than 656,000 of the nation's 8.8 million workers are working short shifts because of the lack of demand for East German products. Also today, top-level meetings got under way in both Germanys to try to work out the precise date of German unity and the best means of stemming East Germany's escalating economic and social problems. The Social Democrats _ second-largest party in both Germanys _ have demanded unity by Sept. 15. But the Christian Democrats of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere insist unity must wait for all-German elections that should be held Oct. 14. Since the West German mark became the East German currency on July 1, the country's 8,000 major businesses have faced increasing difficulties staying afloat. ``The next six months will be the hardest,'' the newspaper Neue Zeit quoted Gohlke as saying. Gohlke is President of the Trust Institute of the German Democratic Republic. The institute was established to oversee the East German economy's change from a state-run economy to a capitalist system. There have been predictions that up to 4 million East Germans could be out of work by early next year as businesses close. That, in turn, has led to predictions of a ``hot autumn'' of worker unrest in the former Communist nation. ``The situation is worse than I had thought,'' Neue Zeit quoted Gohlke as saying. ``We have chaos. Nothing is running normally.'' The Neue Zeit newspaper is closely linked to East Germany's Christian Democrats. Economists expect an economy recovery in East Germany late in 1991, after unproductive, state-run businesses either reform or close. In addition, West German companies are rushing into East Germany to set up production, and will be drawing East German workers.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MIAMI
Hurricane Diana Heads For Mexican Coast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with warnings issued along Mexican coast, people fleeing low-lying areas. Pickup 9th pvs, `The main...
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Diana became Hurricane Diana early today after picking up strength in the Gulf of Mexico, and warnings went up along a 400-mile stretch of Mexico's gulf coast. Hundreds of people fled low-lying areas, fearing Diana's heavy rains and winds up to 80 mph. One man was killed when winds blew over a tree Monday night, said Rosalio Romero Hernandez, a spokesman for the Red Cross in Veracruz. The threatened area included the cities of Veracruz, Tuxpan and Tampico. Ports were closed. Small craft were warned to remain in port from Baffin Bay, Texas, southward. At 9 a.m. EDT, Diana was centered about 110 miles east-southeast of Tuxpan on the central coast, near 20.5 degreees north latitude and 95.8 degrees west longitude. It was moving west at 12 mph, and Mexican weather officials said it would first hit land in the area of Tuxpan. In Tuxpan, Red Cross spokeswoman Matilde Alvino said there were heavy winds and rains and a few reports of early flooding. Area rivers were on the rise, she said. The captain of the port of Tuxpan, Miguelangel Rebolledo, said the Mexican navy installation there was sheltering about 300 people who had fled low-lying areas. Diana is the second storm of the Atlantic season to reach hurricane strength. Rainfall of 10 inches or more was expected along its path, said Max Mayfield, a specialist at the National Hurricane Center near Miami. Tides were expected to be four to six feet above normal, he said. ``The main threat to life will be the rising waters on the coast and the heavy rains producing flash floods and possibly mud slides inland,'' said Mayfield. Diana soaked Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Monday but did little damage as a tropical storm. Meanwhile, tropical storm Cesar weakened to a tropical depression in the mid-Atlantic on Monday. Cesar was 1,150 miles east-southeast of Bermuda with top sustained winds of nearly 35 mph. Little movement was expected today. The hurricane center also reported a new depression formed Monday about 175 miles southwest of the westernmost Azores island in the mid-Atlantic. Tropical depressions become named storms once sustained winds reach 39 mph. A storm becomes a hurricane when winds hit 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Florida-based Carrier Heading for Mediterranean
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier Saratoga and four escort ships steamed out of their home port en route for the Mediterranean and possible Mideast duty today, and 2,500 Marines boarded ships bound for the coast of war-torn Liberia. The mood aboard the Saratoga was ``professional and work-oriented but concerned,'' said Chief Petty Officer Charles Underwood, a spokesman for the Mayport Naval Station at Jacksonville, Fla. ``I think this force is probably going over toward that area and if something happens, these boys can handle it,'' said Wade Andrews of Sebring, Fla., whose son Randell was aboard the Saratoga. There was an air of subdued concern as parents, friends and wives carrying babies wept, blew kisses and waved and yelled goodbyes at dockside as the Saratoga pulled away. It was preceded by the destroyers Spruance and Sampson, the frigate Elmer Montgomery and the guided missile cruiser Philippine Sea. Both deployments had been scheduled before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the Marine mission to rescue Americans from Liberia. The departing Marines, in fact, were scheduled to relieve the Marine unit involved in the Liberian rescue. Marine Col. W.C. Fite III, commander of the 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit leaving Camp Lejeune at Morehead City, N.C., said he hadn't gotten orders yet. ``We haven't been told about our future plans,'' Fite said at a brief news conference as troops boarded ships. ``As far as we know, this is a routine deployment. We have plans to go to Spain, which is routine, and also plans if needed to go to the coast of Monrovia, Liberia.'' The Saratoga could be sent to the eastern Mediterranean and be within striking distance of Iraq, but the use of carrier-based planes from there would be complicated by having to fly through the air space of one or more other countries and probably in-flight refueling. The Saratoga is no stranger to crises in the Middle East. During an eight-month deployment that ended in April 1986, the carrier participated in the capture of terrorists who hijacked the liner Achille Lauro and retaliatory air strikes against Libyan surface-to-air missile sites and armed Libyan patrol boats in the Gulf of Sidra. The ship also patroled the eastern Mediterranean during the Six-Day War between Israel and Egypt in June 1967. At Morehead City, groups of Marines sat on the dock waiting to board ships. ``If we have to do something, we're prepared to do it,'' said Cpl. David Ellis, 22, of Chicago. ``There's no sense worrying about something you don't have any control over.'' ``In events like these that are taking place in Iraq and Libya, we're obviously the nation's force of choice when it comes to initial response,'' Capt. Scott Campbell said earlier. ``Everyone has an idea where we're going,'' said 1st Lt. Chris Maxmin. ``Everyone is apprehensive and excited at the same time. I think you're stupid if you're not.''

DOC.HEAD: Classic Crayon Colors Deemed Ho-Hum Retire to Crayola Hall of Fame
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with ceremony, protests, explain difference between `cerulean' and `sky blue' crayons. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Thousands who...'
DOC.TEXT: A handful of protesters took ``umber-age,'' but it's out with the old and in with the new inside 64-color boxes of Crayola Crayons, the flip-top package that was the first status symbol for Baby Boomers. Crayola maker Binney & Smith created eight brighter colors and given them names like jungle green, wild strawberry and vivid tangerine. To make room, the company decided to ax eight classic but ho-hum colors so that the traditional sharpener-equipped boxes could be preserved, said spokesman Brad Drexler. A ceremony this morning inducting the ``retired'' colors into the newly established ``Crayola Hall of Fame'' was picketed by about a dozen people who said they would miss maize, raw umber, lemon yellow, blue gray, violet blue, green blue, orange red and orange yellow. ``Binney & Smith, America takes umber-age,'' said one sign. ``Indians call it maize, we call it gone,'' said another. The 5-foot-10 models of the retired colors stand in plastic tubes in front of Crayola's production center. Each has a plaque extolling the color's virtues. ``We'll all miss these retired colors. That's why we started the Hall of Fame, so people can come by and see them whenever they want to,'' said Tom Muller, general manager of Binney & Smith's Crayola division. Joining the list of new colors aimed at a fresh generation of children are dandelion, fuchsia, teal blue, royal purple and cerulean, a darker version of Crayola's sky blue. Thousands who grew up with the old colors and some youngsters using them now called or wrote Binney & Smith to complain, but the change was prompted by child surveys in the first place, so the company went forward with the plan. For members of the Baby Boom generation, the flip-top crayon box with all the colors and the built-in sharpener was a childhood status symbol akin to today's designer sneakers and Nintendo video game sets. ``It was always the haves versus the have-nots,'' Drexler said. ``I never had a 64 until I worked here. Now I have two.'' He said the 64-color box was nearly eliminated, but Binney & Smith feared a backlash. ``The first idea was to make the 64-box a 72-box, but then we thought of the Coke scenario and believed we'd be messing with a classic,'' Drexler said. Complaints came anyway, especially regarding a well-known color with a little-known name _ raw umber. It's the golden-brown crayon many children favor for adding detail to tree trunks. Ebony Faison, a 10-year-old from Philadelphia, loves raw umber for a more personal reason. ``Raw umber is the color of me,'' she wrote. ``What color should I color now?''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Interest Increases Threaten Home Sales
DOC.TEXT: Sluggish home sales that had picked up lately as mortgage rates fell are under a new threat from rising interest rates resulting from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, analysts said Tuesday. ``The single factor that affects housing nationally is mortgage financing,'' said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist with the National Association of Realtors. Tuccillo and other economists said Tuesday that a worldwide embargo on oil from Iraq and occupied Kuwait will result in price increases for most goods, including a likely rise in mortgage rates of .25 to .50 percentage points in the near term. ``If they go up .50 now and the thing is resolved in a few weeks, they will go down .50 and will continue going down,'' Tuccillo contended. ``If the crisis lingers on ... mortgage rates are going to go up and they'll stay up and housing's going to be in pretty bad shape.'' Robert Van Order, chief economist with the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, said a .25 percentage point increase in rates would result in an additional mortgage payment of $25 a month on a $100,000 house. According to weekly surveys by Freddie Mac, the average cost fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage fell from its 1990 peak of 10.67 percent in May to 9.84 percent last Friday. The rates do not include add-on fees known as oints. Realtors President Norman D. Flynn said that when mortgage rates began falling in May, buyers resumed house hunting, particularly in areas with relatively affordable prices. As a result, the Commerce Department reported gains in new home sales during May and June after five consecutive monthly declines. And the Realtors said sales of existing homes, which represent about 80 percent of the housing market, posted a 1.2 percent increase in June. It was their first advance in seven months. But the decline in existing home sales in April and May resulted in a 0.5 percent drop in overall resales during the second quarter compared to the same period of 1989, the Realtors said Tuesday. According to their most recent survey, second-quarter resales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.68 million units, compared to 3.70 million units during the April-June period of last year. Sales dropped 2.7 percent from the first quarter to the second. By region, sales were off 14.5 percent to 650,000 units at an annual rate in the Northeast and 3.1 percent to 620,000 units in the West. Sales gained 4.4 percent to 1.41 million units in the South and 4.2 percent to 990,000 units in the Midwest. The Realtors said that in addition to rising mortgage rates, they were concerned over the effect of the government's sale of a large volume of properties in the Southwest that had been acquired from failed savings and loans. In their survey, the Realtors found the U.S. median price was $96,200, a 3.4 percent increase over the second quarter of 1990. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. The median price in the West declined 0.8 percent to $138,300, while it rose 5.8 percent in the Midwest to $75,000. It rose 1.5 percent to $86,200 in the South but fell 1.6 percent to $143,500 in the Northeast. By city, the median price of an existing home ranged from $345,000 in Honolulu to $45,100 in Youngstown, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, 12 Injured In Explosion At Chemical Plant
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire at a chemical plant killed one person and seriously burned 12 others, a newspaper reported Tuesday. The explosion and fire Monday at the plant in Zilina, some 100 miles northeast of Bratislava, caused no significant leakage of toxic gas, the daily Prace reported. ``The fire produced black smoke, but the smoke did not contain toxic materials in concentrations which would represent any health hazard,'' Prace quoted Peter Nemcok, director of the plant, as saying. It was unclear what kind of gases were involved.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Found, Defused in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A bomb attached to the underside of a car fell off the vehicle in southwestern Moscow, but police safely defused it, the Tass news agency reported Tuesday. The device apparently fell off the car because magnets failed to hold it in place, according to the report, which did not say when the incident occurred or offer any possible motive for such an attack. Tass also did not say who owned the car. A. Knyazev, a nearby resident, said he saw the bomb fall off the car as the auto drove away, according to Tass. Police then cordoned off the area and defused the bomb. The bomb was ``expertly made'' and could have destroyed the car and damaged buildings over a wide area, Tass said. Authorities began an investigation into the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Turns Back Tankers, Shuts Iraqi Pipeline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, minor editing to TIGHTEN. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Turkey announced today it has stopped tankers from loading Iraqi oil from the last operating pipeline through the country, blocking the route for half of Iraq's oil exports. Turkey also announced it was stopping all exports to Iraq, with the exception of medicine and food. Imports were also being halted. Mehmet Kececiler, Turkish minister in charge of oil affairs, said Iraq could continue to pump crude through the pipeline until the storage tanks at the terminal were full but then must stop pumping. He said it would take about six days to reach capacity in the tanks. Iraq on Monday shut down one pipeline in Turkey and reduced the flow to 70 percent in the other because the international embargo against Iraq had shrunk the market. The embargo protests Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday. The Turkish pipelines carry more than half of Iraq's daily oil output to a terminal at the northeastern tip of the Mediterranean.. Kececiler told reporters that Turkey notified Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organization of its decision to halt loading from the second pipeline this afternoon. He said the U.N. Security Council vote Monday imposing broad economic sanctions against Iraq was binding for all member states. ``That is why we took this decision. We were not pressured by anyone,'' Kececiler said. Only one tanker, from Morocco, came to the terminal today but was turned back, he said. Earlier in the day President Turgut Ozal said that ``there should be no more loading'' by tankers of Iraqi oil at the terminal. The U.N. measure bans all imports from Iraq and Kuwait. It also prohibits any activities, including the transfer of funds, that would help Iraq and Kuwait export their goods and forbids loans to the two countries. Turkey's border post with Iraq at Habur remained opened today, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported. But the dispatch said Iraq was not allowing travelers other than its own citizens to enter the country. The Washington Post reported today that Iraq has threatened to invade Saudi Arabia if its leaders shut down the Iraqi pipeline running through their country. In another sign that the embargo on Iraqi oil was having an effect, oil executives reported today that Iraq had significantly reduced the flow of its oil through a pipeline across Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea. They said no tankers were loading oil at the Red Sea terminals. Iraq's daily output is about 3 million barrels, about half of which has been flowing through Turkey and smaller amount through Saudi Arabia. A very small amount goes through the Persian Gulf. The White House announced Monday that Secretary of State James A. Baker III would travel to Turkey this week for consultations on the crisis set off by the Iraqi invasion. Turkish newspapers reported today that a number of U.S. F-111 bombers were dispatched to Turkey to the Incirlik U.S. base near the Mediterranean. A U.S. Embassy official said 14 F-111s from a U.S. base in England were flown to Incirlik in what he called a routine regularly scheduled transfer. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the first group of F-111s arrived on June 20.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Fire Burns Soviet Army Testing Ground
DOC.TEXT: A forest fire fed by hot weather and drought conditions burned for two days at a Soviet army testing ground in southwest Poland, the official PAP news agency said Tuesday. The fire, which started Sunday, destroyed 3,200 acres of woodland and caused damage estimated in the millions of dollars, PAP said. It was finally put out Monday. The testing range and training grounds are near Legnica, where the Soviet Union maintains one of its most important military bases in Poland. The Soviet Union maintains about 40,000 troops in Poland. Fire brigades, soldiers, police officers and forest rangers used helicopters and water tankers to fight the fire. PAP said their efforts were hampered by dry conditions and the remote terrain. The cause of the fire was not determined and the provincial prosecutor's office started an investigation, PAP said.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill 42 Rebels Responsible for Attacks on Moslems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Tamil politician claiming that Moslem mob massacred 40 Tamil civilians. Pickup pvs 5th graf, ``The government...'
DOC.TEXT: Government troops tracked down and killed 42 Tamil rebels held responsible for massacring Moslem villagers, officials said today. ``We will show no mercy to these Tamil terrorists, criminals who do not deserve to live,'' Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said of rebels blamed for killing at least 193 Moslems since Friday. Most of the villagers were slain while worshiping in mosques. Wijeratne's statement in Parliament replied to opposition criticism that government forces had not give Moslem civilians protection against rebel attacks. In a separate incident a Moslem mob avenging the massacres raided a Tamil village and killed 40 people, a Tamil politician said today. Kandiah Premachandran, a member of Parliament, quoted survivors as saying the Moslems attacked Thirraikerni village in Ampara district and shot and stabbed residents, leaving 40 dead. The village is 130 miles east of Colombo. There was no independent or police confirmation of Premachandran's allegation. Premachandran is general secretary of the Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front, a former guerrilla group which gave up arms to join mainstream politics. The front is a bitter rival of the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, which has been accused of carrying out the massacres. Saturday and Sunday at least 50 Moslems were shot or hacked to death in Ampara district, according to officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. They blamed the Tamil Tigers for the incident. The Tigers have been involved in an intensive war with government forces since June 11. The government launched search operations in the district for the assailants and killed 42 rebels, the officials said. Most of the clashes occurred Monday, they said. The government clamped an indefinite curfew in the eastern port city of Trincomalee after reports of tension between Moslems and Tamils, who are mainly Hindu. In Colombo, armed police guarded Hindu temples to prevent outbreaks of sectarian violence. The weekend attacks on the Moslems follow a raid on two mosques in the Batticaloa district Friday. At least 143 Moslem worshippers died in machine-gun fire and grenade explosions, according to army and witness accounts. The military and Moslem politicians blamed the Tigers, but a rebel spokesman claimed the attacks were carried out by a rival Tamil group to discredit the Tigers. Moslems, who make up 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim neutrality in the war between Tamil separatists and the government. But the rebels accuse Moslems of siding with the government. The eastern districts of Ampara, Batticaloa and Trincomalee have roughly equal populations of Tamils, Moslems and the mainly Buddhist Sinhalese, who control the island nation's army and the government. The Tamil war has been mainly directed against the Sinhalese, whom they accuse of discrimination. Since June 11, at least 3,150 combatants have been killed in fighting between Tamil rebels and the military. Hundreds of civlians also have died, but there is no precise estimate. Tamil militants began fighting for an independent homeland in 1983 but agreed to a cease-fire in May 1989. That agreement was broken after 13 months when the Tigers overran police stations along the east coast. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old insurrection.

DOC.HEAD: In Closing Argument, Lawyer Charges Statement On Jogger Attack Was Coerced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with closing arguments under way; defense lawyer charges that statement was coerced. Picks up penultimate graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: A defense lawyer in the Central Park jogger trial asked the jury today to acquit his client, charging that detectives coerced an incriminating statement from the teen-ager and lied about it on the witness stand. ``They came in here and they lied to you, and they intended to lie to you,'' said defense attorney Michael Joseph in an 80-minute summation in state Supreme Court in Manhattan. The detectives persuaded 16-year-old Antron McCray to implicate himself in written and videotaped statements by threatening the teen with jail if he didn't cooperate, Joseph charged. ``It's the hope of getting out of trouble that caused the statement to be made,'' said Joseph, the first of three defense attorneys addressing the jury today. The prosecutor was to deliver her summation when the defense finishes. The defense attorney pointed out the lack of physical evidence linking McCray to the attack: no blood on his clothes, none of his semen recovered from the jogger. He also pointed out close to a dozen discrepancies in the testimony of police detectives in the case, charging they had lied to the jury in an effort to get a conviction. Yusef Salaam, 16, Raymond Santana, 15, and McCray are charged with raping and beating a woman jogger in Central Park and leaving her near death the night of April 19, 1989. The jogger, now 30, is back at work at an investment bank but testified she suffers from impaired sight, balance and smell. She does not remember the attack. Summations were delivered one day after Salaam's mother was ejected from the courtroom after she leapt up and screamed at the final witness, a prosecutor. ``She's lying! She's lying!'' Sharonne Salaam shouted Monday as Assistant District Attorney Linda Fairstein told of meeting Mrs. Salaam at the 20th Precinct police station the night Yusef was arrested. `Why are you telling all these lies?
