My son is innocent! You don't have to lie like that! He passed a lie detector test and he's innocent!'' Mrs. Salaam shouted at Fairstein. Two court officers escorted Mrs. Salaam from the courtroom. The results of lie detector tests are inadmissible. Justice Thomas Galligan instructed the jury to ``totally disregard any outbursts like that. It is totally inappropriate.'' Mrs. Salaam testified that she told Fairstein right away that her son was 15 but that the prosecutor stalled for at least an hour while detectives continued to question the boy. It is illegal for police to question anyone under 16 without a parent or guardian present. Fairstein, however, testified that no more than 10 minutes elapsed between the time Mrs. Salaam told her the boy was 15 and the time the woman was allowed to see her son.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Requests Navy Investigation of Nimitz Nuclear System
DOC.TEXT: A congressman asked the Navy to investigate possible safety hazards aboard the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier USS Nimitz after a television station broadcast allegations of violations, an aide said today. U.S. Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., was assured by Adm. Bruce DeMars, Navy director of nuclear propulsion, that his office would join the investigation currently under way aboard the Nimitz, Dicks spokesman George Behan said. The violations were alleged by four men identified as Nimitz sailors who appeared on Seattle television station KIRO last week, with their faces and voices masked. They alleged that crew members had cheated on reactor inspections, that some nuclear operators had to work up to 100 hours a week during a month-long maintenance run at the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard in Bremerton, and that crew members did not have sufficient knowledge to control a nuclear accident. They also said some had discussed sabotaging the reactor to ease their heavy work schedule. However, one later said the comments were not meant as a direct threat by the four. Four sailors believed by the Navy to be the source of the allegations were kept aboard as the aircraft carrier left port Monday, despite objections from their lawyers who wanted them kept ashore pending an independent investigation. The Nimitz set sail Monday night from Bremerton on a 30-day mission. A Navy spokesman said the sailors' rights had not been violated, and they would continue to be part of the investigation until the Navy gets to the bottom of the allegations. Attorneys for the petty officers said the Navy had a ``vendetta'' against the four. The lawyers want independent investigators, not the Navy, to look into the claims. ``We're concerned about our clients. If anything happens to these people while they're out to sea for the next 30 days the Navy is going to be held responsible,'' attorney Michael Withey said Monday. A Navy spokesman, Lt. Comdr. Bob Pritchard, said in the Nimitz's home port of San Diego that the sailors were taken off restrictive status Monday afternoon after the Naval Investigative Service found the threat of possible nuclear sabotage by them groundless. Withey would not confirm whether his clients were the ones who appeared on KIRO last week, but did say they had been interrogated and fingerprinted. In a letter to the ship's captain, Robert Williamson, Withey demanded that the Navy stop questioning the four sailors, make arrangements for them to stay in Bremerton while the carrier sails and ``end the intimidating atmosphere aboard the Nimitz.'' Pritchard said the Navy would not rule out action against the four for possibly releasing classified information on TV, but he denied they had been intimidated during questioning.

DOC.HEAD: West Africans Sending Task Force to Liberia
With PM-Liberia
DOC.TEXT: West African leaders announced today they are sending troops to end Liberia's 7-month-old civil war ``in the interest of the African people as a whole.'' A five-nation cease-fire monitoring group led by a Ghanaian commander and deputy commanded from Guinea will go to Liberia, said a statement at the end of a two-day summit of the Economic Community of West Africa. It did not say when the troops would go. Summit sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said the force probably would involve a naval task force and possibly troops sent by land from neighboring Sierra Leone and Guinea. The troops would impose a cease-fire that would allow the establishment of a broad-based interim government charged with organizing free and fair elections, said the announcement. None of the warring parties would be permitted to participate in the interim government unless they did not wish to stand in the elections, the communique said. It ``assured the people of Liberia that the sole purpose of the ... peacekeeping force is to create the necessary conditions for normal life to resume to the benefit of all Liberians.'' The summit called for the international community and especially the permanent members of the U.N. Security Council ``to support this humanitarian and political action ... in the interest of the African people as a whole, and for the maintenance of international peace and security.'' The region is supporting nearly 400,000 Liberians who fled following the beginning of the insurgency against President Samuel Doe began in December. Doe's forces face rebels from two factions, one led by former Doe aide Charles Taylor and another by Prince Johnson.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Seizes Load of Iraqi Oil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped word `barrels,' calculate gallon equivalent. Spelling of ships' names is as provided by Customs spokeswoman.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Customs officials seized a shipload of Iraqi crude oil this morning at Port Arthur because it violated the trade embargo, authorities said. The nearly 500,000 barrels, roughly 20 million gallons, of Iraqi crude on the Swedish-flagged vessel Thoraas were seized because the shipment was paid for Monday in violation of the U.S. embargo on Iraqi oil, said Donna De La Torre, a spokeswoman for the Customs southwest regional office at Houston. The embargo began at 5 a.m. Thursday after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Customs seized the oil from Bay Oil Co. ``based on the fact that the Iraqi government has already been paid,'' Ms. De La Torre said. The ship was detained, but not seized, she added, until Customs determines what to do with the oil aboard. The Thoraas brings oil into port after it is transfered from a larger vessel, the process oil shippers call lightering. Ms. De La Torre said the oil had been transferred from the ship Cartha Gonova, but she didn't know its whereabouts or country of registration.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Air Force Pilots Grounded in France
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Training courses for about 10 Iraqi air force pilots in France have been abruptly canceled and the aviators await the reopening of air routes before they can go home. The pilots, scattered around several French air force bases for flight training or to familiarize themselves with French equipment purchased by Iraq, were grounded as of Saturday, two days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``They are at the end of their stay,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Tuesday. ``The pilots will return to Iraq when the air frontiers open again. Unless they don't want to.'' Training came to a formal end for the pilots, no matter what the stage of their individual courses, after the 12-nation European Community adopted an oil and arms embargo against Iraq on Saturday. The conservative daily newspaper Le Figaro reported Tuesday that Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement ordered the pilots placed on stand-by Friday, a day before the sanctions were adopted. France has trained Iraqi pilots since the 1970s to fly the modern warplanes it sells to Baghdad, including Mirage fighters. The ministry refuses to reveal how many Iraqi pilots it has trained, but Le Figaro said the number has dropped as Iraq becomes able to instruct its own pilots. A former national intelligence director, Pierre Marion, said in an interview Monday that France has sold Iraq about $5 billion worth of arms, about one-quarter of Baghdad's arsenal. The arms include about 210 Mirages, as well as Exocet anti-ship missiles that Iraq used against oil tankers in its eight-year war with Iran, Marion said.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Forces Chief Says Military Threat To Soviet Union Remains
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's strategic position will be more difficult following German unification, the chief of the Soviet Armed Forces general staff said Tuesday. ``The Soviet people are interested in what policy a united Germany will pursue in future,'' Mikhail Moiseyev told the Tass news agency. ``Regrettably, NATO doctrines and concepts based on the use of nuclear weapons first have not changed.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed last month that a unified Germany could belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. His change-of-mind came after West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised that a united Germany would cut its armed forces. It also followed a NATO agreement to shift from a military to a political alliance. ``We should display realism and restraint in all appraisals,'' Moiseyev said. Noting that the new border between NATO and the Warsaw Pact countries will run along the Oder River, dividing Poland from what is now East Germany, Moiseyev said: ``It would be premature to say today that the military danger for the U.S.S.R. has disappeared.'' Tass quoted him as saying his country's strategic position would then be more difficult. Gorbachev said last month he would withdraw the remaining 380,000 Soviet troops from East Germany within two or three years. Some Western experts predict they will leave even sooner. Kohl promised that a united Germany would reduce its combined armed forces to 370,000. The two Germanys now have 600,000 enlisted men, 480,000 of them in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian President Asks for Calm During Independence Struggle
DOC.TEXT: The new president of Soviet Armenia appealed Tuesday for its restive and armed citizens to act with cool heads as its parliament began debating a declaration of independence. In the Baltic republics of Estonia and Lithuania, where independence drives began earlier, the parliaments approved platforms for negotiations with the Soviet Union on breaking from Moscow. The Soviet Interior Ministry reported that ``extremists'' in Armenia continue to seize arms in defiance of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree demanding that militants disarm and disband by Thursday. Underscoring the danger from the illegal weapons, the Tass news agency reported that a man shot and killed a military cadet on Sunday in Armenia while seizing a submachine gun. Levon Ter-Petrosyan, a nationalist leader whom the parliament elected president on Saturday, said in his address that Armenia could handle its own problems _ a rejoinder to Kremlin threats to send in troops to enforce order if Gorbachev's decree is ignored. ``We are capable in a short period of time and with our own means of solving the complex problems relating to the republic's domestic life and of stabilizing the existing explosive situation, provided that external interference is excluded,'' he told Armenia's parliament. ``I have grounds also to anticipate that the union (Soviet) authorities will receive our position with understanding,'' he said. He urged the population ``to evaluate cool-headedly the current state of crisis in the republic, the only way out of which is the consolidation of the people around the idea of statehood and its embodiment in the national parliament.'' About 40,000 members of Armenian paramilitary units must, under Gorbachev's decree, surrender their weapons or face forcible confiscation by the Red Army. The Armenian parliament already has rejected the decree as interference in the republic's internal affairs, saying it can police itself. ``I call upon all the volunteers to give a pledge of allegiance to the republic's seat of supreme authority and, forgetting internal contradictions, to abstain from any unconsidered operation,'' he said. ``I am obliged to remind you also that the people will not forgive any adventure that endangers the fulfillment of our statehood,'' he added in the speech, a copy of which was provided to The Associated Press by the Armenian National Movement. Tass also carried a report on the speech. Ter-Petrosyan, a leader of the Armenian National Movement, spent six months in jail last year for organizing mass demonstrations against Azerbaijani control of the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. More than 200 people have died in ethnic clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over control of the territory, which Azerbaijan has held since 1923. Tass reported that the lawmakers on Tuesday began discussing a declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. If Armenia adopts the resolution on independence, it would become the fifth of the 15 Soviet republics to move toward complete separation from the Soviet Union. Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Georgia have already taken steps. The Estonian parliament on Tuesday declared that it will negotiate with the Soviet Union with the following understandings: that the Soviet constitution ``ceased to regulate state and social relations in Estonia,'' that it will refuse to help draft a treaty of union among the Soviet republics and that it will consider the Soviet Army's presence illegal unless Estonia and Soviet authorities draft a treaty on the issue. A report on the parliament's actions came from the Estonian News Agency. The Interfax news agency, meanwhile, reported that Lithuania's parliament approved the basic points and goals of negotiations with the Soviet Union on independence. The action was taken at a closed session of parliament, and no further details were released. Armenia's independence proposal calls for specific steps toward achieving separation from the Soviet Union, according to legislator Raphael Popoyan. It does not follow the example of Lithuania, which on March 11 declared overnight independence, with the details to be worked out later. Popoyan said the victory of Ter-Petrosyan, a supporter of the independence proposal, indicated the parliament probably will support complete separation from the Soviet Union, rather than a less-radical declaration of sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Former West Virginia Governor Reports To Prison
DOC.TEXT: Former West Virginia Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. reported to a federal prison camp today to begin serving a five-year, 10-month sentence for political corruption. Moore, 67, entered the 786-prisoner Maxwell Air Force Base camp near Montgomery, Ala., shortly after 1 p.m. He arrived with his wife, Shelley, and an unidentified man, refusing to answer questions before entering the prison. Moore pleaded guilty May 8 to extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice. Prosecutors said Moore extorted $573,000 from a mine company official, H. Paul Kizer, in return for a $2.1 million black lung fund refund for Kizer's coal companies. Shortly afterward, he sought to withdraw his guilty plea to most of the charges, but U.S. District Court Judge Walter Hoffman turned him down last month. In addition to the five-year, 10-month sentence, the judge fined Moore $170,000. Moore won't be eligible for parole for 2{ years. Moore, a Republican who was governor from 1969 to 1977 and again from 1985 to 1989, became the second governor of that state to serve a prison term. The first was Wally Barron, who was governor from 1961 through 1965 and later spent nearly 3{ years in prison for bribing a jury foreman. Moore's fate was sealed Monday when a federal appeals court refused to continue bond pending his appeal of Hoffman's rejection of his bid to withdraw the pleas. The prison generally houses white-collar convicts who, like Moore, are considered non-violent. Among the prominent men who have served time there are U.S. Attorney General John Mitchell and U.S. District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada. In addition to Moore, federal authorities' three-year investigation into government corruption has netted two former state Senate presidents, three other West Virginia legislators, three lobbyists, a former Senate aide and two former state Tax Department workers.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
78 Foreigners Arrive in Amman from Iraq
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi airways jet carrying 78 foreigners and a number of Iraqi citizens arrived today, the first commercial flight allowed out of Iraq since it invaded Kuwait, a Japanese Embassy spokesman said. The mostly Japanese tourists arrived at Amman airport at 6:15 p.m. (11:15 a.m. EDT) along with 34 members of an Iraqi football team, said the spokesman on condition of anonymity. It was not immediately known if there were Americans on board. He said that the plane was due to leave Amman for an undisclosed destination. The spokesman said the plane was supposed to land in Vienna, but it was denied landing rights. The U.N. Security Council on Monday voted economic sanctions that ban all trade and military ties with Iraq. Jordan's information minister, Ibrahim Izzedine, said earlier today that the U.S. government had asked Jordan to facilitate the entrance from Iraq of American diplomats and their dependents. Izzedine said the request was made through the U.S. Embassy in Amman. Thousands of Westerners have been stranded in Kuwait and Iraq since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday. They include more than 350 who were on a British Airways flight that was caught in the unrest in Kuwait. A British Airways spokeswoman said today a ``substantial'' number of those passengers arrived safely in Baghdad on Monday. Among the passengers were 28 Americans, who also turned up in a Baghdad hotel and appear to be fine, a U.S. official said in Washington. In addition, a Kuwaiti businessman said about 1,000 people a day were fleeing Kuwait through the desert to Saudi Arabia. The businessman, who arrived in London on a British Airways flight from Bahrain today, said Kuwaitis and expatriates, including Westerners, were joining convoys to escape the Iraqi forces. Jordan's borders with Iraq had been closed from the Iraqi side since Thursday morning, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The ``provisional government of free Kuwait'' set up by Iraq had threatened Sunday to hold hostage citizens of countries imposing sanctions on it. A U.S. diplomat said Washington had instructed ``American citizens living in or visiting Iraq and Kuwait to leave when circumstances permit.''

DOC.HEAD: Army-Supported Government Takes Control in Pakistan
LaserPhoto ISL7
DOC.TEXT: An army-supported caretaker government assumed power Tuesday and ordered former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and other top officials not to leave the country. One diplomat called it a ``constitutional coup.'' Ms. Bhutto, dismissed by the president on Monday, spent her first day out of office meeting with former Cabinet ministers to chart a strategy for their party, which is now deeply divided and demoralized. Ms. Bhutto, members of her government and members of the disbanded federal legislature were ordered to remain in Pakistan, spokesmen for the new and former governments said. Pakistan appeared calm after the action and troops deployed to maintain order began returning to their barracks Monday night. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan invoked his constitutional authority and dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government, alleging widespread corruption, misuse of power, judicial intimidation and failure to curb ethnic violence that has claimed more than 400 lives since May in her home province of Sindh. Ms. Bhutto called the charges baseless and said she had only one demand: ``Hold fair and free elections, on schedule, and let the people decide.'' The president appointed opposition leader Mustafa Jatoi as acting prime minister, set new elections for Oct. 24 and declared a state of emergency that gave the new government sweeping powers to suspend all laws and individual rights. But many members of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan Peoples Party said privately that the link between Ms. Bhutto and grass roots members has been almost severed, largely because of her unwillingness to compromise and allegations that senior government officials used their positions to make huge fortunes. ``We simply blew it,'' one former minister said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The president's decision took Ms. Bhutto and senior officials by surprise. But some opposition officials said the president starting drafting the order two months ago after telling Ms. Bhutto to reform her government. ``She has nobody to blame but herself. She had plenty of warnings,'' said Abida Hussein, a former lawmaker and one of Ms. Bhutto's most outspoken critics. According to sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, the Pakistani army also had become increasingly impatient with Ms. Bhutto's inability to find a political solution to the ethnic violence in Sindh and her perceived meddling in military affairs. The sources said the army gave Ishaq Khan the green light to dismiss the government after a meeting between army chief of staff Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg and Ms. Bhutto failed to resolve the dispute. ``This was a kind of constitutional coup staged while world attention was focused on the events of Kuwait and Iraq,'' one diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But something had to be done. If things had continued to deteriorate, the only ultimate solution would have been martial law.'' The military has ruled Pakistan for 25 years of its 43-year history. Members of Ms. Bhutto's former government alleged the interim administration appointed by Ishaq Khan was considering investigating and punishing Ms. Bhutto. ``They may be planning to have tribunals of accountability and not let her stand in the next election,'' said her former minister of information, Ahmed Saeed Awan. The tribunals under consideration would reportedly have the authority to suspend participation in elections for five to seven years. Critics dismissed the notion, saying the former prime minister and her party members would be allowed to participate in an election. Jatoi said the new government would initiate a process of accountability, but added: ``Justice will be provided without victimizing anyone.'' Some in Ms. Bhutto's administration have compared Ishaq Khan's move to the events of 1977, when Ms. Bhutto's father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was overthrown in a coup led by Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. He was hanged two years later for alleged complicity in a murder plot. Zia ruled Pakistan until his death in a mysterious plane crash on Aug. 17, 1988. His death cleared the way for democratic elections that installed Ms. Bhutto as prime minister, the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
U.S. says 28 Americans Picked up by Iraqi Troops in Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with official confirmation of Americans' whereabouts; Americans not allowed to leave. EDITS throughout to tighten. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 28 Americans picked up in Kuwait by Iraqi invasion troops turned up at a Baghdad hotel today, but they are not allowed to leave the building, the State Department said. U.S. officials have met with some of the Americans, who were among a group of more than 300 foreigners picked up by the Iraqis on Monday and taken by bus to Baghdad. The Americans were placed in the Rashid Hotel, where 11 American oil workers rounded up by the Iraqis in Kuwait last Thursday are also staying, said spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``The Americans in the hotel in Baghdad with whom we have met appear to be in good shape,'' she said. ``Our understanding is that foreigners in hotels in Baghdad who have been brought from Kuwait are not being allowed to leave the hotels at this point.'' The top U.S. diplomat in Iraq, Joseph Wilson, is discussing with Iraqi authorities a plan that would allow all 500 Americans and the 50 official U.S. employees in the country to leave, she said. ``He made clear that we expect, once the situation is safe and the borders are open, private Americans should be able to leave along with any officials and their dependents,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. The first commercial flight to leave Iraq since the invasion arrived today in Amman, Jordan, with 78 foreigners _ most of them Japanese tourists _ and a number of Iraqi citizens arrived today. It was not immediately known if there were Americans on board the Iraqi Airways jet. The efforts to arrange the departure of Americans from Baghdad seemed designed to preclude any possibility that they might be taken hostage by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. If Americans can get out by cars or buses, they will be able to drive to neighboring Jordan or Turkey, Ms. Tutwiler said, adding that both countries have promised the United States they would help Americans on their way. A senior Iraqi official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said today Iraq is considering allowing foreigners, including U.S. Embassy staff and dependents, to leave by land through Jordan. Ms. Tutwiler said the estimated 3,000 Americans in Kuwait are mostly unable to leave the occupied country, although some have managed to get out. The U.S. Embassy has reported that all Americans in the country are safe, she said. The State Department said the group of foreigners taken Monday included passengers from a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion began. The Iraqi official said today that his country ``might be loosening travel restrictions on foreigners and the government is considering facilitating the departure of the foreign community for those who wish to leave Iraq or Kuwait.'' There are an estimated 3,000 U.S. citizens in Kuwait and 500 others in Iraq. ``We hold Iraq responsible for their safety,'' Ms. Tutwiler said earlier. However, she also said, ``It's premature to call them hostages.'' Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat on Monday to demand information about the 28 Americans taken from Kuwait and to deliver a stern warning about their safety. ``It was a short and tense meeting,'' said an official afterward. Al-Mashat refused to talk with reporters. Another warning against harming Americans was delivered in Baghdad by Wilson, the charge d'affaires in Iraq, to Saddam. Saddam summoned Wilson to his office _ the first contact the United States has had with Saddam since the invasion _ and the meeting lasted two hours, said Ms. Tutwiler. ``We viewed it as a very serious meeting,'' she said, indicating the session was confrontational. The meeting took place before U.S. officials learned of the 28 missing Americans. Secretary of State James A. Baker III discussed the safety of U.S. citizens in Kuwait and Iraq with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in a 30-minute telephone conversation Monday. Shevardnadze, whose government has announced an arms boycott of Iraq, said he was worried about Soviet citizens in Kuwait and Iraq, said another official. The ports in Kuwait and Baghdad remained closed Monday, but some Americans managed to leave Kuwait, Ms. Tutwiler said. Another State Department official said the number who managed to get out was small, but declined to say how they left.

DOC.HEAD: `The Grapes of Wrath,' Tony Winner Best Play, Closing Labor Day Weekend
DOC.TEXT: ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' winner of the 1990 Tony Award as best play, will close Labor Day weekend after a Broadway run of less than six months, a show spokeswoman said Tuesday. The play, based on the classic John Steinbeck novel, will have played 188 performances and 11 previews when it ends its run Sept. 2, said Ellen Levene. The production from Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company opened March 22 to favorable reviews, but never became a hot ticket. Business improved a bit in June after the show won two Tony awards _ for best play and for Frank Galati as best director of a play. The show, which has a large cast of 35 performers, needs to gross around $180,000 a week to break even and has been doing that or a little better in recent weeks. But grosses slipped last week to about $177,900. Galati adapted the sprawling novel, set during the Depression, for the stage. It had its premiere in Chicago in September 1988 and traveled to La Jolla, Calif., and London before opening on Broadway in March. Three other Broadway shows will close the same weekend. Slated to end their runs on Sept. 1 are ``Tru,'' Robert Morse's portrait of author Truman Capote; the musical ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway''; and Wendy Wasserstein's ``The Heidi Chronicles,'' the 1989 best play Tony winner.

DOC.HEAD: Four Monks Injured in Fire At Poland's Holiest Catholic Shrine
DOC.TEXT: A fire has damaged Poland's holiest Roman Catholic shrine and injured four monks who tried to save centuries-old volumes from the blaze, media and officials said Tuesday. The fire at the Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa did not endanger the jewel-robed Black Madonna, the burnished icon to which millions of pilgrims pay homage every year, said Sister Daria at the Roman Catholic curia in Czestochowa. Four monks suffered smoke inhalation while rushing through the burning building to save books, including some illuminated manuscripts dating to the 15th century, from the two-story library built in 1739. The monks were hospitalized in stable condition, Polish television reported. The fire appeared to have started in the attic and been caused by a short circuit in the electrical system, Polish radio reported. A commission of Warsaw specialists was established to investigate. The fire started late Monday and was extinguished at 8:30 a.m. Tuesday, said the Rev. Simon Stefanowicz at the monastery. He said there was no significant damage to the many historical objects housed at Jasna Gora, founded in 1382 by the hermetic Paulite order from Hungary. However, firefighters had to break through the copper roof of the building where the fire broke out. In addition to the library and archives, the building houses a small hotel for visiting priests and the editorial offices of a monthly monastery bulletin, officials said. The building is adjacent to the chapel where the icon is housed. But the curia said the chapel and the rest of the monastery were sealed off and not jeopardized. More than 15,000 pilgrims left Warsaw on Monday on the nine-day, 174-mile walk to Czestochowa for Assumption Day on Aug. 15, a tradition that has been maintained every year since 1711. Up to 170,000 pilgrims make the trip on foot, many covering the last distance on their knees. In all, a half-million worshipers are expected to fill the field at the monastery Aug. 15. Jasna Gora, or Bright Mountain, rests on a brick fortification and houses an extensive collection of Polish historical objects, from the weapons of kings to tear-gas grenades lobbed at Solidarity protesters. The monastery provided sanctuary for the Solidarity movement through its decade-long fight against Poland's Communist government and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki visited Czestochowa two days after becoming the first non-Communist government leader in the East bloc in August 1989. The Black Madonna _ painted, according to legend, by St. Luke _ was brought to the monastery in 1384. Many miracles have been attributed to the doleful painting, including a 1655 siege during which 70 monks and 180 supporters held off nearly 4,000 soldiers from the Protestant Swedish army and inspired the country to rise up and throw out the invaders.

DOC.HEAD: Home of Erskine Caldwell Relocated, to Be Converted Into Museum
DOC.TEXT: Writer Erskine Caldwell's boyhood home has been saved from destruction and moved to the Moreland town square, where it will become a museum honoring the novelist. Caldwell, author of ``Tobacco Road,'' ``God's Little Acre'' and at least 50 other books, was born in the house on Dec. 17, 1903, and lived there until he was 14. The house was the parsonage for the White Oak Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church, where Caldwell's father, the Rev. Ira Sylvester Caldwell, was pastor. The house, estimated to have been built around 1879, was occupied until 1960 and then was used to store hay. It stood about 2 miles from the town square in this community southwest of Atlanta. ``It was scheduled to be torn down and a barn built in its place,'' said Miriam Miller, chairwoman of the committee that had the five-room, one-story house moved. Mrs. Miller said Caldwell's widow, Virginia, has agreed to donate one of her husband's typewriters and some books to the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Politics, Not Military, Answer to Iraqi Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Tuesday it prefers political pressure to an international military buildup to force Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. But it took no chances, dispatching two warships to protect Soviet commercial vessels in the Persian Gulf. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said an anti-submarine ship and a destroyer patrolling the Indian Ocean were sailing toward the Strait of Hormuz, the entrance to the gulf. Journalists in helicopters on Tuesday reported seeing a Soviet destroyer nearing the strait. Gremitskikh said the ships were dispatched ``to ensure safety of navigation of Soviet civilian vessels.'' He urged caution in the naval buildup but was careful to avoid direct criticism of the United States, which has sent even more warships to the gulf. ``A buildup in the military presence and naval muscle-flexing in such a very tense and very complex situation is not the best line of action,'' Gremitskikh told a regular news briefing. The United States moved aircraft carriers into position near the gulf. One is at the mouth of the gulf, and the other is in the Mediterranean within striking distance of Iraq. Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, told CBS on Tuesday an international naval blockade against Iraq was ``very likely.'' The Washington Post said the Pentagon proposed an international blockade that would include forces from the Soviet Union. Gremitskikh told reporters Moscow had not discussed joining such a blockade. The Soviet Union ``prefers political means'' for resolving the crisis, such as the worldwide trade embargo ordered by the U.N. Security Council on Monday, and diplomatic intervention by other Arab states, Gremitskikh said. A senior Soviet military official doubted the superpowers would resort to force against Iraq. ``I think the Soviet Union and the United States will solve this, but not by war. They will use public pressure,'' Lt. Gen. Vladislav Lisovsky, deputy commander of the Leningrad Military District, told reporters watching military exercises near Leningrad. ``It's apparent that the Soviet Union and the United States have taken the humanitarian side,'' he added. U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock met Tuesday in Moscow with Soviet Deputy Foreign Ministry Alexander Belonogov, who has been holding regular talks with Iraq's ambassador, Tass reported. The official news agency did not disclose details of the meeting except to say it was at the American's request. The U.S. Embassy confirmed the report but refused to elaborate. The Soviet Union joined the United States in condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and urging a speedy withdrawal of Iraqi troops. It also halted arms sales to Baghdad, a long-time ally. The Soviet Union has not said what other measures it will take to implement the U.N. Security Council resolution ordering worldwide sanctions against Iraq. Belonogov told the government newspaper Izvestia that whatever action is taken, the Soviet economy will be hurt. He did not elaborate, but the shortage-plagued Soviet Union imports $1.6 billion worth of goods from Iraq. It exports $428 million worth of goods to the Middle Eastern country. ``By taking these measures, we cut the cooperation which we have accumulated with Baghdad for decades,'' Belonogov said. ``But all the same, the U.S.S.R. will unswervingly observe the resolution of the Security Council.'' The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said in a commentary that the Soviet Union's decision to suspend arms supplies to its old friend Iraq was not taken lightly. ``The Soviet Union sided with Iraq at its most trying times, but it is one matter to participate in defense, and other to be involved in piracy,'' the newspaper said. Belonogov said the Foreign Ministry was working on plans to evacuate Soviets from Kuwait by air or sea. Lisovsky said Soviet military officers in Iraq had already left. Almost 900 Soviets live in Kuwait, and 8,000 in Iraq, including diplomats, businessmen, military advisers and oil workers. Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia have asked for Soviet help in evacuating their nationals, Belonogov said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Meets With Mubarak in Attempt to Solve Gulf Crisis
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak met Tuesday with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who was said to be seeking support for a multinational ground force to deter Iraq from invading Saudi Arabia. Cheney met for an hour with Mubarak, who earlier held separate meetings with Iraqi and Kuwaiti leaders. Mubarak, who has been trying to mediate the Iraq-Kuwait crisis, received a message from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein explaining why his troops took over Kuwait on Thursday. Presidential sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the message ``explains the Iraqi viewpoint on the present crisis.'' It was relayed by Izzat Ibrahim, vice president and deputy chairman of Iraq's ruling revolutionary command council. Ibrahim and Mubarak met for two hours. After Ibrahim left, Cheney and Mubarak had their meeting. Cheney refused to talks to reporters afterward. Pentagon sources in Washington said Cheney was seeking approval from Mubarak to move the aircraft carrier USS Eisenhower, with its complement of sophisticated aircraft, through the Suez Canal. From there, it could head toward the Persian Gulf. Cheney also was seeking the cooperation of Middle East nations to station a multinational ground force in Saudi Arabia to contain further Iraqi aggression, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. Earlier in the day, the Middle East News Agency said Mubarak had spoken on the phone with President Bush to discuss the situation in Kuwait. Cheney stopped over on his way home from Saudi Arabia, where he conferred Monday with Saudi officials about bolstering the U.S. presence there in the event of an Iraqi attack on the oil-rich kingdom. Penatagon sources said that although two U.S. aircraft carriers were within range to carry out air strikes in the Persian Gulf or against Iraqi sites, a major air strike would require flying over or landing rights from friendly nations in the region. Although Iraqi officials repeatedly have said they would not attack Saudi Arabia, residents have reported increased military activity in the kingdom, especially near the Kuwaiti border where Iraqi troops have been sighted strenthening their positions. Cheney was accompanied by Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the U.S. Middle East force known as the Central Command; Richard Gates, deputy national security adviser; and Paul Wolowitz, deputy defense secretary. Ibrahim was the first Iraqi official to meet with Mubarak since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He was also the head of the delegation that held talks with Kuwaiti officials Aug. 1 in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to resolve their differences over oil and land. The talks failed, and less than 24 hours later, Iraq invaded Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Scientists Fish for $250,000 Camera
DOC.TEXT: Federal scientists didn't really lose a quarter-million-dollar underwater camera used to map the ocean floor. They know exactly where it is _ 200 miles off the Oregon Coast and more than a mile straight down. The crew of a submersible will try to find and hook a cable to the one-ton camera system, a task sort of like standing atop a skyscraper and trying to drop a rope into an open manhole, said Steve Hammond of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The $250,000 package was suspended from the 303-foot NOAA ship Discoverer last week when its three-quarter-inch cable snapped. The camera system includes a low-light video camera, a 35mm still camera, and various temperature, conductivity and depth sensors, all in sealed containers. The Alvin will try to retrieve the camera later this month, Hammond said from his office at the Hatfield Marine Science Center. The Alvin's crew of three will attempt to approach the camera with a hook and cable so a surface ship can reel it in. However, if the camera is snarled in its broken cable, they may not able to get close enough to attach the hook, Hammond said. The Alvin is too small to raise the camera.

DOC.HEAD: Andrew Young in Uphill Battle in Georgia; Kansas Governor's Job on Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 7 p.m. EDT in Georgia, 8 in Kansas, Michigan and Missouri; matter below dash will stand.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young, struggling to keep alive his hopes of being Georgia's first black governor, needed an upset Tuesday in his Democratic runoff against Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. In Kansas, first-term Gov. Mike Hayden fought for survival in a Republican primary as his chief opponent, real estate executive Nestor Weigand Jr., tried to capitalize on voter anger over higher property taxes. On the Democratic side, former Gov. John Carlin was favored to win the first round of a comeback bid. Two other states also held primaries. Michigan Republicans picked opponents for two Democratic incumbents seeking third terms _ Gov. James Blanchard and Sen. Carl Levin. Polls showed Rep. Bill Schuette a heavy favorite over lawyer Clark Durant for the right to challenge Levin. State Sen. John Engler was expected to trounce General Motors engineer John Lauve and earn a shot at Blanchard. And in Missouri, Rep. Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, sought the Democratic nomination for an eighth term against Nicholas F. Clement, a newspaper carrier who is a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Young, a former Atlanta mayor, congressman and U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, finished 12 percentage points behind Miller in the primary July 17. Two polls released last week showed him trailing by as much as 20 points heading into the runoff. That showing came in spite of an aggressive runoff strategy in which Young suggested that Miller, a white moderate who has been lieutenant governor for 16 years, pushed banking legislation that helped his friends. Miller, 58, denied the charge and kept plugging away at the major themes of his campaign, including support for a state lottery. Young, also 58, conceded that the polls showed he would need a ``miracle'' to win, but added, ``Pollsters have never known what they're talking about.'' The winner of the runoff faces Republican Johnny Isakson in November. Democratic Gov. Joe Frank Harris was barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term. In Kansas, Hayden, 46, had five opponents for the GOP nomination, but polls indicated the one with the best shot at ousting him was Weigand, a Wichita businessman with no political experience. Weigand, 51, hit hard at Hayden's role in property reappraisal and implementing a new classification system that many blamed for big property tax increases in 1989. The changes were felt most by medium and small businesses. Carlin, who served two terms in 1979-87, was challenged on the Democratic side by longtime state Treasurer Joan Finney and minister Fred Phelps. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum had token opposition from political unknown Gregory Walstrom in her bid for the GOP nomination to a third term. The Democratic Senate ballot listed political newcomer Dick Williams of Wichita and former Rep. Bill Roy, who tried too late to remove his name.

Georgia's runoff campaign took a negative turn when Young, shocked by a weaker-than-expected showing among black voters in the primary, adopted a more aggressive strategy for the rematch. He unleashed a series of attacks questioning Miller's ties to the banking industry and broadcast the first negative ad of the campaign season in Georgia _ a spot accusing Miller of changing positions on issues for political expediency. The ad resurrected the appellation hung on Miller in a campaign 10 years ago _ ``Zig-Zag Zell.'' Critics said Young's effort to woo white voters during the primary election, and his failure to include more black elected officials in his campaign, left some black voters feeling ignored. The runoff _ required because no candidate won a majority in the primary _ has been challenged in court as discriminatory against blacks, who make up about 28 percent of Georgia's voters. In Kansas, Weigand gained quick exposure by spending his own money lavishly in a 10-week television blitz. ``What Nestor brought to this campaign is a million dollars and a million yard signs,'' Hayden said Monday. ``He has shown that he's weak on the issues and he really doesn't know much about government.'' Weigand said voters were ``tired of professional politicians who have created problems such as our property tax mess. They want control of their government back, and they don't want politicians telling them one thing and doing another.'' The last Kansas governor to be denied renomination was Fred Hall, who lost the Republican primary in 1956. In Michigan, Schuette virtually ignored Durant, attacking Levin as too liberal on such issues as opposition to the death penalty. Republicans have not won a U.S. Senate election in Michigan since 1972. Similarly, Engler concentrated his fire on Blanchard, accusing him of using public relations gimmicks to put a shiny veneer over deep problems in Michigan's economy and state budget. Blanchard responded that he wiped out the $1.7 billion budget deficit he inherited after he was elected in 1982 and had moved to diversify the state's economy, improve education, and fight crime with new prison construction.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers Evacuated From Jet After Engines Burst into Flames
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE number of injured, ADD company comment. Pick up 3rd pvs, `Two firemen...'
DOC.TEXT: Two engines of a Boeing 747 charter jet burst into flames Tuesday shortly after the plane landed at Gatwick Airport from Montreal, airport authorities said. The 439 passengers and crew on Nationair Flight NXA124 were evacuated down emergency chutes and 24 passengers suffered minor injuries, airport and ambulance authorities said. ``They all had minor injuries _ sprained ankles, bruises, cuts _ and they were all given first aid at the airport. There were no broken limbs,'' the company said. Two firemen overcome by smoke and fumes were treated at East Surrey Hospital and later discharged, the Surrey Ambulance Authority said. The two engines caught fire as the plane turned off the runway toward a parking bay at 11:12 a.m., said a spokeswoman for Gatwick airport. She spoke on condition of anonymity. Fire engines raced down the runway and extinguished the blaze. The emergency closed part of Gatwick's runway for 40 minutes, preventing the takeoff of wide-bodied jets. Four flights were diverted to Heathrow Airport, the spokeswoman said. The charter flight originated at Mirabel airport, outside of Montreal. The jet was towed to a hanger where damage was being assessed, the spokeswoman said. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Adheres to U.N. Resolution, Restricts Iraqi Use of Oil Pipeline
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Complying with U.N.-ordered sanctions, Turkey on Tuesday halted tankers from loading Iraqi oil from Iraq's last operating pipeline through the country. The move effectively cut off the outlet for more than half of Iraqi's crude exports. The government also announced it was freezing all Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets, stopping all imports from those countries and limiting exports to food and medicine. Kuwaiti assets in Turkey total about $25 million, the Foreign Ministry said. No figure was available for Iraqi assets. In imposing the measures, Turkey joined an international campaign intended to pressure Iraq to withdraw its occupying forces from Kuwait. Embargoes of Iraqi products, including oil, had already forced Iraq on Monday to close one of its two pipelines that traverse Turkey and carry oil to a terminal on the Mediterranean. It reduced the capacity of the second pipeline by 30 percent. The twin pipelines had been carrying about 1.6 million barrels a day, more than half Iraq's total oil exports of 3 million barrels daily. Mehmet Kececiler, Turkish minister in charge of oil affairs, said Iraq could continue to pump crude oil through the second pipeline until the storage tanks at the end terminal were filled. The Iraqis will be forced to stop pumping once the tanks are filled, a process expected to take about six days, he said. ``Otherwise this expensive stuff would just float around,'' the minister said. A tanker from Morocco arrived at the terminal Tuesday but was turned back, Kececiler said. The United States, Japan and Economic Community imposed embargoes on Iraqi oil in the past week. Turkey refused to do so until the U.N. Security Council passed a resolution Monday supporting global sanctions against Iraq. The minister said the Security Council vote was binding on all member states. ``This is why we took this decision. We were not pressured by anyone,'' he said. Turkey stands to suffer substantial economic losses by complying with the sanctions. Iraq owes Turkey $741 million and pays off part of its debt with oil. Foreign ministry officials said Turkish contractors have construction equipment worth $40 million in Iraq and that total contracts, which are likely to be halted, amount to $750 million.

DOC.HEAD: Former West Virginia Governor Reports To Federal Prison Camp
DOC.TEXT: Former West Virginia Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. entered a federal prison camp Tuesday to serve a 70-month sentence for political corruption. Moore, 67, arrived at the barracks-style camp at Maxwell Air Force Base with his wife and another man seven minutes after his noon reporting deadline. He refused to answer questions from reporters. Prison camp spokesman James E. Burrell said Moore would first go through an orientation before getting a job assignment. Moore, the only West Virginia governor to serve three four-year terms, pleaded guilty May 8 to extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice. Moore sought to withdraw his guilty plea to four of the charges, but U.S. District Judge Walter Hoffman refused July 8. The next day he sentenced Moore to prison and fined him $170,000, which Moore has since paid. On Monday, a federal appeals court refused to continue bond pending his appeal of Hoffman's ruling. The federal prison camp, housing 786 inmates, has no walls or barbed wire fences, but inmates follow a regimented schedule and get up at 5:30 a.m. daily. ``It is not a country club,'' Burrell said. ``Those are not inmates up there playing golf.'' However, the camp is next to a golf course. The prison generally houses white-collar convicts who, like Moore, are considered nonviolent. It has housed a number of prominent prisoners, including former U.S. Attorney General John Mitchell in 1977 and U.S. District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada in 1986. Former Tennessee Gov. Ray Blanton went to the prison camp in 1984. In addition to Moore, a three-year federal investigation into government corruption in West Virginia netted two former state Senate presidents, three other legislators, three lobbyists, a former Senate aide and two former state Tax Department workers. Moore, a Republican who was governor from 1969 to 1977 and again from 1985 to 1989, is the second West Virginia governor to serve a prison term. The first was W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, governor from 1961 through 1965, who later spent nearly 3{ years in prison for bribing a jury foreman.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: them there.
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. carrier battle groups were already on station in the region _ the USS Independence and its 14 escorts in the Arabian Sea at the mouth of the Persian Gulf, and the force led by the USS Eisenhower in the eastern Mediterranean. ``If something happens, these boys can handle it,'' said a confident Wade Andrews as the Saratoga, with his seaman son aboard, cruised into the Atlantic off Florida. Defense Secretary Cheney met with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to seek Egyptian permission for the Eisenhower to pass through the Suez Canal and into the Red Sea, to get closer to the Gulf flashpoints, Pentagon sources said. A handful of British and French navy vessels, possible partners in a U.S.-led blockade, were also in the Gulf region. A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said a Soviet anti-submarine ship and destroyer were dispatched from the Indian Ocean toward the Straits of Hormuz, but only to ``ensure safety of navigation of Soviet civilian vessels.'' The Pentagon sources said Cheney also intended to sound out Mubarak on the possibility of Egyptian and other Arab participation in a multinational ground force to be stationed in Saudi Arabia as a ``trip wire,'' guarding against any aggression by the Iraqi war machine against that oil kingdom. In Kuwait, occupied by tens of thousands of Iraqi soldiers, living conditions were growing more difficult, said a Kuwaiti businessman who fled his homeland through the desert backcountry to Saudi Arabia. ``Some Iraqi troops are looting private houses and shops,'' he said. The proxy government installed by Iraq in Kuwait declared Tuesday it was abolishing the previous royal government system _ ``the corrupt satellite regime installed by colonialism'' _ and replacing it with a republic. New concerns focused on the Americans and other Westerners stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. Kuwait's ambassador to London suggested they might become hostages. ``Maybe he (Saddam) will behave like anyone who hijacks a plane,'' he said. The U.S. State Department reported that 28 Americans among more than 300 foreigners picked up at Kuwait hotels by Iraqi troops on Monday had turned up at a Baghdad hotel. But they were not allowed to leave the building. Some 3,000 Americans were residing in Kuwait before the invasion, and 500 in Iraq. American diplomats in Baghdad were discussing a plan with Iraqi authorities that would allow all Americans to leave Iraq, the State Department said. Iraqi and Jordanian officials in Jordan's capital, Amman, said foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq might be allowed to leave via an overland route to Jordan. The first commercial flight to depart Iraq since the invasion arrived Tuesday in Jordan with 78 foreigners, mostly Japanese tourists.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Crisis Joins Dilemmas on Bush's Crowded Plate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, ``No doubt xxx with Hess comments; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``Key GOP xxx
DOC.TEXT: The risk-laden Iraq standoff is giving President Bush a respite from partisan attacks on domestic issues and the potential for a major foreign policy trophy, Republican strategists say. But Democrats, who have silenced their attacks to support Bush for now, contend the latest Middle East crisis and its economic repercussions will eventually hurt the president at home. Analysts agree that Bush is at a crucial, defining point of his presidency, facing a number of major challenges with the potential for dramatic and possibly devastating effects on an economy already teetering on recession and, now, the first significant post-Cold War military crisis. ``No doubt, he's got his hands full more than he has at any other time in his presidency,'' said GOP consultant Charles Black, who is helping direct the Republican Party in the absence of ailing Chairman Lee Atwater. ``This is the type of foreign crisis that is very quickly domesticated in terms of U.S. politics,'' said Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution. ``Bush is the one who has said, `Watch how I handle my first real crisis,' and now he's got one.'' The Iraqi crisis presents daunting risks to the U.S. economy and the stability of the Middle East, Hess said. But he said Iraq's Saddam Hussein ``is a villain we love to hate,'' which works in Bush's favor. Key GOP strategists acknowledged that the Iraqi crisis is unusual because of its direct impact on oil prices and therefore on the U.S. economy _ the primary factor in a president's peacetime political fortunes. Because of that linkage and the likelihood of higher oil prices _ at least in the short term, regardless of whether Iraq withdraws from Kuwait _ Democratic strategists believe the economy, and Bush, will suffer. ``If he walks away, he isn't showing any backbone. And if he takes on Iraq, by definition he impacts on the price of energy, badly, which means a burden on the economy that almost surely will bring recession,'' said Democratic consultant Bob Beckel. ``A president's standing with the people depends on their pocketbooks and how they feel about the economy.'' Even before the Iraqi invasion last Thursday, which immediately produced higher gas prices and talk of lines at the pumps, there were growing signs of consumer unease with the economy. That unease has been mirrored in financial markets, wary because mounting data show a virtually idle economy and volatile because of Bush's tax reversal, stalled deficit-reduction negotiations, uncertainty over inflation and the rising cost of the savings and loan bailout. Add the Iraqi crisis to that mix of domestic challenges confronting Bush and Democrats see ``the irony of ironies'' _ a Republican president facing economic problems resembling those of Jimmy Carter; the same problems that Bush and Ronald Reagan often lumped together as symptoms of dreaded Carter-era ``malaise.'' ``There are a lot of ducks to shoot out there, and for a change they're Republican ducks,'' said Beckel. Black and Bush pollster Bob Teeter argued that Americans will not blame Bush for economic hardships resulting from his hard line against Iraq but will credit him for bold leadership if Iraq backs down. ``The public will understand that higher oil prices are not George Bush's fault,'' said Teeter. ``There's as much opportunity here as there is risk.'' Said Black: ``The end result of this will be a reinforcing of the view that George Bush is the most qualified president we have had on foreign policy in modern times.'' He also predicted Bush will ``land on his feet'' in handling the related budgetary issues, without any lasting economic harm. Democratic hopes for partisan gain seem pinned on a recession and the belief that Bush's foreign policy credentials won't matter much to voters if the economy takes a dive. ``For now, Democrats and for that matter I think everyone will be supportive of the president,'' said Democratic pollster Harrison Hickman. But Hickman said polls show ``people preoccupied with domestic problems and starting to stick'' some of the blame on Bush. The Iraqi crisis, said Hickman, ``won't negate that, but it buys him some time because it diverts attention.''

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Mobs Attack Arabs in Jerusalem, 13 Hurt
DOC.TEXT: Jewish mobs on Tuesday attacked Arabs to avenge the slaying of two Israeli teen-agers believed killed by Palestinians. Thousands of mourners at the youths' funeral chanted ``Death to the Arabs!'' Thirteen people, including two Pakistani tourists, were hurt in one stone-throwing attack, police said. Police arrested 22 Jewish youths who were among a crowd of about 100 that moved toward Arab east Jerusalem, police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. Early Tuesday, a Palestinian woman was fatally shot as she rode past a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank. Police said they suspected Jewish vigilantes. Also Tuesday, Arab reporters said the body of a Palestinian suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities was found in a West Bank village. The army command confirmed the death. Thousands of Israelis attended the funeral of 18-year-old Ronen Karamani and 17-year-old Lior Tubul. Religious Affairs Minister Avner Shaki, speaking to the crowd, promised the government ``will spare no efforts to capture these killers.'' But he was shouted down as thousands of mourners began chanting ``Death to the Arabs!'' Others in the crowd demanded that the killers be hanged. Mourners sporadically broke out of the funeral convoy of cars and pedestrians to attack Arabs. The city's entrance was briefly blocked. Near the cemetery, a group of about 100 ultra-Orthodox Jews stopped cars, demanding the drivers show their identity cards. Many Arabs stayed off their jobs in Jerusalem after riots Monday in which some 20 to 30 Palestinians were reported injured. One riot Tuesday broke out after the funeral near Karamani's home, which is close to the Arab village of Beit Tsafafa near Jerusalem. Police said some 100 Arabs stormed out of the village, shouting ``Allahu Akbar!'' or ``God is Great!'' and hurling stones at Jewish houses and cars. Dozens of Jews met them with a barrage of stones, and police forced the Arabs back into their village. There were no immediate reports of injuries. Earlier Tuesday, about 50 masked Israeli teen-agers walking to the funeral went on a rampage in downtown Jerusalem, chanting ``Death to the Arabs!'' and overturning four Arab-owned cars. One driver was hit in the head by a stone, Israel army radio said. ``We want to make a Jewish intefadeh!'' one youth shouted, using the Arab term for the 31-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Dozens of other attacks were reported in Jerusalem, intensifying after dark when the funeral was over. In an unsigned leaflet Tuesday, Palestinian leaders condemned the ``killing of innocents on both sides,'' but blamed the violence on the Israeli occupation and the lack of progress in peace efforts. The two slain youths, who apparently were seized by Palestinian militants while hitchhiking to a West Bank settlement Saturday, were found Monday after a two-day search. In an apparently related development, a Palestinian woman was fatally shot Tuesday morning as she rode in a car past Kiryat Arba, a Jewish West Bank settlement. Police spokesman Danny Brinker said that officials suspect the woman, 27-year-old Aziza Salem Jaber, was slain by settlers in revenge for the killing of the two youths. Mrs. Jaber's death would bring to 726 the number of Palestinians slain by Israelis in the uprising. Another 246 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-seven Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``Miami Vice'' star and powerboat racer Don Johnson said Tuesday he's taking his favorite sport to the Hudson River on Aug. 18. The race is sponsored by the Offshore Professional Tour, which Johnson heads. The course will run 10 laps from Spuyten Duyvil in the Bronx to Tarrytown, a distance of nine miles, Johnson told a Manhattan news conference. Johnson, who races his personal boat in competition, holds second place in the Superboat class: boats that can travel up to 135 mph on straightaways.

Pop singer Madonna has made another record. The telecast of the final concert Sunday of her ``Blonde Ambition'' tour was the most-watched entertainment special in HBO's 18-year history, the cable company said Tuesday. The two-hour concert, ``Madonna _ Live!,'' was shown in the United States on a tape-delay basis because of the time difference in Nice, France, where she performed. The program had a 21.5 rating, meaning it was seen in more than 4.3 million households that pay extra each month for the HBO service. HBO serves 20.3 million households, according to Nielsen estimates.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moving on sport wires.
DOC.TEXT: A restaurant owned by champion cyclist Greg LeMond and some relatives opened Tuesday in this Minneapolis suburb. LeMond, a three-time winner of the Tour de France, is a partner in Scott Kee's Tour de France restaurant being run by Kee and his wife, Lisa. LeMond and his wife, Kathy, are partners in the venture along with David and Sacia Morris, the parents of Mrs. LeMond and Mrs. Kee. ``Scott has been a chef for about eight years and his dream has always been to have his own restaurant,'' Mrs. Kee said Monday. ``Greg has an interest in restaurants. When he and Kathy are in Europe, they go to all the best restaurants.'' LeMond, who lives in nearby Wayzata part of the year, didn't attend Tuesday's opening, but flew into town briefly for a test meal prepared Saturday night to fine-tune the staff. ``He was really excited,'' Mrs. Kee said. ``He sees this as a place where he can come and bring friends, a place you can call your own.''

Singers Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme helped retired General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith say goodbye to hundreds of friends at an opulent bash featuring smoked duck and $120-a-bottle champagne. ``It was one of the most elegant functions like that that I've ever attended, and I've been to quite a few,'' said David Cole, a University of Michigan official and son of the late Edward Cole, former president of GM. ``I would have traded my salary for what it would have cost to put that on,'' Cole said. ``I'm sure it was an expensive proposition.'' Sunday's get-together became known as ``the $5 million party.'' GM officials said that figure was ``ridiculous,'' but declined to say how much it cost. ``This is the usual party we have for retiring top executives,'' said GM spokesman Jim Crellin. There were 326 people on the guest list, including seven of Forbes magazine's 400 richest people in America. No one from Ford Motor Co. nor Chrysler Corp. was there. The guests were entertained by Lawrence and Gorme, backed by the Johnny Trudell Orchestra.

Actor Ricardo Montalban, who played the genial host of televison's ``Fantasy Island,'' sued Columbia Pictures on Tuesday for $10 million-plus, claiming the studio didn't pay a promised 5 percent in profits. The Superior Court lawsuit, which seeks $10 million in punitive damages in addition to the profits, claims the 1977-1983 series on ABC earned more than $100 million and was one of the most successful in TV history. The lawsuit charges that Columbia Pictures Television and Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. manipulated accounting practices to avoid paying Montalban a portion of the profits. The lawsuit said Montalban was unaware of the alleged accounting practices until he got a distribution statement from the studio in 1987 showing ``large and unwarranted interest charges on the cost of production and other items.'' The lawsuit said the studio denies the show ever turned a profit. The studio declined to comment on the lawsuit. ``We are not aware of any suit, but in any event it is not our policy to comment on pending litigation,'' said Don DeMesquita, a spokesman at Columbia Pictures Television.

A business group asked the Postal Service Tuesday to investigate whether postmasters violated lobbying rules by sending hundreds of letters defending the agency's performance and proposed postage rate hike. About one-third of the letters were on Postal Service stationery and were mailed in envelopes marked ``Official Business,'' according to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. The chamber, which was the recipient of the letters, requested an investigation by the Postal Inspection Service, which protects postal funds and property and conducts audits. ``We believe this matter must be investigated for two reasons,'' chamber President Richard L. Lesher said in a letter released Tuesday to postal inspector Mark Grey of the agency's Central Division. ``First, postmasters may be violating lobbying restrictions contained in (federal law). Second, we believe this is an improper use of the Postal Service's time, money and resources,'' Lesher said. The Postal Service says the letters were needed to refute a chamber-published brochure against the proposed new 30-cent stamp. Titled ``Cancel This Stamp,'' the brochure invited the chamber's member businesses to battle the rate increase and ``join the fight against waste in the Postal Service.'' The brochure contained ``misinformation,'' Jim Stordahl, regional Postal Service spokesman, said Tuesday. ``Postmasters are not lobbying. Postmasters are setting the record straight with the facts,'' Stordahl said. ``Postal employees are no less entitled to seek accurate treatment of information than is the chamber to protest,'' he said. ``Using official mail for this purpose is legitimate.''

DOC.HEAD: New Colombian President Vows Unrelenting War Against Drug Lords
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Gaviria sworn in as president; remarks from advance text of inauguration speech. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Gaviria became ...'
DOC.TEXT: Economist Cesar Gaviria was sworn in Tuesday as president of Colombia and vowed to wage an unrelenting war ``without concessions'' against his country's drug traffickers. In remarks prepared for delivery, the new president proposed setting up an international criminal court to try drug traffickers, who he said were guilty of ``crimes against humanity.'' Gaviria was sworn in at 4:22 p.m. EDT. Despite a cease-fire purportedly declared by drug traffickers last month, security was tight for the inauguration ceremonies, which were attended by 88 foreign delegations. The United States was represented by Vice President Dan Quayle, who arrived Tuesday morning. Four armored U.S. Blackhawk helicopters equipped with missiles accompanied Quayle's helicopter from the airport to an army base. Gaviria, 43, who was elected in May to a four-year term to replace President Virgilio Barco, inherits a nation weary of its fight with terrorists and drug traffickers and looking for an end to the violence. Barco, who was prohibitied by the constitution from running again, received international praise for launching the government's war against drug traffickers one year ago. Barco will reportedly become Colombia's next ambassador to Britain Gaviria vowed to continue the war against the drug cartels. ``Drug trafficking is the main threat against our democracy. We will fight it without concessions,'' he said, according to a text of his inauguration speech made available to reporters. But he said Colombia cannot win the fight alone, and must receive help from the United States and Western Europe. He said Colombia is not a wealthy country, and called on the major industrialized to lower their trade barriers to help Colombia finance the drug war. ``It's not direct economic aid, or military assistance we need most. It's fair treatment. It's free trade,'' Gaviria said. He also said the United States and other countries must do more to cut consumption of cocaine. ``No success is possible if the consuming countries do not achieve a substantial reduction in demand,'' he said. Of the major candidates, Gaviria took the strongest stand in support of a continued hard line against the Medellin and Cali cocaine cartels, which are believed to supply 80 percent of the cocaine reaching the United States. He supports continued extradition of drug suspects to the United States. Gaviria became the candidate of the governing Liberal Party after the first candidate, Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, was shot to death by drug lords in August 1989, sparking the government crackdown. Since then, police have blamed drug traffickers for exploding about 300 bombs throughout Colombia and killing about 500 people. At 43, the demure Gaviria is Colombia's youngest president. A former finance minister from the Liberal Party, he said repeatedly that achieving peace and fighting drug terrorism would be priorities. Gaviria also supports economic, not military strength, to fight the drug scourge. Observers expect him to ask for increased monetary aid from developed countries, particularly the United States. Gaviria has said another way to solve Colombia's problems is to increase political participation of the left and other minority parties. In naming his Cabinet on Monday, he appeared to be doing just that. The new ministers include five members of opposition parties, including the M-19, a former leftist guerrilla group that signed a peace treaty with the government in March. The M-19's Antonio Navarro became the first former guerrilla to occupy a Cabinet post in Colombia. He is the minister of health. About 20,000 soldiers, presidential guards and police officers patrolled the streets of Bogota, while army and police helicopter gunships circled above the city to provide protection during the inauguration. Anti-aircraft guns were on hills overlooking the presidential palace. Army snipers stood on buildings throughout the downtown area and especially around the palace, site of the inauguration. Troops at army roadblocks stopped and searched vehicles. Some major thoroughfares were closed. The Bogota daily newspaper El Espectador said the blood types of visiting dignitaries and heads of state had been noted to ensure ample blood supplies if needed.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Minnesota Ties With Utah As America's Healthiest State
With AM-Healthy States-List, AM-Healthy States-Factors
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota and Utah tied as the healthiest states in the nation while Alaska was rated the least healthy in a study by Northwestern National Life Health Insurance Co. Utah, which had the No. 1 ranking to itself in last year's Northwestern National study, benefits from ``strong lifestyle activities,'' according to a report issued Tuesday. Mormon traditions that dominate Utah life discourage smoking and other unhealthy habits. The study, which uses data from government agencies and health organizations, was based on 17 statistical measures of health such as smoking, traffic death rates and mortality indexes. Utah was No. 1 for low prevalence of smoking and cancer rates. It also ranked in the 10 best for violent crime rate, which was five times less than the lowest-ranked Florida. Favorable access to health care and above-average mortality figures also strengthened its standing. Minnesota had the nation's lowest motor vehicle death rate per 100,000 miles driven, the 16th lowest violent crime rate and the 19th lowest smoking rate. The state was deemed sixth best in providing good access to medical care and it tied with Utah for the third lowest overall mortality rate. Minnesota's infant mortality rate was the 10th lowest. Minnesota ranked third best for having relatively low disease rates. That index included cancer, heart disease and major infectious diseases such as AIDS. Contributing factors to Alaska's 50th overall ranking were a high incidence of major infectious diseases and poor access to health care, particularly primary care, the study said. But with the exception of high levels of smoking, Alaskans seem to have relatively health lifestyles. Overall scores ranked New Hampshire third and Hawaii fourth. Hawaiians had the longest life expectancy at birth with Minnesotans the second longest, based on federal studies using 1980 data. Fredric Sattler, vice president at the Minneapolis-based Northwestern National, acknowledged that some people might be suspicious that Minnesota came out on top in a study conducted by a Minnesota company. But he defended the findings. ``We didn't know what we'd find until we ran the numbers,'' he said. The top 11 states were very close, Sattler added. ``I'm a bit surprised Minnesota tied for No. 1, but not shocked,'' said Paul Gunderson, chief of health statistics at the Minnesota Department of Health. ``I would have expected us to be in the top six. Minnesotans can feel very good about this, but there certainly is space for improvements'' Minnesotans scored in the bottom half of the national ranking in only one of the 17 categories: Acute-illness visits to the doctor. While Minnesota had the 41st highest rate of such visits, the report noted that the difference between the highest-ranked and lowest-ranked states was small. Sattler said a key aim of the study is to show where improvements can be made.
