DOC.TEXT: Here are some of Tuesday's quotes on the Iraq-Kuwait crisis:
``We would rather die than be humiliated, and we will pluck out the eyes of those who attack the Arab nation,'' _ President Saddam Hussein in a speech read by a Baghdad Radio announcer.

``I think the Soviet Union and the United States will solve this, but not by war. They will use public pressure. It's apparent that the Soviet Union and the United States have taken the humanitarian side,'' _ Lt. Gen. Vladislav Lisovsky, deputy commander of the Leningrad Military District.

``We need to get to get their military forces out of Kuwait. I think that is the most important thing now because they threaten Saudi Arabia. In doing that, though, we have to have the cooperation of the Saudis in terms of helping with the blockade or embargo _ and that cooperation itself makes it more likely the Iraqis will take some action,'' _ Sam Nunn, D-Ga.
``What is going on there affects the entire free world and it is appropriate NATO meet to discuss the overall implications,'' _ Margaret Tutwiler, State Department spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Brando's Son Pleads Innocent to Murder; Defense Seeks Lower Bail
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son pleaded innocent Tuesday to murdering his sister's lover and his lawyer asked to lower Christian Brando's $10 million bail. ``We are going to ask that Christian not be singled out and treated differently than anyone else would be in a similar situation,'' said attorney Robert L. Shapiro. An average prisoner in such a case would post between $50,000 and $100,000, he said. Superior Court Judge David Perez said he would consider the bail proposal at a hearing Thursday. Shapiro made the move to win freedom for his client after the 32-year-old Brando answered ``yes'' to a number of questions concerning his innocent plea to charges of first degree murder and possession of a machine gun. His case was moved to Superior Court after a Municipal Court judge found there was sufficient evidence to hold him for trial. The courtroom was jammed with spectators, friends of Brando, reporters and even tourists who wandered in from the beach hoping to get a glimpse of the defendant's famous father. But Marlon Brando, who has attended several previous hearings, didn't show. Prosecutors argued previously for no bail, saying if Brando is freed he may attempt to flee the country. Two weeks ago, another judge set the $10 million bail, taking into consideration his father's vast wealth. As a condition of the bail, the judge required that Brando surrender his passport but Brando maintains it was lost during a move from an apartment into his father's house. Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop noted then that Brando's 20-year-old half-sister, Cheyenne Brando, recently went to Tahiti. Officials say she is unwilling to return to testify at her brother's trial. Brando is accused of killing Miss Brando's 26-year-old Tahitian lover, Dag Drollet, during an argument May 16 at the Brando estate. Miss Brando gave birth June 30 in Tahiti to Drollet's son. Shapiro maintains that Christian Brando was drunk and the shooting was an accident that occurred when he and Drollet fought over a gun. He indicated Tuesday that would continue to be the defense.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush sending troops to Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs; Will stand for PMs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today ordered the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to help protect the oil-rich kingdom from Iraq, a Pentagon source said. A separate source said the deployment would be part of a multi-national force. The disclosure came as the White House said there was an ``imminent threat to Saudi Arabia,'' but would not confirm any military maneuvers. ``The U.S. government is prepared for eventualities and doing planning as appropriate,'' said spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. One report said some U.S. troops had been on the ground in Saudi Arabia for several hours. The United States was counting on Egyptian troops to join the international group aiding Saudi defense. Pentagon sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they expected Army troops from several points to be readied for movement to the Middle East, including airborne units from Ft. Bragg, N.C., as well as troops from Fort Stewart, Ga. and Fort Campbell, Ky. There was no immediate word on the size of the deployment. The airborne divisions will be used to secure air bases, so that other troops, aircraft and equipment can be sent in later, sources said. Aside from possible deployment of troops, the administration was exploring the possibility of an international blockade to choke off trade in and out of Iraq in an effort to reverse its invasion of Kuwait. One key source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Saudis had responded positively to Defense Secretary Richard Cheney's request that a multi-national military force _ including Americans _ be allowed into Saudi Arabia. President Bush twice ducked reporters' questions about the crisis in the Persian Gulf that has resulted in a swift run-up in domestic gasoline prices. ``Not going to take any questions today, thanks,'' he said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was wrapping up talks in Egypt that sources said focused on a coordinated military response to the Persian Gulf crisis, including the possibility of a multi-national ground force in Saudi Arabia as a ``trip wire'' against further Iraqi military moves. Pentagon sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said Cheney was seeking approval to move the aircraft carrier USS Eisenhower _ with its complement of sophisticated aircraft _ through the Suez Canal. Cheney, who stopped earlier in Saudi Arabia, was expected back in Washington on Wednesday. At the White House, Fitzwater said Bush had told his Cabinet earlier in the day ``that he views the Iraqi troops lined up in Kuwait facing Saudi Arabia as a threat to the United States security interests. ``That has been our message to Saudi Arabia and we believe that they understand that.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said an international naval blockade is ``very likely unless the Iraqis back off.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Secretary of State James A. Baker III, already planning a trip to Turkey on Wednesday, would go to NATO headquarters in Brussels on Friday to meet with allied foreign ministers. ``What is going on there affects the entire free world and it is appropriate NATO meet to discuss the overall implications,'' she said. The international campaign to implement a United Nations-backed trade embargo against Saddam gained ground when Turkey announced it had stopped tankers from loading Iraqi oil from the last operating pipeline through its country. But the Soviets urged caution: ``A buildup in the military presence and naval muscle-flexing in such a very tense and very complex situation is not the best line of action,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said in Moscow. The Bush administration said it would scrutinize the increase in gasoline prices at home since the Iraqi invasion, and three congressional committees conducted hearings on the topic. ``Saddam Hussein might not be the only greedy person in this picture,'' said Rep. Phil Sharp, D-Ind. Bush, who called Monday for ``full and total implementation'' of the United Nations-backed trade embargo, went to CIA headquarters later in the day for briefings on the Middle East and other matters. He again refused to respond to questions from reporters. Earlier, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater had said ``this blockade talk is premature'' and that the administration was committed to carrying out the trade embargo approved Monday. ``We expect them to work,'' Fitzwater said about the U.N. sanctions. The competing congressional hearings seemed designed to gain media attention as well as explore the increase in gasoline prices. Energy Department official John Easton told one session that oil supplies are at the highest level in nine years, and rebuffed suggestions that the administration tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in an attempt to bring down prices. As Iraq announced a 100,000-troop increase in its 1-million-member armed forces, the U.S. military moved aircraft carriers into position outside the Persian Gulf. Carriers are outfitted with a range of F-A18 Hornet jet fighters, F-14 Tomcat attack aircraft and A-6E Intruder bombers, including specially outfitted KA-6D jets to handle aerial refueling missions. Diplomatic contacts continued between Washington and Baghdad. U.S. officials were discussing with Iraq a plan to allow the departure of some of the estimated 500 Americans stranded in Baghdad, including some of the 50 Americans at the U.S. Embassy. The Washington Post quoted an unidentified administration official as saying Saddam warned the U.S. charge d'affaires, Joseph Wilson, that he wouldattack Saudi Arabia if his pipelines through that country are closed. But State Department sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, denied the published report. Fitzwater would not give details of Wilson's talks with Saddam or confirm that the Iraqi ruler had delivered such a warning. Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, said today that a naval blockade of Iraq is ``very likely unless the Iraqis back off and start moving out of Kuwait.'' ``We need to get to get their military forces out of Kuwait. I think that is the most important thing now because they threaten Saudi Arabia. In doing that, though, we have to have the cooperation of the Saudis in terms of helping with the blockade or embargo _ and that cooperation itself makes it more likely the Iraqis will take some action,'' the Georgia Democrat told CBS News. The aircraft carrier Saratoga was leaving Mayport, Fla., on a week-long voyage to the gulf region. The battleship Wisconsin was to leave Norfolk, Va., for the same area. They would join the carriers Independence and Eisenhower, which Pentagon sources said had moved within range to launch warplanes down the Persian Gulf to reach Iraqi targets.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Finds Merger Hard To Swallow
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department, suffering heartburn over a plan by the maker of Pepto-Bismol to acquire the exclusive sales rights for Maalox, filed suit Tuesday to stop the stomach-remedy alliance. The Justice Department sought a court injunction under the Clayton Anti-Trust Act to prevent Procter & Gamble Co., which makes Pepto-Bismol, from acquiring the exclusive rights to market and distribute Maalox. Court papers filed in federal court in Philadelphia charged that the proposed agreement between Procter & Gamble and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc., which makes Maalox, would lessen competition in the market of over-the-counter stomach remedies. Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, sold $125 million worth of Pepto-Bismol last year, or 14 percent of the domestic retail market. Domestic sales of Maalox totalled $111 million last year or 12 percent of the market. Under the proposal, Procter & Gamble would acquire the exclusive rights to market and sell Maalox and an option to purchase the manufacturing assets from Rhone-Pulenc Rorer, which is based in Ft. Washington, Pa. The deal would make Procter & Gamble the largest seller of stomach remedies in the U.S. market, according to the complaint.

DOC.HEAD: Proponents Say Use Wind, Sun, Trees To Replace Iraqi Oil
DOC.TEXT: The United States could get enough energy from the wind, sun, trees and rivers to eliminate dependence on oil imported from countries like Iraq, proponents of renewable energy said Tuesday. ``We should really have learned a lesson 17 years ago, when the first Arab oil embargo struck the United States in October 1973,'' Ken Bossong of the public interest group Public Citizen told a news conference. ``It is strategically dangerous and economically costly to rely on imported oil.'' Bossong urged state and federal government action to encourage increased use of wind power, solar energy and biomass to reduce oil consumption, thus diminishing reliance on imports. ``The cheapest, safest, cleanest option overall is simply improving energy efficiency,'' he said. Already, renewable sources account for about 10 percent of the energy produced in the United States, according to a Public Citizen study published in June. Nearly half comes from hydroelectric projects, but once-marginal projects like windmills, wood-fired generators and solar heaters are growing fast, it found. ``I think we could wean ourselves off fossil fuels if we had a commitment on the federal level,'' said Scott Sklar, director of the Solar Energy Industries Association, who also spoke at the news conference. Sklar said tougher environmental laws, a tax on carbon-dioxide producing fuels and other government initiatives could give renewable energy sources the boost they need to displace imported oil.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Pledges Help on Oil
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Ledes with 13 grafs Venezuelan pledge; picks up 3rd graf pvs: ``Security was,''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Colombia Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez promised Tuesday to do everything he could to make up crude oil supplies lost by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, a U.S. official said. The Venezuelan president also said other OPEC nations will try to add to supplies and push down prices, the official reported. This official is traveling with Vice President Dan Quayle, who conferred with Perez while both were in Bogota for the inauguration of Cesar Gaviria as president of Colombia. The official reported afterward, on condition of anonymity, that Perez had said, ``There will be no problem'' in making up for about 4.5 million barrels of oil a day that had been flowing from Iraq and Kuwait, roughly 10 percent of world supply now under an international embargo. Perez was quoted as telling Quayle that Venezuela would deliver an additional 500,000 barrels a day. He said that Venezuela and other OPEC states were working to stabilize oil prices at or near the cartel's reference price of $21 a barrel. The price has soared to $28 dollars a barrel and more since the invasion. Venezuela is a major oil producer, averaging 1.88 million barrels a day last year, or about what Kuwait supplied. Forty-six percent of Venezuela's output was sent to the United States. ``It's not good for anyone if there are rapid fluctuations,'' Perez was said to have told Quayle. The official said that Perez told Quayle he had been in constant communication with other OPEC nations since Saddam Hussein's thrust into Kuwait and that they agreed to make up shortages. No other nations were specified. ``This is welcome news,'' Quayle was quoted as telling Perez after a meeting and lunch at the Venezuelan Embassy. Quayle also conferred with Carlos Menem of Argentina, with Gaviria and with Brazilian officials attending the inauguration, urging that they join in withholding weapons and technology from Iraq. After a 5{-hour flight from Washington to a heavily guarded airfield outside the city, Quayle went by helicopter into Bogota to meet Gaviria at the Bogota bank building that houses his transition office. Security was tight at every step in the capital of a country that has been ravaged by drug-related violence. Gaviria entered the presidential race after a leading candidate was assassinated. ``I thank you for the gesture of coming,'' Gaviria told Quayle. ``We have the will always to have good relations with the United States.'' Quayle praised both Gaviria and outgoing president Virgilio Barco for the Colombian stand against drug trafficking. He also lauded the Colombians for sponsoring a United Nations resolution to punish the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait cannot stand, will not stand,'' Quayle told a news conference. He said Gaviria agreed with that. The inaugural ceremony was the first stop on Quayle's three-day trip to the Andean cocaine-producing nations, a follow-up to President Bush's February drug summit with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. ``I am here for this inauguration to show the strong importance the United States places on our continuing partnership with Colombia,'' Quayle said. The vice president said the partnership goes beyond drug-fighting activities to embrace trade and economic development. He added that U.S.-Colombian talks on a new trade agreement will begin by the first week in September. Amid signs of Colombian weariness with the violence stirred by the campaign against cocaine, Quayle said he anticipates the new administration will continue the fight begun by Barco. The vice president said he agreed with Gaviria that extradition of Colombian cocaine traffickers to face trial in the United States ``isn't the only answer'' to the cocaine problem. ``But it is part of an answer. We anticipate extradition will go forward and we think that it will,'' Quayle said. The extradition policy was launched by Barco as part of his drug-fighting initiative. It has provoked a violent reaction from the cocaine cartel.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Announce Plan For Limited Ruble Trade
DOC.TEXT: The government announced a plan Tuesday to let some businesses and organizations trade rubles for foreign currency at market rates in a step toward making the ruble convertible. The ruble is not traded on world foreign currency exchanges, and its convertibility is seen as essential to real economic reform in the Soviet Union. The action announced Tuesday would establish currency markets in the Soviet Union beginning Jan. 1, the official Tass news agency said. It said the Soviet Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, took the decision on Saturday. Legal enterprises and organizations _ but apparently not individuals _ would be permitted to buy and sell foreign currency in exchange for rubles at rates established by banks, currency auctions and other operations, Tass said. It did not say what the other operations would be or what other limits and controls would be placed on such markets. Currency auctions have been held in the Soviet Union in the past among some Soviet enterprises. Tass said the decision to set up a currency market was prompted by preparations for the Soviet Union's transition to a regulated market economy. The government's plan for such a transition is to go before the Soviet legislature next month. Tass did not say whether the government planned further devaluations of the ruble. The government last devalued the ruble on Nov. 1, 1989. It was devalued from $1.59 to 16 cents for travelers' cash exchanges. The higher rate remains on commercial transactions. Officials said then that the official rate of $1.59 was not realistic. On the black market, tourists can receive up to 20 times as many rubles for their convertible currency as in state bank outlets. Western economists say the ruble cannot become truly convertible until the Soviet Union establishes a market pricing system for all its goods and allows free cross-border trade. They also say it is not possible to have a convertible currency in a controlled market. ``Development of the market relations in the currency sphere will help to overcome tight limits of the principle of hard currency self-repayment, to make currency resources more easily available for all enterprises and organizations, and in advancing toward convertibility of the ruble,'' Tass said. Tass said the currency exchanges will be set up in Moscow as well as in other Soviet republics, with the Soviet State Bank controlling operations. On Aug. 1, Soviet citizens were given permission to spend foreign currency at special shops without telling the government where they got the money. In addition, a special network of stores is to be set up, where Soviet enterprises, as well as citizens, will be able to buy imported and domestic goods for hard currency.

DOC.HEAD: Council Prepares To Enforce Sanctions But Has Only Moral Force
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council began work on Tuesday to enforce the worldwide economic boycott it ordered against Iraq, but so far the only weapon in the U.N. arsenal is moral persuasion. The 15-member council began informal consultations on forming a committee to monitor compliance by the member states with the sanctions resolution adopted Monday. ``We already are in an enforcement mode,'' said a U.N. official. If the Security Council decides on military steps, it could call for an international blockade of Iraq to force Iraqi invaders to withdraw from Kuwait. But diplomats said Tuesday they hoped Iraq would heed international will and force would not be necessary. Like many of the sources, the diplomats and U.N. official spoke on condition of anonymity. Publication of a member's failure to comply with the sanctions is one of the strongest moves the United Nations can make, unless it votes to take military action. President Bush on Tuesday ordered deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to help protect the oil-rich kingdom from Iraq, a Pentagon source said. Iraq's increasingly isolated President Saddam Hussein has rejected foreign pressure to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. A separate source in Washington said the U.S. deployment would be part of a multinational force. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar cabled copies of the council's resolution to all 159 U.N. members Monday and informed them the sanctions were legally binding. He was expected to request soon that all members inform him in detail of steps they have taken to enforce the sanctions. He is to report to the council in 30 days. The United Nations has no means of enforcing the resolution and must rely on the good will of member states and international pressure. The resolution, one of the strongest ever adopted by the council, calls for a worldwide ban on oil purchases from Iraq; a general trade embargo; freezing of Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets, and a halt to all military arms sales and aid to Iraq. It asks member states to supply information requested about their trade, financial and military relations with Iraq. Canadian Ambassador L. Yves Fortier told the council Monday: ``The sanctions resolution would impose hardships on many countries, public and private organizations and individuals throughout the world. But sacrifices are necessary to maintain the peace and security of states and the integrity of the international system.'' The U.N. boycott of Iraq was only the third time since the world body was founded 45 years ago that the Security Council imposed sanctions on a member state. In 1977, an arms embargo was imposed on South Africa in an effort to force the government to dismantle apartheid. In 1967, the council imposed a comprehensive embargo against the white minority government of Rhodesia, which later became Zimbabwe. If sanctions don't work, the Security Council could meet again and call for international military action against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Ratings Controversy Spreads to Video Stores
DOC.TEXT: The rating controversy that hit the film industry two months ago is invading home video, bringing both worry and new opportunities to the videocassette business. Blockbuster Video, the nation's leading chain with 12 percent of video rentals, refuses to carry X-rated titles and won't take an R-rated version of ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover.'' A number of independent stores, facing labeling legislation, are concerned about the proliferation of unrated films. ``It will be impossible to distribute `Frankenhooker' in video stores if we can't get an R rating,'' James Glickenhaus, chairman of Shapiro Glickenhaus Entertainment, said Tuesday during the Video Software Dealers Association convention here. The film, which he called ``a horror comedy, not an adult film,'' was rated X by the Motion Picture Association of America. The rating is being appealed. Rhino Home Video, which will distribute the videocassette ``The Best of Comic Relief '90,'' fears some of the comedians' rough language in the video will yield rough sales. ``I think there are people who will get uptight about it,'' said Rhino vice president Arny Schorr. Because Comic Relief was first shown on cable's Home Box Office, it was not submitted to the MPAA and therefore bears no rating. ``The rating system works only for theatrical releases,'' Schorr said. Many small companies do not submit direct-to-video movies to the MPAA ratings board, which charges about $1,000 to rate films. According to the MPAA, 25 states are considering legislation aimed at making stores display cassette ratings. Titles with no ratings _ everything from Jane Fonda exercise tapes to low-budget slasher films like ``Three on a Meathook '' _ would have to carry no-rating stickers in most of those states. Vidmark Entertainment will release its controversial ``The Cook, the Thief'' in two versions _ unrated and R-rated. Company representatives say that Blockbuster Video won't take the R-rated version and has yet to decide on the unrated edition. For many filmmakers, the home video market gives them a chance to release their movies the way they intended, without making cuts needed for an R rating in theaters. According to Steven Apple, executive editor of the trade publication Video Insider, renters are likely to prefer the unrated versions of ``Angel Heart'' and ``Wild Orchid'' to the R-rated cuts of the same films. One company, 10th Avenue Video, is producing soft-core movies it hopes will satisfy customers in markets where adult films are either banned or hidden in a back corner. The company's new release, ``Intimate Lessons,'' is actually a more modest version of the hard-core film ``Veil.'' ``We want to ride the line on this,'' said 10th Avenue's Bill Nash. ``We want a husband and wife to watch this and not have the wife say, `Why did you bring this piece of trash home?''' The film about strippers, he said, can also be sold in mass-market stores that do not stock adult films. Turner Home Video, seeking to cut the cost of ratings and find more descriptive classifications, submits its video releases to the Film Advisory Board. In May, Spanish filmmaker Pedro Almodovar's film ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' attracted a storm of controversy before its release in this country. The MPAA ratings board recoiled at a graphic sex scene and dealt the film an X rating. An appeal failed to reverse the decision. FAB ratings include M for mature and AO for adults only. The FAB rating system, unlike the MPAA, describes content, too, listing degrees of nudity, violence and substance abuse. ``Treasure Island'' earned an F for family, as opposed to a C for children.

DOC.HEAD: Defiant Saddam Vows He Will Never Back Down
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A defiant Saddam Hussein vowed Tuesday that he will never back down despite growing international pressure to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. The Iraqi president said last week's invasion was meant to correct flawed borders drawn up by the colonial powers that left a corrupt minority in control of the Arabian Peninsula's rich oil reserves while the Arab masses suffered. He said he would reject any foreign pressure for him to pull his forces out of Kuwait. ``We would rather die than be humiliated, and we will pluck out the eyes of those who attack the Arab nation,'' Saddam said in a speech read by an annnouncer for Baghdad Radio, monitored in Nicosia. The speech reiterated much of the rhetoric Saddam has been using since first launching a blistering verbal attack against the Kuwaiti royal family July 17, two weeks before Thursday's invasion. The Kuwait invasion has ushered in ``a new period in which the sun will shine on us in the coming days,'' Saddam said. In his speech, Saddam apparently tried to play on the resentment felt by many poorer Arabs toward the oil-rich sheiks. Saddam said the colonial powers drew up the borders of Middle East nations to keep the population centers away from the region's wealth of natural resources. Britain and France were the main colonial powers who helped reshape the map of the Middle East after World War I eliminated Turkish dominance over the region. Saddam said the colonial powers left ``the minority with a vast amount of rich reserves of the area it did not own, while the majority fell in need.'' Due to their wealth, the minority made ``corrupt decisions'' in alliance with the West, which Saddam said was worse than falling under foreign occupation. Saddam said the Kuwaiti invasion carried on the tradition of Iraqi victories that started with the Gulf war with Iran in 1980-88. That war ended in a cease-fire in August 1988 and no peace treaty has been signed. More than 100,000 prisoners of war remain to be exchanged and the disputed Shatt al-Arab, Iraq's main outlet to the Gulf, remains blocked. Saddam has claimed the war as a major victory even though he did not gain control over the Shatt al-Arab, his initial objective in starting the war, or gain much territory from Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Continues Jamming Voice Of America Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has been jamming the Arabic-language broadcasts of the Voice of America for the past three days, the station announced Tuesday. The government-funded radio station said it will try to bypass the interruption by beaming its programs to Iraq through satellite television broadcasts starting Tuesday night. Iraqis can tune in to these radio broadcasts on their television sets if they have a satellite dish or access to one through a local TV station. VOA's Deputy Director Robert Coonrod said many Iraqis have such access. Iraq is also jamming the BBC's Arabic-language radio programs from England, Coonrod said. The English-language programs of the VOA and BBC have not been blocked, he said. The jamming affects all VOA's broadcasts to the Middle East, including the Persian Gulf and Jordan, he said. Egypt is partly affected, too. VOA is increasing the number of hours it broadcasts in Arabic to the Middle East, from seven and a-half daily to nearly 10, and replacing the music programs with more news, Coonrod said. The broadcasts have been heavy on news about the Iraqi invasion of Kuwaiti and international efforts to punish President Saddam Hussein. ``We want Iraqis to have accurate, uncensored information,'' Coonrod said. Iraq is a police state, and the media is government-controlled and severely restricted. Satellite transmissions, too, can be jammed. But experts say Iraq would need to jam the entire Indian Ocean satellite in order to block VOA. VOA officials hope the experiment with Iraq succeeds as it did in China last summer, after Chinese authorities jammed the VOA's short and medium-wave broadcasts during Beijing's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. Coonrod said Iraq is using a type of sophisticated technique called ``bubble jamming'' which was used to block radio programs from Iran during the eight-year war between the two countries.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Palestinian Group Says It Will Free Swiss Hostages in 24 Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with photo of captive accompanying statement, demands said to be met, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A group calling itself the Palestine Revolutionary Squads said Tuesday it will release within 24 hours two Swiss hostages of the International Committee of the Red Cross. The previously unknown faction made the announcement in a handwritten Arabic language statement delivered to the independent Beirut newspaper An-Nahar shortly before midnight Tuesday. The 10-line statement was accompanied by an instant, color photograph of Swiss captive Emmanuel Christen, 32. The close-up showed him with a short beard and moustache. The other hostage is Elio Erriquez, 23. The two were kidnapped on Oct. 6, 1989 in Sidon, the provincial capital of south Lebanon. No group had previously claimed responsibility for their abduction. The statement said the decision to free the Red Cross captives came in response to the wishes of President Hafez Assad of Syria, Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi and President Chadli Bendjedid of Algeria. It also said the group had guarantees that its demands would be met, but did not specify what the demands were. An earlier report had said no picture accompanied the statement. Police in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, had blamed the abduction of Christen and Erriquez on the Libyan-financed Fatah-Revolutionary Council faction, led by notorious Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal. The group denied it. The Abu Nidal group has been reported undergoing bloody internal purges over the past year. The two Swiss captives are among 16 foreigners held hostage in Lebanon. The others are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. Longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was seized in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Two American hostages _ educators Frank Herbert Reed and Robert Polhill _ were released eight days apart in April. This is the text of Tuesday's statement: ``After we acquired guarantees that our demands will be met, and in response to the wishes of the Syrian command personified by the president, Field Marshal Hafez Assad, the leader of the September 1 revolution, brother Col. Moammar Gadhafi and Algerian president Chadli Bendjedid that the two International Red Cross delegates we hold be released, and after expressing our gratitude for the efforts exerted by them to fulfill the demands we presented, the organization of the Palestinian Revolutionary squads announces that it has decided to free the two Swiss prisoners within the next 24 hours. ``Victory shall be for the revolution, ``The Palestinian Revolutionary Squads.''

DOC.HEAD: Low Temp Records Fall; Rivers Rise
With AM-Record Lows
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures cooled to record lows across the center of the nation Tuesday, and heavy rain caused flooding in the Northeast. The record lows, mostly in the 50s and 60s, were reported in Texas, New Mexico, Illinois, Ohio, Indiana, Arkansas, Kansas, West Virginia, Alabama, Missouri, Kentucky, Michigan, Tennessee, and Colorado. Marquette, Mich., on the shore of Lake Superior, chilled to 38 degrees. At the opposite extreme, Pocatello, Idaho, warmed to a record-tying high of 99. Showers with occasional thunderstorms spread rain Tuesday over the central Atlantic coast, Florida, and southwestern Texas. Because of heavy rain Monday and overnight in the Northeast, there was flooding on some smaller streams in Berkshire County in western Massachusetts, Mass. The upper Housatonic River was out of its banks near Pittsfield. The Hackensack was flooding near Nyack, N.Y., and the Mahwah River was out of its banks at Suffern, N.Y. Many streams also ran high in the Hudson Valley in Vermont. The center of hurricane Diana was located near Tuxpan, Mexico, by afternoon. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 34 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 60 at Ruidoso, N.M., to 107 at Lemoore Naval Air Station, Calif.
