DOC.HEAD: German Leaders Choose Showdown over Compromise on Unity Date
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the two Germanys and their political rivals opted for a parliamentary showdown rather than a compromise Tuesday to determine the exact date of German unity. As politicians feuded over whether unity in September or October would best help the beleaguered East Germans, a senior official warned that East German economy is falling into ``chaos'' and conditions will only get worse. Reiner Gohlke, who is overseeing East Germany's economic reform attempts, was quoted by the East German newspaper Neue Zeit as saying: ``The situation is worse than I had thought. We have chaos. Nothing is running normally.'' A major lobbying group, the West German Association of Industry and Trade, demanded that unity come ``as soon as possible'' before East Germany's economy collapses. ``Every day of divided political responsibility in both parts of Germany prolongs'' troubles in East Germany, it said in a statement. East Germany, meanwhile, announced that joblessness nearly doubled within a month, spiraling to 272,017. Deteriorating economic and social conditions in East Germany are central to the political dispute in both German states over when unity and all-German elections should occur. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday rejected demands by the opposition Social Democrats that the two countries merge by Sept. 15 and elections for an all-German parliament be held on Dec. 2. Kohl told reporters after meeting Social Democratic leaders he will not budge from his plan for all-German elections and simultaneous unity on Oct. 14. He said his East German Christian Democratic allies, led by Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, will propose a parliamentary resolution on Wednesday supporting unity and elections on Oct. 14. On Thursday, his own coalition will make a similar proposal in the Bundestag, West Germany's parliament, he added. East Germany's Social Democrats, who are in de Maiziere's coalition, plan to offer their own measure on Wednesday calling for German unity by Sept. 15 and elections later. Richard Schroeder, parliamentary chief of the East German Social Democrats, told reporters in East Berlin his party and de Maiziere were in ``insurmountable disagreement.'' In Bonn, Kohl said he still plans to seek a change in West Germany's constitution to allow elections on Oct. 14. Under constitutional constraints, Dec. 2 would be the earliest for new elections. But Kohl needs Social Democratic support for the two-thirds parliamentary majority he needs for a constitutional change, and that opposition party swears he will not get his two-thirds. Both sides claim their respective unity and elections time proposals are best for helping out troubled East Germany. The Social Democrats claim Kohl wants the earlier election date because he fears voters will turn against him as East Germany's economy erodes. Kohl says separating unity from elections could have bad psychological effects on East Germans, who want the two to occur simultaneously.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Inner City School Choice Program
DOC.TEXT: As many as 1,000 poor city students could be enrolled in private schools with state money this fall, say supporters who won a court challenge of the nations' first school voucher plan. However, opponents, including Wisconsin's top education offical, said they'd appeal the ruling before the program takes effect this fall. Dane County Circuit Judge Susan Steingass on Monday ruled the program was legal because it aims to improve education ``to the benefit of the entire state,'' thereby filling the ``public purpose'' requirement of Wisconsin's Constitution. The program, approved by the Legislature and signed by Gov. Tommy Thompson last spring, provides up to $2,500 in state money per pupil to let poor Milwaukee schoolchildren attend non-sectarian private schools. This year's budget includes funding _ to be deducted from the city's school budget _ for 1,000 students, who would receive vouchers from the state. Milwaukee has about 97,000 students. The average yearly tuition to a Milwaukee private school is about $3,200. State School Superintendent Herbert Grover and the Wisconsin Education Association Council, the state's largest teachers' union, said the program undermines public education and that private schools are not fully accountable to the state. Grover, the union and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a lawsuit seeking to block the subsidies. Steingass said Grover exceeded his authority in devising requirements for participating private schools and ordered him to carry out the Legislature's intent. Grover said Tuesday he was disappointed with the ruling but anticipated it would be appealed. The union's president also said an appeal was likely. ``We're going to have two school systems in this state and both paid for by public money,'' he said. ``One will have accountability and one won't.'' However, the program's sponsor called the ruling a victory for parents and students. ``This is the right thing to do. We are trying to save our children that our dying right now because the Milwaukee Public Schools are not doing their job,'' said Rep. Polly Williams. ``The children are going to be in these schools this year,'' she said. About 10 private schools in Milwaukee, with students in kindergarten through eighth grade, would participate in the program. They were deluged with student applicants, she said. One of the participants, Urban Day School, accepted about 100 student transfers but had to reject another 200 because of a lack of room, Executive Director Zakiya Courtney said Tuesday. `There's some disappointment for parents whose children could not get in the school,'' Ms. Courtney said. ``But those parents who did get are elated because now their children have the same opportunity that others have had but they could not afford in the past.''

DOC.HEAD: Former S&L Chairman Charged
DOC.TEXT: The former chairman of a failed Texas savings and loan association has been charged with embezzling more than $4 million after purchasing a controlling interest in the thrift in 1985, according to an indictment unsealed Tuesday. Alan Ross Rothery, a California attorney and former chairman of Trinity Valley Savings and Loan Association of Cleveland, Texas, was accused of bank fraud, embezzlement, self-dealing and giving false information to a federal bank examiner. Each count carries a five-year sentence and a possible $250,000 fine. The indictment, returned Aug. 2 by a federal grand jury in Beaumont, Texas, was unsealed in court Tuesday. It accuses Rothery and two California businessman, Errol Coughlan, of Malibu, and John Coughlan Jr., of Long Beach, of participating in a scheme to fraudulently divert loan proceeds. The brothers were accused of aiding and abetting the fraudulent loan diversion. They also were charged with making false statements on loan applications and participating in a separate bank-fraud scheme to divert funds to their own use. On July 24, the Coughlans were named in a 17-count fraud indictment returned in Los Angeles that accuses them of defrauding a number of financial institutions. The Texas thrift was taken over by federal regulators in March 1989 and sold Oct. 6, 1989, to Hibernia National Bank in Texas, regulators said. The loss to the government for insured deposits and speculative loans is expected to reach $33 million, the Justice Department said. Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said Trinity Valley is on the agency's list of top 100 S&Ls that were referred to the Justice Department for criminal prosecutions. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement that ``the alleged scheme whereby Rothery acquired ownership of Trinity Valley and manipulated the institution's loan proceeds to satisfy his own greed is a textbook example of criminal fraud in our nation's thrift industry.''

DOC.HEAD: 78 Foreigners Arrive in Amman from Iraq
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jet carrying 78 foreigners and some Iraqis arrived here Tuesday, the first commercial flight allowed out of Iraq since it invaded Kuwait, a Japanese embassy spokesman said. No Americans were on the flight. Thousands of Westerners remain stranded in Kuwait and Iraq since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said Iraq has offered to allow Britons in Baghdad on short-term visas to leave. It was not clear if the offer included several hundred foreigners rounded up in Kuwait and taken to Iraq, including Americans, Britons, West Germans and a Spaniard. Those rounded up included 350 passengers on a British Airways flight bound for Malaysia that was caught in the unrest in Kuwait. A British Airways spokeswoman said a ``substantial'' number of those passengers arrived safely in Baghdad on Monday. Among the passengers were 28 Americans, who also turned up in a Baghdad hotel and appear to be fine, a U.S. official said in Washington. ``We do not know what is happening to people after they arrive in Baghdad,'' said the British Airways spokeswoman. Thirty-four British servicemen and an oil field worker picked up in Kuwait over the weekend are being held in Baghdad. The Iraqi offer appeared to apply only to tourists and businessmen but not to British residents in Iraq, said the Foreign Office spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. The spokesman added they were trying to confirm and clarify the Iraqi offer. Those allowed to leave would probably travel through Jordan, which has told the Foreign Office that it would receive people and grant them visas. ``We are making preparations to receive a huge number of people,'' said one Jordanian official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Until Tuesday, there had been no indication of what plans Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has for foreigners in occupied Kuwait or Iraq. Iraq's ambassador to Greece, Abdel Fatah Al Khereji, said Tuesday, ``any foreigners in Kuwait who wish to leave ... can do so by land from Iraq through Turkey or Jordan.'' The first large group of foreigners to arrive from Baghdad were those on board the Iraqi Airways flight, which arrived at Queen Alia International Airport, 30 miles south of Amman, the Jordanian capital, at 6:15 p.m., the Japanese diplomat said. Most of the foreigners on the flight were Japanese tourists who were visiting Iraq, the diplomat said. Also on board the Boeing 727 jetliner were two Belgians, a Spaniard, a Dutchman, an Italian, as well as 34 members of an Iraqi soccer team, he said. ``We are very happy that we are in Jordan,'' said Masyi Yoshiko, a computer clerk from Tokyo. ``It was very difficult for me to be in a country at war.'' Ms. Yoshiko, 42, said the group did not feel threatened at all after Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait on Thursday, but were not allowed to leave their hotel for five days. ``We enjoyed our stay in the hotel,'' she said. ``Iraqi people were not bad. The people and police were very good with us.'' The embassy spokesman said the plane was supposed to fly on to Vienna after refueling, but the Austrian government denied landing rights. The U.N. Security Council on Monday voted sanctions that impose a ban on trade and financial contacts with Iraq. Hundreds of foreigners are expected to flood into Jordan in the next two days once Iraqi authorities ease travel restrictions for foreigners stranded by the invasion. Iraq's borders and airports were completely closed. The only people to escape from Kuwait since Saturday used obscure desert routes into Saudi Arabia. A Kuwaiti businessman said about 1,000 people a day were fleeing Kuwait through the desert to Saudi Arabia. The businessman, who arrived in London on a British Airways flight from Bahrain today, said Kuwaitis and expatriates, including Westerners, were joining convoys to escape the Iraqi forces. Earlier Tuesday, Jordan's information minister, Ibrahim Izzedine, said the U.S. government had asked Jordan to facilitate the entrance from Iraq of American diplomats and their dependents. U.S. Embassy officials said about 12 diplomats in addition to their dependents are expected to arrive in Jordan from Iraq on Wednesday. The ``provisional government of free Kuwait'' set up by Iraq had threatened Sunday to hold hostage citizens of countries imposing sanctions on it. Kuwait's ambassador in London said that despite the Iraqi assurances about allowing foreigners to leave, Iraq might choose to hold some Westerners as a bargaining chip. ``He (Saddam) will choose some to keep,'' said Ambassador Ghazi Al-Rayes said. ``He can't afford to keep 5,000 or 10,000 hostages. He will keep Americans, Europeans, whatever nationalities he thinks are valuable. ``Maybe he will behave like anyone who hijacks a plane. He has hijacked a country.'' A U.S. diplomat said Washington had instructed ``American citizens living in or visiting Iraq and Kuwait to leave when circumstances permit.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq Bjt
Besides Multinational Force, Naval Quarantine Seen as Option
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with U.S. action in top 6 grafs, picking up in 7th graf pvs, Engage the
DOC.TEXT: A naval blockade to sever Iraq's oil lifeline may be the best hope for pushing Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, but it would require hundreds of ships and perhaps months of enforcement, military experts said Tuesday. Meanwhile, government sources said President Bush was dispatching American warplanes and ground troops to Saudi Arabia where they were to be joined by forces from Egypt and Morocco in an effort to discourage Iraq from pushing on into Kuwait's larger neighbor. While that move was being made and talk continued of a United Nations-sanctioned blockade by U.S., European and perhaps Soviet forces, other more drastic and risky military options were available, experts said. Among the options: _Launch air strikes on Iraqi oil fields. Iraq's economy is built on oil. Destroying the oil production facilities would be tantamount to destroying the economy. _Bomb troop supply lines in southern Iraq. The purpose would be to isolate the 100,000-man Iraqi occupation force in Kuwait by preventing supplies and reinforcements from crossing the border. _Engage the Iraqis in a full-scale air and land battle in Kuwait and Iraq. Experts say this would be highly costly and would risk starting an Arab-Israeli war. The U.N. Security Council voted 13-0 on Monday to impose a worldwide ban on trade with Iraq. Bush hinted afterward that he was prepared to order a naval blockade to enforce that embargo if Iraq finds a way to circumvent it. ``These sanctions will be enforced, no matter what it takes,'' Bush said Monday. Vice Adm. Henry C. Mustin, a recently retired deputy chief of naval operations, said in an interview that an international naval blockade of Iraq's three main oil outlets _ in the Mediterranean Sea, the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea _ would be the best military option so long as Saddam has not invaded Saudi Arabia. Mustin added, however, that a blockade would run the risk of triggering actual combat. ``A blockade is an act of war. To effect a blockade you have to enforce it,'' he said. If the United States set a blockade on its own the operation ``would take probably most of the U.S. Navy,'' meaning several hundred ships and tens of thousands of sailors, Mustin said. Reconnaissance aircraft would be needed to ensure that tankers in the gulf not carrying Iraqi or Kuwaiti oil actually arrived at their stated destinations. A joint operation with European allies would be more effective, Mustin said. The Washington Post reported Tuesday that the Pentagon had proposed an international blockade that would include Soviet ships, but a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said, ``I don't think that we are thinking about such an idea.'' The United States has two aircraft carrier groups in the gulf area and a third on the way. It also has a group of eight naval ships inside the gulf. Britain has one ship in the gulf and two more due by week's end. On Tuesday a French naval destroyer sailed into the Suez Canal enroute to the gulf by way of the Red Sea. Journalists in helicopters reported spotting a Soviet destroyer nearing the Straits of Hormuz, the narrow entrance to the gulf from the Arabian Sea. Gen. Jack Merritt, recently retired from the Army and a former U.S. representative to NATO's highest military council, said he doubted that either a naval blockade or carrier-based air strikes against Iraqi economic targets would be enough. Of the chances of dislodging the Iraqi army from Kuwait with air power alone Merritt said, ``Just forget it.'' Merritt said that if Bush's goal is to deter Saddam from striking at Saudi Arabia the administration should already be moving ground and air forces into the gulf area from Western Europe. The United States has no military bases in the area. In the event the 1 million-strong Iraqi army moved on Saudi Arabia, the United States would be compelled to engage in a ground war, Merritt said. That would require perhaps 500,000 U.S. troops, plus large numbers of attack aircraft and bombers, he said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said Tuesday that in addition to preparing for a possible naval blockage of Iraq, the Bush administration should be trying to persuade Egypt or other Arab nations to participate in a multinational ground force deterrent in Saudi Arabia. ``I think it's enormously important this not simply be a Saudi-U.S. operation,'' Nunn told CBS News. ``We need our allies involved, but the Saudis also need the indigenous Arab forces that will come to their aid.'' Nunn's counterpart in the House, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said sending U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia as a tripwire, or deterrent force, would a ``high risk'' option, one that would mean an American commitment to all-out war with Iraq. ``The message to Mr. Hussein would be, `If you attack those American troops, right along that line, I mean that is war right to the end'.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department, Senators Voice Concern About Democracy, Bhutto Safety
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Tuesday voiced concern about any interruption of democracy in Pakistan and said it expects the new military-backed caretaker government to carry out promised October elections. Four Democratic senators including Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell strongly criticized Monday's dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto by Pakistan's president and said they are concerned about the safety of Ms. Bhutto and her family. In dismissing Ms. Bhutto, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan announced new parliamentary elections for Oct. 24. ``We expect they will take place,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters. ``We strongly support democracy taking root in Pakistan, and we are concerned about any action that would interrupt that process,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, adding, ``we are watching this closely because we are concerned.'' The statement of U.S. concern went beyond the State Department's initial reaction Monday calling Prime Minister Bhutto's dismissal ``an internal matter for the people of Pakistan to decide.''

DOC.HEAD: Secord Takes Stand in Hasenfus Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Richard Secord, who ran the illegal Contra supply network for Oliver North, testified Tuesday that the State Department and the CIA were briefed on the operation several times. Secord and Miami-based Southern Air Transport are being sued by Eugene Hasenfus of Marinette, Wis., the only survivor of the October 1986 cargo plane crash in Nicaragua that helped expose the network supplying Nicaraguan rebels. Secord, who pleaded guilty to lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra scandal and is serving probation, took the stand as a hostile witness for Hasenfus. He quickly sought to play down his control over the network and its finances. Secord said he ran the operation ``in conjunction with the White House and some private companies.'' When Congress moved toward again granting lethal aid to the Contras in the fall of 1986, it was decided to turn the private supply operation over to the CIA, he said. ``It was my understanding that there were several interagency meetings, including the State Department and the CIA,'' Secord testified. He sparred with Hasenfus attorney Brian Strange over his control of Swiss bank accounts through which money from the Iran arms sale was funneled to the supply operation. Strange read Secord his 1987 congressional testimony saying he had verbal control over the accounts. Secord eventually conceded that point. But he bristled when asked if he was to keep the profits left in those accounts when the government took over later in 1986. ``I don't think I've ever taken that position,'' he said, although he agreed the ``enterprise'' would keep whatever money remained. After a lunch break, Strange asked Secord if within the past month he had transferred $92,000 from the sale of spare Contra supply plane parts to his personal account. After the judge overruled objections to the question, Secord responded, ``Yes.'' ``My attorneys offered to settle,'' Secord said before Senior U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins interrupted him. Secord apparently referred to meetings before the trial in which the two sides attempted to reach a settlement. Atkins has ruled that Strange may refer to Secord's conviction to attack his credibility, and Strange did. Secord had pleaded guilty to lying to congressional investigators about money North received from the enterprise. Jurors, who are allowed to ask questions through the judge, wanted to know why Secord did not pay death benefits to the family of co-pilot Wallace Sawyer Jr., even though he controlled the bank accounts. Secord said he had ordered his attorney to do so but the congressional investigation into the case frightened the lawyer, who never made the payment. Hasenfus' attorney zeroed in on that question, noting that Secord had ordered $250,000 paid to Southern Air Transport a year later, yet had chosen not to pay the victims' families. ``You're quite wrong,'' an angry Secord responded. ``You can put any kind of gloss on it you want.'' Secord retired as an Air Force general in 1983 and shortly afterward was recruited by North, a National Security Council aide working out of the White House, to run the network at a time Congress had banned lethal aid to the Contras. Hasenfus and Sawyer's family of Magnolia, Ark., say Secord ran the operation and is responsible for misleading the crews and using shoddy equipment that led to their plane being shot down by a Nicaraguan rocket. Hasenfus parachuted to safety, and was held captive by Nicaragua's Sandinista government for three months before being released. Secord has said he never met Hasenfus or Sawyer. Southern Air has denied involvement with the Hasenfus flight and claims Hasenfus and Sawyer worked for Corporate Air Services, a separate company. The two families have listed actual damages of just under $4 million, but that does not include distress or punitive damages.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Asks End of Anti-trust Immunity
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Tuesday urged the withdrawal of a longstanding immunity of U.S. airlines from anti-trust laws that allows the companies to fix fares to and from this country. The department's anti-trust division made the recommendation in comments filed with the Transportation Department, which is considering whether to extend the anti-trust immunity for the International Air Transport Association. IATA's members, who include American and foreign airlines, set international air fares under an anti-trust immunity that the organization has enjoyed since 1946. The Federal Aviation Act allows the granting of such anti-trust exemptions to further ``international comity'' or other foreign policy interests. The Justice Department said that ``when persons affected by price fixing are U.S. consumers and the airlines involved are U.S. carriers, the U.S. interest is clearly paramount.'' It urged the Transportation Department to review on a country-by-country basis the anti-trust immunity give foreign-owned carriers to fix fares on flights to and from the United States. ``Immunity for IATA appears particularly unwarranted in those markets where the involved foreign government does not actively support or favor cartel pricing,'' the Justice Department said, noting that European Common Market nations are pushing for increased airline competiton. ``Many Americans may not realize that the prices of their airline tickets for travel abroad are set by what is in efect a legalized international cartel,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. ``Lower fares and better service are what we seek,'' the attorney general said. ``With so many of the countries of the world now recognizing the benefits of competitive free-market economies, we should not continue to grant blanket immunity to a multilateral cartel, but should address the needs and concerns of individual foreign governments on a case-by-case basis,'' Thornburgh said. Now that airline deregulation has promoted competition on domestic flights, ``there is a strong interest in protecting consumers when they travel on U.S. carriers from the United States to foreign countries,'' said James F. Rill, assistant attorney general for anti-trust.

DOC.HEAD: Architect of Modern Corporate Buildings Dead
DOC.TEXT: Gordon Bunshaft, whose designs for glass and steel office towers helped form a style of modern corporate architecture, died after a brief illness, his firm said Wednesday. He was 81. Bunshaft, a retired partner in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, died of cardiac arrest at his home in Manhattan on Monday. Bunshaft's first big project, Lever House, was also his most famous. The 24-story, blue-green office building constructed in 1952 introduced the sleek International Style to Manhattan's Park Avenue, then lined by traditional masonry buildings. Architecture critic Wolf Von Eckardt called Lever House ``the proud proclamation of a new era,'' and it helped make Skidmore one of the nation's leading design firms. Lever House was designated a New York City landmark in 1982, the first structure of its kind to win that designation. Bunshaft also designed a number of other Manhattan office towers, including the Manufacturer's Hanover Trust building, the PepsiCo building and the headquarters of the Chase Manhattan Bank. The latter brought modernism to the financial district, as Lever House had to Park Avenue. Bunshaft's designs outside New York included the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library in Austin, Texas, the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, and his last and most elaborate project, the National Commercial Bank in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. The latter, a triangular-shaped building 27 stories high with no apparent front or back, ``is so abstract that it is impossible to judge its actual size except upon close examination,'' noted The New York Times. ``It barely reads as a building.'' In 1988 Bunshaft was awarded the Pritzker Prize for architecture in recognition of his early designs. He also was a member of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters and a fellow of the American Institute of Architects. Bunshaft is survived by his wife, Nina.

DOC.HEAD: Stark Apologizes To Sullivan Over Racial Remark
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Pete Stark apologized to Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan for calling him a ``disgrace to his race'' last week, spokesmen said on Tuesday. Neither Sullivan nor Stark's office would release the text of the letter of apology delivered Monday night. ``He did apologize,'' said Bob Shemermund, a spokesman for Sullivan. Stark's remark last week infuriated Sullivan, the only black member of President Bush's Cabinet, who called the statement ``incomprehensibly offensive.'' Stark, who said the intended target of his criticism was Bush administration policies he believes harm blacks and the poor, said on the House floor afterward, ``I blew it.'' Sullivan did not take that as an apology. He did take the letter that way, but did not send a reply, Schmermund said. In a speech Tuesday, Sullivan said ``he accepted the apology and considered the incident closed,'' Schmermund said. Perry Plumart, a spokesman for Stark, refused to discuss the contents of the letter.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Said To Fear Iraqi Threat If Saddam Is Not Reined In
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens called Tuesday for stronger Western measures against Iraq in a speech underscoring growing nervousness here over the invasion of Kuwait by the Jewish state's most formidable Arab foe. Arens' speech to Parliament was made before President Bush ordered U.S. troops and warplanes to the front line Tuesday to guard Saudi Arabia against Iraq. Other officials said Israel would favor a U.S.-led naval blockade to bring an end to the Gulf conflict. In an early reaction here to the latest U.S. move, Ron Ben-Ishai, political analyst and journalist for the Yediot Ahronot newspaper, said on Israel army radio: ``This is not completely suprising. It was expected that the U.S. would want to land soldiers in Saudi Arabia but what was not expected was that the Saudis would agree so quickly. ... If it is true, it is indeed a extraordinary change ... in Saudi policy, that needed great courage, because they will (have to) deal with the results if the Americans don't succeed.'' Other analysts said earlier that considerable concern existed in Israel that unless Saddam was reined in, the unpredictable Iraqi president could pose a direct threat to Israel. They noted Saddam's warnings this spring that he would torch half of Israel with binary chemical weapons if Iraq ever came under attack by Israel. Saddam was accused of using chemical arms against Kurdish rebels at home and against Iranian forces during his eight-year war with Iran. ``Unfortunately the international community didn't take any action after he used chemical weapons and threatened to attack Israel with chemical weapons,'' Arens said. ``Nations of the world have a capability to influence Iraq. The nations of the world can prove that aggression doesn't pay. And that Iraq will pay the heaviest price for attacks staged by its leaders.'' Arens warned that ``Saddam Hussein is liable not to suffice with Kuwait just as he didn't suffice with his attack on Iran,'' in September 1980 which led to a war that went on until 1988. ``He has a big army and limitless aspirations,'' Arens said of Saddam. Arens reiterated that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last Thursday ``doesn't constitute a geostrategic change for Israel. But the moment we detect such a change like the entry of Iraqi forces into Jordan, we will act.'' Jordan has a long border with Israel. King Hussein of Jordan, facing serious economic and political problems, has lately forged an alliance with Saddam. In February, Jordan and Iraq announced formation of a joint air force training squadron. Arens said Israel was closely watching developments in Kuwait. ``We will know to defend our interests and security,'' he concluded. Moshe Shahal, a former Cabinet minister of the left-of-center Labor Party, said of Saddam: ``If he has a problem with the Arabs, that's his problem. But if someone messes with us, we know how to settle an account. And you, Saddam Hussein, will bring a Holocaust on yourself and your people because Israel is not Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Reax: U.S. Deployment Will Strengthen Saudis But Not End Occupation
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Early foreign reaction Tuesday to the dispatch of U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia described it as certain to strengthen the Saudis, but unlikely to bring a swift end to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. ``I think that this is an obvious step that has to be taken if Iraq is to be deterred from some move forward in Saudi Arabia...,'' said Sir John Moberly, a former British ambassador to Iraq who is now with the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London. ``It is a protective measure,'' he said in a television interview. ``But I agree that to get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait is a very different question, and it's a very long haul.'' In The Hague, a Dutch government official predicted the deployment of U.S. forces would bring a substantial ``de-escalation'' of the tense situation in the Persian Gulf. Because of the move, ``We're pretty much drifting toward a kind of stalemate,'' said the official, who declined to be identified by name. ``The world is now going to wait until shortages develop in Iraq and then we'll be able to find an elegant way out for Saddam Hussein,'' the source said. In Israel, political analyst Ron Ben-Ishai of the newspaper Yediot Ahronot said on Israel army radio: ``This is not completely suprising. It was expected that the U.S. would want to land soldiers in Saudi Arabia, but what was not expected was that the Saudis would agree so quickly. ``If it is true, it is indeed an extraordinary change ... it is an extraordinary change in Saudi policy, that needed great courage, because they will deal with the results if the Americans don't succeed.''

DOC.HEAD: Combat Units Readying for Gulf are Part of Rapid Deployment Force
With AM-US-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The Army units readying for duty in Saudi Arabia are part of the nation's rapid deployment force, a contingent of air and land forces created during the Carter administration to respond to a Middle East crisis. Pentagon sources said Tuesday that President Bush had ordered elements of the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky.; the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga., and the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said elements of those three units would be deployed with the 18th Airborne Corps, a command and control unit at Fort Bragg that directs operations of the three combat divisions. The Bush administration declined to confirm the deployment plan, which sources said was designed as part of a multinational deterrent force to be placed in Saudi Arabia as a warning to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein not to attack the desert kingdom. It could not be learned whether parts or all of the three divisions would participate in the operation. The 82nd Airborne Division, with 12,000 soldiers, is paratroop divison, one of the Army's elite units ever since World War II. It has three brigades, with three battalions in each brigade. Each battalion is equipped with 20 TOW anti-tank weapons. The 101st Airborne Division, with about 15,400 troops, includes two attack battalions armed with 18 AH-64 Apache helicopters and 18 AH-1 Cobra anti-tank helicopters. Also included are two assault helicopter battalions, each with 45 Blackhawk helicopters. Its soldiers are not paratroopers, and are carried into battle by helicopters. The division also has one medium lift helicopter battalion equipped with 18 CH-47 Chinook helicopters, and one air cavalry squadron, which performs air reconnaissance with 12 AH-1 Cobra helicopters and 12 OH-58 observation helicopters. The 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) has 16,600 soldiers and is composed of two active combat brigades and one in the Georgia National Guard. The active brigades include three M-1 tank battalions, each with 58 tanks, and three infantry battalions, each with 54 Bradley fighting vehicles. The Bradleys double as personnel carriers. The 24th also has two active artillery battalions equipped with 155mm self-propelled artillery, and one active battalion equipped with nine multiple-launch rocket systems. The air power of the 24th includes one company of 15 UH-60 Blackhawk troop transport helicopters and one company of about 18 AH-1 Cobra anti-tank helicopters.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Cabinet, Premier Resign In Routine Procedure
DOC.TEXT: Bulgarian Premier Andrei Lukanov and his Cabinet resigned Tuesday to allow the country's new president to choose his own cabinet, the state BTA news agency reported. The action took place a week after Parliament elected Zhelyu Zhelev the first non-Communist president in more than four decades, BTA reported. Lukanov, a 51-year-old multilingual economist and a former moderate Communist, was elected premier in February. BTA said he was likely to continue as premier, heading a new Cabinet to be chosen at a four-day parliament session that opened Tuesday. The new government is expected to include independent experts and possibly members of the democratic opposition as well as of Lukanov's Socialist party, formerly the Communists. The former Communist party won free elections in June but has lost power steadily since then. Lukanov has repeatedly said he does not want to head an all-Socialist cabinet. Lukanov submitted his cabinet's resignation, as mandated by the constitution, to Parliament president Nikolai Todorov, BTA said. ``The Bulgarian economy is in a general crisis ... the shortage of all basic (commodities) is growing,'' BTA quoted Lukanov as telling Parliament in a speech. ``The internal (trade) imbalance has become so acute now that the country's market is actually threatened by disintegration,'' the former premier said. Lukanov cited a drop in industrial output by 9.3 percent this year, surpassing an expected decrease of 5 percent. ``The cause for the crisis is the command ... neo-Stalinist model of development and management in the field of economy,'' that was in force for four decades, he said. Zhelev, a 55-year-old philosopher turned politician, was elected president Aug. 1. Zhelev, who led the opposition Union of Democratic Forces (UDF) in June's free elections, was a compromise candidate for president backed by all parties, including Socialist leaders. He has called for a ``strong, competent government'' that presumably could include opposition members. With the backing of the UDF, which has 144 parliamentary seats, the opposition could block key constitutional reforms, which need a two-thirds majority for approval. The Socialists have 211 seats in the 400-member Grand National Assembly. The opposition repeatedly has rejected offers of a coalition from Lukanov, arguing that the former Communist Party must shoulder responsibility for past political crimes and the rapidly deteriorating economy. In a nationwide TV address Sunday, Zhelev called on political parties in Parliament to form a council with him in a bid to solve a deepening economic crisis. ``The crisis is worsening, the state coffers are empty ... there are raw materials and energy shortages in industry, prices are galloping, the unemployment rate is growing,'' Zhelev said. Bulgaria has stopped paying either capital or interest on its foreign debt of nearly $11 billion. The daily Svoboden Narod reported Tuesday that Bulgaria, a country of just under 9 million people, will be 1 million tons short of grain this year. Rationing already has been introduced in some towns for sugar, detergent and soap, and long lines form in Sofia for many basic consumer items.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Worker, Held by Filipino Rebels, Returns To Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: A Peace Corps worker held captive for 50 days in the jungles of the Philippines returned home Tuesday to Wyoming, steak and rhubarb pie. ``I'm glad to see you,'' Tim Swanson said as he bear-hugged his mother, Lynne Swanson, at the end of his 24-hour trip from Manila to Cheyenne. The 26-year-old was freed by New People's Army insurgents last Thursday after the Philippine military agreed to a three-day truce. Released to members of the International Red Cross, Swanson was taken to the U.S. embassy in Manila where he was checked by doctors and met with Peace Corps officials. Swanson, who admitted to feeling overwhelmed to be back in Wyoming, didn't think long when asked how he planned to celebrate. ``I guess I want to eat the steak and the rhubarb pie that my mother told me about and get some sleep,'' he said. Swanson considers the Philippines his home now, but he's not sure when he'll return or what he'll do when he gets there. He won't go back to the Peace Corps and his Filipino wife, Merle, is on leave from her teaching job. Swanson said his brief foray into the forefront of international politics was not welcome. ``I resented it,'' he said. ``I didn't like being used as a pawn by the NPA.'' He was kidnapped on June 13th, when three rebels came to his home and insisted he come with them. Swanson said he had limited freedom in the jungle hideout near his Philippine home of Patag, but for the most part had little to do but sit and wait. The United States suspended Peace Corps operations in the Philippines on June 27 and sent volunteers home because of alleged reports that rebels planned to target them. U.S. officials said they were unaware of Swanson's kidnapping when the order was issued.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: Talks On Ending White Rule Could Begin Early Next Year
With AM-SAfrica-Troubled Future, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government officials say talks with the African National Congress on ending white-minority rule could begin by early next year now that the ANC has suspended its guerrilla campaign, a news report said Tuesday. The independent South African Press Association quoted unidentified government officials as saying the ANC's announcement that it was halting its armed struggle meant formal constitutional negotiations could begin by early 1991. ``This indicates their (the ANC's) seriousness to take to the road of negotiation, and their subtlety and realism,'' one official was quoted as saying. Early Tuesday, the government and the ANC released a joint statement in which the anti-apartheid group announced it was suspending its guerrilla campaign. The statement followed 16 hours of talks between delegations headed by President F.W. de Klerk and ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela. Joe Slovo, a senior ANC official, told a news conference that the organization agreed to end its armed struggle so the government could begin talks on sharing power with the black majority. ``We came here to break the logjam in the peace process, and I believe we walked away with complete success in that direction,'' he said. But Slovo said the ANC reserved the right to resume armed actions ``should the government fail to carry out its undertakings.'' Mandela said the ANC was making every effort to notify supporters to end all armed action against the government immediately. The joint statement by the government and the ANC said both sides had reached ``a milestone on the road to true peace and prosperity for our country.'' It said, ``The way is now open to proceed towards negotiations on a new constitution.'' But the agreement did not halt protests. In Worcester outside Cape Town, police used teargas and rubber bullets on Tuesday to break up an illegal protest march by about 2,000 residents of a mixed race suburb. No serious injuries were reported. Police said Tuesday at least 15 blacks had been killed in scattered factional fighting around the country since Sunday. The dead included 11 killed in Kagiso outside Johannesburg in a power struggle between ANC supporters and Inkatha, the conservative Zulu political movement, police said. The government and the ANC have been trying since May to remove obstacles to full-scale constitutional talks on ending white rule. Although the ANC's guerrilla wing, Spear of the Nation, has launched no major attacks in the past year, ANC officials have acknowledged that guerrillas were continuing to infiltrate the country, stockpile weapons and plan attacks. Mandela had resisted declaring a cease-fire, saying the government must make concessions. The ANC demanded that the government release hundreds of political prisoners, grant amnesty to about 20,000 exiles, remove laws restricting political activity and end the state of emergency in Natal province. Tuesday's statement indicated the government had gone some way towards meeting the ANC demands, but stopped short of outright acceptance. Further discussion of the issues will take place. The joint statement said the government would consider repealing some security laws and lifting the state of emergency in Natal, which gives police wide powers to detain people and restrict political activity. Both sides also agreed to draw up plans for the release of ANC-connected prisoners and for granting amnesty to many of the exiles who want to return home. De Klerk has been under pressure to secure major concessions from the ANC after he legalized black opposition groups and freed Mandela last February after 27 years in jail. White critics had charged the government failed to gain anything by its concessions.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq-Units
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are principal characteristics of U.S. warplanes reported to be sent to Saudi Arabia or known to be at nearby bases or aboard aircraft carriers in the region. The characteristics are taken from various volumes of ``Jane's All the World's Aircraft'' of recent years, and generally apply to the most numerous model. For some planes, ``combat radius'' is reported; this is the distance the plane can fly, loaded with weapons for combat and return to base after fighting. For other planes, only ``range'' was given, and this is the longest possible one-way flight with maximum fuel. Combat radius would be less than half this distance because the weapons load would degrade performance and might replace some of the fuel. Numbers in service are taken from ``The Military Balance 1989-1990,'' published by the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. These do not include aircraft stored.
DOC.HEAD: Fighters
DOC.TEXT: F-16: A single-seat, single-engine fighter and ground attack plane. Combat radius is 575 miles. Can carry 12,000 pounds of bombs and other weapons. The Air Force has 1,083 on active duty. Made by General Dynamics Corp. F-15: A two-place, twin-engine ``air superiority'' fighter also capable of ground attack. Combat radius is 790 miles; weapon load is 24,500 pounds. The Air Force has 642. McDonnell-Douglas Corp. is the manufacturer.
DOC.HEAD: Bombers
DOC.TEXT: B-52G: The Air Force has 61 of the eight-engine giants modified to carry conventional explosives. Crew is six. Range is 7,500 miles. An earlier model, the B-52D, was reported to carry 37 tons of bombs in the Vietnam War. Boeing Corp. made these planes about 30 years ago. The U.S. base at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean is a base for some of these bombers. FB-111: A twin-engine, twin-seat bomber used from bases in England against Libya in 1986, designed for ground-hugging ``penetration'' missions. Range is 3,800 miles. Nine tons of bombs can be carried. General Dynamics was the maker. Planes have been based in Turkey, next door to Iraq, for an exercise. Home bases for the 48 are in England and the United States.

F-A-18: A twin-engine, single-seat plane designed as both a fighter and attack aircraft. Combat radius is 662 miles and weapons load is 17,000 pounds. The Navy has 246; most aircraft carriers have 20 each. McDonnell-Douglas is the manufacturer. F-14: A twin-engine, two-person plane designed as a fighter to win air superiority over the fleet. Maximum range is 2,000 miles; weapons load is said to be 14,500 pounds. The Navy has 398; each carrier has 20. Grumman Corp. is the manufacturer. A-6: An all-weather, two-person, twin-engine plane equipped with sophisticated electronic gear to seek out targets at night and in bad weather. Some of these also were used in the 1986 Libya attack. The bomb load is given as 18,000 pounds; range is listed as 1,100 miles. There are 340 in the fleet; each carrier has 20. Grumman Corp. is the manufacturer.

DOC.HEAD: Troops, Ships Steaming from East Coast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with total number of troops expected to be involved, that they are part of a multinational force, CLARIFY 82nd and 101st Airbornes make up 18th Airborne Corps. Picks up 6th graf, `The role ...'. ^With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XMOR4
DOC.TEXT: A Marine force sailed Tuesday for Liberia, ships and jet fighters set out from East Coast bases for the Middle East and combat troops readied to help defend Saudi Arabia. President Bush ordered American warplanes and ground forces to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday. A Pentagon source said the president had ordered deployment of U.S. combat troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia to help protect the U.S.-aligned desert kingdom against Iraq. Pentagon sources, who spoke on condition of not being identified by name, said they expected Army units heading for Saudi Arabia to include elements of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C.; the 24th Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. and the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky., near Clarksville, Tenn. The 82nd and the 101st make up the 18th Airborne Corps. The three divisions together would total about 44,800 soldiers, if all elements of each division, including a Georgia National Guard Brigade in the 24th, were assembled. Another source said the American GIs would be part of a multinational force, a condition set by the Saudis. Capitol Hill sources said Egypt and Morocco were joining the effort. Authorities at Fort Bragg, home of the 82nd Airborne Division, refused to comment on reports that soldiers from the Fayetteville, N.C., base had been dispatched to Saudi Arabia. The role of the airborne divisions would be to secure air bases, so other troops, aircraft and equipment can be sent in to support the ground forces, other sources said. Troops at Fort Bragg had been placed on alert, soldiers said. Fayetteville radio station WKML reported that 82nd Airborne soldiers were confined to their barracks and were updating wills and power of attorney, a routine procedure before a deployment. Four Navy ships prepared to leave Norfolk, Va., for the Mediterranean as part of a 10-ship group that had been scheduled to sail for a six-month assignment. The group included the battleship Wisconsin. In Florida, the aircraft carrier Saratoga and a flotilla of destroyers and frigates steamed out of Mayport en route to the Mediterranean. The Saratoga normally carries a crew of 7,730. The Saratoga, which Navy officials said was being deployed on a normal six-month mission, was aqccompanied by the destroyers Spruance and Sampson, the frigate Elmer Montgomery and the guided missile cruiser Phillipine Sea. The mood aboard the Saratoga was ``professional and work-oriented but concerned,'' Chief Petty Officer Charles Underwood, a spokesman for the Mayport Naval Station, said before departure. The force of 2,500 Marines headed for Liberia left by ship from Camp Lejeune in North Carolina. They had been previously scheduled to relieve the Marine Expeditionary Unit that is stationed off the coast of Liberia, where it rescued Americans during the weekend. The deployment was routine because the forces are rotated during the year, but some Marines said they expected to be sent to the Middle East. Col. W.C. Fite III, commander of the troops _ called the 26th Marine Expedionary Unit, said he hadn't gotten orders yet. ``We haven't been told about our future plans,'' Fite said during a brief news conference as troops boarded ships. ``We have plans to go to Spain, which is routine, and also plans if needed to go to the coast of Monrovia, Liberia.'' The Marines sailed aboard a five-ship squadron.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt, Morocco First to Commit Troops to Multinational Force, Sources Say
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Egypt and Morocco were the first nations to commit troops to the multinational military force led by the United States to protect Saudi Arabia from possible Iraqi attack, Washington sources said Tuesday. There were no reports of any Western European or other Arab nations joining the force. Japan said it would not participate in any such action. President Bush ordered U.S. troops and warplanes to the front line of the explosive standoff, according to authoritative Pentagon sources and sources on Capitol Hill. There was no announcement of military moves from the White House. A source in Washington said U.S. troops would be part of a multinational force, a condition set by the Saudis. U.S congressional sources said Egypt and Morocco were joining the effort. Saudi Arabia, sharing Arab sensitivities, had never before agreed to stationing U.S. military power on its soil. Egypt is the second-largest recipient of U.S. economic and military aid, with current annual aid level of $2.3 billion and a large arsenal of U.S.-supplied weapons. Since 1981, the United States has conducted joint maneuvers with Egypt involving several thousand troops from each country every two years. Morocco's King Hassan II enjoys close relations with the United States and receives millions of dollars a year in U.S. military aid. The moderate Arab country has U.S.-made tanks. Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said that the country's no-war constitution would bar it from joining any international military effort in the Persian Gulf. The West German Foreign Ministry also said there were no plans for German troops to join a multinational force in the gulf. A duty officer noted that the West German constitution bars the use of German troops outside the country. Turkey, which closed Iraqi oil pipelines, had received no request to join such a force, Foreign Ministry spokesman Murat Sungar said. Two U.S. carrier battle groups were already on station in the region _ the USS Independence and its 14 escorts in the Arabian Sea at the mouth of the Persian Gulf, and the force led by the USS Eisenhower in the eastern Mediterranean. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in Egypt, persuaded Egyptian officials to allow the Eisenhower to pass through the Suez Canal on Tuesday night to move closer to the embattled gulf region, Pentagon sources said. A handful of British and French navy vessels were also in the region. A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said a Soviet anti-submarine ship and destroyer were dispatched from the Indian Ocean toward the area, but only to ``ensure safety of navigation of Soviet civilian vessels.'' Diplomats said the U.N. Security Council resolution calling for a worldwide boycott against Iraq could be used as justification by the United States and other nations to act unilaterally, or in concert apart from the United Nations, to enforce the boycott. There was hope that a multinational defense of Saudi Arabia would deter Saddam Hussein's million-man Iraqi army from storming the Saudi oil fields. Iraqi forces conquered Kuwait last week. Saudi Arabia borders Kuwait and also has a common border with Iraq. Secretary of State James Baker made plans to meet Friday in Brussels with the foreign ministers of the 15 U.S. allies in Europe after a quick consultation trip to Turkey. The move appeared to be an effort to enlist Western Europe in the Saudi defense effort.

DOC.HEAD: Small Fire Put Out In Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: A smoky fire that broke out in a room at the Pentagon was put out Tuesday night with no one being injured, authorities said. Investigators did not know what caused the fire, and a damage estimate was not available, said Air Force Capt. Sam Grizzle, a Pentagon spokesman. The fire started about 8 p.m. and was brought under control about 20 minutes later, Grizzle said. He did not know what type of work is performed in the room.

DOC.HEAD: Lights, Parties Featured in National Night Against Crime
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with activities across nation. Picks up 4th graf, `Peskin is ...' SUBS 9th graf, `New Orleans ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with New York City event.
DOC.TEXT: Neighborhoods across the country took a stand against crime and celebrated safety Tuesday night with block parties, candlelight marches and flashing lights in the seventh annual National Night Out. ``The block is running over with people,'' said Barbara Landers, who held a block party in the Philadelphia's Hunting Park neighborhood. ``The kids are out here playing, they helped decorate the street. We're all having fun here tonight. The block is out!'' In Charleston, W.Va., at least 25 neighborhood groups held rallies, cookouts, marches and block parties. Among the events was a senior citizens' march with flashlights around their highrise apartment complex, said Sgt. Dallas Staples. In Columbus, Ohio, police coordinated the activities of 194 community block watches, said the police department's Howard Wilson. In Barrow, Alaska, police officer Brent Robles said timing just wasn't right. Barrow gets just a couple hours of semi-darkness at this time of year. ``We're going to do it when we get a night,'' said Robles. National Night Out ``turns the clock back about 40 years to a time when communities were safer because people knew their neighbors, routinely looked out for one another, and everyone knew the cop on the beat,'' said organizer Matt Peskin. Peskin is director of the National Association of Town Watch, a non-profit organization based in this Philadelphia suburb. It is dedicated to the development of law-nforcement affiliated crime and drug prevention activities. About 400 communities participated in the first Night Out through their local Town Watch groups in 1984, Peskin said. This year, he was looking for a turnout of 21 million in 8,000 communities in all 50 states and in Canada and at U.S. military bases around the world. Last year, police in Dayton, Ohio, gave out mock citations and light bulbs to people who didn't have their outside lights on. This year, the Night Out ceremonies began at noon, with a ``Hands Across the Border'' trek from Fort Erie, Ont., to Buffalo, N.Y., for 300 police and members of citizens groups. ``What we're trying to show is crime doesn't have any boundaries,'' said Buffalo police Lt. Ron Christopher after more than 100 police officials from New York state and Canada staged an afternoon motorcade across the international Peace bridge from Buffalo to Fort Erie, Ontario. In New York City, Mayor David Dinkins urged citizens to join the fight against crime, saying public safety is ``my highest priority, but I can't do it alone.'' ``I'm not calling for you to become vigilantes, but I am preaching vigilance,'' said Dinkins, speaking to about 250 people in Harlem. Night Out organizers in Butte, Mont., said they would light up the 90-foot ``Lady of the Rockies'' statue atop the continental divide. Milwaukee, the leading city in the celebration last year, planned 1,000 block parties and security lighting demonstrations. Most important, Peskin said, is the way the Night Out draws people together and gets them in touch with the police. ``You have police in the neighborhood and nothing's wrong,'' he said. ``It's a rare chance, especially for the kids. The event seems to draw out neighborhoods that have usually been tough to involve in anything. ``Generally, most people are law-abiding and they want to be neighborly,'' Peskin said. ``But nowadays, if you try to be neighborly, many people are likely to be suspicious. You can do that on this night.''

Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, says he thinks a subcommittee he chairs has established the legal basis to overturn a 1988 savings and loan bailout he describes as ``very sweet.'' Arizona insurance executive James M. Fail acknowledged on Monday there were inaccuracies and omissions in disclosure statements he signed before acquiring 15 failed thrifts, now operating under the name Bluebonnet Savings Bank, Dallas. One of the penalties for improper disclosure is removal as S&L owner. ``I believe there is enough to reopen and renegotiate the contract. The real issue is can we save the taxpayers millions and possibly billions of dollars. I believe the answer is yes,'' Metzenbaum told reporters after an all-day session of his Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust.

The American Bar Association is demonstrating how deeply divided it is over taking a public stand on abortion, and the future of its pro-choice policy remains in doubt. By a vote of 885-836 Monday, members at the ABA's Assembly meeting adopted a resolution that supporters say is designed to restore the nation's largest lawyers' group to a position of neutrality on abortion. ``Questions presented by a decision to terminate pregnancy are extremely divisive,'' the resolution said. ``The ABA for the good of the association will not adopt a policy supportive of a particular viewpoint.'' The resolution urged repeal of a pro-abortion-rights stand adopted by the ABA's policymaking body, its House of Delegates.

A bodyguard has been convicted in the slayings of two American tourists he mistook for U.S. agents after they wandered into a restaurant celebration by Mexican drug traffickers. Monday's verdict against Javier Vasquez Velasco was the last in the latest trial over the slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. The case has strained U.S. relations with Mexico and entangled more than 40 people in the two countries. Vasquez, 38, portrayed by federal prosecutors as a drug lord's bodyguard, was convicted of two counts of violent crimes in aid of racketeering in the 1985 slayings of John Walker and Alberto Radelat in a Guadalajara restaurant. Prosecutors said Walker and Radelat were mistaken for drug agents after they wandered into a party for drug kingpins.

After 10 years of fast-forward growth, video retailers facing industrywide slo-mo are adding pizzazz, and in at least one case pizzas, to get movie rentals back on track. Film-savvy clerks, easier-to-find titles, candy counters, video reference databases and free telephones for renters who need to consult with those at home regarding second choices are among the perks being offered to keep the customer satisfied, participants at an industry convention say. ``Going to the video store is no longer fun,'' said Robert Klingensmith, president of Paramount Picture's video division. In a glum keynote address at the ninth annual Video Software Dealers Association convention, Klingensmith told retailers what they already knew _ that sales growth has leveled off after a boom decade.

The mother of a defendant in the Central Park jogger trial was thrown out of court after shouting in front of the jury that her 16-year-old son had passed a lie detector test. Sharonne Salaam's outburst Monday came as a prosecutor testified about the night her son, Yusef Salaam, was picked up by police last year. Mrs. Salaam leapt from her chair and accused the witness, Assistant District Attorney Linda Fairstein, of lying about a conversation they had at a precinct house about Salaam's age. ``Why are you telling all these lies? My son is innocent! You don't have to lie like that! He passed a lie detector test and he's innocent!'' Mrs. Salaam shouted at Fairstein, the final witness in the trial. Two court officers escorted Mrs. Salaam from the courtroom.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv12
For Release Sunday, Aug. 12
DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 12, the 224th day of 1990. There are 141 days left in the year.
Today's Highlight in History: On Aug. 12, 1898, Hawaii was formally annexed to the United States after Congress passed a joint resolution. Hawaii was granted territorial status in 1900, and became the 50th state of the union in 1959.
DOC.HEAD: On this date:
DOC.TEXT:
In 1851, Isaac Singer was granted a patent on his sewing machine. In 1867, President Andrew Johnson sparked a move to impeach him as he defied Congress by suspending Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton. In 1898, the peace protocol ending the Spanish-American War was signed. In 1915, 75 years ago, the novel ``Of Human Bondage,'' by William Somerset Maugham, was published. In 1941, French Marshal Henri Petain called on his countrymen to give their full support to Nazi Germany. In 1948, Soviet schoolteacher Oksana Kasenkina survived a leap from a window of the Soviet consulate in New York to avoid being returned to her homeland. In 1953, the Soviet Union conducted a secret test of its first hydrogen bomb. In 1955, President Eisenhower signed a bill raising the minimum wage from 75 cents to $1 an hour, effective the following March. In 1960, the first balloon satellite, the Echo 1, was launched by the United States from Cape Canaveral, Fla. In 1962, one day after launching Andrian Nikolayev into orbit, the Soviet Union also sent up cosmonaut Pavel Popovich. Both men landed safely Aug. 15. In 1972, the last American combat ground troops left Vietnam. In 1977, the space shuttle Enterprise passed its first solo flight test by taking off atop a Boeing 747, separating, and then touching down on its own in California's Mojave Desert. In 1978, Pope Paul VI, who had died Aug. 6 at age 80, was buried in St. Peter's Basilica after an outdoor funeral mass attended by thousands of mourners.
Ten years ago: One day after ending his presidential bid, Senator Edward M. Kennedy exhorted the Democratic national convention in New York to unite behind ``democratic principles'' and march on to victory in November. Five years ago: The world's worst single-aircraft disaster occurred as a crippled Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 crashed into a mountain during a domestic flight, killing 520 people. One year ago: The Pentagon said it was stepping up efforts to find missing U.S. Rep. Mickey Leland, D-Texas, and 15 companions in Ethiopia. (The wreckage of the group's airplane was found the following day. There were no survivors.)
Today's Birthdays: Mexican comedy actor Mario ``Cantinflas'' Moreno is 79. Actress Jane Wyatt is 78. Choreographer Michael Kidd is 71. Senator Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., is 65. Actor-director John Derek is 64. Singer-musician Buck Owens is 61. Actor George Hamilton is 51.
Thought for Today: ``The best of all the preachers are the men who live their creeds.'' _ Edgar A. Guest, American author, journalist and poet (1881-1959).
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 12
$Adv13
For Release Monday, Aug. 13
DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 13, the 225th day of 1990. There are 140 days left in the year.
Today's Highlight in History: On Aug. 13, 1961, the city of Berlin was divided as East Germany sealed off the border between the eastern and western sectors. East German police and troops used barbed wire and barricades to block crossing points in order to halt the flight of refugees. Two days later, work began on the Berlin Wall.
On this date: In 1521, Spanish conqueror Hernando Cortez captured what is now Mexico City from the Aztecs. In 1624, French King Louis the 13th named Cardinal Richelieu his first minister. In 1792, French revolutionaries imprisoned the royal family. In 1818, suffragist Lucy Stone was born in West Brookfield, Mass. In 1846, the U.S. flag was raised for the first time in Los Angeles. In 1889, William Gray of Hartford, Conn., received a patent for a coin-operated telephone. In 1899, movie director Alfred Hitchcock was born in London. In 1910, Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing, died in London. In 1932, Adolf Hitler rejected the post of vice-chancellor of Germany, saying he was prepared to hold out ``for all or nothing.'' In 1946, author H.G. Wells died in London. In 1960, the first two-way telephone convg. 17, 1807, Robert Fulton's North River Steam Boat, popularly, albeit erroneously, known as the Clermont began chugging up New York's Hudson River on its successful round-trip to Albany.
On this date: In 1863, Federal batteries and ships bombarded Fort Sumter in Charleston harbor during the Civil War. In 1915, 75 years ago, a mob in Cobb County, Ga., lynched Jewish businessman Leo Frank, whose death sentence for the murder of a 13-year-old girl had been commuted to life imprisonment. In 1940, 50 years ago, President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Canadian Prime Minister William Mackenzie King met in Ogdensburg, N.Y., where they agreed to set up a joint defense commission. In 1942, U.S. bombers raided Rouen, France. In 1943, Allied forces gained control of Sicily. In 1948, former State Department official Alger Hiss faced his chief accuser, Whittaker Chambers, during a closed-door meeting in New York of the House Un-American Activities Committee, and repeated his denial that he'd ever been a Communist agent. In 1962, East German border guards shot and mortally wounded 18-year-old Peter Fechter, who had attempted to cross the Berlin Wall into the western sector. In 1969, 248 people were killed as Hurricane Camille slammed into the U.S. Gulf Coast with winds clocked at up to 200 miles an hour. In 1969, the Woodstock Music and Art Fair concluded near Bethel, N.Y. In 1978, the first successful trans-Atlantic balloon flight ended as Maxie Anderson, Ben Abruzzo and Larry Newman landed their Double Eagle 2 in a wheat field outside Paris. In 1987, Rudolf Hess, the last member of Adolf Hitler's inner circle, died at a Berlin hospital near Spandau Prison at age 93, having apparently strangled himself with an electrical cord. In 1988, Vice President Bush was nominated for president at the Republican national convention in New Orleans. In 1988, Pakistani President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq and U-S Ambassador Arnold Raphel were killed in a mysterious plane crash.
Ten years ago: Britain announced the temporary closing of its embassy in Tehran and sent eight of its diplomats home, following earlier demonstrations by thousands of Iranians in front of the embassy compound. Five years ago: More than 1,400 meatpackers walked off the job at the Geo. A. Hormel and Company's main plant in Austin, Minn., in a bitter strike that lasted just over a year. One year ago: The Commerce Department reported that the U.S. trade deficit shrank to $8.17 billion dollars in June, the smallest monthly imbalance since December 1984.
Today's Birthdays: Actress Maureen O'Hara is 70. Actor Robert DeNiro is 47. Singer Belinda Carlisle is 32. Actor Sean Penn is 30. Singer Donnie Wahlberg is 21.
Thought for Today: ``A river has no politics.'' _ David E. Lilienthal, American public official (1899-1981).
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday, Aug. 17

For Release Wednesday, Aug. 15
DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Wednesday, Aug. 15, the 227th day of 1990. There are 138 days left in the year.
Today's Highlight in History: On Aug. 15, 1947, India became independent after some 200 years of British rule. Jawaharlal Nehru became India's first prime minister.

On this date: In 1057, Macbeth, the King of Scotland, was slain by the son of King Duncan. In 1769, Napoleon Bonaparte was born on the island of Corsica. In 1888, T.E. Lawrence, the British soldier who gained fame as ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' was born in Tremadoc, Wales. In 1914, the Panama Canal opened to traffic. In 1918, the United States and Russia severed diplomatic ties. In 1935, humorist Will Rogers and aviator Wiley Post were killed when their airplane crashed near Point Barrow, Alaska. In 1939, ``The Wizard of Oz,'' MGM's movie version of the L. Frank Baum fantasy starring Judy Garland as Dorothy, premiered at the Grauman's Chinese Theater in Hollywood. In 1945, U.S. wartime rationing of gasoline and fuel oil ended. In 1948, the Republic of Korea was proclaimed. In 1961, East German workers began building the Berlin Wall. In 1969, the Woodstock Music and Art Fair opened in New York State. In 1971, President Nixon announced a 90-day freeze on wages, prices and rents. In 1974, South Korean President Park Chung-hee escaped an assassination attempt in which his wife died. In 1979, Andrew Young resigned as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations after coming under fire for an unauthorized meeting with the U.N. observer for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

Ten years ago: An expedition searching for the Titanic reported that sonar equipment had picked up the outline of what was believed to be the sunken luxury liner 380 miles off the Newfoundland coast. (However, it took another three expeditions to actually find the ship.) Five years ago: South African President P.W. Botha delivered an internationally broadcast speech in which he rejected calls to dismantle apartheid, saying it would lead white South Africans ``on a road to abdication and suicide.'' One year ago: F.W. de Klerk was sworn in as acting president of South Africa, one day after P.W. Botha resigned as the result of a power struggle within the National Party.
Today's Birthdays: Cooking expert Julia Child is 78. Actress Wendy Hiller is 78. Eagle Forum president Phyllis Schlafly is 66. Playwright Robert Bolt is 66. Actress Rose Marie is 65. Actor Mike Connors is 65. Actress Janice Rule is 59. Civil rights activist Vernon Jordan is 55. Actor Jim Dale is 55. Author-journalist Linda Ellerbee is 46. Britain's Princess Anne is 40.
Thought for Today: ``Forgiveness is the key to action and freedom.'' _ Hannah Arendt, American author and philosopher (1906-1975).
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday, Aug. 15.

For Release Thursday, Aug. 16
DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 16, the 228th day of 1990. There are 137 days left in the year.
Today's Highlight in History: On Aug. 16, 1977, the ``King'' of rock 'n' roll, Elvis Presley, died at Graceland Mansion in Memphis, Tenn., at the age of 42.
On this date: In 1777, American forces won an important victory of the Revolutionary War at the Battle of Bennington, Vt. In 1812, Detroit fell to British and Indian forces in the War of 1812. In 1829, the original ``Siamese'' twins, Chang and Eng Bunker, arrived in Boston aboard the ship Sachem to be exhibited to the Western world. DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 10, the 222nd day of 1990. There are 143 days left in the year.
Today's Highlight in History: On Aug. 10, 1846, Congress chartered the Smithsonian Institution, named after English scientist Joseph Smithson, whose bequest of $500,000 made it possible.
On this date: In 1792, mobs in Paris attacked the palace of Louis XVI. In 1809, Ecuador struck its first blow for independence from Spain. In 1821, Missouri became the 24th state. In 1874, Herbert Clark Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, was born in West Branch, Iowa. In 1885, Leo Daft opened America's first commercially operated electric streetcar, in Baltimore. In 1921, Franklin D. Roosevelt was stricken with polio while at his summer home on the Canadian island of Campobello. In 1945, during World War II, Japan announced its willingness to surrender to the Allies provided the status of Emperor Hirohito remained unchanged. In 1948, Allen Funt's ``Candid Camera'' made its television debut on ABC under the title ``Candid Microphone,'' which was also the name of a radio program produced by Funt. In 1949, the National Military Establishment was renamed the Department of Defense. In 1969, Leno and Rosemary LaBianca were murdered in their Los Angeles home by members of Charles Manson's cult, one day after actress Sharon Tate and four other people were slain. In 1975, television personality David Frost announced he had purchased the exclusive rights to interview former President Nixon. In 1977, postal employee David Berkowitz was arrested in Yonkers, N.Y., accused of being ``Son of Sam,'' the gunman whose yearlong series of six murders and seven woundings terrorized New Yorkers. In 1984, the women's 3,000-meter race at the Los Angeles Olympics ended for Mary Decker of the U.S. when she fell after colliding with South African-born Zola Budd. The race was won by Romanian Maricica Puica. In 1988, President Reagan signed a measure providing $20,000 payments to Japanese-Americans who were interned during World War II.
Ten years ago: The day before the start of the Democratic national convention in New York, President Carter agreed to compromise with Massachusetts Sen. Edward M. Kennedy on economic policies contained in the party platform. Five years ago: In South Africa, relative calm returned to Durban's black and Indian townships, where days of rioting had claimed dozens of lives. One year ago: Poland's Roman Catholic church suspended an agreement to move nuns from a convent on the edge of Auschwitz, blaming Jewish groups for creating what it called an ``atmosphere of aggressive demands.''
Today's Birthdays: Actress Rhonda Fleming is 67. Singer Jimmy Dean is 62. Singer Eddie Fisher is 62. Rock musician Ian Anderson is 43. Singer Patti Austin is 42. Actress Rosanna Arquette is 31.
Thought for Today: ``A man may fulfill the object of his existence by asking a question he cannot answer, and attempting a task he cannot achieve.'' _Oliver Wendell Holmes, American author (1809-1894).
