DOC.HEAD: `I'm Dangerous Tonight' _ Not Really, But It's A Fine B Movie
DOC.TEXT: Remember how much fun it was to stay up too late on a Saturday night with popcorn and orange soda pop and wait expectantly for the Late Nite Shriek Theater Shock Horror Creature Feature? ``I'm Dangerous Tonight,'' airing tonight on cable's USA Network, is just like those good old B movies. It doesn't pretend to be Great Art, just a nice, scary movie that is suitable for middle-school viewers. It means, also, that the movie is not quite that scary for grownups. Don't blame director Tobe Hooper (``Poltergeist'' and ``Texas Chainsaw Massacre''), who makes the most of the slenderest of premises: ``A cloak used in early Aztec blood sacrifices which transmits forbidding, evil, supernatural powers to unwitting victims who come in contact with it.'' The opening credits for ``I'm Dangerous Tonight'' run while a big tractor-trailer rig rolls into view and onto the campus of good old State U. ``I got a delivery for Dr. Jonas Wilson,'' the surly, Latin American-accented driver tells the security guard and forklifts in a huge, stone Aztec-symbol inscribed whatchamacallit. ``What the heck is that?'' asks the security guard. ``It's an Aztec sacrificial altar,'' the driver says, having readahead in the script. ``During important festivals they say the blood ran from this altar in rivers. ... Your professor should be pleased with it.'' Enter the professor. Ooh, he's pleased. His fingertips twitch greedily as he moves to touch the profane altar. ``Hey, professor, some sacrificial altar, eh?'' says the security guard. A line reading as stupid as that, kids, automatically moves the security guard onto the list of Minor Characters About to be Scragged Horribly. The professor caresses the stone as he waxes rhapsodic about the ancient Corn Festivals where the Aztec priests who sacrifice 20,000 victims a day. His eyes get misty as he says `` ... their hearts torn from their living bodies.'' Then our professor friend OPENS the altar and inside is ... ``AAAAAAAAAAGH!!!'' Scared ya, huh? You get the picture. Hooper moves the teleplay of producers Bruce Lansbury and Philip John Taylor as steadily as a sine wave, pacing the thrills and the lulls as dependably as a train schedule. All too soon the cloak comes into the possession of Amy (the oddly lovely ``Twin Peaks'' regular Madchen Amick), a worthy, Cinderella-type freshman at State U. who falls under the cloak's spell and makes an evening dress of it. She is transformed into a sensual, man-hungry vamp ... just as long as she's wearing the dress. This causes some understandable confusion for the lad who removes her from it during a friendly embrace at the college dance. Ah, but there's still plenty of confusion, mayhem, and murder ahead, kids. R. Lee Emery (remember the tough DI in ``Full Metal Jacket''?) turns in his usual superlative performance as a police detective investigating what has become a string of homicides. He is a surprisingly competent policeman and not at all typical of the scary movie genre. ``Losing a relative is a tragedy,'' he tells one potential victim, ``but losing two in two days is downright careless.'' Anthony Perkins, who's becoming known as a great cable television actor, phones in his role as an archaeology professor, and Dee Wallace-Stone (``Cujo'') puts in late-innings relief as a cloak victim-cum-perpetrator. ``I'm Dangerous Tonight'' is well-directed even it it isn't particlarly well-written. Director Hooper creates some scary images and is still prodding the material for thrills even when the script has run out of steam.

Elswewhere in television ... SISTERHOOD IS POWERFUL DEPT.: You'll probably find yourself wishing for better things for the cast, should you tune in tonight's special preview of of ABC's sitcom ``New Attitude.'' Sheryl Lee Ralph and Phyllis Yvonne Stickney star as two sisters who've sunk their life savings into a beauty salon where ... WAIT for it ... ``the sets, perms and rinses often take a back seat to their misadventures.'' Drat. If you were hoping for a black version of ``Steel Magnolias,'' you'll be disappointed. Miss Ralph plays the down-to-earth one and Miss Stickney the wild and impulsive one. They convey warmth in their relationship despite the snappy patter. Morris Day does a nice job as a self-absorbed hairdresser. Sadly, that's about as far as it goes. The show is underwritten, its comedic situations lack a sense of risk or danger and its characters are thin. We're still waiting for an comedy about black women that can entertain us without patronizing us and wasting the talents of performers like Miss Stickney, who was in ``The Women of Brewster Place'' miniseries, and Miss Ralph of ``The Mighty Quinn'' movie and Broadway's ``Dream Girls.'' End Adv PM Wed Aug. 8

DOC.HEAD: ANOTHER LOOK: Monument Avenue, 100 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: Some Southerners look at Monument Avenue's stately statues of Confederate heroes and see ``the most beautiful street in America.'' Some Northerners look at the same scene and see ``Losers' Lane.'' Norrece T. Jones Jr. looks out on the statue of J.E.B. Stuart from his apartment, and he sees human suffering. ``When I see those monuments, I think of people who enslaved African Americans. I can never look at them dispassionately or indifferently,'' says Jones, professor of Afro-American history at Virginia Commonwealth University. One hundred years after Robert E. Lee became the first son of the South to be memorialized on Monument Avenue, the 140-foot-wide thoroughfare symbolizes both the scars of slavery and the elegance of a time long ago. It is ``more than a Confederate Valhalla,'' says Edwin J. Slipek Jr., director of the avenue's centennial celebration. ``It's a linear Central Park or town square, tracking the development of an American city.'' The 62-foot-tall statue of Lee on his horse was dedicated on Memorial Day in 1890. Jeb Stuart and Jefferson Davis followed up in 1907, Stonewall Jackson in 1919 and Matthew Fontaine Maury, ``Pathfinder of the Sea,'' in 1927. By the 1920s, Monument Avenue was Richmond's most prestigious address. Douglas Southall Freeman, the Richmond historian whose writing about Lee won the Pulitzer Prize, doffed his hat whenever he passed ``Marse Lee.'' ``They didn't start out by saying, `We're going to dedicate a street to the men who lost the Civil War,'' said Robert Winthrop, an architectural historian. Instead, the row of statues grew ``piece by piece,'' he said. ``If the city government was focused on a memorial to the Lost Cause it might be different.'' George Callcott, professor of Southern history at the University of Maryland, said: ``One of the things American historians have noticed is the South's preoccupation with the past. Monument Avenue is an indicator of that.'' John Zehmer, executive director of the Historic Richmond Foundation, is among those who suggest Monument Avenue is not so much a commemoration of Confederate heroes as a display of fine art. Still, when other statues were proposed through the years _ non-Civil War types like Thomas Jefferson, Woodrow Wilson, William Henry Harrison and Edgar Allan Poe, among them _ none was built. In the late 1970s, when Richmond first elected a city council with a black majority, the outgoing administration feared that blacks would move or tear down the Lee monument. So the whites deeded Robert E. Lee to the state. But Henry Marsh, the city's first black mayor, laid a wreath at the Jefferson Davis monument, assuring the United Daughters of the Confederacy that he was ``mayor of all the city.'' ``The city had never experienced what they perceived as black control and didn't know what to expect,'' Marsh said. The avenue, he says today, is ``one of the great boulevards in the world.'' Monument Avenue is a haven to joggers and children who frolic on the grassy, tree-lined median. It is an avenue of mansions _ the average home is 5,000 square feet, with a half-dozen fireplaces, four bathrooms, maids quarters, and a dozen rooms on three floors. Some of the houses have been sold to new owners who find them too large to handle and turn them into offices and apartments. Some have been purchased by newcomers eager to buy a mansion for a relatively cheap price; Ceci Amrhein, a real estate broker who is also co-chairwoman of the centennial, said a house in need of major renovation is on the market for $250,000, while another, fully renovated, sold for $775,000. The centennial has had its goofy side, including a croquet festival, billed at ``the world's largest croquet match,'' on the avenue's lawns. But when, as part of the celebration, a jazz group was invited to play, black youths in the band refused to perform under the statue of Lee, Jones said. The band moved the show a block away. ``The Civil War, in essence, was fought to preserve a certain culture _ that culture predicated on the enslavement of hundreds of thousands of African Americans,'' Jones said. Though he can look out of his window and see the statue of Stuart, renowned as one of the best cavalry commanders of the Army of Northern Virginia, Jones says he enjoys living there. The building in which he lives, designed by architect William Lawrence Bottomley, is on the Virginia Historic Register and the National Register of Historic Places. He enjoys the model of a Claes Oldenburg sculpture on a neighbor's lawn _ the sculpture depicts not a war hero, but a clothespin. And there have been signs of change. The Virginia chapter of the American Institute of Architects held a mock competition for a new sculpture on Monument Avenue, and drew responses from 250 architecture students. The most popular subject? Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, the first black elected chief executive of any state. End Adv PM Mon Aug. 13

DOC.HEAD: Templeton: The Profits Belong To The Steady Investor
DOC.TEXT: These are times that test investors and separate them from traders, guessers, speculators, and crowd and guru followers. Investors think long-term, absorbing and measuring the daily and monthly events against their basic analysis of sales and earnings possibilities. Good investors maintain a distant view. They tend not to panic. Sir John Templeton expresses the philosophy this way: ``The short term _ the next month or year _ depends very heavily on human emotions. The long term, however, depends on values _ and values keep rising.'' That is, the value of well-chosen investments grow. They grow because the economies of which they are a part grow, because their markets are expanding, because they are well managed. Templeton, based in Nassau, Bahamas, is one of the most successful investors of all time, a living legend, a knight, a founder of mutual funds in which 700,000 investors own shares. There have been seven bear markets since Templeton founded the Templeton Growth Fund in 1954. But in that time, a $10,000 investment would have grown to well over $1 million, after payment of all fees and expenses. Ask Templeton about short-term events and how to deal with them and he might say, as he said to Steven Halpern, ``Your guess is as good as mine.'' Templeton recently told Halpern, editor of a stock market newsletter, that ``We have been investment counselors for 58 years, and in all that time we have never been able to tell our clients when a bear market will start or stop.'' Rather than trying to forecast, Templeton buys shares selling at a low price in relation to long-term prospects. In that way, he said, he can produce better long-term results than if he had tried to forecast the market. Overall, and in spite of bear markets and unforeseen events, he observes, stock prices have doubled about every 10 years throughout the history of American markets. ``As a result, if you invest over a period of one or two full stock market cycles, we believe you'll come out a winner,'' he told Halpern, who produces the Dick Davis Digest, a compilation of views from 400 advisory services. During those cycles, he suggests, you might consider bear markets not to be a catastrophe, a reason to sell or to drop out of the market, but as an opportunity, a chance to buy at a relatively low price. The significance of Templeton's words is obvious these days, when nervous stockholders call their brokers every hour, when gloom is pervasive, when fears of a collapse are rampant, when short-term events cloud long-term perspectives. It takes conviction to stand firm, of course, and not everyone can do it. Some people bend under the onslaught of negative news and views. Others are compelled to sell because they need the money. But those who can hold out during negative times, says Templeton, are likely to be as well rewarded in the future as they have been in the past. Maybe even more so, he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday, Aug. 8

DOC.HEAD: Political Exiles Begin To Return
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5 `The ANC' and 12-15 `President F.W. ... daughter behind' to update with agreements reached Monday, Aug. 6. ^By SAHM VENTER
DOC.TEXT: Lindiwe Phillip, an anti-apartheid activist, fled into exile and expected to return triumphantly in a few months. That was 14 years ago. She came home in June, when the government granted temporary amnesty to dozens of African National Congress leaders so they could return and prepare for talks on ending apartheid, the racial policy that gives 5 million whites supremacy over the nation's 28 million blacks. Ms. Phillip, now 32, was among thousands of young blacks who left after the the 1976 student uprisings. Hundreds of people were killed in 1976 and the uprising helped shape a generation of militant activists. ``I thought (exile) would be very temporary, about three months,'' she said. ``As time went on, I had to grapple with the fact that I am in exile and that I can no longer go home.'' The ANC, South Africa's leading black opposition movement, has an estimated 20,000 members in exile. The ANC and the government agreed Monday to clear the way for their return, starting in September. While Ms. Phillip was in exile in Zambia, her parents died. After she was in touch with her brother about the deaths, he was killed, and then her younger brother was found stabbed to death. She still does not know who killed either of them. ``I was just heartbroken,'' she said. ``I was almost on the verge of going nuts, crazy.'' During her exile, Ms. Phillip received military training and studied in Cuba and Tanzania. She also worked in the ANC Women's Section and the Department of Information and Publicity in Lusaka, Zambia, the ANC's exile headquarters. Her feelings were mixed when she returned in June with a group sent to recruit members for the ANC Women's League. ``We had so longed to be back home, but at the same time we were not sure it was the correct time,'' she said. African National Congress members began trickling out of South Africa when the organization was banned in 1960. President F.W. de Klerk lifted the 30-year ban in February. A law passed at that time empowers de Klerk to grant immunity, but so far he has given only temporary amnesty to a few dozen ANC leaders and officials. Officials say that, under Monday's agreement, the cases of all exiles will be reviewed and disputed cases will be handled by a special commission. Mathews Phosa, a lawyer on the ANC negotiating team, fled South Africa five years ago when he was told his life was in danger, but had to leave his wife and 3-year-old daughter behind. ``It is one of the most traumatic decisions one could take in one's life, a very very painful experience _ shattering, terrible,'' he said. What sustained exiles, Phosa said, was unshakeable belief in the struggle to end apartheid. ``You don't know where you are going to exactly,'' he said. ``You are being uprooted from your loved ones. ... You know you are going to comrades, but that's not enough. You still have to make new friends.'' After the initial shock, life in exile becomes normal, the lawyer said: ``People get married, they fall in love, they work, and home is not something that haunts you every day.'' Finding a place to live is a major problem for returning exiles. There is a severe shortage of housing for blacks. Many will want to catch up on education they missed while fighting for Spear of the Nation, the ANC military wing, but black schools are overcrowded, qualified teachers are rare and violence has disrupted classes for years. Recent right-wing violence against blacks and against whites opposed to apartheid is a source of fear for returning exiles, Phosa said, ``but that can't be a reason for us not to come home.'' With ``the political space being there to organize and build our organization, it would be irresponsible for us not to deploy our cadres inside the country,'' he said. ``I think I am optimistic that we will get over the stumbling blocks. There is a willingness on the part of the government. They are very slow ... hesitant, but I think they are moving forward and they should be credited for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Urban Gardeners Soften Gritty City
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Gertrude Rainey lives in a Harlem neighborhood scarred by boarded-up brick apartment buildings and the effects of drugs, but her half-acre vegetable and flower garden thrives among the ruins. ``The streets can separate you from life,'' she said. ``But this garden lifts you up and the soil feels so good in your hands.'' The concrete-and-steel maze of New York City contains many colorful patches tended by people like Ms. Rainey, who garden to soften the edge of city living. Urban children who didn't know where tomatoes came from are dazzled by the plots, and tourists from around the world include them on their itineraries. A group of gardeners called the Green Guerrillas began the movement to make the city greener in 1972 by cleaning out empty lots piled with trash and planting shrubs and flowers. The city became involved in 1979 when it began Operation GreenThumb to help pay for fencing, seeds and tools. Today, nearly 550 community gardens can be found on lots owned by the city, and GreenThumb says the value of the fruit and vegetables they yield amounts to $375,000 a year. There also are many gardens on private lots. Gardens give people greater pride in their neighborhoods, said Lisa Stephano, a spokeswoman for the American Community Garden Association, based in Philadelphia. The national association claims 250 community garden programs nationwide as members, but estimates there are nearly 1,000. ``We find that once a garden is developed, it takes over people's lives,'' said Jane Weissman, director of Operation GreenThumb. ``What they are really doing is throwing open their doors, going down in their streets, meeting their neighbors and creating an environment of safety with others.'' Three years ago, John English was a jeweler on Wall Street. Today, he owns a construction company he founded to stop a city plan to pave over what is considered the city's first community garden. English, 47, couldn't understand how developers' plans to widen the sidewalk and put in shops and low- and middle-income housing would improve the neighborhood more than the Liz Christy Garden. He became an expert on housing to argue his case that the garden should stay and that the homes should be built elsewhere. English won, and the graceful garden still gives the feel of the backyard of a country estate. Only it's on Houston Street, a main thoroughfare pounded day and night by trucks and cabs. ``A garden is part of the soul. Without the cycles of life, one loses track of reality,'' he said. ``So to me, this is real in a city which is surreal.'' The noise of clattering trucks fades in the tranquility of the garden, but the syringes and other trash tossed over the fence are a reminder of the mean streets outside. All of the city-sponsored gardens must be opened to the public at least once a week, and on a recent evening passers-by strolled among the peach, apricot and plum trees while some of English's employees barbecued lobster and corn and drank beer. ``This is my yard,'' he said. Teresa Civello, a neighborhood resident, calls the garden ``a piece of heaven.'' ``I walk by every morning and here, in the middle of this desolate, miserable neighborhood, there is a little bit of hope,'' she said. ``It's always exciting and full of mystery.'' The Green Guerrillas have a paid staff of four and 250 volunteers who share their technical expertise to help start new gardens. The group helped Ms. Rainey landscape her garden in a lot that had been a neighborhood dumping ground, full of discarded appliances, trash and bricks from crumbled buildings. Now, there are plots of greens, okra, string beans, cabbage and tomatoes, surounded by zinnias, gladioluses and wild grass. Ms. Rainey, 61, has lived only in Miami and New York City. She said she had to sit down in the dirt and get acquainted with it. Her friends see the garden as a neighborhood improvement project, she said. ``Even the crackheads haven't bothered me,'' she said. ``They come by and say, `Gert, it's looking good.' ``They sort of protect it. They wouldn't take so much as a tomato.'' But plant rustling is on the rise in the city, and many, including GreenThumb's Ms. Weissman, blame addicts who sell flowers and shrubs on the streets for fast cash. Landscapers also are suspected of stealing plants. Some gardeners have begun chaining bushes and anchoring trees to buried cinder blocks. Over in the Bronx, Geneva McFadden heard about Operation GreenThumb about four years ago and, in one day, rounded up eight neighbors she had never met and received approval for a garden from the community board. They turned a lot that had been piled with burned-out cars and trash into an idyllic patch in a noisy neighborhood of apartment buildings and mini-markets. The garden is a mix of meticulous brick-lined flower beds of roses, geraniums, petunias, marigolds and pink clover, and wood-framed vegetable plots thick with healthy tomato plants, cabbage and corn. ``People stop and comment _ white, black and Spanish _ so it brings the neighborhood together,'' said Mrs. McFadden, 75, who grew up on a farm in South Carolina. ``The kids stand there looking. A lot of them have never seen flowers grow before.'' Thousands of people walk by Randy Glaser's garden in Greenwich Village each day to gaze through the chain-link fence at elegant rosebushes, climbing trellises, neat vegetable plots and beds of Johnny-jump-ups, delphinium and fire lillies. Many of the admirers are drawn as they leave a supermarket just feet away. ``People are constantly stopping, asking questions, saying thank you for the garden,'' Glaser said. ``They almost become poets _ some call it an oasis in a cement desert; some say they've changed stores just to come by here.'' ``It's like I've reunited with the earth, the world,'' Ms. Rainey said recently as she sat under in the shade of a tree, smoking a cigarette. ``You look out the window and see vacant buildings, homeless people on TV, our children destroyed by drugs,'' she said. ``It's all like a big sore festering and the garden takes your mind off that.''

DOC.HEAD: `Chinatown' Sequel Finally Makes It to Screen After 16 Years
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jack Nicholson was philosophical as he looked back on his strife-filled, five-year ordeal in making ``The Two Jakes,'' the long-awaited sequel to ``Chinatown.'' ``It's like the Army: As soon as it's over, somehow it all reduces down to a bunch of funny camp stories,'' he said. A mellowed-out Nicholson was holed up in a Beverly Hills Hotel suite for a round of interviews to call attention to the release of ``The Two Jakes,'' in which he starred as well as directed. He had just returned from New York, where he showed the film to a few pals, including directors Mike Nichols, Bernardo Bertolucci and Sidney Lumet. He thinks they liked it. ``The only way you can gauge your friends is when the lights come up. Can they look at one another?'' he said. ``If they go like this (glancing sideways), you know that back in their minds they're saying, `How do I deal with this?' We've all been in that situation.'' The arrival of ``The Two Jakes'' climaxes a long and dramatic history that began nearly two decades ago. Nicholson and screenwriter Robert Towne, once classmates in Jeff Corey's acting class, conceived a plan to make three films based on power and corruption in earlier Los Angeles. ``Chinatown'' in 1974 was the first of the trilogy. In 1985, Nicholson and Towne joined forces with producer Robert Evans, who had been production head at Paramount Pictures when ``Chinatown'' was made, for ``The Two Jakes.'' Towne would direct, and Evans, who hadn't acted in 25 years, would play Jake Berman, enemy of Nicholson's detective Jake Gittes. Trouble in the partnership developed, Nicholson said because Towne believed Evans wasn't right for such an important role, and refused to proceed unless Evans was replaced. Harvey Keitel eventually got the role, but the impasse led to the film's cancellation. The triad was patched together enough to revive ``The Two Jakes,'' and production began on April 18, 1989, with Nicholson directing and receiving Directors Guild scale. Why did he assume the double duty? ``It kind of evolved that way,'' he explained. ``We had spent quite a bit of money, the budget had been hammered down to minimal _ not low-budget but good, astringent movie-making. There really wasn't enough left to get Bertolucci, or Nichols, or Roman (Polanski, who directed `Chinatown') or whoever we might have wanted. ``Doing both has got to be one of the hardest jobs you can do. ... You're doing 20-hour days. There's no way around it. You got to get the call, get to makeup, set up the shots; you're done at dark, you got to travel, see the dailies, go home, shower, eat, learn the lines for tomorrow, get the shots in your mind. By then it's 2-3 o'clock in the morning and you got to get up at 7 or 8 in order to be on the set. ``There's no time to catch up, should you lose energy. Being a hysterical person, I didn't lose much energy.'' Nicholson's decade in the Roger Corman quickie factory helped him make ``The Two Jakes'' on schedule and on budget (reportedly $25 million, including hefty charges for the aborted version). His lesson from the Corman days: ``That good and cheap is more creative than good and expensive.'' ``The Two Jakes'' was originally set for release last Christmas, a deadline Nicholson considered unrealistic. There had been rumors that preview audiences were confused by the complicated plot, hence he added narration to help explain it. ``The narration is very philosophical; it's not plot,'' he said. ``Oddly, just the sense of `If we don't understand it, he'll tell us' gave that security that I'm not sure I actually got in the rest of the movie.'' At the beginning of the interview, Nicholson was downing a frothy, purplish drink which he has termed ``the elixir of life.'' It is part of the liquid diet that has helped him lose 30 excess pounds he carried as Jake Gittes. He proudly displayed his new figure. He also spoke proudly of his 4-month-old daughter, born to Rebecca Brousard, who plays Gittes' secretary in ``The Two Jakes.'' ``She's fantastic, a boon from divine nature,'' he exulted. ``Nothing's any better in life, as you know. When I see those big cheeks, I gargle and google like the next guy. I feel very blessed.'' The romance with Brousard and the baby reportedly caused the break in Nicholson's 17-year alliance with Anjelica Huston. He has another daughter from his first and only marriage, to Sandra Knight, another classmate at Jeff Corey's. She is Jennifer, 26, who also worked on ``The Two Jakes'' as a design assistant. The only situation clouding Jack Nicholson's life at 53 concerns the Los Angeles Lakers. He worries about rumored trades and lineup changes. ``Magic (Johnson) is Magic, but he can't carry the whole load himself,'' he commented. ``Otherwise Michael Jordan would win the championship. ``But we'll have a representative team out there to watch. Only for kids do you have to win the championship every year.'' One thing is certain: Nicholson will be occupying his usual courtside position when the Laker season begins. During his recent trip to New York, he switched sports and attended a Yankees baseball game. He was amused by the reaction. ``A bunch of people saw me, and like a moron, I stood up and waved. Pandemonium broke out and the fans started chanting, `Jack! Buy the Yanks!' ``I took $5 out of my pocket and waved it at them. All the players were looking over and wondering what the hell was going on,'' he said. ``You never know what's going to happen in life.''

DOC.HEAD: From Baseball Hopeful to Comic Book Artist
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Growing up, Todd McFarlane was an indiscriminate comic book addict. ``Anything that came out, I grabbed it,'' he says. Today the 29-year-old Canadian artist _ the man behind the new, improved Spider-Man, has become the favorite of comic book aficionados by remembering what caught his eye years ago. ``I still believe comic books are for kids,'' he says. ``I try to put onto the pages all the things that I used to like when I was growing up.'' It's not only kids, though, who are captivated by McFarlane's extraordinarily detailed, action-packed work. The first issue of his new Marvel Comics series, titled simply ``Spider-Man,'' quickly sold nearly 3 million copies this summer to become the best-selling comic book in U.S. history. McFarlane, who garnered a huge following during the two years he drew for the original title, ``Amazing Spider-Man,'' is both writer and artist on the new series, the fifth to feature the wall-crawler. Maggie Thompson, co-editor of the Comics Buyer's Guide, a trade journal based in Iola, Wis., credits the new book's success to, ``the combination of a popular character, a popular creator, a No. 1 (first issue) title and a couple of special editions that have fanned the flames a little bit.'' McFarlane was named favorite cover artist and favorite penciler for the second year in a row in this summer's Comics Buyer's Guide readers poll. In a telephone interview from his home and studio on Vancouver Island, McFarlane said he went into comics after failing at his first love: professional baseball. He attended Eastern Washington University on a baseball scholarship, but majored in graphic design. After failing to make a Toronto Blue Jays minor league team, he started sending out samples to comics companies, eventually landing a job at Marvel working on ``The Incredible Hulk.'' In 1988, he switched to ``Amazing Spider-Man'' and began the webslinger's makeover, redesigning the costume and adding a ``creepier'' feel. ``I wanted to emphasize the `spider' in the word `Spider-Man,''' he says. ``So I made his eyes a lot bigger to make them look like bug eyes. He has webbing on his costume _ I made about five times as much.'' McFarlane also puts as much effort into the background as he does the star. ``His style is extremely intricate,'' Thompson says. ``He doesn't leave a large area blank because he's too lazy to draw it.'' McFarlane also wants to give kids the same action and excitement in comics that they get from such things as computer games and adventure movies. ``I think that maybe I put a little more energy onto the page,'' he says. ``When somebody is getting slugged, they're flying across the room, they're not just falling over. If somebody gets hit by a ray gun or something, the guy is blasting.'' The wisecracking wall-crawler took ``favorite character'' honors this year in the Buyer's Guide poll, defeating Batman, the titleholder since 1985. Spider-Man made his debut in 1962 as an unpopular, wimpish teen-ager whose life changed forever when he was bitten by a radioactive spider in a high school science lab. Today he's a graduate student in biophysics who shares a SoHo loft with his glamorous actress-model wife. The fact that Spider-Man continues to draw new generations into his web doesn't surprise Stan Lee, the writer who created the character with artist Steve Ditko. ``They like Spider-Man because they can relate to him,'' Lee said. ``He worries about earning a living. He has domestic problems. He has personal problems. He's as apt to get an ingrown toenail or an allergy attack or worry about dandruff as anybody else.'' The character was conceived as an average kid who happens to get super powers, in sharp contrast to the more established characters such as Superman, who comes from outer space, and Batman, whose alter ego, Bruce Wayne, is a multimillionaire. ``The original concept of Spider-Man _ the teen-ager who's unpopular in school but has these secret powers and is someone to be reckoned with _ feeds a lot of fantasies of a lot of people,'' Thompson says. Lee is now publisher at Marvel and at work on developing movie projects, including a possible Spider-Man feature. He confesses to a special love for his most popular creation and says McFarlane has ``a great take'' on the character. ``The toughest part of my job is trying to get as wide an audience as possible,'' McFarlane says. ``You don't want to make it too simple, then you're going to lose the 20-year-olds. But on the other hand, you don't want to make it too funky or weird _ then you're going to lose the 10-year-old kids.''

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a movement that's pushing record companies to ditch the cardboard packaging in which compact discs are sold is claiming victory for his side. By the end of the year, a system will be in place to get rid of the environmentally wasteful ``long boxes,'' says Robert Simonds, chief financial officer of Rykodisc. ``Even the most vehement retailers would admit off the record that the days of the long box are numbered,'' Simonds said. ``I think what they're mostly fighting for now is to make sure they're not stuck with the whole bill to pay for a new system.'' His opponents don't quite share his optimism, but admit they're looking for alternatives. In an industry that loves to show its public concern for the environment and other causes, the controversy over the so-called long boxes is making people squirm. Compact discs are generally packed into 5- by 6-inch plastic ``jewel boxes.'' In order to curtail theft and use more eye-catching graphics, record companies wrap these containers in 6-by 12-inch cardboard boxes. When they buy a CD, most consumers simply tear the boxes apart and throw them away. That doesn't make much sense to Simonds, who says the long boxes are both a waste of money and waste of paper. His ``Ban the Box'' movement started with a letter published in Billboard magazine and grew with the 20th anniversary celebration of Earth Day. Such musicians as R.E.M, Bobby McFerrin, the B-52s, Sting, Rosanne Cash, Olivia Newton-John, the Grateful Dead and Crosby, Stills and Nash have pledged their support. ``If consumers stop and think about the package, they will think that it is kind of a pain in the neck,'' said Simonds, whose company is based in Minneapolis. ``Then when they find out they're paying up to a dollar or more per disc just for the package, then they start getting angry. It's really struck a chord with consumers.'' Simonds stepped up the pressure in recent weeks by asking CD purchasers to tear open the cardboard package in the music store and dump it on the clerk's counter. The Tower Records chain, one of the loudest opponents of ``Ban the Box,'' have put recycling bins in some stores. Long boxes were created partly to enable retailers to place CDs in bins once reserved for records, eliminating the need for a costly change in how stores are set up as records replace CDs as the music source of choice. The smaller package also lessens the chance of an ``impulse buy'' from consumers attracted by colorful graphics, said Floyd Glinert, head of the Entertainment Packaging Association, a group of paper companies that supply the long boxes. ``It has replaced the record jacket as an art form, which is very important to conveying to the public the excitement of a record,'' he said. The United States is the only country that uses long boxes. Getting rid of the boxes, retailers fear, will make them more vulnerable to shoplifters. Despite all the talk about the environment, the issue now is essentially economy. Record companies have changed their tune in recent weeks _ instead of dismissing ``Ban the Box,'' they admit they're seriously examining the criticisms. ``They're not thinking through what the alternatives are before screaming `ban the box,''' said Paul Smith, president of CBS Records distribution. ``There has to be some way of merchandising the product. I think every record company in the business is actively seeking an alternative to the 6-by-12 box.'' Henry Droz, the president of WEA, told Billboard that his company has no specific plans to abandon the long box, ``but I don't know that we have a long-term commitment to keep it.'' Although Simonds is the leader of ``Ban the Box,'' most of his company's product _ particularly the popular CD reissues of old David Bowie albums _ are offered with long boxes. That's because some music chains have told him they won't sell the discs any other way, he said. Simonds offers a discount to retailers who buy his discs without the box. Despite all the environmentally conscious musicians jumping on Simonds' bandwagon, it was Raffi, the Canadian singer of songs written for pre-school youngsters, who blazed a trail. He was the first to insist in a contract with his record company that his CDs be marketed without long boxes. ``I simply believe that the excessive packaging of cassettes and CDs can no longer be tolerated in a global environmental crisis,'' said Raffi, who's signed to MCA. ``If there's enough pressure from artists and their audience, the buying public, I think record stores will respond by eliminating the long box.'' Rocker Joan Jett has asked CBS Records not to release her next CD with a long box or, if the company can't, to not release the album in a CD format at all. Smith said no decision has been made on the request. A state senator from New York has proposed legislation banning the long box from being marketed here. It's the first state to make such a proposal, according to ``Ban the Box'' spokesman Martin Folkman. Simonds suggested this country follow the Canadian record industry's example when it banned the box. In Canada, record companies contributed to a fund that helped retailers make their improvements. ``Ban the Box'' has suggested various alternatives, including new display cases built for jewel boxes and reusable plastic frames that can be taken apart by a clerk. Many paper companies are trying to come up with their own solutions, Glinert said. ``I sense that the major record companies are supportive of getting rid of the long box but are in an awkward position of not wanting to take that stand against their retail customers until they're forced to,'' Simonds said. ``That would force them, if just a few of their superstar artists throw us their support.''

DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Chinese Jews Live in Old Imperial Capital

When residents of North and South Scripture Lane see a foreigner wandering down their alley, they can guess why. ``Are you looking for descendants of the Jews?'' asked an old man sitting beside the dirt lane in his undershirt, and told the visitor about Li, who lived a few streets away. He waved a hand toward where Zhao lived, but would not take the stranger there. `He's not accepting visitors anymore,'' the old man said. ``He's had too many.'' Zhao Pingyu, 68, is one of a few hundred descendants of Jews living in this ancient center of Judaism, 390 miles from Beijing in Henan province. Kaifeng, the imperial capital from the 10th to the 13th century, once was home to thousands of Jews, but they gradually became so assimilated that little is left to distinguish them except their memories and stories. In the 1980s, as China opened to the outside world, Kaifeng officials sought to cash in on the mystique of Jews in China to draw attract tourists. Their attitude appears to have changed since the crackdown last year on ``bourgeois liberalism,'' the catch phrase for Western ideas. When a New York family held a bat mitzvah in Kaifeng last month for their daughter's coming of age, their requests for permission to invite the local Jewish community were ignored. Zhao said the Kaifeng foreign affairs office had told him not to receive foreigners except at official receptions, then he added: ``But if people come on their own to my house, how can I not invite them in? That would be inhospitable.'' Although neighbors are reluctant to take people to Zhao, visitors have little trouble finding him. Zhao is well-known in Kaifeng because he is one of the few Jews with knowledge of Jewish history and culture. He lives with his wife, a non-Jew, in a large room at the back of a courtyard on South Scripture Lane that once was part of the synagogue compound. The synagogue was built in 1163 and stood for 700 years through 10 renovations. It eventually was destroyed by flooding from the Yellow River, and the No. 4 People's Hospital now stands on the site. Zhao has a diagram of the synagogue, which his great-great-grandfather restored after retiring from an imperial court office. A few years ago, after his own retirement from the tax bureau, Zhao started building a model of the synagogue, which included three elaborate worship halls and several side buildings. Much work still remains. One of the three stone tablets displayed in Kaifeng's museum exhibit on Jews in China came from Zhao's family. The tablets are the Jews' best historical record. Jewish merchants arrived in China in the 7th century, joining other traders on the journey along the Silk Road or by sea from south India. Thousands settled in Kaifeng, eventually creating China's largest Jewish community and the one that lasted longest. As recently as 200 years ago, 2,000 to 3,000 Jews worshipped weekly in the Kaifeng's synagogue. By the mid-19th century, the Jews had intermarried and become assimilated. They adopted the customs of the majority Han Chinese or the Moslems, forgot the Hebrew language and took Chinese names. A survey of Kaifeng in 1980 found only 79 Jewish families with 166 members. Other accounts say Kaifeng's population of 500,000 includes up to 300 descendants of Jews. Zhao and other Jews in the old imperial capital do not observe Jewish rituals or holidays, but he remembers eating unleavened bread for the Passover meal as a child. Many Chinese Jews observed Passover during the Chinese Lunar New Year. Even though he does not practice Judaism, Zhao maintains his sense of Jewish identity. ``When the Jews come here from foreign countries, I feel there's some connection, some relationship by blood,'' he said. ``They're our friends and our brothers.'' A menorah given him by an American Jew is displayed in the middle of Zhao's room, but he never uses the ceremonial candleholder. A blue yarmulke, handmade by one of his daughters, hangs on a wall. ``I have five daughters,'' he said. ``That's a good thing for a Jew, because Judaism is passed down through the mother.'' Zhao's household registration lists him as a Jew, but his new citizen identification card says says he is Han Chinese. He said one daughter was so adamant about being Jewish that she refused to get an identification card, because it would identify her as Han Chinese. China has 54 minority groups. It does not recognize Jews as a minority because they no longer have a language or customs to distinguish them from Han Chinese. Moslems, who still practice their religion and have kept their traditions, are China's second-largest minority. They have token representation in government and the Communist Party and are entitled to special treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Returns Hemisphere's First Book of Medicine to Mexico
By LAURA CASTANEDA
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Curanderos no longer recommend drinking jaguar blood for strength, but the medicine men still use herbs to induce abortions. The prescriptions and procedures are in the first known book of medicine written in North or South America. The book has returned to Mexico after more than 400 years, a gift of Pope John Paul II. ``It is very important because it provides a series of prescriptions that allow us to study indigenous medicines,'' said Dr. Carlos Viesca, a professor of history and medicine at the National Autonomous University of Mexico. Viesca is the nation's leading authority on the 140-page book, which bears the title ``Libellus de Medicinalibus Indorum Herbis'' but is commonly known as the Badiano Manuscript. In it are lists of ailments, treatments used by central Mexico's indigenous population and illustrations of 185 plants. Viesca said modern-day curanderos still use 90 percent of the plants as medicines. Martin de la Cruz, an Indian doctor at the College of Santa Cruz at Tlatelolco, wrote the manuscript in the Nahuatl language in 1552, and Juan Badiano translated it into Latin. Little else is known of the two men. Francisco de Mendoza, the son of New Spain's first viceroy, commissioned the volume as a gift for King Charles I of Spain, who eventually gave it to one of his librarians. It was sold to Cardinal Francisco Barberini of Rome, who kept it until his death in 1902, then went to the Vatican library, to be forgotten until two researchers disovered it 27 years later. Besides chronicling indigenous cures, Viesca said, the book ``could be used as a model to study traditional medicine to see how much has been maintained, how much has been lost and how much has been integrated'' into modern medicine. Some plants described in it have effective medicinal properties and about 10 percent have been studied by modern scientists, he said. Yolloxochetl, related to the magnolia, functions as a heart stimulant much like the drug digitalis, Viesca said in an interview. Cihuapatli has been found to induce labor, menstruation and abortions. Many religious-magical aspects of the treatments have passed out of vogue, he said. Before the Spanish came, curanderos called for divine intervention and recommended feasting on the bones, bile, organs and blood of animals. Viesca said jaguar blood was believed to bring extraordinary physical strength. John Paul returned the book after President Carlos Salinas de Gortari mentioned it during the pope's visit to Mexico in May. A copy is on display at the National Museum of Anthropology, but the original is permanently stored to prevent further damage from light or temperature variations. Viesca said the museum may publish an edition for public sale.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Valmont'' (Orion. VHS-Beta, $89.98. Rated R)
Filmmakers seem to have a love affair with Choderlos de Laclos' 1782 epistolary novel, ``Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' And with his story of seduction, hedonism and revenge in 18th-century France, it's no surprise. The work was first interpreted on film by Roger Vadim in 1959. It starred Gerard Phillipe and Jeanne Moreau as two icy, modern-day opportunists with an ``open marriage.'' It had a jazzy score by Thelonius Monk and Jack Murray. The second movie version was 1988's ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' an Americanized, fast-paced drama directed by Stephen Frears and starring Glenn Close as the scheming Marquise de Merteuil and John Malkovich as the notorious rake Valmont. Next comes Milos Forman's ``Valmont,'' a 1989 movie now available on video. And it is as different from the other efforts as the many interpretations of Shakespeare's ``Hamlet.'' It is a lush and elegant movie, graced by the seductive camera work of Miroslav Ondricek. With a keen eye for detail, Forman eases into de Laclos' story against the blind morals of prerevolutionary France. His vision is sweeping _ there's no rush but still much activity. Forman loves the bustle and business of earlier times _ jugglers, merchants, servants always underfoot. As Madame de Merteuil, Annette Bening brings a sugary bitchiness. She is less brittle than the Glenn Close interpretation and also less focused. But her intent is clear: She loves playing games, wicked, vicious games that ultimately destroy people and bring ruin to a way of life. Colin Firth's Valmont is far more attractive than Malkovich's. Indeed, one wondered why women would ever be drawn to the Malkovich character, with his pasty visage and deep-set eyes, and Bronx sounding voice. Firth is almost too cute, almost too soft. And the steely maliciousness is missing. Meg Tilly is convincing as a vulnerable and pious young wife, a woman Valmontw orships and for whom he lusts. Fairuza Balk (``Return to Oz'') portrays Cecile, the target of Valmont's seduction and the innocent victim of Merteuil's revenge. Her mother has arranged for the convent school girl to marry Gercourt, an older man who will take only a virgin as his wife. He's also Merteuil's ex-lover. Forman dances his characters about in a game of musical beds, a game that's a no-win for just about all. Jean-Claude Carriere's screenplay makes good use of de Laclos' focus on letter writing. Letters show up just about everywhere, and even Valmont gets into the spirit by dictating erotic passages to an unsuspecting Cecile to send to the young music teacher (Henry Thomas) who loves her. As a video, ``Valmont'' is worth renting or buying as a companion to other dangerous liaisons.

``Blaze'' (Touchstone. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated R)
``Blaze'' is one of those warm, peppery movies that seem to work better on the small screen and hence are a welcomed video find. Louisiana Gov. Earl K. Long was a raunchy delight who believed in good ol' boy politics and good time women in the 1950s-style South. His affair with striptease dancer Blaze Starr created a scandal that eventually led to his undoing. As Long, Paul Newman is a treat. He's brash and egocentric, a womanizer who thinks nothing of having his mistress attend a formal dinner party at the governor's mansion. He even wears his boots when he engages in love-making. Lolita Davidovich is the voluptuous Blaze, a poor mountain girl who leaves home to seek her fame and fortune with her guitar and a few downhome songs. But it's not her singing the bar boys want. But when Blaze gets into the strip business, she does it her way and in her own style. As director, Ron Shelton creates the same feel in ``Blaze'' that he had in ``Bull Durham.'' There's a nice touch to it all, and he lets the story unravel on its own with just a dab of humor and humanity. Watch this one.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis pushed oil prices to the highest levels in five years, pummeled stock prices and raised more fears about the economy's vulnerability to an energy-cost shock. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of key West Texas Intermediate crude jumped $3.56 a barrel Monday to settle at $28.05. Prices for refined products such as heating oil and gasoline also surged dramatically.

Analysts predict the Federal Reserve Board will soon lower its federal funds rate to 7} percent from 8 percent to stimulate the economy after the damaging new blow from higher oil prices. The economy, slowed already to barely perceptible growth during the first half of the year, was threatened further Monday by embargoes imposed by the United States and many other Western nations on imports of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil.

The chairman of a House energy subcommittee called on the Bush administration, in coordination with Japan and Europe, to start pumping oil from emergency government reserves to halt the price spiral brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The Strategic Petroleum Reserve has to be used to make sure shortages don't show up ..., to short the market and protect the consumer,'' Rep. Philip R. Sharp, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on energy and power, said Monday.

Pan American World Airways became the second major airline to raise fares following the Iraqi invasion, boosting the price of all flights by 10 percent to offset rising jet fuel costs. Several other airlines said Monday such increases were still premature. Northwest Airlines previously had announced an $8 per ticket fuel surcharge.

Gasoline prices soaring nationwide are drawing anger from consumers, station owners and state officials who claim major oil companies are exploiting Middle East tensions to jack up prices. Companies on Monday blamed the increases on higher costs, fluctuations on the frenetic oil markets and added demand during the summer driving season.

U.S. worker productivity has improved for the first time in 18 months and is climbing at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the government said. Analysts said Monday the gain in non-farm productivity provided encouraging news in light of recent reports showing rising unemployment and stagnant economic growth.

A federal judge has extended for 30 days a freeze on payments to asbestos victims by the financially ailing Manville trust. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said the extension he ordered Monday would allow completion of a court-appointed reorganization plan for the trust, which has run out of money to pay new claims by tens of thousands of workers made sick from inhaling asbestos fibers.

Arizona insurance executive James M. Fail says he fully disclosed allegations of fraud leveled against him in 1976 before federal regulators allowed him to acquire a bailed-out savings and loan. Testifying before a Senate subcommittee Monday about his acquisition of Bluebonnet Savings Bank, Fail acknowledged incomplete and inaccurate disclosure documents were filed with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board but he later provided full details about the fraud case in Alabama.

Salim B. ``Sandy'' Lewis, one of the best known Wall Street traders, agreed to pay $475,000 to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit arising from his guilty plea to criminal stock manipulation charges. The SEC suit, filed Monday in federal court, alleged Lewis violated securities laws by helping to manipulate the price of Fireman's Fund Corp. stock in 1986 _ the same accusations to which he pleaded guilty in a criminal proceeding.

The stock market took its worst hit since the ``mini-crash'' last October amid panicky selling sparked by fears that consequences of the Persian Gulf crisis could topple the teetering U.S. economy into recession. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chips ended down 93.31 points, or 3.32 percent, at 2,716.34. Since July 30, the widely watched market barometer has lost 200.99 points. Elsewhere, long-term government bond prices plunged, the dollar weakened, gold strengthened and other commodoties were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: The Economic Machine Needs Oil
Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: Turmoil in oil prices leaves no market unaffected and throws a wrench into every stock forecast and economic projection _ of gross national product, inflation, interest rates _ made by government or private sages. There isn't a person who can say for sure, not even the President or the Federal Reserve chairman, what the immediate economic future holds, except to say that not one American is immune from the effects. There isn't a single economist who can rely on his or her own estimates of future activity, not one stock market guru from the most conservative to the zaniest whose thinking hasn't been changed. Unless resolved quickly, the oil crisis has the potential to cut half a percentage point or more from the gross national product this year, which means it could be the difference between slow growth and official recession. It forces the White House to reconsider fiscal strategies and it compels the Federal Reserve to think again before moving against inflation. It changes the dollar's trade value, the corporate profits outlook, and the outlook for budget and balance-of-payments deficits. For individuals, it means higher fuel oil prices, higher prices for gasoline, higher ticket prices on airlines. It could mean higher utility bills, and higher prices for almost any product you can name. It could mean jobs. If the word ``vulnerable'' is overused generally, it is not in regard to the developed world's dependency on oil. Japan imports almost all its oil. The United States now imports nearly half, the highest level ever. The health of Europe depends on a few pipes running from the Mideast through Turkey. Compared with 1973, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries created the first big oil shortage and sent the entire economy into a tailspin, the United States is even more vulnerable. U.S. domestic production has fallen. Alaska's oil output rose steadily from the late 1970s through 1988. Last year, that state's output dropped 7 percent, and the trans-Alaska pipeline has begun to show signs of corrosion. United Kingdom output in the North Sea, a friendly source and one relied upon by trading partners, has also been down because of labor and maintenance problems. It could worsen into fall. Mexican production also is off, but stepped-up Mexican, Venezuelan and American production couldn't for long, if at all, make up the shortfall from a cessation, however brief, of oil shipments from the Mideast. Incredibly, evidence of Western World vulnerability has been available _ measured almost to the gallon _ to almost everyone in a position to take action, including the White House and Congress. Every White House economic adviser knew that any official projections made included assumptions of a plentiful supply of oil at a moderate price, and that if that assurance was lost then no forecast made any sense at all. That also includes those who made projections of American industrial production, of stock and bond market performance, of inflation, interest rates and recession, of homebuilding, automobile production, airline travel ... America's dependency on oil, especially foreign oil, is rising in spite of at least two serious scares in the 1970s, after which many leaders declared we could never let it happen again. It has grown as reliance on other sources _ hydraulic, solar and nuclear _ diminished. It has grown as a result of abandonment of efforts at conservation, which had worked so well. It has grown as domestic production declined. Oil's impact is fundamental and pervasive, even bringing into question the political and military usage of the word ``powerful,'' as in ``the most powerful nation on earth.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Price Hikes Would Produce Mostly Losers
DOC.TEXT: Houston real estate dealers and the Soviet Union are potential gainers, but nearly everyone else stands to lose economically if the Iraqiinvasion of Kuwait leads to a spell of high oil prices, analysts say. ``The oil price increases are both recessionary and inflationary and there are many more losers than winners,'' said Allen Sinai, an economist with Boston Co. and Economic Advisers Inc. in an interview Monday. ``If the price increase sticks, it will lead to a major transfer of wealth from non-oil producing countries to oil countries,'' he said. He and other economists and industry analysts listed a long string of losers if the current Middle East crisis leads to sustained oil price increases: the auto industry, housing, nearly all consumer-related industries, and entertainment and travel firms. But higher prices might benefit others, analysts say: investors in gold and other precious metals, domestic oil companies and oil drilling companies, as well as the economies of oil-rich states like Texas and Louisiana. Added Sinai: ``The Soviet Union, with its oil and gold reserves, is a potential winner.'' Each stressed that any such economic impacts depended on whether the oil price increase proves to be a momentary blip or a long-term fact of life. John Chadderdon, editor of Offshore Data Services, a Houston-based publisher of information on offshore drilling for oil and gas, said that if oil prices rise well above $20 a barrel and stay there, that might spur exploration in the Gulf of Mexico. The price of West Texas crude oil has risen to about $25 a barrel, up about $4 in the last week, Chadderdon said. ``If it's long term, that's something that should spur U.S. activity. A $20 per barrel price is just not enough for many companies to go after areas in the Gulf of Mexico. It's just too expensive,'' he said. He speculated that what's good for domestic oil companies might be good, in the long run, for local real estate in oil producing regions of the country. George McCauley, an oil analyst for the National Utility Service, Inc., a private consulting firm, said motorists already feeling the effects at the gas pump will continue to be losers, along with air travellers. Two airlines, Pan American World Airways and Northwest, have announced ticket price increases to offset rising jet fuel costs. And the oil price increases may mean a long, cold, and expensive winter for homeowners, he said. ``If the rise in oil futures prices translates into actual dollar increases, then come fall when utility companies draw down current inventories, they will have to be replaced at higher cost which will be passed on to the consumer,'' McCauley said. Sinai added that oil prices would be bad news for nearly all investors. Only holders of commodities and precious metals might stand to gain. ``Normally, the dollar does well; that is not happening this time,'' Sinai said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Linked to Boyd Jefferies Sanctioned By SEC
DOC.TEXT: Two stock brokers who cooperated with prosecutors in securities cases stemming from the Ivan Boesky insider trading scandals settled administrative charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. James T. Melton, who testified for the government at the GAF Corp. stock manipulation trial and Michael Z. Landy, a government witness against takeover strategist Paul Bilzerian, settled SEC actions Monday. Both men, without admitting or denying wrongdoing, agreed to a six-month ban from dealing in the securities industry. Attorneys for neither man were in their office Monday when called for comment. Melton, 47, a former director of trading for Los Angeles-based Jefferies & Co. testified at two of the three trials of GAF and GAF Vice Chairman James Sherwin. They were accused of plotting to drive up the price of Union Carbide stock after a failed GAF takeover attempt of the chemical-maker. The case ended in a mistrial twice before a guilty verdict in December 1989. Boyd Jefferies, who founded the securities firm and who himself pleaded guilty to securities law violations, was the government's key witness against GAF, which was fined $2 million and Sherwin, who was sentenced to six months in prison. Jefferies was given up to authorities by convicted stock speculator Ivan Boesky, who implicated several Wall Street professionals in the industry's biggest scandal. Melton left Jefferies & Co. in 1989. Landy, also 47, a senior vice president at Jefferies, cooperated with investigators and testified at Bilzerian's trial. Bilzerian was convicted of submitting false documents to the SEC, filing false tax returns and rigging transactions to skirt federal tax and disclosure laws in tandem with Jefferies. The case was the first criminal trial of illegal stock ``parking,'' in which securities ownership is disguised to dodge federal tax or disclosure laws. Bilzerian was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $1.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Extends Freeze on Payments by Asbestos Trust
DOC.TEXT: People awaiting compensation from the Manville trust fund for asbestos victims will have to wait at least another month. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn on Monday extended for 30 days a freeze on payments for asbestos-related diseases to allow completion of a plan to restructure the financially ailing trust. Weinstein said the extension would allow completion of a court-appointed reorganization plan for the trust, which has run out of money to pay new claims by thousands of workers made sick from inhaling asbestos fibers. But Leon Silverman, the bankruptcy court-appointed adviser supervising the reorganization, said ``it is almost impossible to conclude'' that the more than 130,000 pending claimants would receive the full value of their claims. The reorganization is designed to speed payments and alter the compensation scheme to process claims based on victims' health and financial need rather than when they file a claim. Weinstein last month set Monday as a deadline for the overhaul plan and froze spending during the process to prevent a further cash drain. The trust was created in 1988 as part of Manville Corp.'s bankruptcy court reorganization, a result of rising liability from lung cancer and other serious and fatal diseases caused by asbestos. The trust has paid $974 million to settle more than 22,000 cases, but still has 130,000 claims pending. A cash shortfall led the trust recently to say it would not be able to pay new claims until well into the 21st century. U.S. District Judge Thomas D. Lambros in Cleveland on Monday proposed consolidating pending Manville trust claims with a private consortium that has been negotiating settlements for other asbestos-makers. Under the proposal, the Center for Claims Resolution in Princeton, N.J., would be annexed to the legal system and directed by a board of judges with input from plaintiffs and defense lawyers and other parties involved. The center, which is funded by 20 asbestos defendants and insurance companies, has settled 36,000 claims in 18 months. Lambros said a court-affiliated center could minimize transaction costs and resolve pending claims until a long-term national settlement scheme is reached. Silverman said progress had been made toward providing ``meaningful funds in the near term to victims without sacrificing the long-term value of the Manville stock.'' The trust effectively owns 80 percent of Denver-based Manville, which must make annual payments to the trust beginning next year and is shielded from further legal liability for asbestos claims. Weinstein and Silverman supported continuing an injunction barring lawsuits against Manville, which would hurt the trust by depleting the value of Manville assets. But the judge criticized Manville, saying the company was unrealistic about its role in refinancing the trust. Weinstein in the past has suggested that the company should make new direct payments of more than $200 million to the trust. Manville has said its financial commitment ended with large contributions when the trust was created and its role is to strengthen Manville to bolster the trust's value. Manville Chief Executive Thomas Stephens said he was disappointed with Weinstein's comments. He said the company had offered to inject $500 million last November through a stock repurchase plan. In an interview, Stephens said the company last week recommended a plan to inject some cash into the trust, which in return would sell some Manville stock into the marketplace. ``We're fully aware and sympathetic of the needs of the claimants and are doing everything we can to optimize today's dollar and tomorrow's dollar,'' he said. The trust, based in Washington, is named in more than 100,000 lawsuits on the dockets of every federal district court and more than 500 state courts nationwide. The cash shortage at the trust had been anticipated, but made worse by more cases, larger payouts and quicker settlements than expected. Victims had received an average of $43,000 per claim, compared with estimates of $25,000. According to court documents, the trust has $93.2 million to pay $112.8 million in claims already settled. That money is frozen by the judge's order. Asbestos, a white mineral used for heat resistance and insulation, was widely used in shipbuilding, construction and other industries. Six federal judges are scheduled to meet later this week in Washington to discuss prospects for consolidating the asbestos litigation docket into a class action to speed resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu To Ask Arabs To Boost Oil Production
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will ask Arab leaders to help offset the burden of an oil embargo against Iraq by boosting their oil production, a top government official said Tuesday. Trade Minister Kabun Muto told reporters Kaifu had decided to make the request to pre-empt problems that could be caused if an international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil exports is prolonged. Kaifu plans to make the request of Arab leaders during a tour of the Middle East that is to begin Aug. 15 and take him to Saudi Arabia, Oman, Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, Muto said. Kaifu's journey had been arranged before the Iraq-Kuwait crisis erupted. Oil-poor Japan on Sunday joined the United States and the European Community in the embargo to try to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces that invaded Kuwait last Thursday. Japan also suspended trade credits to Iraq and Kuwait, banned trade with both countries, and instructed banks and securities companies to freeze assets. In announcing the sanctions, which were officially approved Tuesday by the Cabinet, Kaifu stressed that Japan has 142 days of reserves and ``will come up with necesssary measures to cope with the problem.'' Tokyo's actions are seen as especially tough since Japan had previously taken a low profile in the Middle East, which supplies much of Japan's oil needs. Iraq and Kuwait accounted for 11.2 percent of Japan's oil supply, or 470,000 barrels a day, in the first quarter of the year, according to the trade ministry. Kaifu and other leaders are calling on the Japanese to conserve energy, but no measures have been implemented. Officials are reportedly considering whether the use of air conditioning should be limited at government offices and gas stations shut down on weekends. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto tried to reassure traders by saying he does not expect stocks and bonds to suffer an extended weakness because of the crisis. But share prices on Tokyo's rich, and often volatile, stock market began to tumble almost immediately after the sanctions were announced. The market's main barometer lost 3.1 percent Monday and tumbled another 3.3 percent Tuesday, bringing the Nikkei Stock Average index to its lowest level in nearly two years. ``Market players were concerned about how much the incident may prompt inflation,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. ``Unless they figure out the extent of its effect, investors are inclined to stay away from the stock market.'' ``Prices of crude are beginning to increase, so that might have an effect on inflation,'' conceded Shousuke Tanaka, head of the Economic Planning Agency's Research Bureau. Tanaka said that with each 10 percent increase in crude prices, consumer prices go up 0.1 percent. Tanaka, however, stressed that his agency does not foresee any major change in Japan's economic growth that has continued for 44 consecutive months. ``So what we really have to be cautious about (at this time) is inflationary psychology,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Announces Up To 2,000 Layoffs in Consolidation
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics Corp., faced with sagging business prospects in the defense industry, has announced plans to eliminate between 1,500 and 2,000 jobs in California. The St. Louis-based defense contractor said Monday it would combine its Pomona and Valley Systems divisions into a single unit to be called the Air Defense Systems Division. The two divisions, located in Pomona and Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., produce missiles. ``The consolidation, effective immediately, is the result of declining business prospects in the defense industry,'' said Ralph Hawes, executive vice president for missiles and electronics. The announcement was another blow to the defense industry, which last month was hit with the news that the nation's largest defense contractor, St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas Corp., was reducing its workforce by up to 11 percent, or 17,000 jobs nationwide, by the end of this year. ``In order to remain competitive in a declining market for missiles and other air defense systems, General Dynamics must more efficiently use its existing resources and reduce overhead,'' said Michael C. Keel, who has been named corporate vice president and general manager of the new division. Keel had been corporate vice president and general manager of the Valley Systems division since 1988. Sterling Starr, who had been corporate vice president and general manager of the Valley Systems division, will help in the initial steps of the consolidation before being reassigned. ``While we all welcomed a diminished threat from the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, these changes have brought unfortunate personal economic consequences for many people in the U.S. defense industry,'' Keel said. Keel added that the company would provide the laid-off employees with career consulting and placement assistance services. More than 600 of the layoffs will be caused by the elimination of duplicate jobs, he said. The Pomona division produces Standard and Sparrow Missiles and Phalanx Close-in Weapon Systems, while Valley Systems builds Stinger and Rolling Airframe Missiles for the U.S. military and its allies. The Pomona division was formed in 1952 and Valley Systems was created in 1985 in response to the then expanding military market. The company said the Air Defense Systems Division would not only operate facilities in Pomona and Rancho Cucamonga, but also in New Mexico, Arizona, Arkansas and San Diego County in California. With the consolidation, General Dynamics, the nation's second largest defense contractor, has eight divisions and six subsidiaries. They are all involved in defense work expect Cessna Aircraft, which makes general aviation aircraft. Overall, the company reportedly employs about 103,000 people.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 18.06 at 2,734.40 by 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Thomas Czech, chairman of the investment committee at Blunt Ellis & Loewi, said there is a perception that actions taken by the United States and other countries to thwart Iraq are working and will help steady the turbulent oil market. The explosion in oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait last week has fanned inflation fears and fueled anxiety about the U.S. and world economic outlook. But Czech said he doesn't expect a sudden change in market sentiment. The financial markets remain cautious in the face of increasingly sluggish U.S. economic growth. Trading activity slowed slightly from Friday's brisk pace. DOC.HEAD: Exec Says Toyota Likely to Take Control of California Plant in '96
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. may take control of its joint venture plant with General Motors Corp. in California when the option arises in 1996, an executive says. If Toyota acquires the New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. factory in Fremont, Calif., it will double its own U.S. manufacturing base now centered at a car plant in Georgetown, Ky. ``Our estimation is that we might become a Toyota factory here in America,'' Gary Convis, NUMMI's vice president for manufacturing, said Monday. Convis, speaking at the opening of a weeklong management seminar, also said that the company's relationship with the United Auto Workers union has worked well. The UAW has had trouble organizing the so-called transplants _ factories owned wholly or partly by Japanese companies. Three of the eight non-Big Three factories in the United States have UAW-negotiated contracts. GM and Toyota began producing cars at NUMMI in 1984 and limited the duration of the joint venture to 12 years because of U.S. government antitrust requirements. So far, neither GM nor Toyota has announced which company would own the plant after the agreement ends. The factory produces the Geo Prizm for GM and the Toyota Corolla. Last year, Toyota announced a $300 million expansion at NUMMI to add pickup truck production.

DOC.HEAD: Beleaguered Brokerage Sued, Accused of Misrepresenting Finances
DOC.TEXT: Stotler Group Inc., until recently a formidable presence in the futures industry, says it will fight a federal court lawsuit accusing it of financial misrepresentations. A shareholder of the company sued in U.S. District Court, contending false and misleading information was given to the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding both Stotler Group and its principal subsidiary, Stotler and Co. Stotler Group was headed by Karsten Mahlmann until last Wednesday, when he resigned from the company and from the chairmanship of the Chicago Board of Trade. The company was the subject of an involuntary bankruptcy filing last week by three creditors who said they were stuck with more than $1 million in unredeemed loans and investments. The brokerage said Monday the latest lawsuit was filed in Chicago by Robert Elson, a Connecticut investor who reported buying 2,000 shares of Stotler common stock in 1988. The complaint, which asks for unspecified damages and for class-action status, names Stotler Group and certain officers and directors; Stotler and Co.; and the company's accountant, Coopers & Lybrand. The day before Mahlmann's resignation, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission filed a civil complaint accusing a Stotler subsidiary, Stotler Funds Inc., of improperly using pools of clients' money that had been set up for investing in commodity futures contracts.
