DOC.HEAD: Index Futures Trip Upside Circuit Breaker
DOC.TEXT: Volatile price movements this morning in the stock-index futures market tripped a ``circuit breaker'' for the fourth straight day _ only this time the market was moving higher instead of lower. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures contract for September delivery soared five points to 339.40 within the first 10 minutes of trading, triggering an automatic two-minute trading halt. The market rose another 1.6 points when trading resumed, then retreated. The September contract was trading at 339.15 at around 10:30 a.m. EDT. The contract is valued at $500 per point. The early gain in the index futures market coincided with a similarly strong opening in the stock market following reports that Iraq may allow citizens of the United States and other Western nations to leave the country. The reports prompted an easing of concerns about Iraqi aggression in the Middle East. Iraq's invasion last week of its neighbor Kuwait has caused stock markets and index-futures markets to plunge, and oil prices to soar. Stock-index futures are contracts for future deliveries of baskets of stocks. Investors buy and sell the contracts to hedge against losses on the stock market or to speculate on market movements. Futures exchanges installed circuit breakers on index futures after the 1987 stock market crash as a way of building trading pauses and price limits into the markets to prevent runaway market moves.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 79 Percent Profit Increase for First Fiscal Quarter
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC said Tuesday its first-quarter profit climbed 79 percent despite a much slower rise in sales and the adverse impact of a strong pound on its international earnings. The results were boosted by interest income and asset disposals, the airline said. British Airways said its profit for the three months ended June 30 came to 111 million pounds, or $194 million, from 62 million pounds in the same period a year earlier. Pre-tax profit jumped 62.5 percent to 156 million pounds, or $273 million, from 96 million pounds a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent to 1.33 billion pounds, or $2.3 billion, from 1.17 billion pounds a year earlier. Earnings included 50 million pounds, or $88 million, from interest and asset disposals, including airplane sales, compared to a net loss on such items of 1 million pounds a year ago. British Airways Chairman Lord King said: ``The increased value of sterling is putting some pressure on yields but nevertheless the revenue prospects remain good.'' He added that the sudden rise in oil prices related to turbulence in the Middle East is a ``matter of concern.'' Fuel costs are expected to soar in the near-term in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week. In the latest quarter, fuel costs edged 7.4 percent higher to 131 million pounds, or $229 million. The airline said its traffic remains buoyant. Passenger loads on scheduled flights increased to 72.2 percent from 70.4 percent over the same period, British Airways said. Offsetting the improved operating performance, however, were foreign exchange movements which cost the company an estimated 30 million pounds, or $53 million, in the first quarter and leasing costs which increased 80 percent to 63 million pounds, or $110 million. The 1990 figures were converted at a rate of $1.75 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly reflecting perceptions that tensions in the Middle East are easing. Reports that Iraq may allow foreign nationals to leave the country led to a drop in oil prices this morning, which reduced inflation fears and prompted selling of grain and soybean futures. The crop markets had risen sharply in recent days on expectations that inflationary pressures would drive food prices up. But that ``seems to be abating this morning,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He said selling pressure was offset by buying interest linked to Monday's weekly Agriculture Department crop-progress report. The report showed corn and soybean development still lagging far behind the normal pace. The report also showed slight deterioration of the soybean crop's condition. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.83 a bushel; corn was } cent lower to { cent higher with September at $2.53{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with September at $1.17{ a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with August at $5.95 a bushel. Cattle futures were sharply higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were mixed. Live cattle futures were .40 cent to .80 cent higher with August at 77.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .50 cent to 1.03 cents higher with August at 89.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .23 cent lower to .63 cent higher with August at 58.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent to 1.5 cents higher with August at 52.05 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Monday; pork futures rose.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 27 Percent Profit Rise for First Half
DOC.TEXT: Advertising and marketing giant WPP Group PLC on Tuesday posted a 27 percent increase in its profit for the first half, boosted by strong contributions from its J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide ad agencies. WPP said its profit rose to 17.4 million pounds, or $29 million, in the first six months of the year compared with 13.8 million pounds in the same period a year ago. Pre-tax profit soared 77 percent to 46 million pounds, or $77 million, from 26 million pounds a year earlier. Revenue nearly doubled to 2.57 billion pounds, or $4.3 billion, from 1.29 billion pounds a year earlier. The company said its concentration on packaged goods advertising would help it outperform the U.S. and British advertising industries generally, which have suffered slowdowns. The company said advertising revenues from companies launching new products or defending market share would benefit WPP, despite industry fears that the drop in consumer demand would affect advertising spending. WPP said its J. Walter Thompson advertising division is operating ahead of budget, helped by $195 million of net new business during the first half. Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide is also working ahead of budget, winning net new billings of $270 million. WPP acquired Ogilvy & Mather for $862 million last June. The company's public relations firm Hill and Knowlton added net new business of $14 million in the first half, WPP said. The 1990 figures were converted at a rate of $1.67 to the pound, a figure provided by the company.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Price Hikes Bring Invasion Home, But Blame Goes Beyond Saddam
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 12 grafs new with testimony; picks up 7th graf pvs, Oil companies ... DELETES last 3 grafs to tighten. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers today called for presidential jawboning and tapping of emergency oil reserves to combat rising gasoline prices that have followed the invasion of Kuwait. ``In the last week, American consumers have been ripped off on a massive scale,'' Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., complained at a hearing before the Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose troops took over oil-rich Kuwait on Thursday, ``may not be the only greedy person in this picture,'' said Rep. Phil Sharp, D-Ind., as he opened a hearing of the House Energy subcommittee on energy and power. The chief targets of the hearings were U.S. oil companies, which have raised gasoline prices by as much as 19 cents a gallon since the invasion. The Justice Department served notice Monday that it will seek out and prosecute any anti-competitive practices. Charles J. Dibona, president of the industry's American Petroleum Institute, said critics of the price increases were taking ``a naive, one-sided view of how markets work.'' In written testimony for the Senate subcommittee, Dibona said oil companies had no choice but to pass on to consumers immediately the higher cost of oil _ even though gasoline from that oil will not reach pumps for months. Lieberman and witnesses at his hearing said President Bush should summon executives of the big oil companies and tell them to stop gouging the public. Lieberman cited President Kennedy's example in dealing with a steel price increase. ``It's called leadership,'' said Rhode Island Attorney General James E. O'Neil. He sid there is little that state and local officials could do to bring down gasoline prices. Sharp said the loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait calls for dipping into the 509-million-barrel U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve. ``The time to use it is now,'' he said. But John Easton of the Energy Department said the law allows use of those reserves only to make up for supply shortages, not to bring down prices. He said U.S. commercial supplies of 392 million barrels are at the highest level in nine years. ``There is not a significant shortfall and there are unused production capacities in many countries,'' Easton said. On Monday, Jim Connolly, who heads a group of gasoline dealers in the Northeast, said statons are caught in the middle, with oil companies following a ``greed is good'' motto. Oil companies said the increases were necessary because the price of crude oil already has gone up, and the invasion of Kuwait only added further justification. As gas prices went up as much as 19 cents a gallon at service stations across the country, the pressure for other increases began to spread through transportation industries. Pan American and Northwest airlines announced higher ticket prices, and the American Trucking Associations appealed to the government to let haulers respond more quickly with freight increases each time the price of diesel fuel goes up. Higher freight rates could lead to increased costs for virtually everything shipped to a retail store or America's front doors. The oil companies are ``profiteering at a time of international tension,'' said Edwin Rothschild of the consumer group Citizen Action, and he called for a boycott of the highest-priced gas stations in each community. State officials in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina and Pennsylvania announced investigations of possible local price-gouging by oil companies. The companies say their prices are the result of increases in crude oil costs from $16 a barrel in July to $27 after the Kuwaiti invasion. ``Refiners are not yet recovering in the marketplace a significant portion of crude oil cost increases that they've already incurred,'' said Anita Larsen, a Texaco Co. spokeswoman. The Interstate Commerce Commission said the average price of diesel fuel, based on a check of 16 stations nationwide, rose 8.6 cents to $1.186 per gallon Monday from July 31. An interstate trucker in Virginia reported paying 19 cents more per gallon this week than on July 27. The American Automobile Association said the average cost of self-service unleaded gasoline increased 11.1 cents from last Thursday to $1.186 per gallon, including a 7.1-cent jump over the weekend. Energy and Transportation department officials issued a joint statement with the Justice Department expressing concern about the price increases ``and the hardships they may be causing.'' Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore urged consumer conservation and said, ``We believe that the oil industry should not be carried away by speculation about future events.''

Thomas Czech, chairman of the investment committee at Blunt Ellis & Loewi, said there is a perception that actions taken by the United States and other countries to thwart Iraq are working and will help steady the turbulent oil market. The explosion in oil prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week has fanned inflation fears and fueled anxiety about the U.S. and world economic outlook. DOC.HEAD: Companies Settle Patent Fight over Swine Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: Syntro Corp. has agreed to pay royalties to Upjohn Co. for sales of a genetically engineered vaccine for swine, settling a patent dispute between the companies, Upjohn said Tuesday. Both Upjohn and Syntro will continue marketing their pseudorabies vaccines, Syntro, under license from Upjohn, the companies said. The amount of royalties wasn't divulged. Upjohn claimed in a March 1989 lawsuit the PRV-Marker pseudorabies vaccine marketed by Syntro's SyntroVet Inc. animal health subsidiary infringed on Upjohn's patent for its TOLVID pseudorabies vaccine. The Kalamazoo-based pharmaceutical company, with 1989 sales of $2.91 billion, also filed suit against SyntroVet in Kansas. Syntro, a biotechnology company based in San Diego and Lenexa, Kan., with 1989 revenues of $2.1 million, filed counterclaims. ``We are pleased that this settlement provides further recognition of our scientific efforts,'' said Gerald A. Welch, senior vice president of Upjohn and general manager of its Agricultural Division. ``Syntro will now focus our resources on additional applications of our technology,'' Syntro President J. Donald Todd said. Pseudorabies is caused by a herpes virus. It causes respiratory problems, crippling and reduced size in pigs, and death in baby pigs. It doesn't affect humans.

DOC.HEAD: Textile Workers Union Files Suit Against Health-tex Over Closings
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge set a hearing next week on a lawsuit filed by the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union to keep Health-tex from closing six plants and laying off workers. The union and 12 workers filed the suit against the children's wear manufacturer Monday in U.S. District Court in Birmingham on behalf of 4,000 Health-tex workers nationwide. They also sought a temporary restraining order to keep the financially troubled company from closing six U.S. plants and distribution centers, laying off workers or liquidating assets. U.S. District Judge William Acker declined to issue the order, but set a hearing for Aug. 13, said John W. Hargrove, one of the company's Birmingham lawyers. The union's claims are ``without merit, and we're going to respond to that lawsuit appropriately,'' Hargrove said. Friday was the last day of work for most employees at Health-tex's plant in Gadsden, Ala., which once employed 600. The suit also affects employees at manufacturing or distribution facilities in Cumberland, R.I., Danville, Va., LaFollette, Tenn., Warrenton, Ga. and Centreville, Ala. Union general counsel Ronald Rosenberg said in a statement Monday that Health-tex's ``unilateral move to close its plants and liquidate its assets is clearly illegal under its collective barganing agreement with its employees.'' ``Already, these employees and their communities have suffered tremendous losses,'' he said. Rosenberg said the union's collective bargaining agreement requires Health-tex to ``meet, discuss and negotiate'' with union officials about plant closings. The suit was filed after company officials did not respond to union requests for arbitration, he said. Hargrove said Rosenberg's interpretation of the collective bargaining agreement was inaccurate. ``That was taken out of context,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Firm, Gold Rises

DOC.TEXT: The dollar held fairly steady today against major European currencies following big losses the previous day. Dealers said the dollar steadied as reports that foreigners were being transferred from Kuwait to Baghdad were taken as a sign that tensions in the region could be easing. A moderate recovery in the European and U.S. equity and bond markets also helped the dollar. Nonetheless, traders in London said the dollar still appears fundamentally weak. Recent government reports have indicated weakness in the U.S. economy which some analysts say will prompt the Federal Reserve to encourage lower interest rates. Falling rates would make the dollar-denominated investments less attractive to foreign investors, and curb demand for the currency. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 150.60 Japanese yen from 149.50 yen at Monday's close. Later in London, it fell to 149.90 yen. The dollar was quoted at 150.015 yen at midday in New York. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8765 from $1.8725 late Tuesday. At midday in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.8780. DOC.HEAD: Mexico Unable To Increase Crude Oil Exports During Iraqi Crisis
With AM-Iraq-Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mexico does not plan to increase its crude oil exports, even though oil prices have shot up since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, government officials say. ``We're watching prices very closely, but _ absolutely not _ we have not changed our policy,'' a source at the state petroleum monopoly Pemex said in an interview Monday night. Furthermore, experts said Mexico already is producing at full capacity and would be hard-pressed to boost exports significantly even if it wanted to. The Pemex source denied rumors that Mexico _ the world's fifth biggest crude oil exporter _ planned to increase sales to Spain to make up for a shortfall caused by the Iraqi invasion. Officials at Pemex and elsewhere in President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's administration, all of whom insisted on anonymity, said Mexico may gain billions of dollars in revenue from higher world oil prices but in the long run a sharp rise could be harmful. ``What we want _ and it's in our interest _ is market and price stability. We don't like prices to shoot up all of a sudden and then suddenly slide sharply,'' said another official at Pemex, officially known as Petroleos Mexicanos SA. The world oil crisis in the 1970s gave Mexico a roaring economy but had aftereffects of runaway inflation, high unemployment, high interest rates and a foreign debt now estimated at $90 billion. A number of business leaders believe a sustained rise in global oil prices could lead to higher world inflation, higher interest rates, falling stock prices, and in the long run a shrinking of foreign investment and credit on which Mexico heavily depends for development. West Texas Intermediate and North Sea Brent _ two grades Pemex uses as guidelines for setting prices on its crude _ both were up sharply again Tuesday, with WTI trading near five-year highs of more than $28 a barrel. During the past five months, Mexico has been exporting an average of 1.216 million barrels a day of a mixture of its extra-light Olmec, sold only to the United States, and its light Isthmus and heavy Maya. Of these, 656,000 barrels a day went to the United States, 65,000 to Central America and the Caribbean, 351,000 to Spain and 144,000 to Japan. Mexico is the United States' sixth-biggest supplier after Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Nigeria, Canada and Iraq. Mexico has produced about 2.61 million barrels a day during the past five months. But experts say Pemex cannot raise production levels significantly due to lack of investment and oil field development. Its oil wells are pumping at full capacity and no new fields have been explored or developed in recent years. A June report by the Private Sector for Economic Studies think tank showed Pemex cut its capital investments by more than half since oil prices plunged in 1982, throwing Mexico into an economic crisis from which it is just beginning to recover. As a result, the report said, Mexico's proven petroleum reserves dropped from 72.5 billion barrels in 1983 to 66.45 billion barrels in 1989. Meanwhile, domestic gasoline consumption rose by 23 percent from 1985 to 1989 and Pemex has been importing the fuel in rising amounts, according to the report. It said gasoline imports rose to $229.5 million in 1989 from $18.9 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Profit Rise in Fourth Quarter, Decline for Year
DOC.TEXT: Quaker Oats Co. said Tuesday its earnings climbed 17.3 percent in its fourth fiscal quarter but plunged 16.7 percent for the year. Quaker said a decline in demand for oat bran, as well as costs associated with the reorganization of the company's grocery products business, contributed to the slump for the year. But it said a renewed focus on its food business following the spin off of its Fisher-Price toy division is helping the company get back on track. For the fourth quarter, which ended June 30, net income totaled $66.3 million, or 86 cents per share, compared with $56.5 million, or 71 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 3.7 percent to $1.41 billion from $1.36 billion a year earlier. Net income for fiscal 1990 fell to $169 million, or $2.15 per share, from $203 million, or $2.56 a share, in 1989. Sales for the year rose 3.1 percent to $5.03 billion from $4.88 billion. William D. Smithburg, Quaker's chairman and chief executive, said the fiscal 1990 results were below expectations. ``In our U.S. Grocery Products business, intense competition in cereals and pet foods, along with unfavorably cool weather conditions for Gatorade early in the fiscal year, and the sudden decline in demand for oat bran products, all combined to produce results below expectations even though operating income was up for the year,'' he said. But he said ``operational streamlining over the last year, combined with our renewed focus as a pure food company, will help us regain the earnings momentum established during the 1980s.'' Quaker announced in April the spin off of troubled Fisher-Price. In reorganizing its U.S. grocery products business and in an effort to cut costs, the company said in June that up to 400 jobs would be cut from that unit by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Found Violations at Lilly's Puerto Rican Plants Last Year
DOC.TEXT: Three Eli Lilly & Co. plants in Puerto Rico failed to follow federal regulations on manufacturing practices last year, according to inspection reports released by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. No products were recalled, and the Indianapolis-based pharmaceutical company agreed in January to a schedule for making corrections. ``We believe the steps we have taken have resolved those issues, and we continue to work with FDA inspectors to ensure our practices comply with all existing regulations,'' said Lilly spokesman Edward A. West. The FDA reports were obtained Monday by The Indianapolis Star under the Freedom of Information Act. In one document, Edward R. Esparza, director of the FDA's district office in Puerto Rico, said the company failed to maintain manufacturing practices required by federal regulations. FDA inspectors criticized an uncovered section of a conveyor line in which bottles were being filled with Ilosone liquid, an antibiotic. Gaps in an overhead conveyor chute ``permitted pieces of broken caps to fall onto and around the bottle conveyor,'' the report said. The document referred to inspections conducted June 1989 through October 1989 at three Lilly plants in Carolina, Puerto Rico. In subsequent correspondence, Esparza said Lilly had answered most of the questions raised by the inspections and had produced a satisfactory schedule for correcting the problems. The inspections of Lilly's Puerto Rican operations occurred during and after a four-month FDA inspection of Lilly's Indianapolis facilities, which resulted in the recall of some batches of more than 10 products.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Called Chaotic, Unemployment Jumps
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's economy is in chaos and faces an extremely difficult six months ahead, says the West German overseeing the nation's businesses. Reiner Gohlke's remarks, published Tuesday in an East German newspaper, are some of the most ominous to date about the country's rapidly deteriorating economic situation. They coincided with the release of the latest official unemployment figures showing the number of East German jobless jumped to 272,017 last month, up from 142,096 in June. More than 656,000 of the nation's 8.8 million workers were working short shifts because of the lack of demand for East German products. Since the West German mark became the East German currency on July 1, the country's 8,000 major businesses have faced increasing difficulties staying afloat. ``The next six months will be the hardest,'' the newspaper Neue Zeit quoted Gohlke as saying. ``We will have to go through a very deep swamp.'' There have been predictions that up to 4 million East Germans could be out of work by early next year as businesses close. That, in turn, has led to predictions of worker unrest in the former Communist nation. ``The situation is worse than I had thought,'' Gohlke said. ``We have chaos. Nothing is running normally.'' The Neue Zeit newspaper is closely linked to the Christian Democrats of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Gohlke, former chief of West Germany's huge railroad system, recently became the chief of the board overseeing East German economic reform attempts. That makes him one of the most influential people in East Germany today. The country is making a headlong rush from a state-run economy to a capitalist system. Despite the troubles, Gohlke's opinion was not all negative. East Germany's resources and people are the key to rebuilding the country, he said. East Germany will be united with economic powerhouse West Germany by the end of the year. Economists expect an economy recovery in East Germany late in 1991, after unproductive, state-run businesses reform or close for good. In addition, West German companies are rushing in to set up production and will be using East German workers. Also, thousands of East Germans are setting up small business, many in the long-neglected service industry.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Narrowly Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed narrowly mixed Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as tensions in the Middle East appeared to ease, reducing inflationary pressures. Reports that Iraq may allow foreign nationals to leave the country led to a drop in oil prices Tuesday morning, which reduced inflation fears and prompted selling of grain and soybean futures. In the absence of dramatic developments in the Iraq-Kuwait conflict, traders in Chicago concentrated on evening up their market positions ahead of Thursday's Agriculture Department crop report, said Gerald Zusel, director of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the exchange. The report, scheduled for release after Thursday's close, will contain the government's first official estimates of 1990 U.S. corn and soybean production. A survey indicated grain analysts expect a corn harvest of 7.9 billion bushels compared with 7.5 billion last year. Analysts projected soybean production at 1.86 billion bushels, slightly below last year's 1.93 billion. DOC.HEAD: June Consumers' Borrowing Falls from Level in May
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $463 million more in consumer credit than they paid off in June, the government said Tuesday, but the borrowing pace fell well below that of May. Many analysts have been concerned recently over the caution displayed by consumers, who have fueled an economic expansion that would reach its eighth anniversary in November. Consumers represent about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The Commerce Department said consumer credit edged up just 0.8 percent at an annual rate following a 6.1 percent gain, or $3.65 billion, in May. The slowing resulted in part from a 6.6 percent decline in automobile loans, down from a level of $1.58 billion in May. The May rate of growth had been unchanged after an 8.2 percent decline in the previous month. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations. At the same time, revolving or credit card debt gained $1.3 billion, a 7.6 percent advance at an annual rate. The advance came on top of a 18.8 percent increase in April. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $827 million, a 4.8 percent annual rate after gains of 2.1 percent in May and 4.0 percent in April. But borrowing for mobile homes fell 4.5 percent, a $85 million decline, nearly giving up its 6.0 percent advance in May. Mobile home debt had declined 0.3 percent in April. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of June at $724.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Seesaw on Middle East Uncertainty, But Panic Trading Eases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 new grafs to UPDATE with oil prices back up, stocks and bonds weaker, edits to conform. Picks up 9th graf pvs, Today's biggest...
DOC.TEXT: Conflicting rumors from the tense Middle East buffeted oil prices today and jolted other financial markets, but the panicky trading atmosphere caused by Iraq's seizure of Kuwait last week seemed to subside. Oil traders said speculative reports about the possibility of a Middle East war mainly influenced the energy markets, where crude prices seesawed this afternoon after shooting above $28 a barrel on Monday, the highest level in five years. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, a key barometer of energy prices, the cost of benchmark West Texas Intermediate was weaker at midday on indications that the Iraqis might be capitulating to the effects of a worldwide boycott. But prices later jumped ahead to about $29 a barrel on reports that Iraq had strengthened troop readiness along the Saudi Arabian frontier. Stock prices tumbled in Tokyo, rallied in London and seesawed in New York following Monday's big loss. By late afternoon on Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average was down about 13 points to the 2,703 level in choppy trading. Other market indicators also fluctuated. ``It's been bouncing up and down,'' said Robert O'Toole, manager of over-the-counter stock trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. ``Any time people see a little strength, they say, `let me out.''' Elsewhere, U.S. bond prices rebounded from losses Monday then weakened again over anxiety about possible oil-shock inflation. The dollar gained ground against the Japanese yen, but was fairly steady in trading against major European currencies. Gold prices followed the behavior of oil. Still, the volatility that gripped Wall Street and other markets Monday and last week seemed to ease noticeably, reflecting what traders called less emotional knee-jerk reactions to events coming out of the Middle East. Today's biggest losers appeared to be Japanese stocks. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average dropped 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent, to close at 27,653.07. Japan is particularly vulnerable to oil shocks because it imports 99 percent of its oil. The Japanese market has dropped nearly 3,200 points since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday. ``A pessimistic view is dominating the market. ... Unless investors have some idea how this Middle East situation would actually affect the Japanese economy, their uncertainties and fears will keep affecting the stock market,'' Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said referring to the Tokyo exchange. While the dollar held steady against most major currencies today in Europe, it was up against the Japanese yen. The dollar rose 1.10 yen to close at 150.60 yen in Tokyo. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at a lower rate of 149.73 yen but strengthened later in New York to about 149.90 yen. The world's financial markets have been rocked by rising oil prices in recent days because of the potential impact higher fuel costs could have throughout the world economy. ``As oil prices are actually rising, investors' fears of inflation are intensifying,'' said Kideyuki Matsuda, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. ``Basically, there is no positive factor in the market now.'' Wholesale oil prices soared to five-year highs in New York on Monday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude jumped $3.56 to settle at $28.05 a 42-gallon barrel _ its highest price since August 1985. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange Monday, wholesale unleaded gasoline jumped 9.34 cents to 81.52 cents a gallon and wholesale home heating oil was up 8.97 cents to 75.55 cents. Concerns about rapidly rising oil prices stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis pushed stocks, bonds and the dollar sharply lower Monday. In foreign exchange, the dollar closed lower against all major currencies, except the Japanese yen, in New York. U.S. traders said the markets were jolted by continued worries that sharply higher oil prices, stemming from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week, could trigger higher inflation and push the nation into a recession. ``The economy is in pretty bad shape now. This could make things worse,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York.
The stock market was lower in late trading today at the end of a volatile session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was off 7.68 at 2,708.66 with five minutes left to go.

Stocks mostly moved lower in heavy and choppy activity today as traders reacted to Middle East developments. The panicky selling wave that engulfed Wall Street Monday, producing the worst performance since the ``mini-crash'' last October, subsided. But buyers failed to flock back to the market as pessmism prevailed in the face of an ailing economy, a rising inflation threat and the Middle East crisis. Developments unfolding in the Mideast made the stock market reverse course several times. Traders appeared to pounce on each piece of news regarding the Iraq-Kuwait conflict. Word from the State Department in Washington that Iraq was increasing its troop readiness on the Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia increased the edginess in financial markets. A rumor, later denied, that Iraq had invaded Saudi Arabia temporarily incited heavy selling. The White House refused to comment on a report that the United States was beginning a major troop deployment in Saudi Arabia. Oil and related stocks were particularly sensitive to fluctuations in petroleum futures. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude settled at $28.31 a barrel, up 26 cents. For the most part, foreign stock markets steadied, which helped restore calm in the United States. The London stock market staged a partial rebound and the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 15.6 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,235.8. But in oil-dependent Japan, stocks continued to suffer. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average dropped 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent, to close at 27,653.07. Blue chip stocks, which posted gains for most of the morning, abruptly reversed course and tumbled shortly before midday. Later, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks bobbed up and down but never managed to move back into the plus column.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Fund Buys Minority Stake in Radio Company
DOC.TEXT: Merchant banking funds headed by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have agreed to buy a significant minority interest in Infinity Broadcasting Corp., which owns 17 radio stations. The privately owned company announced Monday that the Merchant Banking Partnerships of Lehman Brothers agreed to buy $26.7 million in newly-issued stock and warrants from Infinity Broadcasting. In addition, the funds agreed to pay an undisclosed sum for additional stock from the founders of Infinity Broadcasting, Michael Weiner and Gerald Carrus. After the deal is completed, the partnership will own just under 50 percent of the company's stock, according to Infinity spokesman Farid Suleman. The biggest individual shareholder will be Mel Karmazin, Infinity's president and chief executive, who holds just under 20 percent. Weiner and Carrus, who will stay on as co-chairmen of the company, each will own under 10 percent of the company, Suleman said. Warrants held by bondholders and employee stock options account for most of the remainder of the company's stock. ``We are strong believers in the continuing and future value of radio-related assets and are excited to enter into this strategic partnership with Inifinity, the largest privately held radio company in the country,'' Jim Stern, Lehman Brothers' managing director, said in a news release. Suleman said Infinity had $107.8 million in revenue last year. Infinity owns and operates the following radio stations: WXRK-FM and WZRC-AM in New York; KROQ-FM, Los Angeles; WJMK-FM and WJJD-AM, Chicago; WYSP-FM, Philadelphia; KOME-FM, San Jose-San Francisco; WBCN-FM, Boston; WOMC-FM, Detroit, and KVIL-AM and KVIL-FM, Dallas. Also, WJFK-FM, Washington, D.C.; KXYZ-AM, Houston; WLIF-AM and WLIF-FM, Baltimore; and WQYK-AM and WQYK-FM, Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Western Union, Union Employees Still Without Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: May stand
DOC.TEXT: With an expired contract looming, representatives of Western Union Corp. and 2,500 union workers on Tuesday were expected to resume stalled negotiations. The negotiator for the union, the Communications Workers of America, reported progress on a wage agreement but said the company had not yielded on demands that medical benefits be reduced, job categories be consolidated and the number of part-time employees be increased. A two-year contract between employees and the giant telegram company expired Monday, but workers decided to return to the bargaining table rather than strike, said Dan J. Beckstead, president of the CWA-United Telegraph Workers Bargaining Council. In the event of a walkout, the company has trained more than 1,000 temporary workers to keep operations afloat, the company said. Western Union spokesman Warren Bechtel said he thought progress had been made in the late-night talks that broke up at 2 a.m. Tuesday, but he declined to discuss details. On Monday, Bechtel said the Upper Saddle River-based company sought a contract that will allow it to operate profitably for the first time in more than seven years. A major obstacle to a settlement was the company's demand that union workers pay higher medical insurance premiums, Bechtel said. Neither he nor Beckstead would provide specific details about how the costs would be shared, but on Monday Bechtel said union employees would pay as much as non-union employees do under Western Union's proposal. The union also balked at the company's proposals to combine the duties of operators and customer relations clerks, and to increase the number of part-time employees not entitled to benefits under the union contract. Labor-management disputes have led to three major strikes in the past four decades. Workers walked off the job for 10 days in 1985, for 57 days in 1971 and 53 days in 1952, Beckstead said. The union has not set a settlement deadline, he said. Communications Workers of America represents operators, customer relations clerks, other clerical workers and field technicians who work for Western Union nationwide, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended higher Tuesday against all major currencies except the German mark, as traders kept a close watch on the Persian Gulf crisis and its effect on interest rates. Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $384.50 a troy ounce, down 20 cents from Monday. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid for gold at $385.50 an ounce, up $1.50. Ronald H. Holzer, chief currency dealer at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, attributed the dollar's rise largely to technical factors. But he said traders were also buying dollars on the belief that U.S. interest rates would remain stable for the short term. ``Short-term rates have not moved lower,'' Holzer said. In fact, interest rates in the public bond markets have risen sharply in recent days on inflation fears, which stemmed from the rapid rise in oil prices following Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait last week. When interest rates decline the value of a currency tends to follow suit. The dollar had fallen sharply on Tuesday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen, on worries that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates lower to prevent the country from falling into a recession. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar closed up 150.60 Japanese yen from 149.50 yen Monday. It traded at 149.90 yen in London, and at 150.90 yen in New York, up from 150.35 yen Monday. The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared to Monday. Sterling bought $1.8765 in London, up from $1.8725, and $1.8715 in New York, down from $1.8725. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.5875 German marks, down from 1.57875; 1.3370 Swiss francs, up from 1.3310; 5.3230 French francs, up from 5.2890; 1,162.25 Italian lire, up from 1,154.50, and 1.15125 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14955. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.5763 West German marks, up from 1.5762; 1.3315 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.2295 French francs, down from 5.2863; 1.7785 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7766; 1,155.37 Italian lire, up from 1,154.00, and 1.1495 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1490. Gold rose in London to $383.25 an ounce from $382.50 late Monday. In Zurich, it rose to $383.15 an ounce from $382.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $4.94 to $383.52 an ounce. DOC.HEAD: Bush Urged to Jawbone Oil Executives on Price Increases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, Oil companies, with 2 grafs to UPDATE with latest gas prices. Picks up 8th graf pvs, Tuesday's spate. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats charged Tuesday that oil companies are engaging in price-gouging and exhorted President Bush to stop it. ``Someone is making a killing,'' Sen. John Kerry exclaimed, at one of three hastily arranged public hearings on sharp increases in American fuel prices following Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Charles J. Di Bona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, vehemently denied the accusation. Critics of the oil industry are taking ``a naive, one-sided view of how markets work,'' he said. U.S. oil companies had no choice but to pass on to consumers the higher cost of oil on the world market, Di Bona maintained, saying prices would drop if world prices fall. But angry members of Congress said Bush should jawbone industry leaders for price relief _ in much the same way President John F. Kennedy did with the steel industry. Bush also was urged to tap the government's crude oil reserve. The aim would be to cushion American consumers against further economic repercussions from Mideast hostilities. Oil companies have raised gasoline prices by as much as 25 cents a gallon since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his forces into neighboring Kuwait last week. Company executives said their prices are the result of increases in crude oil costs from $16 a barrel in July to $27 after the invasion. The American Automobile Association reported Tuesday that prices for self-service unleaded gas went up an average of 1.5 cents per gallon overnight and have averaged 12.6 cents higher than they were Aug. 1. The average is now $1.20 per gallon, the highest since 1985, said the AAA, which checked 1,400 service stations nationwide. Tuesday's spate of hearings was an unusual occurrence during a congressional recess. But lawmakers were anxious to vent constituents' anger over price hikes. They were joined in this high-profile public interrogation by officials of state and local governments and consumer groups. Despite oil industry denials of price-gouging, several witnesses maintained the evidence was otherwise. They complained that oil companies are quick to pass on price increases but slow to pass along any savings. ``The American public is angry. It's mad as hell. They have a sense they are being held hostage to you, the oil companies,'' said Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev. The industry executives were summoned a day after the Justice Department pledged it would look into the soaring fuel prices. Anti-competitive pricing activities will be aggressively prosecuted, it said. But that did not satisfy angry congressmen. ``In the last week, American consumers have been ripped off on a massive scale,'' Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., complained to witnesses appearing before a Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee. Rep. Phil Sharp, D-Ind., said Saddam ``may not be the only greedy person in this picture.'' Added Sen. John Danforth of Missouri: ``There is another villain on the scene.'' Bryan cited a nationwide survey by the American Automobile Association showing gas prices up at least 11 cents _ and as high as 19 cents _ since last week's invasion. The prices have soared despite evidence showing supplies are still plentiful. ``One is left with the inescapable conclusion that profiteering is occurring at the expense of the American consumer,'' Bryan said. But Glenn Tilton, president of Texaco Refining and Marketing Inc., said his company was a hostage to supply and demand _ and thus had to raise its prices along with everyone else. ``This one company cannot price... out of step with the realities of the market,'' or its supplies would be stripped, he said. But William McGilacuddy, president of the Virginia Service Station Dealers and Auto Repair Association, acknowledged, ``There is no competition at the wholesale level whatsoever.'' Lieberman said Bush should summon executives of the big oil companies and tell them to exercise price restraint. When the Connecticut Democrat's attempt to put the onus on Bush was echoed by Rhode Island Attorney General James E. O'Neil, Danforth, the only Republican at the hearing, questioned what good it would do. After all, he said, the oil companies could merely refuse to cooperate. ``It's called leadership,'' O'Neil shot back. On the House side of Capitol Hill, John Easton, deputy assistant secretary of energy for international affairs and energy emergencies, told Sharp's subcommittee the administration was prepared to use the Strategic Petroleum Reserve _ if there were a ``severe energy supply interruption.'' He said American consumers may not tolerate high gas prices but they also will not tolerate use of U.S. reserves to bolster world supplies without similar sacrifices by other countries. Easton said the law allows use of the 590 million barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve to make up for severe supply interruptions, not to bring down prices. But Sharp said the U.S. government should consider dipping into the reserves unilaterally to protect the economy and consumers. ``There is a higher risk of damage in delay,'' he said. Sharp said Congress would not tolerate ``a legalistic determination about supply interruption'' to justify lack of action. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, said at one point during the Senate subcommittee hearing that the public didn't ``want to hear a lot of politicians yelling about it.'' But they all did it anyway at the televised hearings. ``I'm perfectly willing to pile on this one,'' Danforth admitted.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Smaller Loss in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said Tuesday it lost $23 million in the second quarter compared with a loss of $42.6 million for the same period a year earlier. The smaller loss reflected higher revenue from publishing and insurance operations, cost reductions in publishing and lower interest expenses due to the paydown of debt with proceeds from asset sales, the company said. The company has a $1.6 billion debt, much of it taken on when it thwarted a hostile takeover offer in 1987. Harcourt also said its annual meeting of shareholders, which was scheduled for September 1990, will be rescheduled for a later date. On a per-share basis, the company said it lost 39 cents for the three months ended June 30 compared with a loss of 84 cents in the same quarter in 1989. Revenue rose 6.1 percent to $348.5 million in the quarter from $328.6 million a year earlier. The company's publishing operations reported income from operations of $34.7 million in the quarter, up 39.4 percent from a year earlier, as revenue rose 2.7 percent to $227 million. Income from insurance operations rose 11.6 percent to $10.6 million in the quarter as revenue rose 13 percent to $121.5 million. Interest expense fell to $66 million from $91.6 million a year earlier. For the first half, the company reported it lost $94.9 million, or $1.47 a share, compared with a loss of $158.7 million, or $2.64 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose 9.7 percent to $625.4 million from $570.2 million a year earlier. The company said its first half revenues are not indicative of the entire year because the publishing business is highly seasonal, with the majority of revenues and operating profits coming in during the third quarter. Harcourt undertook a $3 billion recapitalization in 1987 after an unsolicited buyout offer from Britain's Robert Maxwell. As part of the plan, the company borrowed heavily to pay special dividends to shareholders. Last fall, Harcourt sold its Sea World theme parks for $1.1 billion in an effort to reduce its debt. In June, longtime Harcourt chairman William I. Jovanovich resigned and was replaced by John S. Herrington, a former secretary of energy during the Reagan administration. The job of running the company has fallen to Jovanovich's son, Peter, who has been chief executive of the company since last December. Many analysts say HBJ generates enough cash to meet its interest obligations over the next 18 months to two years. But they have warned that trouble could develop in 1992 when cash payments start coming due on preferred stock and bonds which now are issuing additional securities as dividends. They say the company will have to either sell assets, reschedule debt payments or get a capital infusion to meet those obligations.

DOC.HEAD: Increased Investments in Savings Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Americans poured $629 million into U.S. savings bonds in July, a 4 percent increase over their investment a year earlier and a 2 percent gain over June, the government reported Tuesday. The Treasury Department said July's purchases brought total sales for the first 10 months of fiscal year 1990 to $6.58 billion, up from $6.57 billion during the same period of 1989. It also brought to $122.55 billion the value of savings bonds now held by Americans, 7 percent more than a year ago. Savings bonds held 5 years or longer earn market-based interest rates or a guaranteed rate, whichever is higher. The current semi-annual market-based rate is 7.01 percent, effective through Oct.31. The guaranteed rate is 6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Panic Subsides But Heavy Selling Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Stocks stumbled through a choppy session Tuesday but several market indicators eked out small gains. The selling wave that pounded Wall Street Monday _ producing the worst performance since the ``mini-crash'' last October _ subsided somewhat. But buyers failed to flock back to the market as pessmism prevailed in the face of an ailing economy, a mounting inflation threat and the Middle East crisis. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lengthened its string of losses to a sixth straight session, falling 5.70 to 2,710.64. Since the market started sliding last Thursday when Iraq invaded Kuwait, the best-known market indicator has lost 188.62 points, or 6.5 percent. Broader market measures managed to post minor improvements. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.40 to 334.83 and the New York Stock Exchange composite index of all its listed common stocks added 0.13 to 183.45. But overall, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks as jittery investors continued to pull money out of equities. There were 740 issues up, 845 down and 449 unchanged. Trading activity was heavy for a fourth session in a row. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 231.58 million shares, down slightly from 240.40 million on Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 274.71 million shares. Developments unfolding in the Mideast made the stock market reverse course several times. Traders appeared to pounce on each piece of news regarding the Iraq-Kuwait conflict. Word from the State Department in Washington that Iraq was increasing its troop readiness on the Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia increased the edginess in financial markets. A rumor, later denied, that Iraq had invaded Saudi Arabia temporarily incited heavy selling. Oil and related stocks were particularly sensitive to fluctuations in petroleum futures, which have soared amid the Mideast turmoil. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude settled at $28.31 a barrel, up 26 cents after swinging widely. Investors took advantage of the recent runup in oil stocks to sell and collect profits Tuesday. The selloff in a few blue chip oil stocks accounted for virtually all of the drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. Texaco topped the Big Board's list of active issues as more than 11.4 million shares changed hands in dividend-related maneuvers. It fell ] to 64|. Other losers in the oil sector included: Exxon, down \ to 53]; Mobil, down { to 67{; and Chevron, down } to 78|. Among the active blue chips, Philip Morris jumped 1[ to 45[, General Electric gained 1\ to 67\, Boeing rose 1{ to 52, American Telephone & Telegraph advanced 1 to 35] and International Business Machines fell ~ to 103. For the most part, foreign stock markets steadied Tuesday, which helped to restore calm in the United States. The London stock market staged a partial rebound and the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 15.6 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,235.8. But in oil-dependent Japan, stocks continued to suffer. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average dropped 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent, to close at 27,653.07. Japan is particularly vulnerable to oil shocks because it imports almost all of its oil. The Japanese market has dropped nearly 3,200 points since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $2.60 billion, or 0.08 percent, in value. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.36 to 395.10. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.04 to 402.08. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 339.84, off 0.43.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Plans to Market Its Blank Videotapes to Consumers
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. plans an expensive consumer-oriented advertising campaign to support its new line of blank videotapes, the company said Tuesday. Sony declined to say how much it intended to spend on the campaign, but it said it would exceed the estimated $4 million to $5 million all the major brands combined spent on advertising blank tapes last year. Sony estimated U.S. blank tape sales amount to $750 million a year industrywide. The company said its consumer-oriented ad approach, which will use television and magazines such as People and TV Guide, breaks with the industry's practice of aiming advertising mainly at tape dealers. ``Video tape has been treated as a commodity item and that has resulted in disenchanted dealers, confused consumers and sluggish sales,'' said John Bermingham, president of domestic sales and marketing for Sony Magnetic Products Group of America. He said Sony's advertising for its new ``V'' tapes is designed to give the Sony tapes a brand personality that consumers will recognize. The new line of tapes provide better picture quality, durability, sound and performance, the company claimed. The tapes will be available at authorized dealers later this month and the ad campaign will start in September, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: KCPL Fires Another Legal Shot at Takeover Target KG&E
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power & Light Co. has filed an amended court complaint accusing takeover target Kansas Gas and Electric Co. of violating federal Securities and Exchange Commission regulations since the takeover was announced. KCPL filed the complaint Monday altering its pending lawsuit against KG&E in U.S. District Court in Kansas City, Mo. KCPL requested a court order declaring its tender offer legal and requiring KG&E to provide a shareholder list and call a special meeting of stockholders. KCPL also asked that KG&E be required to file with the SEC a more complete response to KCPL's proposal. KG&E refused comment on the new court action. ``Really, we cannot discuss these issues outside the courts,'' said Lyle Koerper, a KG&E spokesman. On July 23, KCPL launched a $27-per-share cash tender offer for KG&E, a bid worth about $857 million. KG&E is fighting the takeover. It has refused to provide a list of shareholders and declined to call a stockholder meeting, saying KCPL hasn't met the requirements to force either request. Kansas Gas claims KCPL's acquisition attempt needs SEC approval. KCPL's amendment to its lawsuit asserts KG&E knows prior SEC approval isn't necessary. The suit also attacks KG&E's release of an eight-page question-and-answer list to employees, stockholders and the news media. KCPL claims the release violated SEC regulations concerning solicitations and recommendations during a tender offer. KCPL also claims KG&E's formal SEC filing responding to KCPL's offer fails to include the basis for some conclusions drawn, in violation of SEC requirements. The suit charges that the question-and-answer sheet falsely disparages the KCPL offer and hints that KCPL could terminate KG&E pension plans and labor agreements. KCPL also claims that the SEC filing doesn't disclose KG&E has been involved in a massive stock repurchase program that has bought back more than 9 million shares. In addition, KCPL accused Wilson Cadman, KG&E president and chairman, of making false public statements when he talked about KG&E's excess generating capacity being a ``gold mine.'' ``Mr. Cadman failed to disclose that KG&E has had excess capacity for a number of years, has for several years attempted unsuccessfully to sell generating capacity and has demonstrated no ability to do so and has been unable to capitalize on this `gold mine,''' the KCPL suit said.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Futures Rally as Economic Fears Ease
DOC.TEXT: Cattle futures prices surged Tuesday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting an easing of economic worries linked to the Middle East crisis, strength in the cash cattle markets and chart-inspired buying. On other commodity markets, pork futures ended mixed; petroleum futures were mixed; precious metals were mostly lower; and grains and soybeans were mixed. News from the Middle East remained a major influence in many commodity markets but signs during the day that hostilities were cooling allowed traders to focus on other factors as well. Live cattle futures settled .28 cent to 1.15 cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in August at 77.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .55 cent to 1.12 cent higher with August at 89.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .95 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 58.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent lower to .52 cent higher with August at 51.07 cents a pound. Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the inflation and recession fears caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait had had a depressing effect on cattle prices recently because consumers would tend to bypass beef in favor of cheaper meats if the economy took a downturn. ``When you start comparing beef with chicken at the meat counters, you know which is going to get the nod,'' he said. But cattle prices bounced back strongly Tuesday as the stock and crude-oil markets steadied amid indications the Iraqi government had assumed a less aggressive posture. Further support stemmed from stronger packer demand for live cattle and stonger demand for feeder cattle by feedlot operators. Paul Hare, livestock analyst with Linnco Futures Inc. in Chicago, said the live cattle market was oversold and due for a correction after falling for four straight days. Crude oil trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange was relatively calm after several days of skyrocketing prices. In the gasoline and heating oil markets, the contracts for deferred deliveries, which are restricted in their movements by exchange-enforced limits, rose most sharply in an attempt to catch up with the limitless near-month contracts. After the close, the American Petroleum Institute released weekly supply figures showing a steeper-than-expected decline in U.S. stocks of crude oil and an unexpected increase in gasoline supplies. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 89 cents lower to $1.50 higher with September at $28.31 a barrel; heating oil was .41 cent lower to 4 cents higher with September at 75.14 cents per gallon; unleaded gasoline was .87 cent to 4 cents higher with September at 82.39 cents per gallon. Gold and silver futures settled mostly lower on New York's Commodity Exchange after a day of back-and-forth trading in reaction to rumors about the Iraq-Kuwait conflict. A report that Iraq was holding 39 Americans in a Baghdad hotel and concerns about possible U.S. retaliation contributed to nervousness in the gold market, said Bette Raptopoulos, senior metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``They've been responding to every little rumor and every little story,'' she said. Gold futures settled 10 cents higher to 70 cents lower with August at $384.50 a troy ounce; silver futures settled 3.2 cents to 3.5 cents lower with August at $4.857 an ounce. Grain and soybean futures ended narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade as signs of easing tensions in the Middle East reduced inflationary pressures. Traders also began evening up their positions ahead of Thursday's Agriculture Department crop report, analysts said. The report, scheduled for release after Thursday's close, will contain the government's first official estimates of 1990 U.S. corn and soybean production. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to { cent higher with September at $2.81\ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 3 cents higher with September at $2.54 a bushel; oats were { cent to } cents higher with September at $1.17\ a bushel; soybeans 2{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with August at $5.95{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Continue Rising
With AM-Iraq-Markets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices moved higher again Tuesday as prospects of curtailed supplies from the Middle East triggered frantic trading amid market rumors. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate climbed 26 cents to settle at $28.31 a 42-gallon barrel. It was the highest level for the the benchmark grade of U.S. crude since Dec. 6, 1985, when the price reached $28.74 per barrel, the Merc said. Among refined petroleum products, wholesale unleaded gasoline was up 0.87 cent to 82.39 cents a gallon. Later contract months showed sharper gains. The September contract for wholesale home heating oil settled 0.41 cent lower to 75.14 cents, but later contract months soared the 4-cent daily limit. The increases were smaller than in recent days, indicating some selling to take profits. Prices fluctuated in near-record volume in trading for crude oil contracts. ``It's hard to envision a more bullish scenario than what we have now _ the potential that two of the largest producers in the Persian Gulf could go to war,'' said Andrew Lebow, an energy futures analyst with E.D.F. Man International Futures Inc. Lebow said unconfirmed rumors _ including ones that Iraq had invaded Saudi Arabia _ drove the market up and down fitfully. The market opened calmer than expected on word that Iraqi leader Sadaam Husein would allowe foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq to leave, a statement that calmed the markets. Also bearish for the market was a report that Assistant U.S. Energy Secretary John Easton told Congress the government is prepared to use its Strategic Petroleum Reserve in the event of a severe supply interruption. After trading closed on the Merc, the United States said American troops were being sent to Saudi Arabia as part of a multinational force to defend the country. Among other products, natural gas settled down 1.11 cents to $1.447 per million British thermal units.

DOC.HEAD: War Rumors Buffet Markets: Oil Surges Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf, In early ..., after 15th graf, The Treasury's ..., to UPDATE with early Tokyo trading; PICK UP 16th graf pvs ``Basically, what's ...
DOC.TEXT: Persian Gulf war rumors raced through the financial world Tuesday, pushing oil prices toward $29 a barrel and sending more jolts through markets for U.S. stocks and bonds. Increasing indications of a possible Iraq-U.S. showdown in the vital oil-producing region transfixed professional investors and speculators through most of the day and made many markets seesaw without warning. Each suggestion of a conflict sent oil prices higher and stocks and bonds lower on the theory that a fresh blanket of oil-shock inflation would wallop the already weak U.S. economy. Conversely, rumors that the situation was easing weakened oil prices and sent money back into the stock and bond markets. Although many traders said the panicky psychology that had gripped the markets since Iraq seized Kuwait last week seemed to subside, others said widespread fear and anxiety persisted. ``It's an emotional, volatile market,'' said William Veronda, a fixed-income strategist at the Denver investment firm Financial Programs Inc. The United States announced after domestic markets closed that it was deploying American troops as part of a multinational force in Iraq's key neighbor, Saudi Arabia. Oil brokers said that development escalated the prospects of fighting and likely would push oil prices higher when trading resumed. The oil market again was the key influence on other markets worldwide, affecting trillions of dollars in investments. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, a widely followed barometer of prices, the cost of key West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery gyrated throughout the day, falling as much as $1.55 a barrel to $26.50 and jumping as high as $1 a barrel to $29.05. The price settled at $28.31 a barrel by the close of trading, up 26 cents from Monday and up more than 40 percent from a week ago. The close was the highest since $28.74 on Dec. 6, 1985, according to Mercantile Exchange records. Other blends of crude and refined products such as gasoline and heating oil also rose, though not as sharply as in recent days. Michael Broder, vice president of the energy futures group at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York, said the market's behavior was dictated almost entirely by ``the uncertainty over what's happening in the Middle East.'' On Wall Street, stocks escaped the large-scale drubbing they took Monday. But brokers said buying interest was poor, reflecting underlying fears about the consequences of higher oil prices. The Dow average ended down 5.70 points to 2,710.64, its sixth straight loss. Overall, the number of losing stocks slightly outnumbered advances in heavy trading. Prices had plunged Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 93 points, its worst one-day slide since the minicrash of last October. Prices also fell Tuesday in the bond market, a barometer of interest rates and economic health. The weakness especially affected long-term bonds, reflecting investor fear that higher inflation would erode their value. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell about $6 per $1,000 face amount, while its yield rose to 8.86 percent from 8.80 percent late Monday. In early trading in Tokyo Wednesday, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues regained some of the ground it lost Tuesday when it dropped 946.46 points to 27,653.07, its lowest level in almost 22 months. ``Basically, what's happened over the past week or so is that people have become more pessimistic about inflation in the U.S. economy,'' said Giulio Martini, an economist with the Sanford C. Bernstein investment firm in New York. ``What you conclude about this episode depends on where you think the price of oil will settle.'' In foreign exchange, the dollar ended higher against all major currencies except the German mark. Traders attributed the rise to a belief that short-term U.S. interest rates, which directly affect the dollar's value, were likely to remain stable for the time being. Gold prices, which moved sharply higher in recent days because of the metal's historic value as a hedge against inflation, ended the day little changed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $384.50 a troy ounce, down 20 cents from Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Hoechst Celanese Corp. Earnings Drop 19 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Hoechst Celanese Corp.'s second-quarter earnings dropped 19.3 percent, the chemical company said Tuesday. The company said soft housing and automobile markets would continue to depress earnings in the second half of the year. For the April-June period, earnings were $67 million on sales of $1.5 billion compared to earnings of $83 million on revenue of $1.6 billion in the same period in 1989. Second quarter sales declined in three of the company's four major divisions _ 13.4 percent in chemicals; 3.2 percent in fibers and film; and 1.1 percent in plastic materials. Sales increased 13 percent to $156 million in the life sciences division in the second quarter. Last year, the life science's division's sales were $138 million in the second quarter. For the first six months of the year, earnings dropped 25.7 percent compared to the first half of 1989. Earnings were $110 million on sales of $2.8 billion compared to earnings of $148 million on sales of $3 billion for the first six months of last year. Hoechst Celanese is not publicly traded in the United States. It is a wholly owned subsidiary of the West German chemical giant, Hoechst AG, which posted sales of $24 billion last year, Norton said.
